column2: It is from the music that Balanchine achieves the astonishing contrasts of scale, speed and tone that occur throughout “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
20th Century Props, which offers a vast inventory of items to be used in film and television productions, became the latest victim of a rapidly changing Hollywood.
The concluding 90-board match to select the U.S.A.-2 team for the Bermuda Bowl world championship was won Monday evening.
The pace of over-35 enlistment in the Army jumped sharply in the first months of this year. Rising unemployment is a major reason, say Army officials, recruiters and training officers.
On Tuesday the pianist Marc Ponthus assembled a multimedia program, in which video and stream-of-consciousness poetry were woven around and sometimes into the music.

The fictional Weston clan of Tracy Letts’s Broadway play, “August: Osage County,” may have survived three incarnations of its vicious matriarch, Violet, but the play itself could not survive long into the new theater season. It is scheduled to close after the June 28 performance, its press representatives said. The play, which opened on Dec. 4, 2007, at the Imperial Theater and transferred in April 2008 to the Music Box Theater, won the Pulitzer Prize for drama as well as the Tony Award for best new play. Deanna Dunagan also won a Tony for her performance as Violet. She was succeeded in the role by Estelle Parsons and now Phylicia Rashad. A national tour of the play, featuring Ms. Parsons, is scheduled to begin in Denver on July 24.
Reruns of CBS’s crime dramas attracted nearly twice as many viewers on average as their closest competitors on Tuesday night.

Theatergoers who have been waiting patiently for the Neil LaBute play “The Break of Noon” to make its debut will have to wait a little longer. MCC Theater said that the play would not be part of its 2009-10 season, confirming a report that appeared on the Web site of The Los Angeles Times. The play, about religious faith, was first announced for the theater company’s 2008-9 season, but was postponed so that Mr. LaBute could work on the Broadway transfer of “reasons to be pretty” and other commitments. Blake West, the executive director of MCC Theater, said in an interview, “We hope when it’s ready and when Neil’s ready, we’ll be producing it here at MCC.” Mr. West said there had been “no official change” in Mr. LaBute’s status as the theater company’s playwright in residence. ... Here’s hoping that the Nederlander Theater brings better luck to the coming revivals of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound” than it did to “Guys and Dolls.” That West 41st Street theater, recently vacated by the “Guys and Dolls” revival that closed on Sunday, will be home to the two Neil Simon comedies, which will be performed there in repertory in the fall. As part of a double bill called “The Neil Simon Plays,” “Brighton Beach Memoirs” will begin previews on Oct. 2 and open on Oct. 25; “Broadway Bound” will begin previews on Nov. 18 and open on Dec. 10.

Rain, the South Korean pop star and actor, has settled a suit brought by a Hawaiian concert promotion company that won an $8 million judgment against him and his managers, Agence France-Presse reported. In March a court found in favor of the promoter, Click Entertainment, which had sued Rain and his representatives at JYP Entertainment after the singer (whose real name is Jung Ji-hoon) canceled a concert scheduled for June 15, 2007, at Honolulu’s Aloha Stadium, a few days before the show. Lawyers for the promoter argued that Rain never intended to perform, and that his crew members never shipped their equipment or applied for visas. Citing a report from the Korean Yonhap news agency, Agence France-Presse said that the two sides reached an agreement on June 10 to settle the case and avoid an appeal. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

The Spanish tenor Rolando Villazón, who was expected to resume performances in 2010 after surgery to remove a cyst on his vocal cords, has canceled his involvement in a production of “Carmen” planned in May for the Vienna State Opera, The Associated Press reported. In April managers for Mr. Villazón announced that he was canceling his performances through the end of the year, saying that he needed surgery “as soon as possible.” He was to have sung “Carmen” alongside the soprano Anna Netrebko and the mezzo-soprano Elina Garanca at its May 3, 2010, premiere in Vienna, but Mr. Villazón said he was being especially cautious to ensure his full recovery, according to The A.P. On Tuesday the Metropolitan Opera said that Joseph Calleja would replace Mr. Villazón in its coming production of Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann.”.

The Black Eyed Peas’ ubiquitous single “Boom Boom Pow” has been at the top of Billboard’s Hot 100 chart for the last 10 weeks, and now the group has notched another No. 1. Its new album, “The E.N.D.” (Interscope) — it stands for “the energy never dies” — has become the Black Eyed Peas’ first to reach No. 1, with first-week sales of 304,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Last week’s best seller, the Dave Matthews Band’s “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” (RCA), is No. 2 with 128,000 sales, a 70 percent drop, and Eminem’s “Relapse” (Interscope) is No. 3 with 87,000. Chickenfoot, a band featuring current and former members of Van Halen and the Red Hot Chili Peppers, holds at No. 4 with 79,000 sales of its self-titled album on the Redline label, and Aventura, a group from the Bronx that proudly advertises itself as “kings of bachata,” opens at No. 5 with 47,000 sales of “The Last” (Sony). Down the chart, Mos Def’s latest, “Ecstatic” (Downtown), opens at No. 9 with 39,000, only a few hundred more than Pleasure P’s “Introduction of Marcus Cooper” (Atlantic), which bows at No. 10.

Sean Penn’s tenure with the Three Stooges has proved even shorter than Joe Besser’s, Variety reported. Mr. Penn, right, who was set to play the role of Larry in a “Three Stooges” movie written and directed by Bobby and Peter Farrelly (the brothers behind “There’s Something About Mary”), has withdrawn from that project. Mr. Penn, who recently won his second Academy Award for his starring role in “Milk,” has also dropped out of a coming drama, “Cartel,” to be directed by Asger Leth. Variety said that Mr. Penn cited personal reasons for his departure from the films. It was unclear if the “Three Stooges” film, which was also to star Benicio Del Toro as Moe and Jim Carrey as Curly, would recast the role of Larry or be postponed.

The North Shore Music Theater of Beverly, Mass., announced Tuesday that it was unable to raise enough money to finance its summer season and will close down permanently, The Boston Globe reported. The theater, which opened in 1955, was once the region’s largest nonprofit theater, drawing as many as 350,000 people a year. But in 2005 its auditorium was destroyed in a fire caused by a defective fog machine. In 2008 a year-end production of “High School Musical 2” sold poorly, and the theater laid off 57 employees as it sought $4 million in additional financing. David Fellows, the chairman of the theater’s board, told The Globe that the theater had about $10 million of debt.
If nonprofit cultural organizations were run like corporations, the chairwoman of New York City Opera might well be out of a job.
Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler celebrate the ninth issue of A Magazine, coming out this week.
Can the manipulation of smell really lead to weight loss? A handful of niche products would have you believe just that.
Is it possible to eat by breathing? Can an inhaler replace a fork?

Bolgiano, Laurel, "Petie", 85, died peacefully June 10, 2009. Graduate of Cornell and Columbia, she had a successful career as a group social worker in NYC. She is survived by her companion, Margaret Treanor, her sister, Frances Smith and brother-in-law Gordon Smith, nephews Peter, Jeffrey, and Stuart Smith and a niece Susan Smith. In her memory please donate to your local food bank.

Internet radio is a fascinating world to explore, but in my house, the exploration began and ended in front of a computer screen. Now there's a fashionable alternative -- one that provides a richer sound than dinky PC speakers, a portable approach to where you listen and another twist: Italian design.

DANIELS--Natalie Black, on June 17, 2009. Adored wife of Harvey. Beloved mother of Stuart (Ismene) and Andrew. Cherished grandmother of Alexander and Peter. Loving daughter of the late Anna and Samuel Black. Funeral services Friday, 11am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make donations in her name to the charity of your choice.

WAGNER--Martin, labor arbitrator, university leader and influential scholar died on Tuesday in his home. He was 97 and lived in Urbana, Illinois. Professor Wagner served as director of the Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations (now the School of Labor and Employment Relations) at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, from 1958 to 1968. He continued as a professor until 1982, when he retired and was awarded emeritus status. Wagner played a central role in the development of public sector labor relations laws for the state of Illinois, including five years of service as chairman of the Illinois Educational Labor Relations Board and leadership on numerous state and regional federal commissions and boards on training, labor-management relations, unemployment, wage-price controls, civil service, and related matters. Early in his career, Wagner served in the WWII Office of Production Management and as a regional director for the National Labor Relations Board in San Francisco and Cincinnati. In 1948, he served as the founding executive director of the Louisville Labor-Management Committee, the nation's first area labor-management committee. In that same year, he was a founding member of the Industrial Relations Research Association (now the Labor and Employment Relations Association), which recently honored Wagner with its lifetime achievement award. He was also recognized recently for 50 years of service in the National Academy of Arbitrators (NAA), a rare accomplishment as individuals are only inducted into the NAA after they have already achieved prominence in the profession. The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) provided Wagner with a Lifetime Membership Award in 1996, a particularly significant accomplishment for a labor neutral. At the School of Labor and Employment Relations at the University of Illinois, Wagner launched one of the early doctoral programs in industrial relations in 1966. He was beloved by former students and colleagues alike and is seen as having provided the core "dna" for what is one of the nation's top programs in labor and employment relations. Born on September 11, 1911, in Newport Kentucky, Wagner earned A.B. and M.A. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1933 and 1935 respectively. He was a Rhodes Scholar, (Magdalen '36) earning a B.A. from Oxford University in 1937 and later an M.A. from Oxford in 1960. At the 100th anniversary celebration of the Rhodes Scholar program in 2003, Martin Wagner was the third oldest recipient in attendance. Wagner is survived by his son John, of Orlando, FL, his daughter Martha Wagner Weinberg, of Brookline, MA, and two grandchildren, David and Katy Weinberg. His wife Nelle Nordstrom Wagner preceded him in death in 1997. A commemorative celebration of Martin Wagner's life and accomplishments is on Saturday morning, September 12th in the Martin Wagner Education Center at the School of Labor and Employment Relations, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, with a memorial service to follow on that weekend.

Investigators for the Congressional committee that Sammy Sosa appeared before in March 2005 are looking into whether he was truthful when he testified that he never used performance-enhancing drugs. ''The Oversight and Government Reform Committee always takes seriously suggestions that a witness misled the committee while testifying under oath,'' Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat who chairs the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, said in a statement. ''Investigators will begin a review of this matter and, upon learning the results, I will determine appropriate next steps.''

MAHLER--Ida May, on June 17, 2009. Beloved wife of Richard; devoted mother of Susan and Jonathan, doting grandmother of Gus, Nora and Benjamin; sister of Kenneth and Heather and friend of many. She will be dearly missed and fiercely remembered.

Olympus has introduced its long-awaited Micro Four Thirds format camera, the E-P1. It is a compact, slick-looking retro model that pays homage to the company's PEN-series cameras that arrived 50 years ago. Think of the E-P1 as the love child of a point-and-shoot camera and a digital single-lens reflex model. Olympus says the 12.3-megapixel E-P1, the world's smallest interchangeable lens camera, marries the image quality of digital S.L.R. models with high-definition video capabilities found on smaller cameras. It also includes 16-bit stereo audio.

BEN-ZVI--Zionah. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Zionah Ben-Zvi, mother of Rena Goodman and mother-in-law of Andy Goodman, whose generosity strengthens our ability to serve those in need in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our condolences to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

What was once called ''good old American know-how'' may seem like a lost trait, but it isn't lost. It's on your phone. The how-to Web site Howcast, whose roughly 100,000 videos cover topics from surviving a plane crash to improving the flavor of ramen noodles, has created a mobile site accessible from any phone with a Web browser, m.howcast.com.

On Monday, Hillcrest Labs introduced a production version of its radically rethought PC mouse, which costs $99 and is available from hillcrestlabs.com and Amazon.com. Hillcrest Labs is pushing the mouse, called the Loop, as the perfect device to use when you're watching video Web sites that you've accessed on your computer and are displaying on your TV.

FINO--Hon. Paul A.,on June 16, 2009, at the age of 95. Devoted husband of 70 years to Esther C. Fino. Beloved and dedicated father of Lucille A. Dimuro (Peter), of Menlo Park, California, and Paul A. Fino, Jr. (Kathleen) of Bronxville, New York. Judge Fino was the proud grandfather of five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Judge Fino dedicated the majority of his life to public service. From 1943-1944 Assistant Attorney General of the State of New York (Bureau Chief of the Criminal Division of the Education Bureau); 1945-1950 New York State Senator (Chairman of the Senate Committee on the Affairs of the City of New York); 1950-1952 Commissioner of the Municipal Civil Service Commmission; 1953-1968 United States Congressman (Member of the House Committee on Veteran's Affairs, member of the House Banking & Currency Committee, Member of the Joint Committee of Defense Production); 1961-1968 Chairman of the Bronx Republican County Commitee (County Leader); 1969-1972 Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York (First Department); 1973-1975 member of the law firm of Fino & Fino, PC. Judge Fino was also the author of "My Life in Politics and Public Service", published in 1986. Reposing at Farenga Brothers Funeral Home, 920 Allerton Ave., Bronx, on Friday, June 19, 2009 from 2-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, June 20, 2009 at 10am at the Church of the Holy Rosary, Bronx. Interment to follow at the Woodlawn Cemetery.

COREN--Oscar Jacob, 95, died June 12, 2009. Husband to wife Rebecca (deceased 2003), father of Jessica Karmen (Andrew Karmen) and Melissa Coren. Cherished grandfather of Emily Ann (Andy Myers). He will be greatly missed. Graveside funeral June 18, 2009, 10:30am, New Montifiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

INSECT bites that itch, turn red and swell are a common malady of the summer. What causes the itch is the body's release of histamines as an immune-system response to the bite. ''Mosquitoes inject their saliva as an anticoagulant, and the protein antigens, or toxins, in the saliva is what the body is reacting against,'' said Dr. Dirk Elston, a dermatologist in Danville, Pa., who has studied the pathology of insect bites. ''So the vast majority of bug bite reactions is largely allergic.'' To combat the allergic reactions, pharmaceutical and skin care companies offer topical antihistamines or anti-inflammatories, which now are combined with skin soothers like oatmeal, or can be applied as a spray instead of a cream. Other companies, taking a cue from the growing market for ''all natural'' formulations, rely on plant extracts and essential oils to reduce irritation. Dr. Elston pointed out that that the folk remedy of using Preparation H hemorrhoid cream on insect bites is well founded because one of its ingredients, pramoxine, is a painkiller.
SIEGEL--George. McLaughlin & Stern, LLP mourns the death of George Siegel, our colleague in recent years. He left us too soon.

BERRY--Mildred F.,formerly of Huntington Woods, MI and Longboat Key, FL, passed away June 16, 2009 at the age of 95. She is survived by her daughter, Judy Kunreuther (Steven), son, James Berry (Hali Edison), son, Donald Berry (Amanda), seven grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. Longtime member of the Detroit Puppet Guild and the Puppeteers of America, she was an active member of the National Council of Jewish Women for many years. She was a wonderful role model and leaves her family with beautiful memories. Memorial service 11:30 Sunday, June 21 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam and 76th St.

TESLENKO--Betty, died peacefully at her home on June 14, 2009 at age 86. A former court reporter and United Airlines flight attendant, she was recruited to work at the United Nations at its inception in 1945. She made many contributions to the work of the United Nations, first as Chief of the English Verbatim Section and then as Deputy Head of the entire Verbatim Reporting Section at the United Nations. Her husband Nicolas Teslenko, a simultaneous translator at the U.N., and her sister, Sylvia Clemens, predeceased her. She had an unwavering dedication to the United Nations, where she served for over 50 years, and was extremely proud of the U.N.'s accomplishments and the wars it has helped avoid. Betty will be forever remembered for her intelligence, graciousness and generosity by her close colleagues and many friends all over the world. Memorial donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders U.S.A., City Meals-on-Wheels or Fountain House.

MASON--Frank. Artist and beloved instructor at The Art Students League of New York for 57 years died Tuesday morning at the age of 88. Recognized by the Knights of St. John of Malta for his paintings on the life of St. Anthony of Padua which hang in the church of San Giovanni di Malta in Venice, Italy. He is survived by his wife Anne, sons Arden Mason and Crispin Connery and hundreds of devoted students and artists.
GREENFIELD--Rhoda. Temple Sinai of Long Island mourns the death of our member Rhoda Greenfield. Condolences to her husband Irwin and family. Rabbi Paula Jayne Winnig Marge Nordell, President

SIEGEL--George, died June 16 after an extended illness. Devoted husband to Alice for 50 years. Loving father to Andrew (Marla), Howard and Jim (Pam). Doting grandfather to Layne and Jake. Services will take place at 10:00am Friday, June 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon. Family will receive visitors Sunday from 1-7pm.

GILSON--Stanley B.,Jr., also known as "Gil", died peacefully at his home in NYC on April 18, 2009 of Park- inson's disease. He was 84. At Gil's request no funeral was held and his ashes will be spread in the same place as his first wife, Sheila Bakerman. Gil was born in Cleveland, Ohio, on December 25, 1924. He moved to New York City in 1953. During his lifetime, he was a musician, a writer, a photographer, an actor and a talent agent. He is survived by his stepson, Robert Bland, his sister-in-law, Jane Bakerman, his niece Debbie Siskin, his nephew Lenny Siskin, his brother-in-law Michael Siskin and his cousins from the Diener side of the family: Jim, Nathalie, Ruth, Ken, Linda, and Sam. Gil had no children. Gil served in the United States Army during World War II, serving as acting first sergeant, supply sergeant, and mess sergeant for one detachment of 250 German prisoners of War in Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri. Gil would often joke about why he spoke English so well--because the German prisoners (many of whom were educated in the U.S.) would correct his English whenever he spoke to them. Gil received a Victory Medal, American Theatre Ribbon and a Good Conduct Medal before he was honorably discharged in 1946. As a freelance writer, Gil published over 2,000 articles in trade magazines, ranging from the oil industry to the healthcare industry. He quickly learned if he took pictures for his articles, he would make more money. So he learned photography as well. Gil, we will miss your wit, your humor and your generosity. We can no longer laugh in your presence, but we are quite certain that somebody is laughing in yours. Rest in peace, my friend.
DOBRER--Jean. June 18, 1954 --August 18, 2000. Jeannie, we miss you so much. Love, Nina, Mom & Dad

KOLAR--Thomas. The Columbia University School of Social Work community extends its sincerest condolences to Donna Rosenthal, past president of the Alumni Association, past chair of the Dean's Advisory Council and active board member of the Columbia Alumni Association, on the passing of her beloved husband Thomas Kolar. Tom was a much loved friend of the School. He will be missed. Dean Jeanette C. Takamura

CORWIN--Beatrice, of New York City, died June 16, 2009 at the age of 96 years. She was married to Sol Corwin and is survived by her children, Dr. Robert Corwin and Marilyn Corwin, twin granddaughters, Jennifer Corwin and Samantha (Jonathan) Smith, and great-granddaughter, Avery Ella Smith. Bea was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother who loved her family with all her heart. She lived a full and healthy life, traveled the world, and touched the lives of many who knew and cherished her. She will be greatly missed.

DEL CONTE--Andrea, 63, passed away June 16, 2009, of cancer in New York City, New York. Born in Rochester, NY, Andrea is survived by one brother, Henry (Diane) Sciarabba, two nephews, John (Jennifer) and Jason Sciarabba and a great-niece, Olivia and great-nephew, Jack. An internationally recognized performer, choreographer, and teacher, Andrea was the Founder/Artistic Director of the 30-year old Spanish dance company, Andrea Del Conte Danza Espana, and she taught at New York City's Lotus Music & Dance Studios. Funeral services will be held June 19 at 10:30am at St. Stephen's Church, 151 East 28th Street. In her memory, contributions may be made to the Lotus Music & Dance Studios (109 W. 27th St).

HALE--Kathleen, on Friday, May 29, beloved sister of Christopher Hale and stepsister of Diane Sherbrook, mourned by many friends. Pioneer in the audiobook industry; a brilliant editor, producer, and director. Private cremation service. "I go on my way, rejoicing."

AS you have surely noticed, all- American preppy style has come back for another goround. There is madras everything, button-downs everywhere. Nantucket reds -- washed-out pink pants -- are the new khakis; Sperry Top-Siders are more common on roof decks than top decks; and the Polo pony and the Lacoste crocodile are now but two of the critters in a zoo of polo shirt insignia. Lately the trend has taken on a new dimension, via the Internet, with a resurgence of interest in once obscure American brands. Alongside the familiar L. L. Bean duck boots, Brooks Brothers shirts and Ray-Ban Wayfarers, there are Filson duffel bags, Gokey boots, Alden dress shoes, Gitman oxford shirts, Quoddy Trail moccasins, Wm. J. Mills canvas totes -- to name but a few. Moribund brands like Southwick and Woolrich are being revived with new designs. And the old-school look has been furthered by popular American fashion labels -- small houses like Thom Browne, Band of Outsiders and Benjamin Bixby along with megabrands like J. Crew and Ralph Lauren.

THALER--Sheldon S.,of Princeton, NJ on June 12, 2009. Inventor of aerospace and medical devices, holder of 30 patents, significant contributor to the development of the pacemaker. Beloved husband of the late Beverly, devoted father of Melinda (David) Milberg and Seth Thaler and his partner Mithila Pathare and stepdaughter Nirja Churi, dear brother of Bob Thaler and Myrina Merenghi, cherished grandfather of Beverly, Ava and Emmett. Services were held Sunday in Princeton, NJ. Memorial contributions to any dementia related charity, or The Princeton Jewish Center.
PAYNTER--William K.,Public Relations Executive, Cdr., USN, Ret. (Navy Cross), 92, died June 15 in Danbury, CT. Services June 20, 11am, Christ Church, Rt. 58, Redding, CT.

Close to 90,000 fans jammed the Los Angeles Coliseum on Wednesday to welcome home the Lakers after the team won its 15th N.B.A. championship.

GILLOOLEY--John F.,M.D., passed away June 16th, 2009. He was a devoted husband to Virginia and loving father to Sean and Kelly. Dr. Gillooley spent his entire 45 year professional career as at St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center and in 1976 he accepted the position of Chairman and Director of Pathology. As a highly esteemed physician and clinician, he worked to keep St. Vincents at the forefront of medical innovation with his contributions to the diagnosis and recognition of AIDS at the beginning of the epidemic and with cancer. He will be so greatly missed as a husband, father, teacher, doctor, friend, and colleague. In lieu of flowers a fund has been set up in Dr. Gillooley's name at The St. Vincent's Comprehensive Cancer Center, a project he was instrumental in launching. SVCCC 325 West 15th Street, New York, NY 10011, attn: Karen Plummer. Please add "In honor of Dr. John F. Gillooley" in the memo.

WASHINGTON--Edith Joan, died peacefully at home on June 14, at age 88. Beloved aunt of Arthur and Pam Washington, great-aunt of Caroline and James, and loving sister of Artie who predeceased her. Edie was born in The Bronx, was a graduate of Hunter College and a finance officer for Chase Bank prior to her retirement. She loved the vitality and history of New York City, and she owned and had read the George Templeton Strong diaries. She also was a fan and advocate of the ballet and theater; literature and women's rights; travel, swimming and the Yankees. We will miss her elan. Visiting at Thomas M. Quinn & Sons, 718-721-9200, Thursday June 18, 5-8pm. Donations may be made in her honor to the Municipal Art Society of New York or Bridges to Community.
SIEGEL--George. Our deepest sympathy to Alice and the family at this time of great loss. George will be forever in our hearts and memories. The Gleits, Mazarins, Glazers

BIANCO--Antonio. Antonio Bianco, known as "Nino", passed away on June 15th 2009, at the age of 57 after a long battle with cancer. Born in Johannesburg, South Africa, Nino originally came from the city of Foggia, in the Province of Puglia in Italy. He came to the United States in 1976 and established himself as one of the greatest master cutters in the diamond industry. Many of the most historic and important diamonds in the world passed through his hands. Nino was the true master cutter for Safdico and Graff diamonds. Nino met his wife Caterina Cilluffo in New York and soon they were married. He is survived by his wife Caterina and his four children Loredana and her husband Allan Russo, his son Dario, daughter Nadia, and son Sandro, and his three siblings in South Africa, Luigi, Giovanni and Maria. The Wake is on Wednesday, June 17th, 2009 from 2:00 4:00pm and 7:00 9:00pm at: Branchburg Funeral Home, 910 Highway 202, South Branchburg, NJ 08876. Phone Number: 908-526-7638. The Mass is on Thursday, June 18th, 2009 at 10:00am at: Blessed Sacrament Church, 1890 Washington Valley Road, Martinsville, New Jersey 08836. Phone Number: 732-356-4442. Followed by the Burial at: Saint Bernard's Cemetery, 551 Route 28, Bridgewater, New Jersey 08807. Phone Number: 908-725-8305. In Lieu of flowers, friends may make donations by check to: The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th floor, New York, New York 10017 U.S.A. Attention: Elise Cooke. Note: "In Memory of Antonio Bianco" for Pancreatic Cancer Research. Please attach a note if you wish to notify the family of your contribution.

FRANKLIN--Ruth, on June 11, 2009. Small in stature but larger than life, she left an indelible impression on everyone she encountered. She was a trailblazer as a woman in voiceovers, starting as the Campbell's soup kids and known for her 61 voices. She worked in show business for nearly 50 years, and was proud to teach the next generation in her renowned master class. A graduate of Carnegie Tech, she was also an officer of SAG and AFTRA for many years. She was a committed upper west sider where she raised her family. She will be forever loved and missed by her children, Lizzie Schwartz, Adam and Laura Schwartz, and Karla and Peter Farrant, and grandchildren, Daisy, Charlotte, Oliver, Wyatt, and Aidan. Donations can be made to the Boston Foundation for Sight. www.bostonsight.org

WEISENTHAL--Morris, 91, of Montclair, died at home Monday, May 18. Morris was born in New York, and was owner of the Morris Gallery in Manhattan's Greenwich Village for many years. A well loved and respected member of the art community, he gave many notable one man shows of New York artists. He published the well known 21 etchings and Poems in 1960, a collaborative effort between artists and poets of the day. Himself a poet, Morris published his collection of poems, Walls of the Labyrinth in 1953. Veteran of WWII. He is survived by his wife Mary, sisters Eva Levine and Julia Norkin; children Rebecca and David; and grandson Vincent.
SIEGEL--George. Loving friend for many years. Condolences to his family. David Wolf

DOES anyone have a delectable recipe that calls for a square inch of lettuce? Almost three months after I sowed my first seeds indoors in the sunless depths of March, practically nothing in the garden is growing. A few heads of lettuce that I started directly in the soil have grown larger than my thumbnail. (Is this what epicures mean when they talk about microgreens?) Seventeen tomato plants, which I started from seed inside, are making grudging progress.

His remarkable leadership will continue to inspire our faculty and students. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Ellen Schall, Dean

8 P.M. (TCM) GREAT DIRECTORS: FRANÇOIS TRUFFAUT A five-film tribute begins with ''Jules and Jim'' (1962), starring Jeanne Moreau as a tempestuous beauty who comes between college friends (Henri Serre and Oskar Werner, from left above, with Ms. Moreau). The evening continues with the semiautobiographical ''400 Blows'' (1959), about a 12-year-old (Jean-Pierre Léaud) who escapes his dysfunctional family by turning to crime, at 10; ''The Bride Wore Black'' (1968), with Ms. Moreau as a woman who seeks revenge on the five men who murdered her fiancé, at midnight; ''Small Change'' (1976), in which two boys (Geory Desmouceaux and Philippe Goldmann) from different backgrounds share the pain and humor of growing up, at 2 a.m.; and ''The Wild Child'' (1970), starring Truffaut as a crusading doctor who tries to civilize a boy (Jean-Pierre Cargol) raised in the wilderness by wolves. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Michelle Pfeiffer talks about her new film, ''Chéri.'' Also, a deserving father gets a makeover, and Mario Batali cooks.

Today’s Marathon Tech Review on the Gadgetwise blog has a fantastic post about using music to boost your workout. You can find music-based workouts by elite marathoner Kara Goucher and tennis great Serena Williams.
New York Times food writer Mark Bittman is planning to run the New York City marathon. He will offer training insights and favorite post-run recipes building up to the Nov. 1 event.

Update | 12:50 p.m. The Georgia Theater, a performance space in Athens that was a crucible for alternative rock acts like R.E.M. and the B-52s, was destroyed by a fire on Friday morning, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported. Witnesses told The Journal-Constitution that the fire began at around 7 a.m., and by 8 a.m., there were four ladder companies and 50 firefighters on the scene attempting to control the fire. As of 10 a.m., the fire had been contained and the roof of the theater, located in a converted cinema, had collapsed. Wilmot Greene, the owner of the theater, told the Journal-Constitution he was unsure if he would be able to rebuilt it. “Even if the insurance pays for it and we can rebuild, it’ll never be the same,” he said. “They don’t build them like that anymore.”

LONDON — On June 18, my first day in London, where I have arrived for a whopping month of theater going, I awoke to headlines about yet another disgraced British cabinet minister, undone by revelations of financial improprieties. On my first evening in London, I attended a play about a disgrace-fearing British cabinet minister on the verge of being undone by revelations of financial improprieties.

While the United States government is putting tax dollars into automobile makers and insurance companies, the German government has devised a stimulus plan for the final resting place of Richard Wagner, The Associated Press reported. On Thursday, the government there said that it had pledged about $700,000 to renovate the composer’s Wahnfried villa, where he and his wife, Cosima, are buried and his archives are stored. The money to renovate the house in Bayreuth, which has been turned into a museum, will come from an economic stimulus package for improving infrastructure. Sven Friedrich, the director of the Richard Wagner Museum, told The A.P. that the renovation would include new exhibitions on the composer’s life and the role of the Wagner family during the Nazi era.

A Minneapolis jury ruled Thursday that a 32-year-old woman must pay $1.92 million dollars to six record companies for illegally downloading their songs from the Internet, Agence France-Presse reported. The woman, Jammie Thomas-Rasset, a single mother of four from Brainerd, Minn., was found liable for violating the copyrights of major labels including Sony BMG, Warner Brothers and Universal for downloading 24 songs from Kazaa, a peer-to-peer file sharing service. Ms. Thomas-Rasset had testified that her former husband or her children may have downloaded the songs. But a lawyer for the Recording Industry Association of America, which filed the suit, said that she “infringed my clients’ copyrights and then she tried to cover it up,” according to Agence France-Presse. An earlier judgment of $220,000 against Ms. Thomas-Rasset was thrown out by a judge who deemed it excessive.

This is certainly the case with Iran. But that’s an incomplete picture of a country that has with a very complex society and a long and rich tradition of art and culture, including movies like Abbas Kiarostami‘s 1997 film “Taste of Cherry.”

Ellen Richard, the executive director of Second Stage Theater, will leave that position on June 30, publicists for the theater company said in a news release. Ms. Richard has been with Second Stage Theater since 2006, during which time the nonprofit Off Broadway company has helped provide a launching pad for Broadway productions like “Next to Normal” and a home for shows like “Becky Shaw” and “Everyday Rapture,” and acquired the rights to purchase the Helen Hayes Theater on West 44th Street. Ms. Richard had previously been the managing director of Roundabout Theater Company, and has been a producer of Broadway productions including revivals of “Cabaret,” “Assassins” and “Glengarry Glen Ross.” Messages left for Ms. Richard were not immediately returned.

That guy next to you on the train who is relentlessly tapping away at his iPhone could be a workaholic or a tech-savvy solipsist, or he might just be a lover of classical music. The New York Philharmonic said Friday that it is offering a free iPhone application that would allow listeners to keep up with the orchestra even when they’re nowhere near Avery Fisher Hall. The app, which is available for download here, allows users to look up event information, purchase tickets, listen to music and access podcasts from an iPhone or iPod Touch. It syncs with iTunes, too, and it’s much classier to be caught fiddling around with than Crash Bandicoot Nitro Kart 3D.

Last week, the list was filled with graphic novels adapting or inspired by literary works. This week, the top two books on the hardcover list are based on video games. “Halo: Uprising,” published by Marvel, boasts the creative team of Brian Michael Bendis and Alex Maleev, who had a critically-acclaimed four-year run on “Daredevil.” Mr. Bendis and Mr. Maleev are both fans of the Halo video game series, and they bring this enthusiasm to their graphic novel adaptation, which bridges the storyline from the end of Halo 2 to the beginning of Halo 3. A free preview of the first issue can be found here.

The French composer and conductor Pierre Boulez will be among the winners of the Kyoto Prize, awarded annually by the Inamori Foundation in Japan to recognize “contributions to the scientific, cultural and spiritual betterment of mankind,” the foundation said in a news release. Mr. Boulez, 84, will be the prize’s laureate in its arts and philosophy category. (Awards are also given in the disciplines of basic sciences and advanced technology.) The foundation recognized Mr. Boulez for his contributions to the musical field of serialism, and for his “controlled chance” compositions and his work as director of the Institute for Research and Coordination Acoustic/Music at the Pompidou Center in Paris. Mr. Boulez and his fellow laureates will be honored in a week of ceremonies that start on Nov. 9 and will receive gold medals and cash prizes of about $500,000 each.

Thanks to our fashion-savvy first lady, Maria Cornejo, who already has something of a cult following (Tilda Swinton, Cindy Sherman and Michelle Williams are fans), is now enjoying more time in the spotlight in the states. But it remains to be seen if she can draw Madame Sarkozy into her fold when her three-week pop-up store and exhibition opens in the Marais neighborhood of Paris this weekend. The three-week stint (June 20-July 11) at the gallery of Cornejo's friend Ed Brachfeld will celebrate the designer's 10-plus years in fashion. In addition to highlighting pieces from the new pre-fall '09 Zero + Maria Cornejo collection and a range of archive pieces selected by Cornejo, the small space will be lined with sketches, collages and photographs taken over the years by Cornejo's husband, the artist Mark Borthwick.

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had two hours of surgery Friday to mend a fractured right elbow.Ian Kelly, a State Department spokesman, said doctors expect Mrs. Clinton to make a full recovery with no permanent damage. The injury occurred when she tripped and fell at the State Department on Thursday. Mrs. Clinton will rest over the weekend at home, but remains "fully engaged," Mr. Kelly said, adding that she did not hand over any duties to other department officials during the operation at George Washington University Hospital.Mrs. Clinton is scheduled to travel to Italy and Greece next week, then to India in July."She'll consult with her doctor," Mr. Kelly said, adding, "We'll take it from there."

For the last nine years, Iranian-American professionals have met on the third Thursday of each month to network with other Persians. Known as Shabeh Jomeh, which translates to "night of Friday," these events take place in major cities across the United States. They often start with cocktails, and move to the dance floor where D.J.'s play popular Persian music. On Thursday, however, they canceled the D.J. in New York.

With Japan's whale hunt in stormy southern seas wrapped for the season, the battle over efforts by a handful of countries to expand whale hunts has shifted to Iceland. There, Greenpeace filmmakers caught video of a whaling vessel hauling two fin whales to the pier for processing. The environmental group is trying to force the new Iceland government to cancel the whaling quota set by the previous government, which collapsed amid the financial crisis. The quota would allow the killing of 150 fin whales and more than 100 minke whales each year for five seasons. So far, the new government has said it would not cancel this year's hunt.

It took consecutive road wins against the talent-laden Yankees, but the Washington Nationals are finally off to a better start than the 1962 Mets, who set the modern futility record with a .250 winning percentage after beginning the season 17-47. While Washington's 18-46 record and .281 winning percentage are certainly nothing to brag about, the young team can take solace in the fact that things could always be worse.

In this weekend's Travel section the cover story is a last-minute guide to camping at 10 national parks. With the economy still floundering, Americans are downsizing travel plans and trekking to the country's great outdoors. Jane Margolies, a frequent contributor, scopes out where to pitch a tent, from the pine forests of Acadia National Park in Maine to the lesser-hiked camps outside of Yosemite. Also, Michelle Higgins, the Practical Traveler, looks at the amenities creeping into private camps, including Wi-Fi and pizza deliveries. As one groundsman described the trend, "It's Disneyland for campers."

For several years, The Times has been focusing on "the climate divide." This is the glaring gap between nations like the United States, with huge energy appetites and vast resulting emissions of greenhouse gases, and those like the countries of sub-Saharan Africa, where a lack of energy options comes with high environmental and social costs (deforestation, deaths from lung ailments caused by cooking on wood or dung).

"Building High Line Park" (04:07)Last week New York City opened its newest park, this one 30 feet in the air. Built in the 1930s, the High Line used to function as a railway to ferry goods up and down the Manhattan waterfront. The trains stopped running in 1980 and the elevated viaduct fell into disrepair. The city planned to demolish the High Line, but a visionary group called Friends of the High Line launched a campaign to save it and turn it into a park. With $86.2 million and many newly planted perennials, grasses, shrubs and trees, the park is now a reality.

"Ska Face," a rude-boy-inspired men's-wear fashion story, photographed by regular T contributor Alasdair McLellan, and styled by Beat Bolliger, is now live. Featuring natty designs by the likes of Raf Simons, Dries Van Noten and Comme des Garçons, the shoot recalls the disaffected masculine glamour of early English mods and skinheads who later embraced ska, a musical genre that originated in Jamaica in the 1950s. The focus on razor-sharp tailoring remains the same as ever, but you have to wonder whether any self-respecting bad boy would go one step beyond in, say, Riccardo Tisci leggings. Oi!

Which got us thinking about another simple, low-cost car that did enter the American market to some success, at least initially: the $3,990 Yugo. The Boston Globe's largest union has set a date for a contract ratification vote, though there is no agreement on a contract. The Boston Newspaper Guild sent a memo to members late Thursday, telling them that it had scheduled a vote for July 20. The guild and The Globe are still negotiating on a package of pay and benefit cuts, with face-to-face talks set to resume Monday, and people briefed on the discussions say a deal is close. But in the meantime, The Globe's owner, The New York Times Company, is insisting that a 23 percent pay cut is in effect for Guild members. The company unilaterally imposed the cut after guild members narrowly rejected a previous package of concessions, including a 10.3 percent salary reduction and deep cuts in benefits. The guild has challenged the unilateral cut with a complaint to the federal regulators, but that could take years to resolve. Guild bylaws require a 30-day wait before a contract proposal is voted on, and the 23 percent cut -- which will show up in paychecks sent out next week -- gives the union an incentive to start that clock ticking as soon as possible. So betting on the chance that the two sides will strike a deal early next week, the guild set a date for a vote. People briefed on the talks say negotiators have the outlines of a deal similar to the one that was rejected, but with a smaller pay cut in the range of 7 or 8 percent. The major stumbling block, they say, is dealing with the 23 percent cut, which would have been in effect for more than a month. The guild wants to find a way to repay some or all of that money to its members.

A film review on Wednesday about “The Windmill Movie,” based on the filmed autobiography of the documentarian Richard P. Rogers, misidentified the text from which the director, Alexander Olch, reads toward the end of the film. It was written by Mr. Olch; it was not excerpts from Mr. Rogers’s journal. The review, using information Mr. Olch provided to a publicist, also misstated the age of eight-millimeter films shot by Mr. Rogers’s father that Mr. Rogers included in his autobiography and are shown in “The Windmill Movie.” While still images taken by the father in the 1920s are also shown, the eight-millimeter films date to the 1930s, when such film was first marketed by Eastman Kodak, not the 1920s. A listing of credits with the review, using incomplete information Mr. Olch provided to the publicist, omitted a composer of the film’s music. Michael Montes should have been credited along with Robert Humphreville.

A report and a headline in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about a Swedish case involving four men convicted of copyright infringement for their involvement in the Pirate Bay Internet file-sharing service misstated The Hollywood Reporter’s account of recent court developments in the case. The Hollywood Reporter correctly said that the Stockholm District Court had rejected the men’s assertions that the judge who presided over their trial was biased. It did not say that a Swedish appellate court had denied the men’s appeal or ruled on the case. (The Hollywood Reporter correctly noted that the appeals court is expected to rule on the case later this year.).

An article last Friday about a meeting convened by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq with his top military commanders referred incorrectly to the post of commander in chief, a role Mr. Maliki has embraced in recent months. He does in fact have the position of commander in chief, according to Article 75 of the Iraqi Constitution. It is not the case that the post of commander in chief “is not mentioned in the Iraqi Constitution.” (It is the Office of Commander in Chief, a bureaucracy created by Mr. Maliki, that is not mentioned.).

The battle for CBGB is over. Two years ago, shortly after the death of Hilly Kristal, the club’s founder, his former wife, Karen Kristal, filed suit against his estate. She said that she was the rightful owner of the business, but had been tricked into signing it over to Mr. Kristal, who then sold the company for $3.5 million and left most of his estate to their daughter, Lisa Kristal Burgman. (The club made little profit, but the CBGB trademark brought in millions from T-shirts and other memorabilia.) A settlement in the suit, which had been filed in Surrogate’s Court in Manhattan, was reached on June 3, lawyers for both sides of the case said on Thursday, but the terms were not disclosed. CBGB opened in 1973 and closed in 2006 after a long dispute with its landlord over unpaid rent.

''There are Shakespearean pleasures to be found in Balanchine's staging'' of New York City Ballet's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'', Alastair Macaulay writes. This weekend City Ballet ends its spring season with four performances of this two-act ballet featuring Puck, Oberon, Titania and a stage full of other magical characters. Go to listen to the ''marvel'' of a score by Felix Mendelssohn, which he composed when he was just 17, and revel in ''the gossamer workings of fairyland and of dream.'' No special dust required.

After insisting that he would leave the details to Congress, President Obama this month intensified his push to overhaul health care. Democrats, Republicans and special interests are battling to shape the legislation as it begins its journey through Congress. Three separate bills are in the pipeline. Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee hope to unveil a bipartisan measure in the near future. The Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions began formal consideration of its plan this week. And Democrats from three House committees are writing a single plan that could be unveiled soon. In all the proposals, there is Democratic consensus on requiring that almost all Americans have insurance and on establishing an insurance marketplace. But lawmakers are struggling to resolve profound disagreements over whether to create a new government insurance plan, whether to impose new obligations on employers and how to generate the $1 trillion or so that the government will need over the next decade to help pay for universal coverage.

The rain that washed out play at Bethpage Black on Thursday left more than a few people scrambling for Plan B, including the 42,500 fans who had tickets for the day's action. Late Thursday, United States Golf Association officials decided to stick with their policy of not refunding or exchanging tickets that were designated for days when rain washed out play. On the event's Web site, a small notice was posted saying, ''Thursday tickets will not be refunded or exchanged.''

Who among us can resist the glockenspiel's charms? Certainly not the musicians set to perform an hourlong piece for the instrument in the East Meadow of Central Park as part of the Make Music New York festival on Sunday. The third annual festival, a day of free concerts, runs from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m. at public spaces all over the city, from downtown sidewalks to the spiral ramp of the Guggenheim. The museum is presenting the East Coast premiere of Henry Brant's ''Orbits'' (1979). The ''spatial symphonic ritual for 80 trombone players, soprano and organ'' will be conducted by Neely Bruce, with the performers positioned inside the museum rotunda in a marriage of music and architecture.

FRANKLIN--Ruth, on June 11, 2009. Small in stature but larger than life, she left an indelible impression on everyone she encountered. She was a trailblazer as a woman in voiceovers, starting as the Campbell's soup kids and known for her 61 voices. She worked in show business for nearly 50 years, and was proud to teach the next generation in her renowned master class. A graduate of Carnegie Tech, she was also an officer of SAG and AFTRA for many years. She was a committed upper west sider where she raised her family. She will be forever loved and missed by her children, Lizzie Schwartz, Adam and Laura Schwartz, and Karla and Peter Farrant, and grandchildren, Daisy, Charlotte, Oliver, Wyatt, and Aidan. Donations can be made to the Boston Foundation for Sight. www.bostonsight.org

LUKES--Roberta Dorothy, 48, of Arlington, MA, died June 15, 2009, at Sawtelle Family Hospice House in Reading, MA, after a long illness. She was born in Erie, PA, daughter of Robert and Mary Lukes. She is survived by her husband Michael Tsuk; her parents; her sisters Anita Goetz of Louisville, KY, Christina Morris of Indianapolis, IN, and Marguerite Lukes of Brooklyn, NY. She was preceded in death by her sister Stephanie Stone and her brother Anthony Lukes. Roberta was a graduate of Waggener High School in Louisvillle, where she was a student in the Advanced Program, a member of the National Honor Society, and a National Merit Scholar. She had joined the Louisville Youth Orchestra while in the seventh grade, and advanced to first chair violist in her junior year of high school. In her senior year she was hired as a violist in the Louisville Orchestra. She attended the Interlochen Music Academy summer program for two summers while in high school. Roberta attended the University of Illinois in Champaign-Urbana as a music major, graduating in 1984. While at the University of Illinois she was named the Presser Scholar in 1983 and upon her graduation she was awarded University Honors and Bronze Tablet for her academic excellence. She then entered the graduate school at Harvard University to further her studies in musicology. She was awarded the degree Master of Arts in 1989, and the degree Doctor of Philosophy in 1996; both degrees were in musicology. While at Harvard she taught in the Music Department as a Teaching Assistant. Roberta and her husband Michael Tsuk were married on June 17, 1990 in the Memorial Church at Harvard University. Throughout their marriage they resided in Arlington. Roberta had many interests other than music and musicology. During graduate school, she was a volunteer tutor for the Eastern Massachusetts Literacy Council (now English At Large), providing one-on-one instruction in basic reading and in English as a second language. She became the Director of Training and Technology for the EMLC, and eventually created a private practice for aiding children with learning disabilities to improve their reading skills. She was also an artist, painting in watercolors, studying under Marjorie Glick of Boston. She was an avid gardener, and enjoyed hiking, canoeing and sailing. As per her request, Roberta's body has been donated to the Harvard University Medical School. A memorial service will be held in her honor at St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church, 7813 Shelbyville Road, Louisville, KY on Saturday, June 27 at 10am, with a reception following in the church Hospitality Room. There will be an additional memorial service and reception to be held at the DeCordova Museum at 51 Sandy Pond Road in Lincoln, MA on Saturday, July 25, 2009 at 6:30pm. Expressions of sympathy in Roberta's memory may go to English At Large, 400 High Street, Medford, MA 02155 or to the Louisville Youth Orchestra, P.O. Box 997, Louisville, KY 40201-0997.

WAGNER--Martin, labor arbitrator, university leader and influential scholar died on Tuesday in his home. He was 97 and lived in Urbana, Illinois. Professor Wagner served as director of the Institute of Labor and Industrial Relations (now the School of Labor and Employment Relations) at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, from 1958 to 1968. He continued as a professor until 1982, when he retired and was awarded emeritus status. Wagner played a central role in the development of public sector labor relations laws for the state of Illinois, including five years of service as chairman of the Illinois Educational Labor Relations Board and leadership on numerous state and regional federal commissions and boards on training, labor-management relations, unemployment, wage-price controls, civil service, and related matters. Early in his career, Wagner served in the WWII Office of Production Management and as a regional director for the National Labor Relations Board in San Francisco and Cincinnati. In 1948, he served as the founding executive director of the Louisville Labor-Management Committee, the nation's first area labor-management committee. In that same year, he was a founding member of the Industrial Relations Research Association (now the Labor and Employment Relations Association), which recently honored Wagner with its lifetime achievement award. He was also recognized recently for 50 years of service in the National Academy of Arbitrators (NAA), a rare accomplishment as individuals are only inducted into the NAA after they have already achieved prominence in the profession. The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers (IBEW) provided Wagner with a Lifetime Membership Award in 1996, a particularly significant accomplishment for a labor neutral. At the School of Labor and Employment Relations at the University of Illinois, Wagner launched one of the early doctoral programs in industrial relations in 1966. He was beloved by former students and colleagues alike and is seen as having provided the core "dna" for what is one of the nation's top programs in labor and employment relations. Born on September 11, 1911, in Newport Kentucky, Wagner earned A.B. and M.A. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1933 and 1935 respectively. He was a Rhodes Scholar, (Magdalen '36) earning a B.A. from Oxford University in 1937 and later an M.A. from Oxford in 1960. At the 100th anniversary celebration of the Rhodes Scholar program in 2003, Martin Wagner was the third oldest recipient in attendance. Wagner is survived by his son John, of Orlando, FL, his daughter Martha Wagner Weinberg, of Brookline, MA, and two grandchildren, David and Katy Weinberg. His wife Nelle Nordstrom Wagner preceded him in death in 1997. A commemorative celebration of Martin Wagner's life and accomplishments is on Saturday morning, September 12th in the Martin Wagner Education Center at the School of Labor and Employment Relations, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, with a memorial service to follow on that weekend.

VIRTUAL GOLF At one tent, the American Express Championship Experience, there is a booth where you can putt on artificial turf guaranteed to roll at 13 on the Stimpmeter, which is fast but not as fast as the United States Golf Association would like to see on the real grass. You can also undergo a rapid-fire swing analysis, which is sort of like a simultaneous cardiogram and magnetic resonance imaging exam. You put on a harness wired to a computer, take a single swing, whacking a golf ball at a Bethpage backdrop, and a week later a swing doctor will send you a diagnosis by e-mail.

The French composer and conductor Pierre Boulez, left, will be among the winners of the Kyoto Prize, awarded annually by the Inamori Foundation in Japan to recognize ''contributions to the scientific, cultural and spiritual betterment of mankind,'' the foundation said in a news release. Mr. Boulez, 84, will be the prize's laureate in its arts and philosophy category. (Awards are also given in the disciplines of basic sciences and advanced technology.) The foundation recognized Mr. Boulez for his contributions to the musical field of serialism, and for his ''controlled chance'' compositions and his work as director of the Institute for Research and Coordination Acoustic/Music at the Pompidou Center in Paris. Mr. Boulez and his fellow laureates will be honored in a week of ceremonies that start on Nov. 9 and will receive gold medals and cash prizes of about $500,000 each.

Services were held Sunday in Princeton, NJ. Memorial contributions to any dementia related charity, or The Princeton Jewish Center.

MIAMI - Sometime on this road trip, the great Mariano Rivera might earn his 500th career save. There's no magic number for saves, as there is for wins or hits or home runs, but that's only because so few closers have ever gotten this high. Trevor Hoffman has 570 and counting, and Rivera has 497. Only two others - Lee Smith at 478 and John Franco at 424 - have more than 390.

David Rohde, one of the best and most intrepid of the reporters at The Times, has been married for nine months. The Times complied, and so did other news organizations -- a life is always more important than a news story.

Andrew Rueb is the assistant coach of the Harvard University men's tennis team. He played for the Crimson in the early 1990s before devoting four years as a journeyman on the professional tennis circuit. His favorite court is baked cow dung and molasses in Zambia; the grass of Wimbledon, where he played doubles in 1997, is a close second. He published an article of his travels in Tennis Week magazine. Before college coaching, Andrew worked for the Boston Lobsters of WTT and Tenacity, an inner-city youth tennis and academic program. In the summers he is the director of tennis at the Belmont Country Club in Belmont, Mass.

DRISCOLL FILIPPATOS Elisabeth on June 14, 2009 in New York City. Mother of Thea and Lily Filippatos; also survived by parents Michael and Hazel Ball. CHENKIN--Norma. It's been two years since you left. I miss you more and more everyday and I love you more and more. 'Til we meet. Norman

PETERSON--Marcia (Mimi), passed away suddenly, 11 June 2009 at the young age of 89. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Colonel David Allen Peterson. She is survived by her nephews Doron Miller and Iddo Gal, great-nephews Roy Miller and Itai Miller, great-great-nephew Liam Miller and step-grandson David Peterson III. She was a long time resident of Westport and Redding, Connecticut, and in later years, a resident of Southbury, Connecticut. She was very intelligent, with a keen sense of the world around her. She was a very interesting person, having very firm views and being a great conversationalist. She loved to entertain her family and friends, and at least once each year, had a gathering at her home. She was very concerned about world and community issues, and freely shared her opinion with friends and colleagues. She taught school in her early years. Services and burial will be held at 1:00pm on Sunday, June 21, 2009 at Beth David cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY 11003.
ROSEE--Irwin. Celebrating you on your 100th birthday. What a party you would have had! Miss you and love you everyday. Marilyn & Rick

McCAFFREY--William Thomas of Long Beach, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. died June 18th, 2009, at his Long Beach home with his wife Mary by his side. Bill had endured a long illness with ALS-Lou Gherigs Disease. Bill was born in Washington Heights on July 7, 1936. He attended Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Parish School and Cardinal Hayes High School before joining The Equitable Life Assurance Society in 1954 as a clerk. While working full time and supporting his young family, he graduated from NYU and earned a masters degree in Business through the executive degree program at Columbia University. Through his dedication and perseverance he held over twenty-six positions at The Equitable before retiring in 1999 due to his illness as Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of AXA/Equitable. Bill met his wife Mary, at The Equitable and they have been married for forty-nine years. They raised their family together in Rego Park, NY. He is dearly loved by his family and is survived by wife Mary, three children Ann Nicoletti (John), William E. McCaffrey, and Christine Lodato (Joseph), his grandchildren Danielle, Gianna, Samantha, Kian, and by his brothers Daniel, John (Martha) and Joseph, and sister-in-law Dolores. His family is very proud of his many accomplishments, his vast generosity, and unwavering compassion for those in need. He was a great advocate in assisting his community and organizations of many realms. As Chairman Emeritus at Xavier University of Louisiana, he chaired the development committee where he raised over $50 million dollars towards the expansion of the campus. He has personally sponsored the education of over thirty students at Our lady Queen of Martyrs where he attended grammar school. He also worked closely with the Inner City Scholarship Fund, Deafness Research Foundation, Bronx Lebanon Hospital, and Marymount Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Our Lady Queen of Martyrs School, 71 Arden Street, New York City, NY 10040 or Xavier University, Drexel Road, New Orleans, LA. Hundreds of Maoists marched with torches in Katmandu on Friday in a protest of the Nepalese cabinet's formal revocation of a firing. The Maoists' leader, Pushpa Kamal Dahal, known as Prachanda, resigned last month after President Ram Baran Yadav prevented him from firing the army chief, Gen. Rookmangud Katawal.

Ali Akbar Khan, the foremost virtuoso of the lutelike sarod, whose dazzling technique and gift for melodic invention, often on display in concert with his brother-in-law Ravi Shankar, helped popularize North Indian classical music in the West, died on Thursday at his home in San Anselmo, Calif. He was 87. The cause was kidney failure, said a spokesman for the Ali Akbar College of Music.

ROBERTS--Morris Slocum, age 64, of Garrison, NY, and Charleston, SC, died peacefully on June 19, 2009 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He grew up in Ligonier, PA, was graduated from St. George's School, Harvard College, Wharton Business School and Columbia Teachers College. After a career in finance he taught Global Studies at the New York City Public School Frederick Douglass Academy. He served as Treasurer of Planned Parenthood of New York City, a Treasurer of Darkness to Light in Charleston, SC, President of the Garrison's Landing Association and Garrison's Station Plaza, a Trustee of the Kornfeld Foundation, and a Trustee of the Hudson Valley Hospital. He was a loving brother to Toby, Robin and Henry Roberts, devoted husband to Katherine Osborn Roberts and wise father to Timothy and Alice and to Charleston, his chocolate lab. He will be remembered for his mischievous sense of humor and fearless love of life right to the end. There will be a celebration of his life at 12pm on July 11th at St. Phillips Church in the Highlands in Garrison, NY. Donations may be made to the Hudson Valley Hospital, attn: Bill Dauster.

The office of Senator John Ensign of Nevada said Friday that his announcement this week that he had an extramarital affair with a former staff member was preceded by a demand for financial compensation from the woman's husband. It was the first time Mr. Ensign's office had commented on reports by people close to him that the husband, Doug Hampton, above, had sought payment over the affair Mr. Ensign reported having with Cindy Hampton from December 2007 to August 2008.

Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had two hours of surgery on Friday to mend a fractured right elbow. A State Department spokesman, Ian Kelly, said doctors expected Mrs. Clinton to make a full recovery with no permanent damage. The injury occurred Wednesday when she tripped and fell at the State Department.

MORGAN--Dr. Henry H.,90, died June 4 of emphysema. A graduate of St. Paul Academy, 1937, Dr. Morgan completed a B.A. in History at Harvard, 1941, and a Ph.D. in Psychology at the University of Minnesota in 1951. As a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Air Force, he served as a fighter control officer in WWII. Dr. Morgan was a consultant and Senior VP at the Psychological Corp. in New York, and co-founded a consulting firm where he worked until 2001. He wrote numerous articles and books on interviewing. He was a Fellow in the American Psychological Association and a Diplomate in Counseling Psychology. In retirement Dr. Morgan wrote Four Pioneer Families of Minnesota. He was involved with organizations such as the Minnesota Historical Society, and was a lifetime supporter of the Ramsey County History Society, Harvard College, the Metropolitan Museum, the Salvation Army, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. He is survived by his wife Donna Davis Morgan, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was known by friends and family for his poetry and his rich sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at Unity Church, St. Paul, MN on July 3, 2009.

DIMITRIU-BONA--Alexandra. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and the Immunology Institute are deeply saddened by the loss of dear friend and colleague, Alexandra Dimitriu-Bona, M.D., Ph.D., wife of beloved, long-time faculty member Constantin Bona, M.D., Ph.D. Educated in Romania, France, and Los Angeles, Dr. Bona was a dedicated physician and scientist whose research focused on molecular and cellular immunology. Dr. Bona held faculty positions in Europe before coming to the United States to join the National Institutes of Health. She then served as Director of the Laboratory of Clinical Immunopathology at Mount Sinai. The Mount Sinai family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Bona's loved ones. Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO The Mount Sinai Medical Center Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs of The Mount Sinai Medical Center Lloyd F. Mayer, M.D., Co-Director of the Mount Sinai Immunology Institute

The performers include Spencer Bartoletti and Dessa Zuccaro, best friends from Burgettstown, Pa.; the Australians Mark O'Shea and his wife, Jay, who currently live in Nashville; Brandon Green of Lucedale, Miss., and his cousin Jonathan Cox of Lenoir, N.C., who make up the group J B Rocket; and Keeira Lyn Ford of San Dimas, Calif., who auditioned as a single but was paired by the judges with Matt Boggs of Richardson, Tex. AGRESTA--Joseph A. Sr. "Skip", on June 18, 2009 of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. Skip was born in Hoboken, NJ was the Agresta family patriarch and owner of Benzel Busch Motor Car Corp. in Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband to Darel (nee) Christensen; devoted father to Allison DeMarsico, Arthur, Kimberly Chiocco, Joseph Jr., Robert and Jack; dear brother to Phyllis Buonomo; cherished grandfather to Peter Joseph, Taylor, Brooke, Christopher, Ava, Joseph III, Isabella and Gia; and loving uncle to 20 nieces and nephews. Above all things, with Darel ever at his side, Skip found his greatest joys in playing with his grandchildren or spending Sunday evenings with his family. It was the simplest and truest of pursuits that gave him the greatest happiness. Whether it was cheering the Yankees to victory or having a scoop of ice cream, he lived life his own way. He was forever young, driven to succeed and thriving on life as if each coming moment would be even sweeter than the last. He was a man who found instant rapport with everyone he met and garnered respect from those he led. Skip could always uncannily deliver the most desperately needed words at the critical moment to ignite passions and fuel dreams. Many found his do-it-once and do-it-right demeanor to be all the encouragement they needed to succeed. Never shrinking from a good fight, Skip often converted his staunchest adversaries into his greatest advocates, earning all their respect along the way. With charitable heart, he was driven to help sustain countless humanitarian causes. The Funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, June 23, 2009 at the Church of Saint Ann in Hoboken at 10:00am. The family will receive their friends on Monday, June 22, 2009 from 2:00-4:00 and 6:00-9:00 at A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave. Cliffside Park, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the ALS Association Development Dept., 27001 Agoura Road, Suite 250, Calabasas Hills, CA 91301 or The Pancreatic Cancer Center at Columbia University Medical Center Atchley Pavilion, 8th Floor, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.

WEINBERG--Jay, on June 18, 2009, aged 91. Devoted husband for 68 years of Marian Schaap. Graduate of Dartmouth College and Tuck School of Business, he was owner/president of several Avis car rental franchises and was a member of the Advertising and Policy Commission. After surviving malignant melanoma, Jay became an active volunteer for many cancer causes. He worked as a civilian on the Investigational Review Board at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center as well as on the Patient to Patient program and was featured in a major ad for the American Cancer Society, He was co-founder of the Corporate Angel Network (CAN) which uses empty seats on corporate aircraft to fly cancer patients to treatment centers. CAN has flown over 30,000 flights to date. An avid skier and tennis player, he will be remembered for his easy way with people and his infectious smile. He is survived by his wife Marian, his three children Jim, Ann, and Joan, seven grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by all. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

A car bomb killed a police counterterrorism agent on Friday in a town near Bilbao, in northern Spain. Authorities blamed the Basque separatist group ETA. If ETA was responsible, the attack ended a six-month lull in the slow stream of killings by the group. Four of its leaders have been arrested in the past year as the French and Spanish police hunt what authorities say is a dwindling force.

“Prttt-prttt-prttt-prttt-prttt.” The thwacking sound, as regular as a metronome, started (and seldom stopped) during the Saturday matinee of “Duet for One” at the Vaudeville Theater. Since the play – about a violinist (Juliet Stevenson, in a wheelchair) coming to grips with multiple sclerosis with the help of a shrink (Henry Goodman, with German accent) – was set in London, imaginative theatergoers could pretend, perhaps, that the noise belonged to the street outside the psychiatrist’s office.

Monday puzzles are supposed to be easy, but of course easy is in the brain of the besolver. JAPE is a term I know only from crosswords. It's a versatile word, it turns out. It can be an intransitive verb (meaning to joke) or a transitive verb (to make fun of) or a noun (a joke). Remember jape because it shows up about once a year in New York Times puzzles. Of course, on Mondays you can always get it from crosses, right? But is 5 Down ICE DAM or ICE JAM? See, you need to remember that other word, I jape you not.

To the Editor: Joshua Kurlantzick’s experiences in “36 Hours in Williamsburg, Va.” (June 7) were exactly the reasons Colonial Williamsburg and all of Hampton Roads is a wonderful place to live and visit. In addition to being a resident, I am the executive director of the Newport News-Williamsburg International Airport. Our airport is the closer of the two commercial-service airports mentioned in the article and has a variety of commercial airline choices: AirTran Airways, Delta and US Airways offer daily flights to many destinations. AirTran offers daily nonstop flights to and from New York’s LaGuardia Airport for as little as $59 each way. Ken R. Spirito.

To the Editor: Regarding “Bucking the Tide on the Tuscan Shore” (June 7). Reading about Frank Bruni’s trek through Viareggio reminded me of the half-hour I spent on that beach in late March 1958. We had driven to Torre del Lago so that I might visit the house where Puccini had lived and written some of his glorious operas. Late in the afternoon we stood shivering on that misty beach while my mother described how Shelley’s body had washed ashore right there. All in all, a sad and dreamy day in postwar Italy. Maggie Marcus.

The 36 Hours column on May 24, about Prague, included an outdated address for the Futurista boutique. After the article went to press, the shop announced that it was moving, and a correction in this space on June 7 misspelled part of the new address. It is Betlemske Namesti 51, not Nanesti.

ALEXANDER--Dr. Albert. Passed away 13 March, 2009 at a young 95. Educator, intellect, author, traveler and inquiring mind. He truly loved life without complaint and enjoyed it with enthusiasm. Loving husband, father and grandfather, predeceased by his beloved wife Roslyn. Survived by his children Howard and Chun Nan, Nancy and Bob; grandchildren Li and Fred, Katharyn and Hampton, Alexandra, Victoria; step-granddaughters Hannah and Rebecca. Although we miss him, he will always be part of the life he gave us.

IT'S akin to the neighborhood diner taking over McDonald's: the news that Koenigsegg -- a Swedish builder of $1 million supercars with a sales total of only 18 cars last year -- will buy Saab from General Motors seems barely less fantastical. If that wild thought had entered my mind when I was testing the CCX last summer, I would have figured the Koenigsegg's 806-horsepower thrust and severe G-forces were to blame. The CCX looked like a four-wheeled starship, and it was a pure gut-check delight to drive. My most lasting impression of the Koenigsegg -- besides its rocket-sled acceleration -- was that it felt like a real production car, rather than a million-dollar kit car or a poorly disguised racer. But Swedish nationality and quirkiness aside, it's still hard to see any logical connection between the Koenigsegg's cost-no-object fantasy and the practical everyday business of Saab.

SIEGEL--George. Beloved lifelong friend and uncle, we will deeply miss you, your friendship and sage counsel. Forever in our hearts, our love and deepest sympathies to Alice, Andrew and Marla, Howard, Jimmy and Pam, Layne and Jake. Love, Richard, Leslie and Adam Holland

SCRIPPS--Mary Hardwick, 1947-2009, age 61, passed away after a long, brave battle with cancer, surrounded by her children in Brooklyn, NY on May 27, 2009. She is survived by her daughter, Rachel Vaughn of Big Sky, MT, sons Welland and Sam Scripps of Brooklyn, NY, honorary son Christopher Roberts of Putnam, CT, grandsons Seasal Finn Vaughn and Trewyn Vaughn of Big Sky, MT, brothers David Hardwick of Woodstock, CT, Paul Hardwick of Cedaredge, CO, sister Patricia Sterling of Gunnison, CO, as well as former husband Sebastian Scripps of Dayville, CT. Mary attended St. Catherine's University and the University of Minnesota. She started her own jewelry manufacturing company, Haywire, in the 1970s, worked in the stock market for Bache and Smith Barney as well as participated in the management of Amelio's Restaurant in San Francisco. She was a supporter of Pomfret School where her sons graduated, graciously opening her doors to students who needed a home for the holidays. Mary made her homes in Thompson, CT and St. John USVI, where her passionate, boundless enthusiasm for gardening, literature and jewelry making was so keen, colorful, joyous. Donations in her name may be made to Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Ave., 2nd Floor, New York, NY 10001-5004. A memorial and celebration of Mary's life is planned for this October at the Pomfret Chapel in Pomfret, CT. Mom, we miss your kindness, your warmth, your unconventional, liberal spirit, politics, and amusing conversation. Your generosity lives on in many gardens, hearts, dinner parties and in the vivid memories of you reaching out to all, friend and stranger alike. We love you Mom, you are deeply loved and deeply missed by all, Rachel Vaughn, Welland and Sam Scripps.
