SANTANA'S CUT MEN, on 106th Street just west of First Avenue, returns the professional boxer Edgar Santana, 30, to his tonsorial roots. A decade ago, he was a barber on 109th Street, where he met someone who introduced him to a man who would become his manager. Nicknamed ''The Pride of East Harlem,'' Mr. Santana was seen as a contender until he was arrested and charged with conspiracy and sale of cocaine last year. He pleaded not guilty and is out on bail. At the new shop, five barbers wear satin jackets emblazoned with ''We Cut Heads'' on the back. The walls are covered with sketches and slogans by a friend, the artist James De La Vega. Last week, a wide screen television played Ice Cube's video ''Check Yo Self,'' which opens with the rapper being arrested. Santana paid it no mind.

GILSON--Stanley B.,Jr., also known as "Gil", died peacefully at his home in NYC on April 18, 2009 of Park- inson's disease. He was 84. At Gil's request no funeral was held and his ashes will be spread in the same place as his first wife, Sheila Bakerman. Gil was born in Cleveland, Ohio, on December 25, 1924. He moved to New York City in 1953. During his lifetime, he was a musician, a writer, a photographer, an actor and a talent agent. He is survived by his stepson, Robert Bland, his sister-in-law, Jane Bakerman, his niece Debbie Siskin, his nephew Lenny Siskin, his brother-in-law Michael Siskin and his cousins from the Diener side of the family: Jim, Nathalie, Ruth, Ken, Linda, and Sam. Gil had no children. Gil served in the United States Army during World War II, serving as acting first sergeant, supply sergeant, and mess sergeant for one detachment of 250 German prisoners of War in Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri. Gil would often joke about why he spoke English so well--because the German prisoners (many of whom were educated in the U.S.) would correct his English whenever he spoke to them. Gil received a Victory Medal, American Theatre Ribbon and a Good Conduct Medal before he was honorably discharged in 1946. As a freelance writer, Gil published over 2,000 articles in trade magazines, ranging from the oil industry to the healthcare industry. He quickly learned if he took pictures for his articles, he would make more money. So he learned photography as well. Gil, we will miss your wit, your humor and your generosity. We can no longer laugh in your presence, but we are quite certain that somebody is laughing in yours. Rest in peace, my friend.

MASON--Frank. Artist and beloved instructor at The Art Students League of New York for 57 years died Tuesday morning at the age of 88. Recognized by the Knights of St. John of Malta for his paintings on the life of St. Anthony of Padua which hang in the church of San Giovanni di Malta in Venice, Italy. He is survived by his wife Anne, sons Arden Mason and Crispin Connery and hundreds of devoted students and artists.

CONNETT--Eugene Virginius, IV, also known as "The Kid" died peacefully on June 12, 2009. He was born in South Orange, NJ on January 21, 1920. He was the son of Eugene V. Connett, III (Derrydale Press), and Kathryn Elise Underhill Connett. He is predeceased by his sister Elise Migeon Connett Baker. Eugene attended St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, graduating in 1939. He attanded Princeton as a multiple legacy and was a member of the Cottage Club and the crew team. In 1942 he graduated early to enlist as a first lieutenant in the Army Air Corps, as a navigator, and served on a classified assignment with the O.S.S. in the Alsace-Lorraine region of France until 1945. Following WWII, Eugene worked at David Ogilvy Associates in New York, where he met his wife, Etheldred Slosson McGrew (Geneva, NY) (predeceased). They were married on April 29, 1950. Later, Eugene became the Vice President of the American Carpet Institute, worked for Springs Mills, Inc. and consulted to several manufacturers in the fiber industry. Mr. Connett sailed competitively on the Great South Bay and instilled the love of sailing in each of his children. In the 1960s he gained the reputation as a small boat racer's worst nightmare, while sailing for Riverside Yacht Club, Riverside, CT. In 1979, the Connett family moved to Stonington, CT and joined the Wadawannuck Yacht Club. His sterling civic and professional accomplishments are only eclipsed by his greater achievements as a magnificent father, faithful friend and man of integrity. He was adored by all who knew him. The funny man is gone. Eugene is survived by his five children and their partners; Stacey Migeon Connett Spartz, David Wolodko, Bevan Brecount Connett Kinney, Daniel Kinney, Kathryn Underhill Connett Loh, Richard C. Loh, Eugene Virginius Connett, V, Lori R. Connett, Aubrey Fitzhugh Connett, and Kimberly H. Connett. He also was the proud grandfather to seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Episcopal Church, located at 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT 06378, at 12:30pm, on Sunday, June 28, 2009. Donations may be made in his memory to the Visiting Nurse Association of Southeastern Connecticut, 403 Frontage Road, Waterford, CT 06385.

SIMMONS--Lorraine (nee Brown), 82. Dearly beloved wife of Dr. Henry Simmons. Proud, adoring, and adored Grandma of Theodore and Madeleine. Treasured mother and mother-in-law of Judy and Giuseppe Caliano and Robin Bell and Mike Shone, and devoted mother of the late Deborah and Leonard. Suddenly you are gone, and our hearts are aching. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Sunday 11:15am. Friends may visit the Simmons home Sunday, 6-8pm and Tuesday, 6-8pm. We miss you dearly and will love you forever.

Bad, but Not Worst It took consecutive road wins against the Yankees, but the Washington Nationals are finally off to a better start than the 1962 Mets, who set the modern futility record with a .250 winning percentage after beginning the season 17-47. Washington's 20-46 record and .303 winning percentage are certainly nothing to brag about, but the young team could take solace in the fact that things could be worse.

When the 2008 Open at Torrey Pines is boiled down to its essence, Tiger Woods and Rocco Mediate are usually the only golfers who come to mind. After all, they dominated the airwaves with their unforgettable head-to-head duel in a Monday playoff won by an injured Woods. Overlooked was how close Lee Westwood came to being in the playoff. Westwood, 36, had a birdie putt on the 72nd hole to get into the playoff. He remembered it being some 20 feet.

KUPER--lluminada Landa, Nicknamed "Lumi", died on June 17, 2009 at 87. Mrs. Landa, mother of Joseph C. Landa and Maria Luisa Rego Landa, was born in Oriente, Cuba on November 29, 1921. Her family migrated to New York where she married Jose "Pepe" Landa in 1951. In 1953, combining their talents, the Landas' began a business producing fine home furnishings and custom window treatments for top architects and interior designers of their day. Now a third generation business, Interiors by JC Landa, LLC continues the tradition of excellence as her son's work can be found in the most important house in the world, the Presidential White House in Washington, DC. Lumi Landa is survived by Joseph C. Landa and Maria L. Rego Landa and six grandchildren: Rebeca, Jennifer, Adrianna, Joseph F., Alex and Daniel

SETANTA IN FLUX Setanta, the international sports broadcaster that was seeking emergency financial backing to make a nearly $50 million deadline payment to the English Premier League, failed to come up with the money and forfeited the right to carry 46 E.P.L. matches. Setanta's contract to broadcast the 46 games was terminated, and the rights will be put up for auction. In a statement issued late Friday in New York, Setanta Sports US said ''this development does not affect our channels and other services in the U.S.'' because it is a ''separate operation that has separate agreement to show the Barclays Premier League.''

Steve Stricker shot a second-round 66 on Saturday, tied for the third-best score of the day, and his two-round total of 139 tied him for 12th at the United States Open. He is one of only two golfers from the tournament's blighted first group -- the ones who teed off Thursday morning and had to play through heavy rains before the tournament was temporarily suspended -- to rank that high. The other is Lee Westwood. Stricker is a journeyman pro, known more for steadiness and consistency than for shot-making brilliance, and yet his game may be well suited to Bethpage, especially if the weather worsens. He is an accurate driver, with a rounded swing that can sweep the ball off a sodden fairway. Most useful may be his conservative, workmanlike approach.

In today's global economy, vehicles are often assembled far from their brand's traditional home bases. Vehicles with familiar Detroit nameplates may be assembled in Mexico, while some esteemed German models are actually built in the Southern United States, creating confusion for consumers who want to buy an American-made vehicle. This chart lists the cars and trucks currently assembled in the United States and where their engines and transmissions were made. COOPERMAN--Dr. H. Harvey, age 93, on April 25, 2009, in Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved husband for 67 years of the late Beatrice Lazow Cooperman (December '06). A graduate of the University of Wisconsin Medical School, and the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine, Dr. Cooperman was a general and thoracic surgeon for over 40 years in Brooklyn and L.I. A former Professor of Medicine and Surgery at Downstate Medical Center, SUNY, he was well respected for his dedication to his profession and patients, as well as for his personal integrity. Always the intellectual, with an encyclopedic memory, he was an enthusiastic world traveler, seeking knowledge of all disciplines throughout his entire life. A dedicated family man, he will be greatly missed by all, including daughter Carol B. Halper (Steven), son Dr. Elliot Cooperman (Robyn), grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

COWEN--George N. The former partners of Cowen & Co. were saddened by the passing of George N. Cowen, a partner for many years. He was a loyal and steadfast partner and all of us appreciate his loyalty and dedication to our firm. Financial Square Partners

MARTIN--Edward Anthony, died on June 15, 2009 at the age of 59. A longtime and gifted English teacher at the Berkeley Carroll School in Brooklyn, Ed was passionate about Shakespeare and New York City. A graduate of Indiana and Fordham Universities, Ed is survived by his son Ben, former wife Susan, siblings Larry and Tracy, and generations of devoted students. A memorial service will be held on June 26 at 2pm at 181 Lincoln Place.

AGRESTA--Joseph A. Sr. "Skip", on June 18, 2009 of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. Skip was born in Hoboken, NJ was the Agresta family patriarch and owner of Benzel Busch Motor Car Corp. in Englewood, NJ. Beloved husband to Darel (nee) Christensen; devoted father to Allison DeMarsico, Arthur, Kimberly Chiocco, Joseph Jr., Robert and Jack; dear brother to Phyllis Buonomo; cherished grandfather to Peter Joseph, Taylor, Brooke, Christopher, Ava, Joseph III, Isabella and Gia; and loving uncle to 20 nieces and nephews. Above all things, with Darel ever at his side, Skip found his greatest joys in playing with his grandchildren or spending Sunday evenings with his family. It was the simplest and truest of pursuits that gave him the greatest happiness. Whether it was cheering the Yankees to victory or having a scoop of ice cream, he lived life his own way. He was forever young, driven to succeed and thriving on life as if each coming moment would be even sweeter than the last. He was a man who found instant rapport with everyone he met and garnered respect from those he led. Skip could always uncannily deliver the most desperately needed words at the critical moment to ignite passions and fuel dreams. Many found his do-it-once and do-it-right demeanor to be all the encouragement they needed to succeed. Never shrinking from a good fight, Skip often converted his staunchest adversaries into his greatest advocates, earning all their respect along the way. With charitable heart, he was driven to help sustain countless humanitarian causes. The Funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, June 23, 2009 at the Church of Saint Ann in Hoboken at 10:00am. The family will receive their friends on Monday, June 22, 2009 from 2:00-4:00 and 6:00-9:00 at A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave. Cliffside Park, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the ALS Association Development Dept., 27001 Agoura Road, Suite 250, Calabasas Hills, CA 91301 or The Pancreatic Cancer Center at Columbia University Medical Center Atchley Pavilion, 8th Floor, 161 Fort Washington Avenue, New York, NY 10032.

KASARSKY--Leon, Retired Salesman, 91, a former resident of Wantagh, NY, and then of Boynton Beach, FL, died May 22 of Alzheimers' disease. Leon attended Brooklyn's James Madison H.S. followed by NYU. During WWII he served with distinction in the Pacific as a member of the Military Police, earning a Purple Heart. He began his career in his father's fur business, then worked in sales for a variety of companies. Leon and his wife of 36 years, Lorna, raised three children: Dr. Jason Kasarsky of Irvington, NY, Fern Kasarsky Dobuler of Beit El, Israel and Andrea Kasarsky of Arlington, VA. He always considered his three children his greatest accomplishments! Tennis was his leisure time passion, playing well into his 80s. He supported the Israel Tennis Centers, as well as Jerusalem's Alyn Pediatric & Adolescent Rehab Center for infants and youngsters afflicted with physical disabilities. Leon's loving brother Irving of Floral Park survives him. Younger siblings Sidney Kane and Gladys Silvers predeceased him. Leon is survived by his second wife Alice, his three children, seven grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Leon's great humor and gentleness touched all who knew him. Our father will be remembered with much love and affection.

Joaquín Sorolla and Henri Matisse are the subjects of exhibitions in Madrid this summer. Through Sept. 6, the Prado (www.museodelprado.es) is presenting ''Joaquín Sorolla (1863-1923),'' a retrospective featuring more than 100 paintings by the Valencian artist, including his well-known ''Visions of Spain,'' above, which is a collection of 14 panels painted for the Hispanic Society of America. Organized chronologically and by theme (portraits, social issues, beach and landscape), the paintings also include ''The Pink Gown'' and ''The Sad Inheritance.'' Admission is 10 euros, or $14.20 at $1.42 to the euro.

A lot of people perceive comedy as sort of a brag, you know: 'Hey, look at me. I'm so funny.' So when they don't like you, they can't wait to tell you. I did a show and I went outside to smoke a cigarette, and then a guy and his girlfriend walk out. They go, 'You were the worst comedian we've ever seen.' And then they laughed at me and walked away. But to me, like, that is weird. I would never be at a play or seeing a band play and then, oh, there's that guy; I'm going to tell him that he totally stinks.

MORGAN--Dr. Henry H.,90, died June 4 of emphysema. A graduate of St. Paul Academy, 1937, Dr. Morgan completed a B.A. in History at Harvard, 1941, and a Ph.D. in Psychology at the University of Minnesota in 1951. As a 1st Lt. in the U.S. Air Force, he served as a fighter control officer in WWII. Dr. Morgan was a consultant and Senior VP at the Psychological Corp. in New York, and co-founded a consulting firm where he worked until 2001. He wrote numerous articles and books on interviewing. He was a Fellow in the American Psychological Association and a Diplomate in Counseling Psychology. In retirement Dr. Morgan wrote Four Pioneer Families of Minnesota. He was involved with organizations such as the Minnesota Historical Society, and was a lifetime supporter of the Ramsey County History Society, Harvard College, the Metropolitan Museum, the Salvation Army, and the University of Minnesota Foundation. He is survived by his wife Donna Davis Morgan, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was known by friends and family for his poetry and his rich sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at Unity Church, St. Paul, MN on July 3, 2009.

CONNETT--Eugene Virginius IV. On June 12, 2009, Eugene Virginius Connett IV, aka "The Kid", passed on. He was born to his proud parents, Eugene V. Connett III and Kathryn Elise Underhill Connett on a snowy morning on January 21, 1920 in South Orange, NJ. His advent was welcomed with open arms by his sister, Elise Migeon Connett. Eugene was privileged to attend St. Paul's School of Concord, NH, graduating in 1939. In the spring, he fished the chalk streams of England with his father, (who was an expert trout fisherman and distinguished author and owner of the Derrydale Press). He spent his autumns shooting with his father in duck blinds on the Chesapeake and the golden grasslands of North America. Immediately following his high school years, Mr. Connett attended Princeton as a 4th generation legacy, where he graduated with a degree in French Literature in 1942. There, he was a member of the Cottage Club and the Princeton Crew Team. With WWII in full swing in 1942, Mr. Connett enlisted as a first lieutenant in the Army Air Corps. His superb language skills were seen as a valuable asset and bought him a classified assignment with the O.S.S. in the Alsace-Lorraine region of France until 1945. Following the war, Connett returned home and took a position with David Ogilvy Associates in NYC, NY as a marketing executive. He met his future bride, Etheldred Slosson McGrew (of Geneva, NY) in an elevator and smitten with her willowy frame and winsome smile, wed her on April 29, 1950. The following spring, the happy couple was blessed with their first child, Stacey Migeon Connett (Spartz). Within the ensuing seven years, his daughters, (Bevan Brecount Connett Kinney and Kathryn Underhill Connett Loh) and his identical twin sons, (Eugene Virginius Connett V and Aubrey Fitzhugh Connett) had joined the family. Mr. Connett was an accomplished sailor who was familiar throughout the great South Bay of LI, NY, where the Connett family summered until the mid 1950's. In the 1960's, Mr. Connett established himself as a small boat racer's worst nightmare, competing around the harbors of Long Island Sound under the burgee of Riverside Yacht Club in Riverside, CT. In 1979, Eugene and his family relocated to Stonington, CT, where he assumed the distinguished status of M.P.S.O. and enjoyed a membership in the Wadawannuck Yacht Club in Stonington, CT. His professional accomplishments included attaining the Vice Presidency of the American Carpet Institute in NYC, NY and ownership of the world renowned Stonington Clothing Ltd., of Stonington, CT. By far, his greatest achievement was being a magnificent father, faithful friend and man of integrity. He was a lovely guy who led a sun-kissed life and was adored by all who knew him. Eugene Connett IV is survived by all his sons and daughters (above), their spouses and partners; Dan Kinney, Rick Loh, Lori Connett, Kim Connett and David Wolodko. He also leaves behind his handsome grandchildren; Matthew Perry, Eric, Mark and Stacey Loh, Emily Connett and Tommy and Andrew Connett, of whom he was unspeakably proud! Services will be held in his honor at Calvary Episcopal Church located at 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. 06378 at 12:30pm on Sunday, June 28, 2009. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Visiting Nurse Association of Southeastern CT, 403 N. Frontage Rd., Waterford, CT. 06385.

KALLA--Ann, (Sara Ann). 6/21/56-5/31/09. Ann Kalla, 52. Born in Pittsburgh, PA in 1956, daughter of artist and sculptor, Erwin Kalla and Phylis Kalla, she attended Carnegie Mellon University, receiving a Bachelors Degree in Economics in 1976. She earned a Masters Degree in Architecture from Columbia University in 1980 along with an AIA Medal for distinguished design work. After graduation Ann worked for the NYC firm of James Stewart Polshek & Partners and later for John Chimera Architects. A friendship with Pietro Cicognani made on her first day at Columbia University turned into a lifelong business and design collaboration. They organized Aedificare, Inc. later to become Cicognani Kalla Architects, P.C. Over 120 projects were designed in the course of the partnership, including the Heinz Architectural Center at the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh. In NYC the firm received the Restoration Award from the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic District. Ann's lifelong passion for horses, orchid growing and the Sunday crossword puzzle were the few diversions from her work. The firm's work appeared in the English, French, Italian and Russian editions of Architectural Digest, in House & Garden, House Beautiful, Elle Decor, New York Magazine and Vogue. Ann died at Memorial Hospital on May 31st as a result of breast cancer. She is survived by her mother, Phylis Kalla of Pittsburgh, PA. A memorial service will be held in September. Gifts in memory of Ann may be made to Carnegie Mellon University - Ann Kalla Endowed Fund; Gift Administration; 6 PPG Place; Pittsburgh, PA 15222 or to Columbia University School of Architecture Ann Kalla Endowed Fund; 403 Avery Hall; 1172 Amsterdam Ave.; New York, NY 10027

DANIEL Birnbaum, the curator of the 53rd Venice Biennale, took its title -- ''Making Worlds'' -- from a book by the American philosopher Nelson Goodman, who advocated thinking about art less as finished work and more as a means, like science, of comprehending the world. Goodman proposed replacing the slippery question ''What is art?'' with the question ''When is art?'' During the biennale, still arguably the world's most important international exhibition, the answer is: always, constantly, art without interval. And Venice itself -- that ''repository of consolations,'' as Henry James called it -- becomes the glorious frame. Much of the contemporary art scattered throughout the city attempts, if only briefly, to become part of Venice's noble architecture, as with Spencer Finch's multicolored windows at the Arsenale, the rooftops glimpsed through Mona Hatoum's cutouts of soldiers, and the unexpected projections and installations that seem to wait around every corner. As if issuing a reminder of the precariousness of Venice and of art itself, the waters invaded on June 6, during the last evening of the press preview, flooding much of the city and turning the ground into a giant mirror in the twilight -- yet another work, with Venice and its art-world multitudes reflected in the surface. RANDY KENNEDY

JONES--Robert Scott, Jr.,died June 11, 2009 following a short illness. Born to Criss (nee Emma Topping) and Robert Sr., who lived in Rockville Center. A Navy veteran of WWII, Bob attended programs at Duke University and Berea College. Settling in New York City after the war, Bob began modeling for the Harkrider Modeling Agency. He moved to Hampton Bays in the 1970s, establishing the antique and collectible business "Ada's Attic" with George Tetzel, a partner. A 35 year venture! The Town of Southampton has since acquired this site, restoring the building as the historic landmark "King House". Robert is survived by George Tetzel; sister Doris and brother-in-law William; nephews William, Robert, Thomas and niece Mary Criss. Visitation will be held on Friday, June 26, at O'Shea Funeral Home in Hampton Bays, from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass celebrating Bob's life will be held on Saturday, June 27 at St. Rosalie's Church, Hampton Bays, at 10:30am.

VANDERBILT AVENUE, between Dean Street and Park Place in Brooklyn, is blocked off to traffic Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. as part of the city's ''Summer Streets'' festival. Bicyclists and scooter aficionados zig and zag. Children play Hula Hoop across the double yellow line and make chalk masterpieces in the middle of the road. Bars and restaurants hawk drink specials (Beast, a hip bistro with sidewalk seating, had $3 margaritas). One week, the experimental theater group Dzieci presented ''Makbet,'' its ''gypsy retelling'' of ''Macbeth,'' with audience involvement. Another week, the kiddie-rock band Music for Aardvarks led an outdoor sing-along, ending with its signature song, ''Taxicab'': ''Uh-oh, I think I lost my skateboard/Normally that's bad/Good thing I'm a city kid/'cause I can hail a cab.'' Except on Vanderbilt Avenue.

GOLD--David. The Louis Armstrong House Museum is deeply saddened by the death of David Gold, President Emeritus of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation and longtime business associate of Louis Armstrong. For decades, David's vision and leadership has kept Louis Armstrong's legacy alive for millions of people. We will miss him dearly. Our condolences and prayers go out to David's family.

Who would have thought that the cardigan would unseat the structured jacket? Yes, the established designers were horrified when Michelle Obama wore one to the palace to meet the queen. But a new generation is deciding what is appropriate, and last week's chill cemented the look as young women wore cardigans to work in droves. Their sweaters have nothing to do with society women dressing for lunch. The comfort factor and sportswear attitude mirror what Chanel showed the world when she cut jersey into jackets around World War I, completely but not overnight replacing the hothouse elegance of the Edwardian woman.

GREENFELD--Lisbeth G. Over 50 years ago Bryn Mawr classmates took liberty with a popular song's lyrics and sang "We may be wrong, Beth, we think you're wonderful; we may be wrong, Beth, we think you're swell." From 1955 to now we never saw any reason to sing it any other way. Beth's death on June 10th, 2009 leaves a void in all our lives. Although we shall gather together to remember our friend in the near future for now, we say Anassa Kata, kalo, kale...Beth! Rhoads Hall, Bryn Mawr Class of 1959

CURTIS--Kurt L.,son of the late Flora and Isidor Idstein of Mannheim and Krefeld, Germany and Queens, New York, passed away at the age of 97 on June 14, 2009 at his home in Boca Raton, FL. He is survived by Lisa, his loving wife of nearly 69 years, his son Thomas, daughter Linda and her husband Robert Sonderman, his grandchildren Kristina Curtis, Michael Sonderman (wife Amy), David Sonderman (wife Nadia), great-grandsons Matthew Curtis and Oliver Sonderman, and niece Vera Ginsburg (companion Marsha). PETERSON--Marcia (Mimi), passed away suddenly, 11 June 2009 at the young age of 89. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Colonel David Allen Peterson. She is survived by her nephews Doron Miller and Iddo Gal, great-nephews Roy Miller and Itai Miller, great-great-nephew Liam Miller and step-grandson David Peterson III. She was a long time resident of Westport and Redding, Connecticut, and in later years, a resident of Southbury, Connecticut. She was very intelligent, with a keen sense of the world around her. FRANKLIN--Ruth, on June 11, 2009. Small in stature but larger than life, she left an indelible impression on everyone she encountered. She was a trailblazer as a woman in voiceovers, starting as the Campbell's soup kids and known for her 61 voices. She worked in show business for nearly 50 years, and was proud to teach the next generation in her renowned master class. A graduate of Carnegie Tech, she was also an officer of SAG and AFTRA for many years. She was a committed upper west sider where she raised her family. She will be forever loved and missed by her children, Lizzie Schwartz, Adam and Laura Schwartz, and Karla and Peter Farrant, and grandchildren, Daisy, Charlotte, Oliver, Wyatt, and Aidan. WEINBERG--Jay, on June 18, 2009, aged 91. Devoted husband for 68 years of Marian Schaap. Graduate of Dartmouth College and Tuck School of Business, he was owner/president of several Avis car rental franchises and was a member of the Advertising and Policy Commission. After surviving malignant melanoma, Jay became an active volunteer for many cancer causes. He worked as a civilian on the Investigational Review Board at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center as well as on the Patient to Patient program and was featured in a major ad for the American Cancer Society, He was co-founder of the Corporate Angel Network (CAN) which uses empty seats on corporate aircraft to fly cancer patients to treatment centers. CAN has flown over 30,000 flights to date. An avid skier and tennis player, he will be remembered for his easy way with people and his infectious smile. He is survived by his wife Marian, his three children Jim, Ann, and Joan, seven grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed and fondly remembered by all. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

ORNAUER--Richard Lewis, newspaper editor and educator, died June 11, 2009 at Courtland Manor, Dover, Delaware. of a stroke at the age of 86. Mr. Ornauer had been city editor of the Nassau Daily Review-Star in Rockville Centre, NY, and Long Island Press at Jamaica, NY, for 20 years. Previously he had been a reporter, copyreader and night editor at the Review-Star on Long Island, NY. He started his newspaper career as wire editor at the Coastal Georgian in Brunswick, GA. Later, he was an assistant to the commissioner (public information) for the Nassau County (NY) Department of Social Services, and Public Health Information Director for the Nassau County Department of Health from 1971 to 1987. He retired as director of communications for the New York State School Boards Association at Albany, NY, in 1989, and relocated to Dover, DE. On Long Island, Mr. Ornauer was a member of the Merrick Board of Education for 26 years, four years as president; and a founding member of the Board of Cooperative Educational Services (BOCES) of Nassau County for 20 years, 18 as president. He served on the Executive Committee of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association for 26 years, two years as president. Mr. Ornauer was elected to the Board of Directors for the New York State School Board Association in 1979 and served ten years, six as vice president and eight as a member of the Executive Committee. During this period, he was a voting delegate from New York State to the National School Boards Association, served on several of its presidential task forces, and was president of its Northeast Region in 1987. He was a founding member and represented New York's Fourth Congressional District on the National School Boards Association's Federal Relations Network. He also served on the New York State School Board's Legislative Network for the 18th Assembly District. He was the recipient of the Man-of-the-Year awards from the Merrick Chamber of Commerce and Long Island Association of Special Education Administrators. He was named Educator of the Year in 1973 from Phi Delta Kappa, honorary education society. He received Distinguished Service awards from the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association in 1979 and 1987; in 1982 from the Floral Park-Bellerose School District (at which he attended elementary school); and in 1982 from the Public Television Station WLIW-TV (Channel 21) in Garden City. Mr. Ornauer received numerous citations for his work in journalism and public education. He was an honorary life member of both the New York State and National Parent-Teacher Associations. In Delaware, Mr. Ornauer had been an AARP Driver Safety Program (formerly known as 55 Alive/Mature Driving) instructor since 1993, Assistant State Coordinator 1996-2003, and Associate State Coordinator since 2003. He was a member of the AARP's Delaware State Leadership Council, AARP Delaware Executive Council, representing communications since 2004; on the Board of Directors of the Greater Dover Area Chapter 721 of the AARP for six years, serving as its public information officer and chairman of its Bylaws Revision Committee. He was a founding member of the Public Advisory Committee to the Dover/Kent County Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) since 1993 and served as its chairman from 1995 to 2001. He was the Kent County appointee to Delaware Department of Transportation's Prioritization Systems Committee and to its Advisory Committee on Traffic Calming Devices, and the MPO's Project Prioritization Policy Committee. He also was Government Relations chairman of the Mifflin Road Neighborhood Association, member of the City of Dover Transportation Committee, City of Dover Public Safety Issues Implementation Committee and City of Dover Sign Amendment Advisory Committee. He also served as a volunteer communications officer for the Dover (now Mobility) Air Force Base Museum. A graduate of the University of Missouri's School of Journalism, Mr. Ornauer served as an apprentice reporter and copyreader on the Columbia Missourian and a radio news writer for station KFRU in Columbia, MO. He was a life member of the Professional Journalists Society/Sigma Delta Chi, and member of both the Press Club of Long Island, and the Empire State Chapter. He is listed in Who's Who in America since 1977. His hobby was collecting all forms of Puffins, an Arctic sea bird. Mr. Ornauer, an Army sergeant major with both the 5202 and 5221st Engineer Construction Brigades in the Asiatic-Pacific area, served from 1942 to 1945. He participated in invasions at Biak Island in the Netherlands East Indies (now West Papua, Indonesia), Leyte and Luzon Islands in the Philippines. He also served at New Guinea (now Papua), Okinawa and Korea. In the United States, he was assigned to Battery C, 332nd Field Artillery Battalion in the 86th Infantry Division. He is survived by his wife, J. Rexene A. Ornauer, of Dover, DE. They were married on November 24, 1985, at Glen Cove, NY. His parents, Edwin L. and Emma H. Ornauer of Floral Park, NY, and Merrick, NY, died at 95 years of age and 104, respectively. He was the father of three children, David S. of Okinawa, Michael J. of Long Beach, NY, and SaraJo of Merrick, NY; five stepchildren, T. Philip Ashford III of Lake Worth, FL; Mary Collier of Encinitas, CA; Ann Menor of Lake Worth, FL, William R. Ashford of Cherry Valley, NY; and Jean Berrios of West Palm Beach, FL; four grandchildren from Okinawa, and one great-granddaughter on Long Island, NY; 15 step-grandchildren in Florida and upstate New York; and two step great-grandchildren. Born October 19, 1922, in Brooklyn, NY, he was raised on Long Island, NY, residing in Floral Park and Merrick, before moving to Newtonville, NY, and Dover, DE. Interment was in Mt. Ararat at Babylon, NY, following graveside services. A scholarship in his memory has been established at the Long Island High School for the Arts in Syosset, New York. Donations may be sent to Teresa Scaturro at Nassau Boces, 71 Clinton Rd, Garden City, New York, 11530. Also, contributions in his memory may be sent to Compassionate Care Hospice, 702 B Kirkwood Highway, Wilmington, Delaware, 19805.

LISTEN, it's not personal. I'm totally fine with you running a combo boot camp-yoga class in the park around the corner from my house. Not that I'm tempted to join the class. The idea of someone yelling, ''Crawl faster,'' while I scramble on all fours through grass that I know for a fact gets fertilized hourly by a gaggle of obese geese, holds zero appeal. But maybe that's just me. The problem is that you bring your dog to your class and you let him run off-leash. That would still be O.K., except that when I ask you to please leash your dog because if you don't my leashed dog will yank so hard he will dislocate my shoulder, you ignore me.

FELSHER--Elaine, nee Vejans, passed away peacefully at home on June 16th after a valiant battle with cancer. She was born in Texas in 1926, and after graduating the University of Texas came to New York at the age of twenty. A beautiful woman with a lovely singing voice Elaine performed in many local church choirs. In 1950 she married Howard Felsher, a successful TV producer. They had one child, Andrew in 1958. Elaine was an archivist for many years at Time Inc., then accompanied her husband to California in the early l970's. Divorced after returning to New York in l980, she rejoined Time Inc., and as chief archivist enjoyed an exceptional reputation for thoughtful, penetrating oral histories.She lived happily for 18 years with Ivin Mann, a respected accountant who also was president of Fountain House, and predeceased her, Elaine is survived by her ex-husband Howard, son Andrew, his loving wife Sharon, adoring grandchildren Cameron and Olivia, and wonderful step-grandchildren Justin, Janae and Julianne Moffet. Send contributions in her memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, NYC 10087 or to Fountain House Development Office, 425 W. 47 St., NYC,10036.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for June 13 to 19. 1. ALL EYES ARE ON TIGER WOODS, THE

Nick Taylor, a 21-year-old amateur from British Columbia, shot a five-under-par 65, tying the 18-hole record for an amateur at the United States Open. Taylor became the third amateur to shoot 65, and the first since 1971, when James Simons did it at Merion Golf Club. James McHale also shot a 65 in 1947 at St. Louis Country Club. Taylor hit every fairway but the 18th on Saturday and might have broken the record for amateurs with a little luck. His ball went into a bunker on the 15th hole to set up one of his two bogeys on the day. Although he missed the fairway on the 18th, he still made birdie, one of seven.

CORNELIUSEN--Clarence, May 28. South Setauket. Born Brooklyn 1920. Parents from Norway. Lived mostly in Queens, then Jefferson's Ferry CCRC with Dot Bennert. After WWII, wed Allie Eugenia Avery; daughter Rosie born 1950. With Allie, became a New York City high school English teacher. Beloved Allie died 2002. Intellectual and engaged, he was a mentor and collector of friends. Loved sailing and its arts. Carved bears and bunnies in wood. Entertained. Read widely. Knew everything, remembered everything. A leader in his co-op and at J. Ferry. Rosie and husband Doug Brooks, Doug's son Chris, beloved Dottie, brother John, pal Jean, nieces, nephews, friends survive. We miss him and miss his affection.

ROBERTS--Morris Slocum, age 64, of Garrison, NY, and Charleston, SC, died peacefully on June 19, 2009 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He grew up in Ligonier, PA, was graduated from St. George's School, Harvard College, Wharton Business School and Columbia Teachers College. After a career in finance he taught Global Studies at the New York City Public School Frederick Douglass Academy. He served as Treasurer of Planned Parenthood of New York City, a Treasurer of Darkness to Light in Charleston, SC, President of the Garrison's Landing Association and Garrison's Station Plaza, a Trustee of the Kornfeld Foundation, and a Trustee of the Hudson Valley Hospital. He was a loving brother to Toby, Robin and Henry Roberts, devoted husband to Katherine Osborn Roberts and wise father to Timothy and Alice and to Charleston, his chocolate lab. He will be remembered for his mischievous sense of humor and fearless love of life right to the end. There will be a celebration of his life at 12pm on July 11th at St. Phillips Church in the Highlands in Garrison, NY. Donations may be made to the Hudson Valley Hospital, attn: Bill Dauster.

As the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus settles into its 2,300- seat tent on the Boardwalk in Coney Island for a 12-week run, the 110-member cast and crew, hailing from 16 countries, must make a temporary home amid the surviving amusements and the abandoned lots of razed history. The show is called Coney Island Boom a Ring, with most tickets $10 to $25. During Thursday's opening, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg likened the Big Top to the State Senate in Albany. VASILY TRIFONOV, 30 Clown, since 1994 FOOD MOST MISSED ON THE ROAD Pelmeni, Russian dumplings. WEIRDEST CIRCUS AUDIENCES In Japan, because they smile and laugh but make no sound. TREASURED GETAWAY His apartment in Kaluga, Russia. ''It's so good: near Coney Island there are Russian stores, Russian restaurants, I can speak Russian. Everything is Russian. But they are living in the past here. They are still living in the Soviet Union. It feels like it did back in 1989. In Brighton Beach, I could be a star here -- but I am a clown.''

BRICKMAN--Newton, 'I grow old, I grow old, I shall wear the bottom of my trousers rolled, These promised words have arrived in my life, Strangely comforting, despite the absence of my wife, Whose torturing pain was finally stilled, At the cost of her life, that was never willed, For near sixty years, we aged and we strove, To accept parenting and its multiple drove, Of Do's and Don'ts that encompass a wave of choice, That bodes good or ill, to Fail or Rejoice, When time and reality combine and take charge, The end game becomes a fleet of mixed barges. He is survived by his loving niece Jill, her husband Richard and their daughter Leeza. Born to Max and Gladys Brickman in Philadelphia. He is predeceased by his dear Lillian, brothers Irv and Ben and sister Dorothy. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Newt's name to the Braille Institute of America, 741 North Vermont Ave, Los Angeles, CA, 90029.

DAVISON--John S.,76, died June 16 in Morlaix, France. BA Harvard 1955; MA Univ. of Oxford 1957; LLB Harvard 1961. U.S. State Department, 36 years. Ambassador to Niger 1993-1996. TURNER--Louis B.,MD, FACP, died at age 88, on Thursday, June 11, 2009, in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife, Tanya K. Turner; his loving children: Jon, Kathi and Bob Turner; Ellen Bornstein, Roger Dubin and Barbara Dubin; his loving grandchildren: Jake Turner, Erin Dubin Ward and Jaid Dubin, Gregory and Jessica Goldner and Tannis Vallely. A graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, he was a devoted internist for 48 years in Roslyn, NY, who practiced at North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Hospital. A specialist in hypertension, he performed some of the initial research on multiple myeloma and peritoneal lavage. He was a Captain in the US Army during WWII and the Korean conflict. Lou leaves behind many loving friends and grateful patients. We are all better for having known him; he was a man filled with heart, who never lost his sense of humor. A memorial service will be held in Palm Beach Gardens, FL at a later date, to be announced.

GOLD--David. The Center for Jazz Studies at Columbia University mourns the passing of David Gold, the distinguished president emeritus and founder of the Louis Armstrong Educational Foundation. Thanks to Mr. Gold's dedication and stewardship, Armstrong's iconic stature remains firm. Our deepest condolences go to the Gold family, and to his many friends.

THE NEWS Regulators warned consumers to stop using Zicam, a popular cold remedy, because it could damage or destroy the sense of smell. BEHIND THE NEWS The Food and Drug Administration said it had received 130 reports of people losing the sense of smell after using one of Zicam's nasal products. The reports date to 1999, when Matrixx Initiatives first brought the product to market. The agency took no action under President Bush; the new warning suggests that the Obama administration may act more aggressively against drug makers. Matrixx agreed to stop shipping the products but said it ''stands behind the science of its products.''

Lately, when that H or E flashes on the scoreboard, signifying a hit or an error on a questionable play, fans are often left scratching their heads. On June 10, Carlos Beltran of the Mets hustled back to the right-center-field wall and seemingly had a fly ball lined up -- until he inexplicably jumped for the ball and it glanced off his glove. It was ruled a hit. The same night, the Yankees' Nick Swisher moved toward the right-field line, came to a jog and simply missed the ball -- another hit. Then last week, Aubrey Huff, the Orioles' first baseman, sprinted some 30 yards down the right-field line, attempted an over-the-shoulder catch of a pop-up, but dropped the ball. That was ruled an error.

If your dream vacation involves staying in a medieval Tuscan village with modern amenities, Castel Monastero (www.castelmonastero.com) might be of interest. Opening on July 1, the resort, built within 13 stone buildings that surround a main piazza (all established in 1050) has stayed true to the village's original architecture. But there are also some decidedly nonmedieval touches like a gelateria and a spa. The 10,000 square foot spa -- the only part of Castel Monastero that was not originally part of the village -- breaks from the resort's traditional style with a sleeker modern look. It has 10 treatment rooms, a tea room and three outdoor pools.

McCAFFREY--William Thomas of Long Beach, NY and Palm Beach Gardens, FL. died June 18th, 2009, at his Long Beach home with his wife Mary by his side. Bill had endured a long illness with ALS-Lou Gherigs Disease. Bill was born in Washington Heights on July 7, 1936. He attended Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Parish School and Cardinal Hayes High School before joining The Equitable Life Assurance Society in 1954 as a clerk. While working full time and supporting his young family, he graduated from NYU and earned a masters degree in Business through the executive degree program at Columbia University. Through his dedication and perseverance he held over twenty-six positions at The Equitable before retiring in 1999 due to his illness as Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of AXA/Equitable. Bill met his wife Mary, at The Equitable and they have been married for forty-nine years. They raised their family together in Rego Park, NY. He is dearly loved by his family and is survived by wife Mary, three children Ann Nicoletti (John), William E. McCaffrey, and Christine Lodato (Joseph), his grandchildren Danielle, Gianna, Samantha, Kian, and by his brothers Daniel, John (Martha) and Joseph, and sister-in-law Dolores. His family is very proud of his many accomplishments, his vast generosity, and unwavering compassion for those in need. He was a great advocate in assisting his community and organizations of many realms. As Chairman Emeritus at Xavier University of Louisiana, he chaired the development committee where he raised over $50 million dollars towards the expansion of the campus. He has personally sponsored the education of over thirty students at Our lady Queen of Martyrs where he attended grammar school. He also worked closely with the Inner City Scholarship Fund, Deafness Research Foundation, Bronx Lebanon Hospital, and Marymount Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Our Lady Queen of Martyrs School, 71 Arden Street, New York City, NY 10040 or Xavier University, Drexel Road, New Orleans, LA. Reposing Macken Mortuary Island Park Chapel Sunday, June 21 and Monday, June 22, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Church on Tuesday, June 23 at 10:30am. Interment All Faiths Cemetery, Middle Village, NY. mackenmortuary.com

KEN THOMPSON says that one second his right thumb was fine, and then it was almost torn off. The reason was that the driver's-side air bag deployed. Dr. Thompson, a psychiatrist from Pittsburgh, was honking the horn of his 2006 BMW 325xi to warn a vehicle that had pulled in front of him. The cars collided, and Dr. Thompson's air bag deployed from the minor impact. The other car drove off. Then Dr. Thompson looked at his thumb.

SACHTJEN--Wilbur Manley. Age 81, died Thursday June 11, 2009 at his home in Vero Beach. He was born October 23, 1927 in Madison, Wisconsin. A graduate of Madison East High School, he served in the U.S. Army, after which he received a B.S. degree from the University of Wisconsin. He has an MBA from the Harvard Business School, where he was a Baker Scholar. Wil's early career was in finance, first with the Harris Trust of Chicago and later with Morgan, Stanley & Co., New York investment bankers. He then spent seven years in the New York office of McKinsey & Company, international management consultants. Following that, he later joined Pfizer, Inc., where he was a Vice President in the international headquarters. In 1972, Wil entered executive recruiting, initially as a partner in a New York City firm, after which he established his own firm in 1976. He retired from executive recruiting in 2000. In Bronxville, New York, where he lived before coming to Vero Beach, he was active in community affairs. These included service as Board President of the Lawrence Hospital in 1975 and 1976, and as a Board Member for thirteen years. He was a member of the Bronxville Field Club and Siwanoy Country Club. In Vero Beach, Wil has been an officer and Board member of the Indian River Land Trust and of Mckee Botanical Garden. He is a member of the Vero Beach Country Club, the Moorings Club, and the Harvard Club of New York City. He married the late Nancy O'Neill of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts in 1956. He is survived by four sons (Barry of Arnold, Maryland; Brendan of Bronxville, New York; Jeffrey of Norwalk, Connecticut; and Todd of Atlanta, Georgia) and four grandchildren. His brother, Dr. Kenneth Sachtjen of Madison, Wisconsin, died in 1987. There will be no visitation and the funeral services will be private. Interment will be in Madison, Wisconsin. Memorial contributions may be made to McKee Botanical Garden, 350 U.S. Highway 1, Vero Beach, FL 32962.

BAER--Dr. George Martin, died on June 2, 2009, in Mexico City, Mexico at the age of 73. Dr. Baer was an eminent scientist, veterinarian and public health specialist. He was responsible for developing the oral vaccine for rabies that led to the eradication of wildlife rabies in Europe. At the time of his death he was working on a new vaccine against numerous strains of the influenza virus, a project that he was especially eager to complete given the recent worldwide outbreak of the H1N1 virus. Throughout his professional career, Dr. Baer acted from a deeply held belief in the power of preventive medicine and the desire to combat disease both in animals and in humans. Dr. Baer was born on January 12, 1936, in London, England. He was the only son of Kathi Meyer Baer, of Berlin, and Curtis Otto Baer, of Strassburg, Germany. His mother was a renowned musicologist and the first woman to be awarded a doctoral degree in musicology in Leipzig, Germany in the 1920s. His father was a student of Heidegger, a professor of art history at Vassar College and a noted collector of 18th and 19th century master drawings and paintings. Dr. Baer's parents fled Nazi Germany for Paris, France, and then emigrated to the United States in 1940. He grew up in New Rochelle, New York, where he became a competitive horseman and thus began his lifelong love of animals. To his parents' surprise, he did not follow a career in the arts, but instead chose the sciences. After graduating from the Westtown School in Westtown, Pennsylvania, in 1952, he attended Cornell University, where he earned an undergraduate degree in agricultural sciences in 1954 and a degree in veterinary medicine in 1959. He earned a master's degree in Public Health from the University of Michigan in 1960. Dr. Baer began his career in public health by joining the New York Public Health Service, where he learned the practice of epidemiology and virology. In 1968 he entered the U.S. Public Health Service and, thanks to Dr. James H. Steele, his friend and mentor, started a long and successful career at the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Atlanta, Georgia. There, he became head of the Rabies Laboratory and with his team of scientists and researchers developed the oral vaccine for wildlife rabies. His expertise in the virology of rabies and his role in developing the oral vaccine against wildlife rabies made him one of the foremost international experts in this area. His book, The Natural History of Rabies, is a definitive reference in the field. On his father's suggestion, in 1959 Dr. Baer traveled to Mexico. There, he met and fell in love with his wife, Maria Olga Lara, and with the country, its people, history, culture and traditions. From 1966 to 1968 he was sent by the CDC to work with the Mexican Public Health Service in Palo Alto, Mexico. Based on his training and working closely with a group of young Mexican scientists and veterinarians, he helped lay the groundwork for Mexico's public health programs against rabies. In addition to his native English and German, Dr. Baer was a fluent Spanish speaker, and loved languages, literature, art and music. He was also an avid mountaineer. Dr. Baer is survived by his wife of 49 years, Maria Olga Baer, three daughters, Katherine Baer, economist, of Washington, D.C., Alexandra Baer, sculptor and artist, of New Paltz, New York, and Isabella Baer, an opera singer, of Mexico City, and four granddaughters. Funeral services were held in Mexico City at the Iglesia de Santa Rosa de Lima on June 4, 2009.

VanDERMEIR--Carol Born November 20, 1927, died June 7, 2009. Struck suddenly by Adenocarcinoma, she courageously battled the disease on her own terms in her own home. She was a woman of many talents: actress, painter, watercolorist, sculptor, teacher, and psychic. Graduate of Washington Irving High School, student at the Arts Students League, studied with Lee Strausberg, and received her B.A., magna cum laude, from NYU. After success as an actress in Street Car Named Desire, Ice Man Cometh, Trojan Woman, and Restoration Comedies, she returned to undergraduate school at age 35, had solo art shows and built a reputation as a fine artist. Her work is included in books about sculpture in light and plastic. She taught art at Ethical Culture School in Manhattan. A student of TM, she studied with Marharishi Mahesh Yogi. Her gift of clairvoyance led her to help many to read their pasts as a tool to light their present dilemmas. She deeply touched many lives. All who met her felt her luminescence. She is survived by her son, Marc Vandermeer, her daughter-in-law Leslie Vandermeer, two grandchildren, Sarah and Miles, a sister Ruth Kaplan, and lifelong friend Richard Fabrizio. She will be deeply missed by her family and many friends. Services Thursday, June 25, 6pm at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

CONTEMPLATING THE LIFE AQUATIC, BERRY SPRINGS, AUSTRALIA, JAN. 15, 2009 Cheya Took, 13, from Ourimbah, on Australia's Central Coast, gazes at Graham, a 60-year-old saltwater crocodile, at Territory Wildlife Park. ''My dad's sister lives in Darwin, near the park, and I've gone up there with my dad before. But this time I went by myself, so it was a chance to get away from the parents, tour around the country, have some fun and just relax. We just went to the park for the day. They had a lot of interesting animals there, and I took some great photos. Most of the park is wilderness, but the aquarium was like this underground area. There was this crocodile that had been there most of its time, doesn't get let out. The owner was explaining to us what they feed him, and I was just watching him. He looked kind of sad. I sat there thinking, 'Poor fella, I've been there.' Just being stuck in there most of your life, being fed, not being allowed to go into the wild and do what you want. He's probably happy, though. He got a lot of food.'' As told to Austin Considine

McMANUS--L. Brian McManus "B-Mac" a Delta Air Lines International Captain based at JFK passed away at his home in Westbrook Connecticut last Friday. Brian was born in Chicago the eldest child of Lois Meidinger McManus and Lee James McManus. Following high school Brian attended Boston College for one year before becoming a member of the Fighting Irish at Notre Dame where he played rugby. While at Notre Dame, he completed the Marine Corps Platoon Leaders Course, and upon graduating with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1981, was commissioned a Second Lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps. He reported to active duty at the Corp's Basic School in Quantico, Virginia before heading to Primary Flight Training at NAS Pensacola, Florida in January, 1982. Brian was subsequently selected for jet training, which he completed at NAS Kingsville, Texas. He pinned on his Naval Aviator wings on July 16, 1983. As a First Lieutenant, he reported to MCAS Yuma, Arizona, for qualification in the F-4 Phantom II with the VMFAT-101 "Sharpshooters". In August, 1984, as a fully qualified Marine Corps fighter pilot, he began his first fleet assignment with VMFA-312 at MCAS Beaufort, South Carolina. While assigned as the Logistics Officer for the "Checkerboards," Brian participated in an extensive Western Pacific deployment to Japan, Korea, Okinawa, and the Philippines. During the squadron's tour of the Western Pacific, Brian's hard work and dedication to our country were recognized when he was promoted to Captain.In March, 1986, Brian transferred to NAS Kingsville, Texas, to serve as a flight instructor in the T-2C Buckeye with the "Professionals" of VT-23. After proudly serving his country for several years, Brian began his career as a pilot for Delta Air Lines on February 20th 1987. During his career at Delta, Brian flew the B-727, L-1011, B-737 and the B757/767 as an International Captain. At Delta, Brian actively served his profession as a leader of the Air Line Pilots Association International. He was elected to two terms as a union representative while based in Miami and another two terms while based in New York. Brian also served as the chairman of the union's Membership Committee and most recently as the chairman of the Stock Advisory Committee. Brian is survived by his mother Lois, brother Curtis, two children, Devin 16 and Kerry 14 and his former wife, and lifelong friend, Selma McManus. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on today June 4, 2009 at 10am in St. John's Church Main Street Old Saybrook. Please visit www.mem.com to leave an online condolence or tribute. The Swan Funeral Home 1224 Boston Post Road Old Saybrook has charge of the services.

The rain at the United States Open has been a pain in the neck for the golfers, particularly for Peter Hanson of Sweden. Between rounds he has been receiving chiropractic treatment for a neck injury. It has not hurt his scoring. Hanson reached the midway point tied for fourth after rounds of 66 and 71. He could become the first European golfer to win the Open since Tony Jacklin of England in 1970. Hanson would seem an unlikely golfer to end the drought. In two previous Opens, his best finish was a tie for 30th. This is his third PGA Tour start this year.

In her memory please donate to your local food bank.

It was only a matter of time before Triumph the Insult Comic Dog showed up on Conan O’Brien‘s “Tonight Show.” On Friday night, the trash-talking, cigar-chomping hand puppet voiced and operated by Robert Smigel, made his inaugural appearance on Mr. O’Brien’s new(ish) program, in a two-part report filed from the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival. Though Mr. Smigel’s voice sounds ragged in places, it’s another instantly memorable performance from his canine alter ego. Watch for cameo appearances from TV on the Radio, some scathing jokes at the expense of the Decemberists and Black Eyed Peas, and some concertgoers you can practically smell through your computer monitor.

After offering a refund to fans who attended a recent concert beset by technical problems, the British rock band Oasis has criticized those who asked for their money back, The Guardian reported. On June 4, the band played its first hometown show in nearly four years at Heaton Park in Manchester, drawing about 70,000 fans to a show that had to be stopped for about a half hour after power to the stage was cut twice. At the concert, Noel Gallagher, the band’s lead guitarist, told the audience, “Anybody who has kept their ticket will get a full refund.” (This could have cost $4.8 million if everyone in attendance accepted the offer.) But on his blog, Mr. Gallagher wrote that he now regrets offering the refund, and added that he was surprised that the 20,000 fans who asked for their money back didn’t walk out of the concert. “So you were genuinely disappointed?” Mr. Gallagher wrote. “There wasn’t a 20,000 gap in the crowd.”

LONDON — I suppose you’re dying to know what the well-dressed Danish royal is wearing this year. Having just seen the hit revival of “Hamlet,” starring Jude Law, at Wyndham’s Theater, I can pronounce with authority that black is bigger than ever. Now, you would expect Hamlet (Mr. Law) to wear black; he’s famous for it.

It wouldn’t be Death Row Records if it didn’t keep coming back to life. Billboard reported that Death Row, the troubled hip-hop label founded by Dr. Dre and Marion (Suge) Knight in the early 1990s, would resume operations as a joint venture between the music publisher EverGreen and WIDEawake, a Toronto-based entertainment company. In January, WIDEawake purchased the assets of Death Row, which in its heyday released hit records from Snoop Dogg and Tupac Shakur, and whose assets included unreleased albums by artists including Warren G and Lisa (Left Eye) Lopes. Under the terms of the deal, EverGreen would handle licensing for the Death Row catalog. The companies plan to create remixes of popular Death Row songs for use in video game soundtracks, and to release a new album of material by Mr. Shakur, who was killed in 1996, to commemorate the rapper’s birthday in June 2010.

Fifteen drawings by Salvador Dali that have not been previously shown will make their debut as part of an exhibition on Dali’s work that will open on Saturday at the Anderson Gallery at the University at Buffalo/State University of New York, the Web site artdaily.org reported. The drawings were made by Dali for Dr. Edmund Klein, a researcher at the university’s School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences who treated the artist for skin cancer beginning in 1972. Paul Chimera, a spokesman for the Klein family, told artdaily.org that Dali, who died in 1989, had paid for his treatments by creating the sketches on blank pages, sketchpads, a photography catalog and the back of a paper written by Dr. Klein, who died in 1999. “The drawings were sequestered for more than 30 years in a bank vault in downtown Buffalo,” Mr. Chimera said, according to artdaily.org.

The latest development in the controversies over Bruce Springsteen tickets is a 1,100-word posting on Mr. Springsteen’s Web site in which his longtime manager, Jon Landau, defends the ticket practices for a concert on May 21 at the 19,000-seat Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J.

Just when we were starting to remember Patti LuPone as a luminescent if detail-oriented theater star — and not, say, the sort of person who brings an entire show to a halt when she catches an audience member snapping photographs of her — she goes and does it again.The Las Vegas Sun reports that Ms. LuPone, the two-time Tony Award winner, stopped in midperformance on Sunday night at the Orleans hotel when she saw an audience member using an electronic device.

An appellate court has reversed a lower court decision that had exonerated Simon & Schuster of breaking federal telecommunications law when it sent cell phone text messages to promote Stephen King’s novel “Cell” three years ago.

Updated | 6:22 p.m. The R&B singer Chris Brown pleaded guilty in a Los Angeles court on Monday to one count of felony assault on the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Mark Geragos, a lawyer for Mr. Brown, said that under the terms of the plea deal, Mr. Brown would receive five years of supervised probation and six months of community labor. Mr. Brown would be allowed to complete his community service in his home state of Virginia but would have to return to California for updates every three months.

Even before the excruciatingly-boring-save-for-the-last-few-minutes episode of “Jon & Kate Plus 8″ was over tonight, People.com was announcing the obvious: that Jon and Kate Gosselin had initiated legal proceedings (on Monday) to end their marriage after tabloids have arguably earned most of their revenue in recent weeks speculating about the couple’s affairs. This news of impending divorce was of course the subject of the big announcement we’d be hearing about in promos for the hour (titled “Houses & Big Changes,” “houses” being a reference to the outdoor play houses Jon and Kate bought the twins and sextuplets presumably as a guilt alleviator.)

Rain has threatened to shipwreck “Twelfth Night” since it started performances June 10 at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, but, miraculously, the show has always gone on, albeit damply, or late, or with a break in the action until storm clouds blew over.

Until recently, it wouldn't have occurred to me that gardening would be a popular pastime for the totalitarian set. But a droll little footnote in a recent biography of Josef Vissarionovich Djugashvili -- you can call him Stalin -- set me straight. Or perhaps I should say, it reeducated me.

The Confederations Cup in South Africa has delivered some compelling soccer from overseas, brought to audiences in the United States via ESPN. But this summer, an ambitious slate of soccer games in North America will allow fans to see Major League Soccer teams and some of the world's top international clubs, and take it in live.

For the first half of this year, more people have been killed in South Sudan than in Darfur, Enough Project notes in an excellent new report. It's another reminder that the focus has to be on "Save Sudan" rather than just "Save Darfur."

Surprising almost nobody, the husband and wife stars of TLC's "Jon & Kate Plus 8" announced on Monday that they were separating, marking a dramatic change in the couple's televised lives -- and for one of the most popular programs on cable TV.

I've never thought of Caleb Madison as an Angry Young Man, but stay clear of him today. This Tuesday puzzle has him exploding in full-force fury. Or, at least, he's come up with an amusing theme. For those of you keeping score at home, this is Mr. Madison's first pangram.

Last week I participated in a discussion of judging under the auspices of the Brennan Center for Justice. The event was held at the New York University School of Law, where an invited audience of about 80 interacted with three panelists - John Payton, head of the NAACP's Legal Defense Fund, Burt Neuborne, professor of law at NYU and me. We were held in check by moderator Dahlia Lithwick of Slate.com and Newsweek.

Starting with a few dozen supporters, including health bloggers, individual physicians, startups and Microsoft, a group is seeking to firmly inject the rights of patients into the Obama administration's multibillion-dollar drive to computerize medical records.

The head of domestic debt investing at Harvard University will leave the Ivy League school's multibillion-dollar endowment at the end of the month, a Harvard official said Monday.
End of an era in the old film business today. Kodak announced that it was retiring its oldest film stock, Kodachrome.

If the point of a good movie promotion is to leave 'em wanting more, Fox Searchlight has done its job. The publicity-savvy studio that made an Oscar winner of "Slumdog Millionaire" has been drumming up business for its romantic comedy "(500) Days of Summer," with Zooey Deschanel, by giving away 500 free treats at a time, often flagged by Twitter tweets, at locations around Los Angeles, New York, Washington and elsewhere.

OMAHA - In the weeks since Texas Coach Augie Garrido let closer Austin Wood throw 169 pitches over 13 innings in a 3-2 regional victory over Boston College, Garrido has heard howls of criticism from over-the-air pundits, bloggers and other college baseball followers for risking Wood's arm and future pro career.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will travel to Ukraine and Georgia after President Obama visits Moscow next month in a trip designed to reassure Russia's embattled neighbors that the new administration will not abandon them as it seeks to improve ties with the Kremlin.

The sale of the Montreal Canadiens hockey team to the Molson family of Canada for an estimated $550 million could be just what Cablevision Systems needs as it explores a spinoff of its Madison Square Garden division.

Among tennis coaches and fans, a debate has been simmering about the hesitancy of men's pro players today to attack the net. Few players look to come in on a short ball, preferring instead to rip a ground-stroke winner. Serving and volleying is rare, even on the grass at Wimbledon, which now plays slower than in the past.

Manager Jerry Manuel has maintained all along that the Mets could stay afloat as long as two of their four players were healthy. Only one, David Wright, is left now that Carlos Beltran was placed on the disabled list Monday with a bone bruise in his right knee.

As advocates for gays and lesbians intensify their criticism of the White House, President Obama has invited some of their leaders to an East Room reception next Monday to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Stonewall Rebellion, the 1969 Greenwich Village demonstrations that gave birth to the modern gay rights movement.

MILAN -- The word "colonial" is being bandied about here, with quite a few designers taking inspiration from the khakis, collarless shirts and tunics that are emblematic of that era.Aquascutum's collection presented in still life form, along with a preview of a great new campaign shot by Tim Walker, showed delicately tailored jackets and lightweight coats along with boldly printed nylon outerwear pieces in the style of Indian batik prints. The label's designer, Graeme Fidler, also lifted a smart trench from the archives of 1957 with some tweaks to proportion and fabric. The result underscored why this house is ready for a Burberry-like renaissance.

Nomenus Quarterly, a limited-edition folio of original or previously unpublished images, typically costs more than your average It bag. (Each issue differs in price, but the rate, until now, was around $2,500.) So, given the current economic climate, it's a little cheeky that Erik Madigan Heck, the publication's founder and editor in chief, has slashed the print run to 10 copies from 50 and raised the price to $6,500. For the cost of an entry-level Birkin, the new, seventh issue includes work by the artists Anselm Kiefer and Lucian Freud, the photographers Adam Fuss and Roger Bollan, and a tribute to Ann Demeulemeester men's wear (above) - shot, by Heck, in the style of the Italian photographer Mario Giacomelli's studies of young priests. Bless.

Formula One: Having won six of the first seven races of the season, Jenson Button came into the British Grand Prix with the best odds in his career of winning his home race. But after a poor showing in qualifying on Saturday, Button never factored in the battle up front on Sunday. In fact, no one did. Sebastian Vettel made the most of his pole position, by gaining a second a lap for the first 20 laps. And by the time he pitted on lap 21, he had stretched out a 20-second lead on his Red Bull teammate, Mark Webber. Vettel carried that momentum to the finish, and Webber was second. Brawn GP did manage third place, but it was Rubens Barrichello, not Button, on the podium. Button finished sixth in what was the final British Grand Prix at Silverstone Circuit. The race is planned for Donnington Circuit from 2010.

Attention armchair curators and otherwise opinionated people: Today, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum inaugurates the Guggenheim Forum, a series of moderated online discussions. Each forum, which is pegged to one of the museum's exhibitions, is two weeks long and includes live chat sessions with experts in various fields, while also giving visitors the opportunity to submit comments, some of which will be selected for posting.The inaugural forum, "Between the Over- and Underdesigned," coincides with the museum's exhibition "Frank Lloyd Wright: From Within Outward," and addresses architecture's social and environmental value in the context of Wright's work and philosophy. Aric Chen, a writer and curator who is a frequent Times contributor, is moderating this forum and will lead a live chat session on June 25th at 11 a.m. EDT. Panelists include Sarah Herda, the executive director of the Graham Foundation for Advanced Studies in Chicago; Arjo Klamer, a professor of the economics of art and culture at Erasmus University in Rotterdam; and Ellen Lupton, the curator of contemporary design at the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum.

Today's idea: American universities had amicable ties with Nazi Germany in the 1930s -- a record of indifference, complicity and collaboration leading into World War II that stemmed from institutional anti-Semitism, an author says. History | In an interview with Inside Higher Ed, Stephen H. Norwood, author of "The Third Reich in the Ivory Tower," summarizes what he calls American colleges' "very shameful record of complicity and indifference to atrocities committed against the Jews from 1933 onward -- and actually a lot of collaboration, in terms of participating in well-organized student exchange programs, participating in well-orchestrated Nazi festivals in Germany, sending delegates to those and ignoring protests" back home.

Many of Jim Hollander's pictures of the running of the bulls in Pamplona look like frames from a modern dance performance. They show bodies flying, limbs flung outward, doubled-over torsos in a row. The shots from the bullfighting ring show something altogether different: tableaux of still lifes, blocks of color, mannequin-like rows of picadors and matadors in filigreed costumes.

''Here With Me'' (Mercury) Last week Holly Williams's father, Hank Williams Jr., continued to grapple with long-cast shadows by releasing ''127 Rose Avenue,'' an album named for the childhood address of his father, the country pioneer Hank Williams. That same day Ms. Williams released her second album, ''Here With Me,'' on which she sings, ''Some days I wanna run from the place I call home/I guess I'm just needing some danger.''

The best-seller list at Barnes & Noble is dominated by books for younger readers, especially those by Stephenie Meyer, above, the author of the Twilight vampire series. ''Eclipse,'' ''New Moon'' and ''Breaking Dawn'' are in the top 10 for the year to date as well -- in the Nos. 1, 2 and 3 spots, respectively. New books by popular authors do well. ''My Sister's Keeper'' and ''The Scarecrow,'' for example, were released in May. Then, there is the perennial springtime best seller, ''Oh, the Places You'll Go!,'' destined as a gift for graduates from pre-K to postdoctoral programs. SHELLY FREIERMAN

ROBINS--Lawrence, died on June 21, 2009 at age 92. After graduating NYU, Larry held positions in numerous fields until appeasing his entrepreneurial itch by first founding Reid and Reid and then co-founding Crazy Horse sportswear in 1962. Crazy Horse became a fashion trendsetter in the 1960s and was one of the first branded alternatives of women's apparel. Ultimately being awarded a Coty Award, it was subsequently sold to Russ Togs, a large, NYSE-traded apparel manufacturer. Upon retiring from Crazy Horse, Larry became involved in numerous activities as was his nature. He hosted numerous seminars for Parsons and the Fashion Institute of Technology (FIT) and was extremely active in counseling burgeoning entrepreneurs through donating generously of his time to SCORE, a retired executives counseling service. He was a devout husband, leaving his wife of 65 years, Diana; a devoted father to three sons, Douglas, Peter, and the late David; a caring brother to James Robbins, and grandfather to Sophie, Noah, Daniel and Marc. Funeral service today, 10am, Jewish Community Center of Harrison, 130 Union Ave., Harrison, NY, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. For more information, Zion Memorial Chapel. 914-381-1809.

GINUWINE ''A Man's Thoughts'' (Notifi/Asylum/Warner Brothers) It's been 13 years since the singer Elgin Lumpkin, known as Ginuwine, made his slow-bumping, lubricious first single, ''Pony.'' That's the same time span in Marvin Gaye's career from the song ''Ain't That Peculiar,'' in which he felt invincible in love, to the album ''Here, My Dear,'' in which he felt victimized by it.

FORTUNE--William D. (Bill), age 52, of Croton-on-Hudson, NY, died peacefully on June 19, 2009 at his home with Charlie Scatamacchia, his life partner of 20 years, at his side. Bill was born in Dorchester, MA, graduated from the Massachusetts College of Art and was the founder of Fortune Designs, a Manhattan-based graphic design studio. He will be remembered for his sense of style, his love of cooking and travel, his fearlessness, and most especially for his garden from which he drew unending strength in his long and courageous battle with cancer. Donations may be made to Hospice Care in Westchester & Putnam: www.vnahv.org

PayPal has learned that the Internet actually reduces risk. People leave a long trail of digital bread crumbs online that, taken together, give a much better picture of a prospective customer than traditional merchants ever had. ''Good people on the Internet leave footprints,'' said Scott Thompson, above, president of PayPal, the online payment service owned by eBay. ''There are e-mail accounts, I.P. addresses, things that accumulate over time that you can find on the Internet if you rummage around.'' Someone who just made up an identity to commit a fraud won't have evidence lying about.

Xstrata, an exporter of coal used by power plants, on Sunday proposed a merger with Anglo American to gain access to iron ore mines and control of the world's biggest platinum producer. ''A merger of these two world-class companies with complementary assets is highly compelling'' and would provide ''enhanced scale and financial flexibility to fund future growth,'' Xstrata said in a statement.

ARLOW--Marlene, of North Shore Towers passed away June 20, 2009 surrounded by her family. She was the widow of NYPD Detective Clifford Arlow. She is also survived by her cherished grandchildren Amanda, Carline and Joey Czaja and her best friend, sister and confidant Linda Chipkin and her husband Ken.
