PATTERSON HOOD ''Murdering Oscar (and other love songs)'' (Ruth St.) Neil Young stirred up echoes of the Civil War with his condemnatory ''Southern Man'' in 1970, soon to be answered by Lynyrd Skynyrd's proud ''Sweet Home Alabama.'' Decades later Patterson Hood and the band he started in 1995, Drive-By Truckers, straddled a musical Mason-Dixon line by realizing what Mr. Young and Lynyrd Skynyrd shared: overdriven guitars and blunt, concise lyrics. Mr. Hood and the band have merged Mr. Young's frazzled high vocals and Crazy Horse's grungy trudge with a guitar twang, drawl and Southern perspective.

GINSBERG--Frances (nee Rossuck), died peacefully on June 19, 2009 at the age of 98 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Frances was born in 1910 in Bay Shore, NY. She was predeceased by her husband of 66 years, Dr. Victor Ginsberg, who died in 2006. Frances is survived by her loving children, Jane Brown and Richard Ginsberg; five adoring grandchildren, Daniel Brown, Matthew Brown, Rachel Newman, Stephen Ginsberg and Allison Schneiderman; and six great-grandchildren. Graveside service will be held at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York on June 25th at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation in Boca Raton, FL or the Multiple Sclerosis Society, Long Island Chapter.

CAPPELLI--John, distinguished foreign correspondent, WWII hero, and fighter for working people's rights, passed away in Poughkeepsie, New York on April 26, 2009 at 81. UN stalwart for over four decades, Life Member of the Foreign Press Association. Survived by wife Nives, children Vanni and Cybele, and many friends and admirers around the world.

ROBERTS--Kenneth, resident of Manhattan and Fire Island was born 99 years ago in New York City the only son of immigrant parents from Latvia and the Ukraine. He attended Dewitt Clinton High School and worked briefly in the office of the future mayor of New York City; Fiorello H. Laguardia as he considered pursuing a career as a lawyer. His real passion though was the theatre and he was blessed with a rich and mellifluent voice, along with an ability to communicate. After a brief stint as the lead in a Broadway play written by Garson Kanin he became an announcer for the Columbia Broadcasting System. He was a very succesful radio and television broadcaster and was the Master of Ceremonies for such programs as "Quick As A Flash", "It Pays To Be Ignorant", "The Shadow", and "Let's Pretend". As one of the founders of AFTRA and SAG he helped establish the rights of performers in the radio and television industries and held high elective office in both Unions. He was a longtime member of The Player's Club and was awarded the Gold Key by AFTRA for his devotion to its' cause for over fifty years. He is survived by his loving children from his marriage to Norma Finkelstein, Nancy and David along with his grandaughter Nicole Burley, and by his adoring wife Sydell and his stepchildren Donald, and Frederic and his stepgrandchildren Mattew, Evan, Jodie and Courtnay Salzberg. Services will be held Monday June 22 at 1pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

9 P.M. (History) THE CRUMBLING OF AMERICA The Romans had their roads and aqueducts; the Mayans, their pyramids and palaces. But what happens when a great civilization neglects its infrastructure? This two-hour report investigates the deterioration of highways, tunnels, dams, levees, ports and pipelines in the United States, including more than 70,000 bridges rated as structurally deficient and 25,000 miles of commercial waterways and locks that have exceeded their 50-year design life. One warning: the 2007 collapse of the Interstate 35W Bridge, above, in Minneapolis. One segment looks at structures on a ''worst of'' list. Another introduces technologies and detection techniques to prevent catastrophes. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Reba Toney talks about her book, ''The Rating Game: The Foolproof Formula for Finding Your Perfect Soul Mate''; also, the recession's effect on pets.

THE MARS VOLTA ''Octahedron'' (Warner Brothers) A few disarming moments on ''Octahedron'' unfold slowly, with pockets of space and calm. Don't be lured into trusting them. This album, the fifth studio release by the Mars Volta, employs stillness as a setup for all manner of disruption: sharply pealing riffs, phantasmagorical metaphors, convoluted song structures. In many ways it's a typical effort from the guitarist Omar Rodriguez-Lopez and the vocalist Cedric Bixler Zavala, who make up the Mars Volta's cunning and ever-agitated core.

LOVE--Dr. Shirley, Ph.D.,on Sunday June 21 at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was born on March 27, 1923 in Brooklyn to Rachel and Morris Greenstein. She completed her undergraduate degree at Brooklyn College, MSW from Columbia University, where she met her husband, Dr. Sidney Love, ABD at Yeshiva University School of Social Work, and Ph.D. from Heed University; she was also a certified physcoanalyst. She was a co-founder of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies in New York City and also co-founded and co-directed the Riverdale Seminars in Modern Psychoanalysis. Not only was Dr. Shirley Love a skilled and dedicated physcoanalyst, she made numerous contributions to her community, such as an active PTA member of Fieldston School, helped to found the Riverdale YM-YWHA, and contributed to UJA Federation. An extremely intelligent, empathic psychoanalyst, she will be sorely missed. She is survived by her two daughters Jeanine Dropkin and Carolyn Bersak, her son-in-law David, four grandchildren Jennifer (Brad, son Anders), Michael, Melissa and Rebecca. She is also survived by her sister Mildred Bierman, brother-in-law Manny, and their children, and her niece Audrey. She was pre-deceased by her husband, Dr. Sidney Love. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th on Wednesday, June 24, 11:15am. Reception and burial to follow.

FRUSTRATED FISHER Ross Fisher is from Surrey, England, so surely he has felt right at home in the dreary weather that has plagued this tournament. ''England's quite nice at the moment,'' he said. ''This is quite shocking.'' Fisher, a member of the European Tour, was tied for third going into the final round after carding a one-under 69 on Sunday, five strokes behind the leader Ricky Barnes. Not coincidentally, Fisher had taken 93 putts through the first three rounds -- five more than Barnes.

For weeks now, I have been struggling to find the right running shoe. I chose one for its pink swoosh, but it never felt right. I tried two other pairs but still struggled with blisters and foot pain. Then I finally checked out my local specialty running store, where the salesman (shout out to Matt at Princeton Running Co.) watched me walk, suggested a few different shoes and let me try them out on a treadmill. Sure enough, I found a shoe that felt great, and several runs later, my feet couldn’t be happier.

LONDON — “Where’s passion in the art? Where’s craft?” When Madame Armfeldt, a once celebrated courtesan, asks (or rather sings) these questions in Trevor Nunn’s new revival of Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s “A Little Night Music” at the Garrick Theater, she is talking about the vanishing arts and crafts of sexual seduction. But because this old professional beauty is played by Maureen Lipman, it’s tempting to extend her questions to Ms. Lipman’s own craft, that of acting, which she has practiced for over four decades.

Representatives of the governments of 49 countries as well as museums, Jewish groups and other organizations will meet in Prague this week for a five-day conference on the restitution of artwork stolen by Nazis, Reuters reported. The Holocaust Era Assets Conference, which begins Friday at the Museum of Decorative Arts, will among other goals assess the progress that has been made since a 1998 conference in Washington, after which 44 countries agreed to a nonbinding set of rules for the return of artwork looted during the Nazi era. The Nazis are believed to have plundered more than 650,000 piece of art and religious objects from Jews and other victims, but laws governing the restitution of these works can vary from country to country, and works by artists including Gustav Klimt and Egon Schiele have yet to be returned to their rightful owners or their heirs.

Barrett Wissman, a businessman who pleaded guilty to securities fraud in an investigation into corruption at the New York State pension fund, has stepped down as chairman of IMG Artists, one of the largest firms representing classical musicians, and has been replaced by Charles Hamlen. Mr. Wissman bought a controlling interest in IMG in 2003. The company, while declining to comment on his ownership, said on Tuesday that his interest remains unchanged.

Of all the things going the way of the Internet these days, one is the gallery exhibition announcement card. For decades this useful bit of art-world indicator has been an indispensable constant creatively deployed by artists, avidly cherished by the ephemera-obsessed and devotedly archived by museums. But lately the death knell has been sounding, each a linguistic (and attitudinal) variation on the same theme.

From her performance in “The Little Dog Laughed,” we know how Julie White takes to the role of a powerful Hollywood agent. (Answer: with relish.) So how will she handle being reduced to a less powerful — if equally imposing — stage manager? We will find out this fall in Roundabout Theater Company‘s production of “The Understudy,” in which Ms. White (“Twelfth Night”) will star, the theater company said in a news release. The play, written by Theresa Rebeck (“Our House,” “Mauritius”), is a comedy about theater performers and a backstage staff member with many frustrations to share. It will be directed by Scott Ellis, and is scheduled to begin previews at the Laura Pels Theatre at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater on Oct. 9. An official opening is planned for Nov. 5.

The original nachos, as described here, was undoubtedly not a bad thing. The contemporary nacho, as served in bars, Taco Bells, and "casual dining" restaurants throughout the country, is probably not quite of the same caliber. Neither, really, has much to do with this week's Minimalist column, a radically homemade version featuring not fried tortilla chips, ground beef, and orange cheese but toasted pitas, ground lamb, and a sauce of yogurt and feta -- with some other options. It will never sweep the country, but you might like it . . .

After looking at the relationship between atmospheres and life a few dozen light years away, a billion years or so in the future and three billion years or more in the past, it's time to look at the one in your lungs at the moment. Given that humans are changing the atmosphere at an unprecedented rate, what responses should we expect from the biosphere? And is there anything that we can do to make those responses work to human benefit?

Maplewood Township received a $10,000 grant from Sustainable Jersey, a certification program that helps municipalities control costs and enact green initiatives. The grant program is funded by Wal-Mart, which awarded four communities with $25,000 and 10 with $10,000. Maplewood's award will fund energy efficiency education programs to low-income households through the NJ Board of Public Utilities. "Wal-Mart recognizes the need for our towns and cities to focus on becoming more sustainable," said Jennifer Hoehn, senior manager of public affairs New Jersey for Wal-Mart, in the news release. "In these economic times, it is wonderful to be able to provide these municipalities with the opportunity to reach that goal for their communities." BOBBY ALLYN

Forget the rain: it's summer! That means it's time for summer reading, even if the beaches are wet, the flights are turbulent and the skies are gray. For the next month, National Public Radio is conducting a poll of the best beach books of all time; meanwhile, NPR's "All Things Considered" is also asking readers to name their "guilty pleasures" (for Kate Christensen, it's Janet Evanovich). But in summertime, no pleasure is guilty. My favorite beach read this year is probably Warren Fahy's "Fragment," an outlandish science thriller about an isolated South Pacific island whose ecosystem could destroy the world. This is purely mindless entertainment - the invisible Muppet-like creatures will tip you off if the stock characters haven't - but isn't that the point?

I thought the above quotation might be appropriate this week for a couple of reasons. First, it comes from a quarterly horticultural journal of the Pacific Northwest, and it's been feeling a lot like Seattle here lately. Second, it gets to the heart of what I love about hydrangea, those gorgeous, uncomplaining workhorses that are making their appearance right now in our yards. In fact, I think the only thing that's stopping me from ditching my Sloggers, my Claw, and the whole enterprise of gardening this soggy, depressing season is that the hydrangea are finally here.

Over at Newsweek, Sharon Begley has a fascinating essay that examines whether we have a rape gene. The argument has been made by evolutionary psychologists that rape could be an evolutionary adaptation. The idea is that a propensity to rape might be transmitted genetically, because someone who rapes who would be more likely to pass on his DNA than a nicer guy. Rapists, in short, have more children than non-rapists. But Begley looks at evidence from a Paraguayan tribe living a traditional existence and finds that in fact that is not the case. Any given rape is quite unlikely to result in offspring -- particularly offspring who survive -- while it often leads to the demise of the rapist.

Last week, a bit of Buenos Aires sprung up on a TriBeCa rooftop as members of The Society got a taste of the South American underground supper club Casa Felix. For the last three years, the chef Diego Felix and his fiancée, Sanra Ritten, have served pescetarian meals in their colorful home in Chacharita, where random groups of stylish foodies are seated every weekend for a (rare) steak-free evening that focuses on the indigenous ingredients that Felix sources throughout the continent. Casa Felix is so popular with American visitors, the couple was able to put together its second North American tour this summer, cooking meals in private homes in six cities through August.

Who says print is dead? Koji Suzuki, the Tokyo-based author of smash-hit horror novels like the "The Ring," has found a new publishing medium: toilet paper. Suzuki has teamed with Hayashi Paper Company, which makes novelty printed paper products for public restrooms, to manufacture rolls of toilet tissue stamped with a nine-chapter horror novella called "Drop." The story, about a goblin living in a public restroom, places the reader at the center of the tale, and each roll contains several copies of the novella so that you can easily pick up the narrative where you left off. (A friend of mine in Tokyo said it's so scary, she was frightened to be alone in the bathroom.) A roll of "Drop" costs 210 yen, which, at just over $2, is a fair price for disposable art.

Fifteen drawings by Salvador Dalí that have not been previously shown will make their debut as part of an exhibition on his work that will open on Saturday at the Anderson Gallery at the State University of New York at Buffalo, the Web site artdaily.org reported. The drawings were made by Dalí for Dr. Edmund Klein, a researcher at the university’s School of Medicine and Biomedical Sciences who treated him for skin cancer beginning in 1972. (Above, an example.) Paul Chimera, a spokesman for the Klein family, told artdaily.org that Dalí, who died in 1989, had paid for his treatments by creating the sketches on blank pages, pads, a photography catalog and the back of a document written by Dr. Klein, who died in 1999.
The Long Wharf Theater in New Haven has become the latest in a growing roster of cultural institutions to announce budget and staff cuts as it copes with the recession.

An appellate court has reversed a lower court decision that had exonerated Simon & Schuster of breaking federal telecommunications law when it sent cellphone text messages to promote the novel “Cell,” written by Stephen King, right, three years ago. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled on Friday that the United States District Court for the Northern District of California had erred in its ruling in Simon & Schuster’s favor in a class-action suit brought by Laci Satterfield, a woman who objected to receiving an ad for “Cell” as a text message. While the district court said that Simon & Schuster, whose imprint Scribner published “Cell,” had not employed a so-called automatic telephone dialing system to send the messages, the appellate court ruled it was not actually clear if an automatic dialing system was used. The court also ruled, contrary to the district court, that a text message could be defined as “a call” and disputed that Ms. Satterfield had consented to receive the message. Adam Rothberg, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, said the company would continue to defend the case.

It wouldn’t be Death Row Records if it didn’t keep coming back to life. Billboard reported that Death Row, the troubled hip-hop label founded by Dr. Dre and Suge Knight in the early 1990s, would resume operations as a joint venture between the music publisher EverGreen and WIDEawake, a Toronto entertainment company. In January WIDEawake purchased the assets of Death Row, which in its heyday released hit records from Snoop Dogg and Tupac Shakur, and whose assets included unreleased albums by artists including Warren G and Lisa (Left Eye) Lopes. Under the terms of the deal EverGreen would handle licensing for the Death Row catalog. The companies plan to create remixes of popular Death Row songs for use in videogame soundtracks, and to release a new album of material by Mr. Shakur, who was killed in 1996, to commemorate the rapper’s birthday in June 2010.

The latest development in the controversies over Bruce Springsteen tickets is a 1,100-word posting on Mr. Springsteen’s Web site (brucespringsteen.net) in which his longtime manager, Jon Landau, defends the ticket practices for a concert on May 21 at the 19,000-seat Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J. Last week The Star-Ledger of Newark, citing data obtained through New Jersey’s Open Public Records Act, reported that 12 percent of all tickets for the concert — including more than 90 percent of “the best seats in the house” — were withheld from public sale, and instead went to Mr. Springsteen, right, his record company and others. Mr. Landau acknowledged that “significant numbers of tickets” are held back for shows in New Jersey, New York and Los Angeles, but countered that of the 2,000 to 3,500 seats closest to the stage, “95 percent of them go to the public.” He also said that some of the held tickets went to the state attorney general, Anne Milgram, for fans who couldn’t get seats when tickets for the show went on sale on Feb. 6. Ticketmaster settled with New Jersey two weeks later over complaints that it had pointed online customers to its resale subsidiary, TicketsNow, where tickets were being offered well above face value.

After offering a refund to fans who attended a recent concert beset by technical problems, the British rock band Oasis has criticized those who asked for their money back, the British newspaper The Guardian reported. On June 4 the band played its first hometown show in nearly four years at Heaton Park in Manchester, drawing about 70,000 to a show that had to be stopped for about a half hour after power to the stage was cut twice. At the concert Noel Gallagher, the lead guitarist, told the audience, “Anybody who has kept their ticket will get a full refund.” (This could have cost $4.8 million if everyone in attendance accepted the offer.) But on his blog Mr. Gallagher wrote that he now regrets offering the refund and added that he was surprised that the 20,000 fans who asked for their money back didn’t walk out of the concert. “So you were genuinely disappointed?” Mr. Gallagher wrote. “There wasn’t a 20,000 gap in the crowd.”.

PERLINE--Brigitte (Metzger), died peacefully on June 20, 2009 after a remarkable and principled life at the age of 77. Beloved wife of Irving for 57 years; cherished mother of Amy, Carol and son-in-law Jesse; doting Baba to Caroline, Julia and Charles Schatten and Daniel, Andrew and Josh Feder; dear sister to Monica DiFilippi and the late Ernst Meyer; devoted friend to many. A memorial service is scheduled for Sunday, June 28 at 12 noon at the Hospice Atlanta Chapel. Gifts in her name may be made to Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Dr NE, Atlanta, GA 30319 or Amnesty International.

LeROY--G. Palmer. The Board and Staff of The Metropolitan Opera Guild mourn the death of our former Executive Director and good friend, G. Palmer LeRoy. From 1985 to 1994, Palmer led us with grace, humor and dignity, and was responsible for moving the Guild into its permanent home at Lincoln Center. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Kyra and their entire family. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr., Chairman Susan S. Braddock, President David A. Dik, Executive Director

As advocates for gays and lesbians intensify their criticism of the White House, President Obama has invited some of their leaders to an East Room reception next Monday to mark the 40th anniversary of the Stonewall Rebellion, the 1969 Greenwich Village demonstrations that gave birth to the modern gay rights movement. The White House has not officially announced the reception, which will also include gay families. But a spokesman, Shin Inouye, said Monday that the long-planned event was ''a chance for the White House to recognize the accomplishments'' of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Americans.

MAY--Edward B.,of Bronx, NY on June 21, 2009. Retired member NYC police department-23rd precinct and 19th precinct. Beloved son of the late Hugh and Mary F. May. Loving brother of Catherine P. and the late Mary C. Family will receive friends Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Williams Funeral Home Inc., 5628 Broadway at West 232nd St., Bronx. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Angels Church, Thursday, 10:30 am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

More than 70 of the malnourished horses discovered in April on the farm of Ernie Paragallo, a prominent New York thoroughbred owner and breeder, have been adopted by individuals and rescue groups. Paragallo, who faces 22 counts of animal cruelty over neglect of the horses on his Center Brook Farm, was scheduled to appear Monday night at a hearing on the charges in Coxsackie, N.Y. Each count carries a punishment of up to a year in prison and a $1,000 fine.

When it comes to using the left-hander Austin Wood, who started two seasons for Texas before becoming a closer as a senior, Longhorns Coach Augie Garrido goes against convention and often brings Wood in long before the ninth inning. That philosophy, and Garrido's trust in him, led to Wood's throwing 169 pitches in a 13-inning relief appearance in an N.C.A.A. regional game against Boston College last month.

STARR--Edward, a Garden City, NY resident for over 40 years, died peacefully on June 21, 2009 at his new home in Berkeley Heights, NJ. He was 82. He was executive vice president and director, of the public relations firm, Hill & Knowlton, NY. He supervised the PR/ affairs of many corporate and non-profit clients in the US and abroad. Ed joined H&K after eight years with NBC-TV, where he was manager of Publications and Communications. A graduate of St. John's University, NY, and a recipient of that school's Pietas Medal for alumni achievement, he was the author of the book, "What You Should Know About Public Relations," (Oceana Publications). From 1986 to 1988 he was a member of Hofstra University's School of Business faculty, teaching courses in public relations, advertising, international marketing and European business. Ed also served as an officer to the Army in the US and Europe in 1945-1946 and again in 1951-1952. He was a member of the Kiwanis Club of Garden City, a trustee of the Garden City Library and the Historical Society. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Grace Wall, two sons in Connecticut and New Jersey and four granddaughters. His son, Christopher Starr died in 2006. Funeral services will be held on June 24 at Fairchild Sons in Garden City from 7 to 9pm. Mass will be held on June 25 at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City at 10am.

ROSENSTEIN--Leo, died June 21, nearly 93. Father of Alan and Mark; grandfather of Josh, Alex, Aaron, and Peter; great-grandfather of Sadie. Husband of the late Dorothy, and companion of Norma Markell Weinstein. Funeral Tuesday, June 23 at 11:15am, Plaza Chapel, 630 Amsterdam, New York City.

ROSEN--Jack, died peacefully at home on June 22 at age 93. Beloved husband of the late Anne (Druz). Loving father of Marjorie Schneidman and the late Matthew Rosen, cherished father-in-law of Richard Schneidman and the late Barbara Salken. Devoted grandfather of Amy and Andrew Bloom, Lisa and Evan Licht and Billy Rosen. Proud great-grandfather of Sydney, Skylar, Harrison and Henry. We will lovingly remember our Papa Jack for his humor, for being our very own Mr. Fix-It and for his devotion to all of us. Contributions may be made to the Christopher and Dana Reeve Paralysis Foundation, 636 Morris Turnpike, Short Hills, NJ 07078. Funeral services at Beth El Synagogue, 1325 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10804.

GINSBERG--Frances (nee Rossuck), died peacefully on June 19, 2009 at the age of 98 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Frances was born in 1910 in Bay Shore, NY. She was predeceased by her husband of 66 years, Dr. Victor Ginsberg, who died in 2006. Frances is survived by her loving children, Jane Brown and Richard Ginsberg; five adoring grandchildren, Daniel Brown, Matthew Brown, Rachel Newman, Stephen Ginsberg and Allison Schneiderman; and six great-grandchildren. Graveside service will be held at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale, New York on June 25th at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation in Boca Raton, FL or the Multiple Sclerosis Society, Long Island Chapter.

KUPER--lluminada Landa, Nicknamed "Lumi", died on June 17, 2009 at 87. Mrs. Landa, mother of Joseph C. Landa and Maria Luisa Rego Landa, was born in Oriente, Cuba on November 29, 1921. Her family migrated to New York where she married Jose "Pepe" Landa in 1951. In 1953, combining their talents, the Landas' began a business producing fine home furnishings and custom window treatments for top architects and interior designers of their day. Now a third generation business, Interiors by JC Landa, LLC continues the tradition of excellence as her son's work can be found in the most important house in the world, the Presidential White House in Washington, DC. Lumi Landa is survived by Joseph C. Landa and Maria L. Rego Landa and six grandchildren: Rebeca, Jennifer, Adrianna, Joseph F., Alex and Daniel

ROBERTS--Kenneth. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and beloved fellow Player. His great life spanned the history of show business since the 1920s. He was a delightful companion and a cultured man with a wicked sense of humor. He will be greatly missed. Our love and sympathies go to the Roberts family. The Players

ROBBINS--Lawrence. Manhattan School of Music and its Board of Trustees are deeply saddened by the passing of Lawrence Robbins, beloved father of MSM's Chairman, Peter Robbins. One of the fashion industry's highly respected entrepreneurs, his vision is a source of inspiration to all he encountered. With heartfelt sorrow, we extend our condolences to the entire Robbins family. Robert Sirota, President

KOCH--Richard. The Board of Directors and the staff of The Film Society of Lincoln Center note with great sadness the passing of Richard Koch, husband of former Executive Director and longtime Board member Joanne Koch. Dick enthusiastically supported The Film Society and Lincoln Center, especially after his retirement as General Council and later Deputy Director of the Museum of Modern Art. Dick was dearly beloved by the Film Society staff, and will be remembered with fondness and affection. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman of the Board Daniel H. Stern, President of the Board Mara Manus, Executive Director Richard Pena, Director of Programming & Staff of The Film Society of Lincoln Center

GIULIANI--Francois. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Francois Giuliani, who steadfastly served the Met as its Press and Public Relations Director from 1996 to 2006. His great personal charm and gift for diplomacy made him a much valued and respected colleague. We extend our sincerest condolences to his friends and loved ones. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

8 P.M. (ABC) THE SUPERSTARS Eight athletes and eight celebrities team up at the Atlantis Resort in the Bahamas to undertake grueling challenges in this new show based on the classic ''Wide World of Sports'' series. The pairings are Terrell Owens of the Buffalo Bills and the model Joanna Krupa; the retired second baseman Jeff Kent and Ali Landry, the former Miss U.S.A. (above); the onetime N.B.A. player Robert Horry and the actress Estella Warren; the skier Bode Miller and Paige Hemmis of ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition''; the freestyle skier Kristi Leskinen and Maksim Chmerkovskiy of ''Dancing With the Stars''; Lisa Leslie of the Los Angeles Sparks and the actor Dan Cortese; the tennis player Jennifer Capriati and the singer and actor David Charvet; and the soccer player Brandi Chastain and the singer Julio Iglesias Jr. Events in this premiere episode include the ''Run and Ride,'' in which each team must run or cycle -- using only one bike -- a 1.1-mile course, and ''Kayak Rapids Relay,'' a boat race through the resort's artificial rapids. John Saunders is host, Warren Sapp is a correspondent, and Jenn Brown reports from the field. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWAbigail Breslin talks about her latest movie, ''My Sister's Keeper''; Bobby Flay prepares a meal.

(Dr. Alex Nacht), Michael Basch, Esq. (Ann Isaacs), and Nancy Schnee (Dr. Scott Schnee); seven grandchildren, Adam, Brian, Daniel, Emily, Jeffrey, Kevin, and Sophie; and by his sister Joyce Basch and brother Dr. Samuel Basch (Dr. Linda Basch). GILLMAN--Seymour, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of NYC; CEO of SGA Collections, Inc; beloved husband of Sharon and father of Gary; cherished grandfather of Christopher and Alexander; loving brother of Floyd (Charlotte) of Old Westbury, NY. He was also predeceased by his first wife, Suzanne. Services Wednesday, June 24th, 12 Noon at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 No. Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL.

SEIGEL--Sylvia (nee Suchow), on June 21, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Max H. Seigel, former reporter for the New York Times. Devoted sister of Sanford M. Suchow and sister-in-law of Ada M. Suchow. A funeral service will be held 11:00am Tuesday at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

KLEEBLATT--Frances F.,83, of Fair Lawn, NJ, passed away on Friday, June 19, 2009. Beloved wife of Karl Kleeblatt, cherished daughter of the late Moritz Aaron and the late Jennie Oppenheimer Aaron, devoted mother of Norman Kleeblatt and his partner Peter Prescott of New York City and Michael Kleeblatt and his wife Monica of River Vale, NJ and proud grandmother of Jeffrey Kleeblatt of Princeton, NJ. Frances was born outside Giessen, Germany and came to America in 1937 settling in New York City and was a resident of Fair Lawn for 44 years. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Lung Association.

FELSHER--Elaine, nee Vejans, passed away peacefully at home on June 16th after a valiant battle with cancer. She was born in Texas in 1926, and after graduating the University of Texas, came to New York at the age of twenty. A beautiful woman with a lovely singing voice Elaine performed in many church and other choirs. In 1950 she married Howard Felsher, a successful TV producer. Their son Andrew was born in 1958. Elaine was an archivist for many years at Time Inc., then accompanied her husband to California in the early l970's. Divorced soon after she returned to New York in l980, she rejoined Time Inc., and as chief archivist enjoyed an exceptional reputation for her thoughtful, penetrating oral histories. She lived happily for 18 years with Ivin Mann, a respected accountant who also was president of Fountain House, and predeceased her. Elaine is survived by her ex-husband Howard, son Andrew, his caring wife Sharon, two adored grandchildren, Cameron and Olivia and wonderful step-grandchildren, Justin, Janae and Julianne Moffet. Her friends and family will never forget her. Contributions in her memory may be sent to MSK Cancer Center, PO Box 27106 NYC, 10087 or to Fountain House Development Office. 425 W. 47 St., NYC 10036.

WHITE--Brenda B. Loving wife, mother, daughter, sister, friend, and industry leader in Corporate Finance passed away on June 21, 2009, due to complications from a rare form of cancer. Born in Monmouth County, New Jersey in 1954 she was the eldest child of Rudy and Theresa Bruno. She began her career at Dun and Bradstreet, moving on to Merrill Lynch as the Vice President of Financial Analysis. While working full time, she attended NYU, earning her MBA in finance, graduating with high honors. In 1984, she began working for Salomon Brothers and was promoted through the ranks to become Managing Director, Head of Investment Banking to the Mortgage Industry. Her promotion in 1994 at the firm was perhaps her proudest professional achievement. In 2002 Brenda started her own company, B.B. White & Consulting, providing consulting services to the mortgage banking industry. Completing her career in 2007, she worked for Deloitte & Touche as partner and Managing Director. Viewed as an expert in her field, she was a regular contributor to Mortgage Banking magazine and was frequently quoted in the Wall Street Journal, and American Banker. A lover of life, Brenda enjoyed traveling with her family, skiing with her daughter, and playing tennis and golf with her friends. She is survived by her parents, husband Tim, daughter Adrienne, sister and brother Donna and Rudy Bruno, and her stepdaughter Sarah. Visitation for Brenda B, White will be on Wednesday, June 24, 2009 from 4-8pm at The William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit. A Mass of Christian Burial will be on June 25, 2009 at 11:15am at Saint Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church, 52 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as expected, has offered the developer Bruce C. Ratner a break on the sale of a portion of the Atlantic Yards site in Brooklyn. Mr. Ratner had agreed to pay $100 million to the authority for a nine-acre site where a railyard is located, but with the economy slumping, he asked to defer some of the payment. The development is to feature a sports arena, apartments and an office tower.

CONNETT--Eugene Virginius IV. On June 12, 2009, Eugene Virginius Connett IV, aka "The Kid", passed on. He was born to his proud parents, Eugene V. Connett III and Kathryn Elise Underhill Connett on a snowy morning on January 21, 1920 in South Orange, NJ. His advent was welcomed with open arms by his sister, Elise Migeon Connett. Eugene was privileged to attend St. Paul's School of Concord, NH, graduating in 1939. In the spring, he fished the chalk streams of England with his father, (who was an expert trout fisherman and distinguished author and owner of the Derrydale Press). He spent his autumns shooting with his father in duck blinds on the Chesapeake and the golden grasslands of North America. Immediately following his high school years, Mr. Connett attended Princeton as a 4th generation legacy, where he graduated with a degree in French Literature in 1942. There, he was a member of the Cottage Club and the Princeton Crew Team. With WWII in full swing in 1942, Mr. Connett enlisted as a first lieutenant in the Army Air Corps. His superb language skills were seen as a valuable asset and bought him a classified assignment with the O.S.S. in the Alsace-Lorraine region of France until 1945. Following the war, Connett returned home and took a position with David Ogilvy Associates in NYC, NY as a marketing executive. He met his future bride, Etheldred Slosson McGrew (of Geneva, NY) in an elevator and smitten with her willowy frame and winsome smile, wed her on April 29, 1950. The following spring, the happy couple was blessed with their first child, Stacey Migeon Connett (Spartz). Within the ensuing seven years, his daughters, (Bevan Brecount Connett Kinney and Kathryn Underhill Connett Loh) and his identical twin sons, (Eugene Virginius Connett V and Aubrey Fitzhugh Connett) had joined the family. Mr. Connett was an accomplished sailor who was familiar throughout the great South Bay of LI, NY, where the Connett family summered until the mid 1950's. In the 1960's, Mr. Connett established himself as a small boat racer's worst nightmare, competing around the harbors of Long Island Sound under the burgee of Riverside Yacht Club in Riverside, CT. In 1979, Eugene and his family relocated to Stonington, CT, where he assumed the distinguished status of M.P.S.O. and enjoyed a membership in the Wadawannuck Yacht Club in Stonington, CT. His professional accomplishments included attaining the Vice Presidency of the American Carpet Institute in NYC, NY and ownership of the world renowned Stonington Clothing Ltd., of Stonington, CT. By far, his greatest achievement was being a magnificent father, faithful friend and man of integrity. He was a lovely guy who led a sun-kissed life and was adored by all who knew him. Eugene Connett IV is survived by all his sons and daughters (above), their spouses and partners; Dan Kinney, Rick Loh, Lori Connett, Kim Connett and David Wolodko. He also leaves behind his handsome grandchildren; Matthew Perry, Eric, Mark and Stacey Loh, Emily Connett and Tommy and Andrew Connett, of whom he was unspeakably proud! Services will be held in his honor at Calvary Episcopal Church located at 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. 06378 at 12:30pm on Sunday, June 28, 2009. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Visiting Nurse Association of Southeastern CT, 403 N. Frontage Rd., Waterford, CT. 06385.

Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina was missing, and neither his wife nor his staff could say where he was on Monday. They were not being evasive; they said they simply did not know. But this, apparently, was not a big deal, at least according to his chief spokesman, Joel Sawyer, who was deluged with phone calls. Mr. Sawyer said Mr. Sanford, above, a Republican, had gone off on his own on Thursday after a busy session of lawmaking.

LOVE--Dr. Shirley, Ph.D.,on Sunday, June 21 at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was born on March 27, 1923 in Brooklyn to Rachel and Morris Greenstein. She completed her undergraduate degree at Brooklyn College, MSW from Columbia University, where she met her husband, Dr. Sidney Love, ABD at Yeshiva University School of Social Work, and Ph.D. from Heed University; she was also a certified psychoanalyst. She was a co-founder of the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies in New York City and also co-founded and co-directed the Riverdale Seminars in Modern Psychoanalysis. Not only was Dr. Shirley Love a skilled and dedicated psychoanalyst, she made numerous contributions to her community, such as an active PTA member of Fieldston School, helped to found the Riverdale YM-YWHA, and contributed to UJA Federation. An extremely intelligent, empathic psychoanalyst, she will be sorely missed. She is survived by her two daughters Jeanine Dropkin and Carolyn Bersak, her son-in-law David, four grandchildren Jennifer (Brad, son Anders), Michael, Melissa and Rebecca. She is also survived by her sister Mildred Bierman, brother-in-law Manny, and their children, and her niece Audrey. She was pre-deceased by her husband, Dr. Sidney Love. Funeral services will be at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th on Wednesday, June 24, 11:15am. Reception and burial to follow.

The Pentagon will adopt a new strategy that for the first time orders the military to anticipate that future conflicts will include a complex mix of conventional, set-piece battles and campaigns against shadowy insurgents and terrorists, according to senior officials. The new strategy has broad implications for training, troop deployment, weapons procurement and other aspects of military planning.
PERA--Teresa M. of Westbury, NY on June 15 at 95. Retired employee of Tiffany & Co. She will be remembered for her devotion to family and friends. Memorial donations accepted at: bsfa.org.

Melissa Bulanhagui is a highly ranked figure skater, but two years ago her right ankle failed her. She sprained it twice and tore a ligament, each time during one of her favorite jumps, the triple lutz. Other skaters have suffered similar injuries, and now science is studying why, aiming to help skaters meet the sport's physical challenges without sacrificing their health.

BRODER--Ruth. Loving wife of Alan passed away on June 6, 2009. She will be remembered as a warm and loving person with a great talent for painting portraits, landscapes and vibrant abstractions. She will be sorely missed by everyone who knew her.

PROKUPETS--Ruvin D. "Rudy," co-founder of Lenel Systems International, now a division of United Technologies Corporation., and a visionary technology entrepreneur, died June 16 in Roches- ter. He was 63. Mr. Prokupets was best known for creating state-of-the-art computer integrated security systems and building with is wife, Elena Prokupets, the Rochester-based Lenel into an international leader in the emerging field. Today, Lenel has installed more than 20,000 systems. Lenel technology has been used by the U.S. military, world conglomerates, government agencies, and homeland security. From the beginning Mr. Prokupets and his wife used their success to help philanthropic and cultural institutions across a broad spectrum. Mr. Prokupets, a lifelong lover of opera, was recognized for his generosity with a plaque at the Metro- politan Opera of New York, of which his wife is a current board member. Mr. Prokupets was a generous supporter of many charities and set up a foundation in support of Rochester-area foundations, Jewish charities, served on the board of Jewish Community Federation in Rochester as well as the board of the University of Rochester Medical Center. Mr. Prokupets put tremendous effort and contributed to various areas of medical research, including Harvard University, Broad Institute, University of Roches- ter and other medical research centers. "Rudy Prokupets' life was a triumph," said University of Rochester President, Joel Seligman. "He rose from the humblest of circumstances in Russia to achieve great success in United States as a scientist and corporate entrepreneur. He was amazingly bright, a lover of the arts, a truly cultured individual. I rarely enjoyed conversations so much as with Rudy. My heart goes out to Rudy's beloved wife Elena and their family. Rudy was a valued member of the University of Rochester Medical Center Board. He will be deeply missed." Mr. Prokupets arrived in Rochester as a political refugee from what is now St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1977 with his wife and young son, with no prospects other than his education and his dreams. Mr. Prokupets held a master's degree in electrophysics from the Electrical Engineering Institute in Leningrad and a master's degree in applied mathematics from the University of Leningrad. In 1986, Mr. Prokupets and his wife, who has a Ph.D. in computer science and electrical engineering, launched their first company, Edicon, as a division of the Eastman Kodak Co. where Mr. Prokupets worked. Mr. Prokupets is recognized for creating an image compression algorithm for digital images. Mr. Prokupets was a pioneer in introducing one of the first in the world multi-media software products. Microsoft Corp. was the first user of Lenel's multi-media and security technology and recognized Mr. Prokupets' vision and technological advances. In addition to his wife, Mr. Prokupets is survived by his son, Daniel Prokupets, and his wife, Bethany Prokupets; three grandchildren, Ella, Samuel, and Haley; a sister, Ida Van- ston, and her husband Joseph Vanston; nieces, Inga Vanston and Laura Cameron; father-in-law, Isaac Vilnits; and brother-in-law, Alex Vilnits and his wife, Anna Vilnits.

WAGNER--Ernest J.,died peacefully on June 21, 2009. He was 80. He was born in Bronx, New York. He graduated from Xavier HS, Fordham '51, and MSW Rutgers '70. He served his country during the Korean War and retired as a Major from the Army Reserves. He spent his career in public service as a health care administrator for NYS. He is survived by his loving wife Mary Ellen, son Michael, daughters Pauline, Lizzy, and Katie and their spouses; and 10 grandchildren. He was a kind and loving husband, father, and friend. Services by McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 914-337-6770.

Bain Capital, an American private investment firm, said Monday that it had agreed to invest as much as $432 million to acquire a minority stake in Gome Electrical Appliances, one of the biggest retailers in China. The deal, which had been rumored for weeks, is expected to bolster Gome, which has been struggling amid weakening sales and the investigation of its founder and former chairman, Huang Guangyu, who was detained by the Chinese authorities on corruption charges in November.

A few years ago, researchers at the National Institute of Health and Nutrition in Japan put rats through a series of swim tests with surprising results. They had one group of rodents paddle in a small pool for six hours, this long workout broken into two sessions of three hours each. A second group of rats were made to stroke furiously through short, intense bouts of swimming, while carrying ballast to increase their workload. After 20 seconds, the weighted rats were scooped out of the water and allowed to rest for 10 seconds, before being placed back in the pool for another 20 seconds of exertion. The scientists had the rats repeat these brief, strenuous swims 14 times, for a total of about four-and-a-half minutes of swimming. Afterward, the researchers tested each rat’s muscle fibers and found that, as expected, the rats that had gone for the six-hour swim showed preliminary molecular changes that would increase endurance. But the second rodent group, which exercised for less than five minutes also showed the same molecular changes.

The Ohio Theater will remain at its longtime SoHo home through August 2010. The highly regarded institution, which has helped push theater forward in New York for more than two decades, on Wednesday signed a 14-month lease with Zar Property NY, which acquired the 66 Wooster Street building last year.

Long Island will come to Washington — and five other cities — this fall when Billy Crystal takes his one-man show, “700 Sundays,” on a national tour. In a news release, publicists for “700 Sundays” said the show, about Mr. Crystal’s upbringing in suburban Long Beach, N.Y., would begin a six-city tour at the National Theater in Washington on Sept. 8. and run there through Sept. 17. The tour will also play in Philadelphia; Dallas; Palm Beach, Fla.; Miami; and Atlanta. The show, which ran at Broadway’s Broadhurst Theater from 2004 to 2005, won the (now retired) Tony Award for special theatrical event.

The boys at the Globe play rough. Though Thea Sharrock’s acclaimed production of “As You Like It” at Shakespeare’s Globe Theater begins with ceremonial courtliness – and in full Elizabethan costume — it soon shifts into a mode that fans of World Wrestling Entertainment might feel at home with. The early, plot-propelling championship fight between the comedy’s brave but slender young hero and a supposedly unbeatable big palooka has been choreographed as a rules-free, below-the-belt bone crusher that spills over the stage and into the audience. Groundlings (those who stand in the theater’s unroofed pit for bargain prices) are forced to back away from the action, even as they cheer in delight.

Theater coverage on NYTimes.com hasn’t been this animated since we posted a slide show of a shirtless Daniel Radcliffe in the London production of “Equus.”

The Virgin Mobile Festival in Maryland is going free. Weezer, Blink-182, Franz Ferdinand, Girl Talk, the Hold Steady, Public Enemy and the National will be among the acts for the fourth annual event, which will be on Aug. 30 at the Merriweather Post Pavilion in Columbia, Md. (In previous years it has been held in Baltimore.) Tickets — a total of 35,000 for the show, with a maximum of two per customer — will become available at 10 a.m. on Saturday at ticketmaster.com, but Virgin Mobile customers and previous festival attendees will have first crack at tickets, on Thursday and Friday. Tickets have no surcharges if picked up at the pavilion or at the 9:30 Club in Washington, but it will cost $5 per order to have them mailed. Information and the full lineup can be found online at virginmobilefreefest.com.

The Jonas Brothers have scored their second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with “Lines, Vines and Trying Times” (Hollywood), which had first-week sales of 247,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It bumped last week’s chart-topper, the Black Eyed Peas’ “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), to No. 2, with 148,000 sales, a 51 percent drop. The Dave Matthews Band’s “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” (RCA) is No. 3 with 88,000, Eminem’s “Relapse” (Interscope) is in fourth place with 72,000, and Incubus’s new greatest hits collection, “Monuments and Melodies” (Epic) is fifth with 70,000. Also this week, Lady Gaga continues her remarkable four-month run on the Top 10 with “The Fame” (Interscope). It holds at No. 6 with 47,000 sales, bringing the album’s 34-week sales total to just less than 1.1 million.

Who owns the Elgin Marbles? The sections of the Parthenon frieze have been a prize of the British Museum since 1816, but the opening of the Acropolis Museum in Athens on June 20 rekindles the debate. In recent weeks, Sean Newsome of the Times of London and Christopher Hitchens have written that Britain’s claim no longer holds. In his Abroad column today, Michael Kimmelman writes that the new $200 million state-of-the-art museum serves as Greece’s “rebuttal” to Britain ‘s reasoning that Greece had nowhere to show off the frieze. What do you think the fate of the Elgin Marbles should be?

If you missed this winter’s benefit readings of “Love, Loss, and What I Wore,” but still want to spend an evening with an eclectic company of women telling stories about life and clothing, the show will receive an Off-Broadway run at the Westside Theater, its publicists said in a news release. The show, written by Nora and Delia Ephron and adapted from the memoir by Ilene Beckerman, will run for 12 weeks with three different five-member casts who will perform the play in four-week cycles. The cast members will include Kristin Chenoweth, Tyne Daly, Samantha Bee, Mary Louise Wilson, Rosie O’Donnell, Katie Finneran and Rita Wilson. The show, produced by Daryl Roth, is scheduled to begin previews on Sept. 21 with an official opening planned for Oct. 1.

At a press conference Wednesday morning in Beverly Hills, Sid Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, said that future Oscar races will include 10 nominees for best picture rather than five. It’s a dramatic change that is sure to roil future Oscar contests, beginning with the upcoming one set for March 7 at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood.

Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired magazine, copied portions of his forthcoming book, “Free: The Future of a Radical Price” from Wikipedia, without attribution. The passages were discovered by a reviewer for the Virginia Quarterly Review, who was reading an advance galley of the book, which is being published by Hyperion Books early next month.

The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts announced Wednesday its schedule for a five-month-long festival that will celebrate the role that the performing arts played in the decline of Communism in Europe. The festival, Performing Revolution in Central and Eastern Europe, will run Nov. 6 through March 31, and feature performances, exhibitions, film screenings, readings and other events, its organizers said in a news release. Among the events planned are a revival of the play “Wormwood,” performed by Poland’s Theater of the Eighth Day, a company that was denounced by Communist authorities; performances of “Petruska” and “The Rite of Spring” by Hungary’s Györ National Ballet; and a series called “Rebel Waltz,” featuring underground bands from Poland, Hungary, Romania and the Czech Republic. More information will be available online at performingrevolution.org.

I wrote my Thursday column about the A.M.A. and health care partly because I think that the A.M.A. takes advantage of our general trust for doctors to lobby for policy positions -- such as opposition to a public insurance option -- that are inimical to the public's health. You can tell there's something fishy with today's Thursday puzzle as soon as you look at the grid. The layout of the black square is odd. It's not just an unusual pattern, it's a mis-oriented one. The five longest answers are vertical. Any puzzle can be flipped to make the across clues down and vice versa, so there has to be a reason we're ignoring the convention that theme answers ought to be horizontal.

The words "craft fair" usually conjure images of macramé plant holders, lopsided candles and tie-dye as far as the eye can see. But Makers Market, which opens this weekend at the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, is one craft fair that comes with a designer pedigree. The three-day open-air marketplace, in tandem with the park's ongoing rural America-themed State Fair exhibition, will feature one-of-a-kind and small-production handmade objects -- from textiles, ceramics and glassware to jewelry, furniture and even hand-built motorcycles. Among the 30 participating designers and craftsmen are local talents like Atlas Industries, hiveminddesign, Platform and Spring Design & Art gallery, who were picked by an all-star team from the sponsor organizations, including Doug DeNicola of the Noguchi Museum; Evan Snyderman, principal of the design gallery R 20th Century; and Andrew Wagner, the editor of ReadyMade.

The best team in the world, Spain, who plays with so much style and panache, was as stunned as those of us watching the Confederations Cup semifinal today. The United States, which had struggled to put together quality soccer and maximum effort, earned a shocking 2-0 victory. A world-class goal by Jozy Altidore and all-universe goalkeeping by Tim Howard gave the Americans their best victory since defeating Portugal, 3-2, in the first game of the 2002 World Cup in South Korea.

Last week we got an e-mail message from Becky Smith announcing that she was closing her Bellwether Gallery in Chelsea due to the economic climate. She's not the first casualty in this cratering art market -- in the last six months galleries like Roebling Hall, Clementine and Guild & Greyshkul have all shuttered - but T Magazine has had a long, fruitful relationship with the artists Smith has represented over the last decade. (In fact, back in 2000, Deborah Solomon profiled Smith, a Yale painting grad-turned-Greenpoint gallerist in "How to Become an Instant Art Star" in the Times Sunday magazine.) From Adam Cvijanovic's epic landscape murals to Sharon Core's photographic homages to Wayne Thiebaud's everyday food items to the extravagent paper cake Kirsten Hassenfeld created for a T wedding bonus, Smith's artists elevated our pages with intelligence, ingenuity and brilliant craftsmanship. Though she'll be working with these artists privately, we hope this gallery closing is not an actual bellwether of things to come in the art world. As Smith lamented in her note, "I tried to have a strong and distinct voice and found the art world to be a very bizarre place to navigate. It's my sincere hope that the closing of Bellwether is a wake-up call and that the collectors come back in support of young art."

Several posts (Nos. 13, 32, 71, 74, 98) berated me for wasting time on something as trivial as a comedian's joke. One comment (No. 41) even suggested a couple of more apt topics: "the looming conflict in Iran and the impending threat of North Korea." Let me reassure you that the news pages of The Times devote much attention to just those things. And I hope it is not tactless to mention that my topic is not so trivial as to keep my critics themselves from commenting on it. But I quite like these putatively unimportant matters. They are a culture's unguarded moments. Examining them can yield glimpses of our assumptions about - as here - power, family and sex. In any case, the persistence of murder doesn't require us to ignore burglary.

Recently a colleague asked me for a travel recommendation for some friends. The brief was that this married couple wanted a weekend getaway in August, someplace they could go without their children and without anyone else's children, either. Money wasn't a huge object. I immediately thought of Twin Farms, the Vermont resort spread over 300 wooded acres with rooms and cottages decorated in timelessly maximalist style by the late Jed Johnson. The food, the service and the art collection are all impeccable - it's one of my, and many other people's, favorite hotels in this country. I suggested it with a huge caveat: They probably won't get in. Even though it's not cheap (but in my opinion not overpriced), Twin Farms is regularly booked a year in advance for nearly every season except maybe mud season. But guess what? They called and found rooms and cottages available on two different weekends in August. Unheard of.

Often, when legislation dies on the Senate floor, you know who did it in. But when Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana and chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee, tried, and failed, to get new consumer credit card protections extended to small businesses last month, the perpetrator - or perpetrators - left no fingerprints. In fact, there's no agreement on what precisely happened, or why. The Congressional Record is ambiguous. And no senator, Democratic or Republican, has explained on the record why small businesses were left behind when the Credit Cardholders' Bill of Rights Act of 2009 became law on May 22.

An obituary on Tuesday about the diplomat Heyward Isham referred incorrectly to his 1950 assignment in Berlin. It was to the American Mission — not to the United States Embassy, which did not open there until 1974.

A museum review on Monday about the Vent Haven Museum in Fort Mitchell, Ky., which honors ventriloquists and their dummies, and the American Sign Museum in Cincinnati misstated the title of a 1945 horror film in which a dummy wreaks havoc. It is “Dead of Night,” not “The Dead of the Night.”.

An article on Tuesday about cultural institutions’ efforts to delay action by the New York State Legislature on a bill that would regulate the deaccessioning of artworks in their collections, citing organizations around the country that had sold or considered selling works, misidentified one such body. It was the Iowa Board of Regents, which oversees the University of Iowa Museum of Art, not the museum itself that at one point considered selling Jackson Pollock’s 1943 “Mural” to defray the cost of damage from a flood. The article also misstated the middle initial of the senator who is sponsoring the bill in the state senate. He is José M. Serrano, not E.

The Riverdale Journal article on Saturday, about a yeshiva that teaches Arabic to its students, referred imprecisely to the language’s origins. Although Arabic is a linguistic cousin to Aramaic — the language of the Talmud, also studied at the yeshiva — it did not evolve directly from Aramaic.

An article on April 28 about a federal judge’s decision not to dismiss criminal charges against the chemical products company W.R. Grace over the asbestos poisoning of Libby, Mont., misstated the title of Kris A. McLean, the lead prosecutor of the case. He is an assistant United States attorney, not the United States attorney for Montana. A reader’s e-mail message last month about the error went astray at The Times. (The company and three of its former executives were acquitted on all charges in May.).

A coroner has concluded that the singer and songwriter Jay Bennett, a former member of the rock band Wilco, died of an overdose of a painkiller, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bennett, who performed with Wilco beginning in 1994 and contributed to the band’s albums “Being There,” “Summerteeth” and “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot,” died on May 24 in Urbana, Ill., where he lived. The cause of death was initially unknown. Duane E. Northrup, the coroner of Champaign County, said that tests showed Mr. Bennett had died from an overdose of fentanyl, a drug prescribed to treat chronic pain, and that his death was being investigated as an accident. Shortly before his death, Mr. Bennett wrote on his MySpace page that he had severe pains in his hip and needed hip-replacement surgery but did not have proper health insurance.

A self-published author in Cape Cod has sued Elisabeth Hasselbeck, a co-host of the ABC program “The View,” for copyright infringement, accusing her of plagiarizing substantial portions of her book, “Living With Celiac Disease.” According to a lawsuit filed Monday in United States District Court in Massachusetts, Ms. Hasselbeck, whose diet book “The G-Free Diet: A Gluten-Free Survival Guide,” was published by the Center Street imprint of the Hachette Book Group in May, copied “significant portions” of various lists from “Living With Celiac Disease” by Susan Hassett. In the complaint, Ms. Hassett says that Ms. Hasselbeck’s book “includes dozens of paraphrased as well as word for word regurgitations of phrases and scrupulously researched factual data entries” and “utilizes a virtually identical order and format of 13 chapters” of Ms. Hassett’s work. The lawsuit states that Ms. Hassett sent a copy of her book to Ms. Hasselbeck in April 2008 after “The View” host disclosed that she had celiac disease. According to the complaint, Ms. Hasselbeck never acknowledged the book or Ms. Hassett. Ms. Hassett and her lawyer, Richard Cunha, declined to comment. In a statement, a Hachette spokeswoman denied the accusations and said that no complaint had been served.

From her performance in “The Little Dog Laughed,” we know how Julie White takes to the role of a powerful Hollywood agent. (Answer: with relish.) So how will she handle being reduced to a less powerful — if equally imposing — stage manager? We will find out this fall in Roundabout Theater Company’s production of “The Understudy,” in which Ms. White, right, will star, the theater announced. The play, written by Theresa Rebeck (“Our House,” “Mauritius”), is a comedy about theater performers and a backstage staff member with many frustrations to share. It will be directed by Scott Ellis, and is scheduled to begin previews at the Laura Pels Theater on Oct. 9 for a Nov. 5 opening.

Costume design has come into its own at the University of California, Los Angeles. The university’s school of theater, film and television on Tuesday said it had named Deborah Nadoolman Landis, a designer whose film credits include “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” to the newly endowed David C. Copley chair for the study of costume design. Ms. Landis, above, who has a doctorate in the history of design from the Royal College of Art in London, is also the founding director of a new center at the university for the study of costume design. Ms. Landis has in the past been president of Hollywood’s Costume Designers Guild.

Barrett Wissman, a businessman who in April pleaded guilty to securities fraud in an investigation into corruption at the New York State pension fund, has stepped down as chairman of IMG Artists, one of the largest firms representing classical musicians, and has been replaced by Charles Hamlen. Mr. Wissman bought a controlling interest in IMG in 2003. The company, while declining to comment on his ownership, said on Tuesday that his interest remained unchanged. Mr. Hamlen co-founded IMG’s predecessor agency in 1979. Mr. Hamlen left IMG in 1992 to establish and run Classical Action, which raises money for AIDS services. He said Mr. Wissman had called him out of the blue and suggested he take the job.

A repeat of CBS’s “Two and a Half Men” delivered Monday night’s highest ratings, drawing 8.6 million viewers at 9 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS led the night over all, with a lineup of all repeats, including “The Big Bang Theory” (7.2 million) and “CSI: Miami” (7.9 million). ABC finished close behind in second place, with new episodes of its reality shows “The Bachelorette” (6.8 million) and “Here Come the Newlyweds” (4.1 million). NBC ranked third with two hours of “I’m a Celebrity... Get Me Out of Here!” (4.3 million) followed by “Dateline” (5.1 million), while Fox finished in fourth with reruns of “House” (4.9 million) and “Lie to Me” (3.8 million).

The R&B singer Chris Brown, below, on left, pleaded guilty in a Los Angeles court on Monday to one count of felony assault on the pop star Rihanna, far right, The Associated Press reported. Under the terms of the plea agreement, Mr. Brown will receive five years of supervised probation and six months of community service. He will be allowed to complete his community service in his home state, Virginia, but will have to return to California for updates every three months. A stay-away order was also imposed by the judge, requiring that Mr. Brown and Rihanna stay at least 50 yards from each other, except at industry events when the distance is reduced to 10 yards. In March, Mr. Brown was charged with assault and making criminal threats against Rihanna after an incident on the morning of Feb. 8 when the two performers had an altercation in Mr. Brown’s car. In April, Mr. Brown pleaded not guilty to both charges. He faced up to five years in prison if convicted.

ROTHLEIN--Robert, passed away on June 21 after an extended struggle with lung cancer. He was 59. His life will be celebrated at the Kittle House in Chappaqua, NY on July 3 from 1 to 4:30. Dr. Rothlein, earned his Ph.D. from Cornell University in immunology, was Senior Vice President for Biology at Trans Tech Pharma, Inc. and had held a senior position at Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals. His post-doctoral work was conducted at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. Dr. Rothlein was a highly respected immunologist. Dr. Rothlein is preceded in death by his father, Marvin Rothlein and is survived by his wife of 29 years, Marie, their two children Lisa and David, his mother, Lucy Rothlein, his brother, Andrew Rothlein, sister-in-law, Pamela Rothlein, sisters, Lollie Goodyear and Mary Ann May, and nieces and nephews, Rebecca, Emily, Sarah, and Mark. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Lung Cancer Partnership.

The Disney NetPal from Asus ($350, coming in early August) is a beefed-up Eee PC Netbook with thicker hinges, a spill-proof keyboard and onboard parental controls, and no shortage of Disney-themed frosting. Once you get past the mouse-ear-shape Web cam, this is really just a typical Intel Atom-powered Windows XP netbook that you could easily imagine prying from your child to find look up a recipe or watch a funny YouTube video. There are three USB ports and an SD slot, plus a VGA graphics out port for school reports and a headphone jack. The Wi-Fi/Web cam combination could make Skyping with a grandparent an option.

ISHAM--Heyward, died June 18 of cardiac arrest, at 82 years of age. Mr. Isham was born in New York City, attended Phillips Academy, earned his BA from Yale and studied at Columbia University's Russian institute in Garmisch, Germany. Mr. Isham had a long and distinguished career in the U.S. State Department, beginning in 1950 with the U.S. Mission in Berlin serving under U.S. High Commissioner John McCloy and rising to Ambassador to Haiti and Assistant Secretary of State and Director of the Office for Combating Terrorism. Mr. Isham also served in the US Embassy in Moscow under Ambassador Charles Bohlen, during the height of the Cold War and US Consulate in Hong Kong where he was one of the first to recognize the emerging Sino-Soviet rift. In 1971-1972 Mr. Isham served as Deputy and Chief of the US Delegation to the Paris Talks on Vietnam negotiating directly with the North Vietnamese which resulted in the Paris Peace Accords signed on January 17, 1973 ending more than 10 years of direct US military involvement in Vietnam. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger said of Mr. Isham's work, "He made a tremendous contribution." In retirement Mr. Isham became a senior editor at Doubleday publishing the memoirs of Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister during the more tense time of the cold war and authored two important books in 1995 and in 2001 introducing new Russian writers to the world. In 1990 Mr. Isham became Vice President and Ambassador-in-Residence at the East-West Institute in New York. For the past 15 years, the Ishams' principal home has been in Sagapon- ack where he was a known and loved member of the community. Mr. Isham is survived by his wife of 59 years, the noted artist Sheila Eaton Isham, and two sons Christopher E. Isham, Vice President and Washington Bureau Chief for CBS News, and Ralph H. Isham, Managing Partner, GH Venture Partners, LLC in New York City and nine grandchildren. His daughter Sandra Isham Vreeland died in 1996. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hopital Albert Schweitzer Haiti, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA 15217 or visit: www.hashaiti.org

RICH--Raymond A.,a resident of Boca Grande, Florida, and major industrialist and business leader, passed away on June 19, 2009, at the age of 97 in Esopus, New York. After serving his country in World War II, Mr. Rich became Vice President and Director of Philco Corporation and then accepted the Presidency and Directorship of Avco Corporation. From there his career escalated to multiple, simultaneous CEO and Chairman positions of numerous companies. The sectors ranged from oil and gas exploration and production, publishing, glass containers, and banks to environmental engineering and production facilities. In this latter category, he led U.S. Filter Corporation as Chairman and CEO to a significant role in its field, increasing revenues twenty-fold in the 1970s. Mr. Rich's wife, Virginia, died in 1985. He is survived by his daughter, Susan Sheridan; his son, John; four grandchildren; three great-grandsons; and his loving companion, Claire Carlson. A memorial service was held at the Corea Baptist Church, Corea, Maine, with interment following at the local cemetery.

The University of Texas relievers gather before each game in foul territory near first base and sprint to the bullpen. One pitcher skipped the ritual Tuesday night, but the freshman right-hander Taylor Jungmann had a great excuse. Coach Augie Garrido entrusted him to start Game 2 of the College World Series championship and try to extend the Longhorns' season one more day. Jungmann, who failed to throw a strike in a ninth-inning relief appearance in a Game 1 loss to L.S.U., came back with masterful five-hitter for his first collegiate complete-game win, 5-1.

It's pretty hard to get all excited about a new printer, but the new Hewlett-Packard Photosmart Premium with TouchSmart Web is certainly an exception. The TouchSmart Web connects to your PCs and the Web via built-in Wi-Fi. Linking to a home computer via wireless networking is nothing new, but the way that the printer directly connects to the Web to print photos, coupons, maps, event tickets and more is truly head-turning.

Colleagues said Mr. Ensign, right, was somber in expressing his regrets. ''This was not a flippant thing that he did,'' said Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee. ''From what I have seen, he has been very stand up about it. He made a mistake. He said he made a mistake. And he has been very apologetic about it.''

General Manager Darryl Sutter hired his brother Brent to be the new coach of the Calgary Flames. Brent Sutter quit as the Devils' coach after the playoffs with one year left on his contract to return to Alberta, saying he missed his family. Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' president, has said that he believes the Devils should be compensated by the Flames, but he has also said that ultimately he sticks by his decision to let Sutter out of the last year of his deal.

PETRIE--Donald Archibald, long time resident of Wainscott, NY- lawyer, investment banker, publisher and author, died peacefully at his home on Wednesday, June 10, 2009 at the age of 88. Born in Charleston, WV on April 27, 1921 to James and Emma Petrie he was raised in Sea Cliff, NY where his family moved after the sudden death of his father. He attended Hofstra University and the University of Chicago, earning BA and JD degrees. He was a veteran of World War II, having served in China and India as Staff Sergeant in the United States Army Air Corps. Upon graduation from law school he joined the Chicago law firm of D'Ancona Pflaum Wyatt & Riskind. He soon joined The Hertz Corporation as Executive Vice-President and Chief Operating Officer. He later became President of Hertz International. From 1962 to 1965 he was Chairman of the Executive Committee at Avis Rent-A-Car. He joined Lazard Freres as partner in the 1960s and remained a partner until 2000. He served on the first board of the Peace Corps and as Treasurer for the Democratic National Committee in 1972. He played a significant role in financing the construction of the Washington Cathedral, and as a tribute to his work, a gargoyle in his likeness - briefcase in hand - projects from the Southwest Tower of the Cathedral. In 1970 he and his good friend and business partner Robert C. Townsend co-founded Leadership Directories Inc., a publisher of government and business directories. He served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer from 1985 until 2002. A former Chairman of Group for the South Fork, his leadership helped mold the Group into a highly professional and effective environmental advocacy organization, now The Group for the East End. For 20 years he published "The Pond Watchers Almanac", his observations of all that happened in and on Georgica Pond. In the 1980s he joined with others to found the Wainscott Citizens Advisory Committee. His love of history, sailing and the law culminated in the 1999 publication by the Naval Institute Press of his book "The Prize Game - Lawful Looting on the High Seas in the Days of Fighting Sail". He is survived by his beloved wife Mary, two children from his first wife Ruth - Ann Elizabeth Sauter and James MacFarlin Petrie, three stepchildren Ramsay Cook, Clare Nicol and Gillian Quinn, and ten grandchildren Kathleen, Virginia, Madeline, Eliza, Connie, Archie, Peter, Catherine, Ramsay and Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held at Wainscott in early August.

Robert Mecea teaching his first official spinning class at a gym in Manhattan. Mr. Mecea was a photographer at Newsday, but he was laid off and decided to pursue another career: personal trainer. While studying to receive his certification, he started to teach spinning classes. ''In many ways,'' he said, ''yes, it is definitely a second chance or blessing in disguise to get me into the next stage of my life.'' Not long ago, a patient in a cardiac support group I was leading told of his response to a recent incident: He and a female friend were on the plaza at Lincoln Center after seeing a performance of Verdi's opera "Il Trovatore" when a car nearly hit the woman. She ran after the vehicle, which was slowly moving away, and slammed the trunk with her rolled up program. The driver emerged from the car hurling expletives in her direction. The patient then hit the driver with his cane. The driver shoved the patient into a fender, at which point, the patient insisted, he had no choice ... It was no ordinary cane he was carrying, but a beautiful 19th-century model with a sleek, sharp sword concealed within. He then insisted that the driver "apologize at swordpoint" in front of a small crowd that had gathered. The characters in "Il Trovatore," he added, proudly brandished swords.

"Life, On the Line," the book proposal Grant Achatz was shopping around, has been sold to Gotham Books. Mr. Achatz had feared that publishers might balk at the dual-voice approach, with passages by Mr. Achatz alternating with others written by Nick Kokonas, his friend and his partner in the Chicago restaurant Alinea. But Gotham has signed both of them. What's less clear is whether the book will look like the proposal, designed by Martin Kastner with striking juxtapositions of photographs. "This is still undecided," Mr. Achatz wrote in an email. "Likely Martin will be involved in some way. We have not finalized all of these details yet." The book is tentatively scheduled to be published next fall.
