PARIS - I have one last thought from the shows that ended two days ago in Milan. First seen on the techno-tailored suits and jackets of Italo Zucchelli's Calvin Klein collection, mesh fabric featured in a few key collections. Miuccia Prada used sheer, slightly overscale mesh to create her fantastic interpretation of black and white cinema at the Prada men's show. Coats, cardigans, polos and vests in varied tones of gray and black were layered for a vivid, filmlike optic effect - all in a sleek French New Wave silhouette. Giorgio Armani's Emporio Armani show opened with an insanely talented freestyle biker doing frightening tricks in front of the front row and rounded out the mesh trend with a grouping of sporty netted drawstring shorts.

It's officially the season of group art shows and rooftop parties. Both come together at the "No Soul For Sale" festival, sponsored by X, a yearlong nonprofit initiative housed in the former Dia building on West 22nd Street. Through Sunday, more than 30 different collectives, alternative galleries and independent spaces from around the globe are featuring installations, performances, lectures, zines and underground film screenings. There's plenty of heady stuff to absorb (avant garde queer video, sonic bed), so take a break on the building's rooftop, where you can lounge on furniture made from colorful foam pool noodles, brought to you by the Los Angeles-based architect Jeffrey Inaba, and watch films by the Studio Film Club, run by Peter Doig and Che Lovelace in Port of Spain, Trinidad. Check out the film schedule as well as other events at x-initiative.org.

Manhattan's century-old flower district occupies little more than a block of West 28th Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, whittled down over the years by soaring real estate prices and condominium encroachment.

Pentax adds to the lineup of swimming snap-shooters with its new Optio W80, which can withstand a dunk off the deep end down to 16 feet. It can shoot underwater photos and high-definition video for up to two hours, according to its maker.

When children are in trouble, it can feel like the entire house is under attack. That is certainly the way Janice Lynch Schuster has felt over the past few months, years even, trying to get help for two of her children (she has six altogether) who were abusing alcohol and drugs. The teens are sober now, if only for a matter of weeks. As she writes in a guest blog today, danger still slithers, both metaphorically and literally, just outside her Annapolis home.

There have been studies that compare text messaging on cellphones and other hand-held devices to driving drunk. And several states have already banned texting while driving. But according to Car and Driver, no one has done a real-world test -- until now.

On Wednesday, James Glanz wrote an article about how fracturing rocks deep in the earth to produce geothermal energy can set off earthquakes. A geothermal project in Basel, Switzerland, was halted in December 2006 after a sharp quake. Now, an American start-up company, AltaRock Energy, plans to use similar methods to drill into a fault-lined area not far from San Francisco.

Or when he demolished Robbie Ginepri in the first round, serving better than ever, moving like he did when he won here seven years ago, and playing aggressively while still keeping his errors stingily low. Well, Hewitt has our attention now, as he outserved and outhit the younger, taller, higher-ranked Juan Del Potro, beating the fifth-ranked Argentine, 6-2, 7-5, 7-5.

Stefano Pilati, the Yves Saint Laurent designer, usually eases us into Paris men's fashion week with a quiet presentation and a short film. This time around, the latter was courtesy of the filmmaker Samuel Benchetrit, who directed his 11-year-old son, Jules, in an idiosyncratic, eight-minute black and white film. The on-screen style pointers were subtle: always stay young at heart, and push up your sleeves if you're wearing a blazer. But even without the fashion component, the film - about an inquisitive young boy who finds himself in a suite at the Bristol Hotel after finding the keys on the sidewalk - stands on its own; and, we're definitely predicting a bright acting future for young Jules.

Jaws are dropping all over Hollywood: "Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen" opened sharply above even robust expectations on Wednesday with $60.6 million in ticket sales at North American theaters, according to Paramount Pictures.

As researchers contemplate the impacts of accumulating greenhouse gases, their concerns are not restricted to rising temperatures and sea levels and other problems they are pretty sure we can expect. They also worry about impacts, big and small, that no one has thought of.

Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, staunchly denied putting improper pressure on Bank of America to complete its ill-starred merger with Merrill Lynch last December, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews and Louise Story report.

With the recommendation of Tina Lehn to take over as principal of the South Mountain Elementary School and Annex, the South Orange Maplewood School District is left with a vacancy in its administrative ranks. But perhaps not for long. When Board of Education members vote on the recommendation of Ms. Lehn Monday night, Superintendent Brian Osborne is also asking them to approve Raquel Horn as her replacement as assistant principal of Seth Boyden Demonstration School. Ms. Horn, who is assistant principal of the Delran Intermediate School in Delran, N.J., is a graduate of Kean College and the University of Phoenix with degrees in communications and education administration and supervision. Ms. Lehn, meanwhile, in a letter addressed to the Families of Seth Boyden, said she was grateful to the Seth Boyden community, and was leaving with "a great deal of sadness. -- Alexandra Flanders

Walter Cronkite, the iconic CBS News anchorman of the 1960s and 1970s, is seriously ill with cerebrovascular disease and is "not expected to recuperate," his family members said in a statement Thursday.

Rosie O'Donnell, a former co-host of "The View," is starting a morning show, this time on the radio. The satellite radio company Sirius XM said Wednesday that Ms. O'Donnell would host a two-hour daily show beginning in the fall.

To get the best predictions about when your company's latest product will ship or how it will sell, you might try asking your employees - anonymously. A start-up, Crowdcast, began selling corporate forecasting software on Thursday that does just that.

Reuters has a useful update on the latest meeting of the Major Economies Forum on Energy and Climate, which concluded yesterday in Cuernavaca, Mexico. The article cites a draft two-page text circulated at the meeting, which appears to indicate movement toward long-term (2050) and near-term (2020) steps to curb emissions of greenhouse gases -- although with all of the soft language required to get both developing and rich countries on board.

Bob Bradley may still be hungover from yesterday's victory over Spain, but the U.S. coach still has a job to do. And while he may be relishing a matchup against either Brazil or South Africa on Sunday in Johannesburg, he also has to prepare for next month's Concacaf Gold Cup. To that end, he's announced his roster (Reuters called it a "largely experimental" squad) for the regional tournament, scheduled to begin July 3.
Location: Storrs, Conn.

According to this Publisher's Weekly article, there are no fewer than seven new bread-baking books appearing this fall, with at least four of them taking either the no-knead or "quick and easy" route. There's "Healthy Breads in Five Minutes a Day," the follow-up to "Artisan Breads in Five Minutes a Day," written about here by the Dining Section's own Nick Fox. (Note to the naïve: not really five minutes.) Then there's the long-awaited (by me at least) collaboration between Jim Lahey (who first popularized no-knead, slow-rise bread) and former Times writer and editor Rick Flaste, called "My Bread: The Revolutionary No-Work, No-Knead Method." Why we need more than that I don't know, and maybe it's much ado about nothing, but it could be an interesting fall, bread-wise.

President Obama may still have high approval ratings but his television ratings have tanked. ABC's "Primetime" special on Wednesday, featuring a town hall discussion with the president about health care, attracted just 4.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. The special ranked third in its 10 p.m. time slot behind CBS's rerun of "CSI: NY" and NBC's premiere of "The Philanthropist," both of which drew 7.4 million viewers.

If artists Yayoi Kusama (she of the polka dots) and Yinka Shonibare (he of the African fabrics refashioned into some kind of Western icon of art history) had a love child, it would be Jacob Hashimoto. While both Kusama and Shonibare are having blockbuster shows at Gagosian gallery and the Brooklyn Museum respectively, the tapestries of Hashimoto quietly hang at Mary Boone. (Kusama, who is celebrating her 80th birthday this year, also has a show up at Victoria Miro in London.)

Americans may have the Fourth of July, but Canadians have July 1, better known as Canada Day. And to celebrate, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Canada - which includes Westin, Sheraton, Four Points by Sheraton, W, Aloft and Le Méridien - is offering discounts of up to 40 percent for stays through Sept. 30. The promotion, which must be booked by July 1, also applies to the recently opened Le Westin Montréal and the soon-to-open Sheraton Vancouver Airport Hotel.Marriot is offering free nights at its 300 hotels across the globe, including JW Marriott, Marriott, Renaissance and Courtyard hotels. Guests who spend three consecutive weekend nights at any Marriot hotel outside of the United States and Canada will enjoy one night free. Guests who spend four nights spent at hotels in Hawaii, the Caribbean, Thailand and Spain will get a fifth night free. Some London hotels are also offering a free night midweek. Promotion is good for stays through Sept. 7 and must be booked by Aug. 21.

People were shocked because Republicans traditionally don't do well with Hispanic women.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on CBS: Anybody here from South Carolina? Their governor down there, Mark Sanford disappears. He's gone for four days. The first time he said he was hiking the Appalachian Trail. Okay, I'm just dumb enough to believe that. Then he says, "No, no, no, forget the Appalachian Trail. I was in South America." Now, I'm not sure I'm with him. Today he said he woke up in Las Vegas, hung over with a tiger and a baby.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Did you hear about Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina? He mysteriously disappeared last week and nobody knew where he was. Today, Sanford admitted to having an affair in Argentina. I'm like, great, now we're outsourcing mistresses.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Mark Sanford, the governor of South Carolina -- this just keeps getting weirder. He was missing for five days. He finally showed up. He claimed that he was just hiking in the Appalachian Mountains. Then just today, he revealed that he was not hiking in the Appalachian Mountains, he was in Argentina the entire time -- in Argentina, where he was having an extramarital affair. Wow! It all seems insane until you realize who his mistress is -- Carmen Sandiego.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: Hey, did any of you watch "Jon & Kate Plus 8" on Monday night? They did not stay together, and according to the big ratings they got, there is nothing America loves more than watching a good old-fashioned divorce. It's really crazy how much attention this is getting. You'd pretty much have to sneak out of the governor's mansion and spend six days holed up in Argentina with your mistress not to have heard about it.

Here are photographs showing the rapid pace at which Greenland's ice sheet is eroding. Changes at one latitude-longitude point over five years do not constitute climate change, but researchers say the same pattern, with some variation south to north, is spread over the entire ice sheet, which is four times the size of California.

The American International Group agreed to sell its consumer finance operations in Mexico to firms related to Afirme Grupo Financiero and Consorcio Villacero. A.I.G. will sell its entire stake in AIG Universal and Markcenter Services, the insurer said in a statement. The transaction, for undisclosed terms, awaits approval from a Mexican regulator, the company said. A.I.G., which is seeking to repay loans within a government bailout valued at $182.5 billion, has disclosed deals raising about $6.7 billion. AIG Universal, which has 50 branches in central and northern Mexico, sells insurance and extends personal loans to about 50,000 customers.

American International Group, the bailed-out United States insurance company, announced Thursday that it had reached an agreement to reduce its debt with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by $25 billion.

Satyam Computer Services named Chander Prakash Gurnani, below, as its chief executive in the aftermath of an accounting scandal. Satyam, an outsourcing firm, has been bought by Tech Mahindra, which is working to reorganize the company. Mr. Gurnani, formerly Tech Mahindra’s head of international operations, replaces A. S. Murty, Satyam said in a statement. Subramaniam Durgashankar, formerly senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions at Mahindra & Mahindra, was appointed chief financial officer. Mr. Gurnani, 50, is in charge of reviving Satyam after a stock collapse prompted by an admission by its former chairman, B. Ramalinga Raju, that he overstated assets by more than $1 billion. Mr. Gurnani pledged to improve corporate governance and customer ties. A reorganization of the company will be announced within 48 hours, he said.
The Lloyds Banking Group plans to cut 270 jobs at its insurance and offshore operations, bringing to more than 4,450 the number of positions the bank has eliminated since April.

The Lloyds Banking Group plans to cut 270 jobs at its insurance and offshore operations, bringing to more than 4,450 the number of positions the bank has eliminated since April. The bank will eliminate jobs at its Channel Islands unit and its insurance division in Clevedon, western England, the bank said in a statement. Lloyds said it planned to create 70 posts in risk management, mostly in Edinburgh. The company has pledged to lower costs after the acquisition of HBOS in January created a bank with more than 3,000 branches and a 28 percent share of Britain’s mortgage market. Lloyds, now 43 percent government-owned, is seeking to save more than £1.5 billion ($2.5 billion) by 2011.

On the first American orbital space mission in 1962, John H. Glenn Jr. was allowed to bring two pounds of personal effects aboard Friendship 7. He packed a St. Christopher medal, other good luck charms from friends and a 35-millimeter Ansco Autoset by Minolta that he had purchased near the launch site. Just minutes after reaching orbit, he photographed - in soft focus - the glowing surface of planet Earth, on grainy Eastmancolor negative film.

The Jonas Brothers have scored their second No. 1 on the Billboard album chart with “Lines, Vines and Trying Times” (Hollywood), which had first-week sales of 247,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It bumped last week’s chart-topper, the Black Eyed Peas’ “E.N.D.” (Interscope), to No. 2, with 148,000 in sales, a 51 percent drop. The Dave Matthews Band’s “Big Whiskey and the GrooGrux King” (RCA) is No. 3 with 88,000, Eminem’s “Relapse” (Interscope) is No. 4 with 72,000, and Incubus’s new greatest-hits collection, “Monuments and Melodies” (Epic) is fifth with 70,000. Lady Gaga continues her remarkable four-month run in the Top 10 with “The Fame” (Interscope). It holds at No. 6 with 47,000 in sales, bringing the album’s 34-week sales total to just less than 1.1 million.

If you missed this winter’s benefit readings of “Love, Loss, and What I Wore” but still want to spend an evening with an eclectic company of women telling stories about life and clothing, the show will receive an Off Broadway run at the Westside Theater, its publicists announced. The show, written by the sisters Nora, right top, and Delia Ephron, right below, and adapted from the memoir by Ilene Beckerman, will run with three different five-member casts who will perform in four-week cycles. The cast will include Kristin Chenoweth, Tyne Daly, Samantha Bee, Mary Louise Wilson, Rosie O’Donnell, Katie Finneran and Rita Wilson. The show, produced by Daryl Roth, is scheduled to begin previews on Sept. 21 with a opening on Oct. 1. ... Billy Crystal will take his one-man show, “700 Sundays,” on a national tour in the fall, the show’s publicists announced. The show, about Mr. Crystal’s upbringing in suburban Long Beach, N.Y., will begin a six-city tour at the National Theater in Washington on Sept. 8. ... Will Chase (of Broadway’s “Rent” and “The Full Monty”) will join the cast of the Broadway musical “Billy Elliot,” in the role of Tony, Billy’s older brother. Mr. Chase is scheduled to begin performances on July 7.

The Virgin Mobile Festival in Maryland is going free. Blink-182, Franz Ferdinand, Girl Talk, the Hold Steady, Public Enemy, the National and Weezer, above, with Rivers Cuomo, will be among the acts for the fourth annual event, on Aug. 30 at the Merriweather Post Pavilion in Columbia. (In previous years it has taken place in Baltimore.) Tickets — 35,000 for the show, with a maximum of two per customer — will become available Saturday at 10 a.m at ticketmaster.com, but Virgin Mobile customers and previous festival attendees will have first crack, on Thursday and Friday. Tickets have no surcharges if picked up at the pavilion or at the 9:30 Club in Washington, but it will cost $5 an order to have them mailed. Information is at virginmobilefestival.com.

A Harvard-based children’s advocacy group is stepping up its confrontation with movie studios over how PG-13 films are marketed. Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood on Wednesday sent a letter to the Federal Trade Commission demanding that the government ensure that films rated PG-13 by the Motion Picture Association of America are not marketed to children younger than 13. The organization said that a push for self-regulation, in which the movie industry was to address concerns over the marketing of films containing sexual references and violence, had failed. The advocacy group is particularly concerned about marketing through fast-food toy giveaways and the sale of licensed merchandise. Between March 17 and June 14 the group counted 2,734 commercials for four PG-13-rated films, their licensed toys and related fast-food promotions. A representative for the Federal Trade Commission could not be immediately reached for comment. In a statement the motion-picture association said it “takes seriously its role of ensuring that ads that run during children’s programming are appropriately placed.”.

The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts announced on Wednesday its schedule for a five-month festival celebrating the role that the performing arts played in the decline of communism in Europe. The festival, Performing Revolution in Central and Eastern Europe, will run Nov. 6 through March 31, and feature performances, exhibitions, film screenings, readings and other events, its organizers said. More information is at performingrevolution.org.

The Ohio Theater will remain at its longtime SoHo home through August 2010. The highly regarded institution, which has helped push theater forward in New York for more than two decades, on Wednesday signed a 14-month lease with Zar Property NY, which acquired the building at 66 Wooster Street last year. “It was important for me to get another whole season,” said the playwright and director Robert Lyons, who has run the Ohio since 1988 and in 1994 founded the Soho Think Tank, a producing entity. He had signed a one-year lease in January, with a mutual opt-out clause for June. The new lease, he said, provides a more realistic time in which to plan and execute his next move — whatever that may be. “There is virtually no chance I’m going to shut down Soho Think Tank,” he said. “But I think it’s possible the Ohio Theater will not live beyond this physical space.”.

ALLEN--Betty. The Board of Directors, artists and staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center note with sorrow the passing of Betty Allen, an esteemed member of the Board from 1988 to 2007, when she was named Trustee Emerita. The Society gratefully acknowledges that it was Betty who created the Education Department of CMS, and served as Chairman of the Education Committee for many years. Her devotion to establishing and promoting programs that would bring chamber music to schools in all five boroughs resulted in thousands of grade school children experiencing this great art, usually for the first time in their lives. Her determination to enrich the general understanding of chamber music brought about an extensive set of programs that have benefitted families, middle and high school students and adults. Her unwavering energies and clear-sighted vision for a world infused with music guided and inspired everyone in our institution. She was also a frequent presence in our concert hall, and we will miss her deeply. We extend heartfelt sympathies to her husband Edward Lee II, and her children Anthony and Juliana. Peter Frelinghuysen, Chairman David Finckel and Wu Han, Artistic Directors Norma Hurlburt, Executive Director

LEE--Cynthia Ann, 59, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died on June 18, 2009 in New York City. Daughter to the late Sue and Wing Mark, Cynthia graduated with a B.A. SUNY Stony Brook, M.Ed. Boston College, and M.S. Tufts University. Cynthia is survived by her husband of 30 years Richard, daughter Samantha, brothers Clifton and Leighton and was the beloved sister-in-law and aunt to many nieces and nephews. She will be remembered for her easy smile, warmth, unconventional and amusing conversations, passion for math, crosswords, travel, and her treasured teddy bear collection. Cynthia was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave., NYC, June 26 from 2-4 and 5-7:30. Donations appreciated at www.mskcc.org

SEIDEL--William K.,suddenly on May 31, 2009 in Varna, Bulgaria. His complete enjoyment of life and extensive travel leaves a huge footprint of love and loss all over the world. His family and many friends will miss him dearly. A Memorial Mass to be held Sts Cyril & Methodius, 125 Half Hollow Road, Deer Park, NY, Friday, June 26, 11:15am.

ALLEN--Betty. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and esteemed colleague, Betty Allen. Betty was an extraordinary artist and an inspirational leader who enjoyed a very special relationship with Carnegie Hall for more than half a century, performing at Carnegie Hall 54 times over a 47-year span, and serving the Hall as a Trustee beginning in 1980 and as an Honorary Trustee since 2005. All of us at Carnegie Hall have greatly valued Betty's presence in our lives, and we will always remember her for her genuine warmth, good natured humor, and consummate grace. We express our deep and heartfelt condolences to her husband, Ritten Edward Lee III; to her two children, Anthony Edward Lee and Juliana Catherine Hogue Lee; and to her three grandchildren: Brittany, Anthony, and Aaron Lee. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

The season premiere of NBC's ''America's Got Talent,'' sibling of the British reality series that gave the world Susan Boyle, attracted 11.3 million viewers on Tuesday night, according to Nielsen's estimates. Those numbers were down by about 1.5 million from last year's debut. Viewership was far lower for the NBC series ''I'm a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!'' (4.3 million) and a new ABC celebrity sports competition, ''The Superstars'' (4.3 million). CBS edged just ahead of NBC as the night's most-watched network over all, with a lineup of mostly repeats including ''NCIS'' (10.9 million) and ''The Mentalist'' (9.1 million). ABC ranked a distant third, ahead of fourth-place Fox.

President Nicolas Sarkozy assembled his new cabinet on Wednesday after a ministerial shake-up late Tuesday. The shuffling was the second since Mr. Sarkozy was elected in 2007. In total, nine ministers changed jobs, eight new officials were appointed and eight others were cut. The changes were more wide-ranging than expected, although Prime Minister François Fillon stayed in his job and incumbents were not shifted from crucial international and financial posts, including budget, environment, foreign affairs and defense. Luc Chatel, Mr. Sarkozy's spokesman, who moved from industry to become education minister, said Wednesday that the president ''really urged them to be reformers, as it's on this basis that the French people will judge us.''

LAY--Opal, on June 24th, beloved wife of the late J. Preston, loving mother of Joan Wright, Preston Lay, Kenneth Lay (Toi), sister of Albert and the late (Norma), and Raymond Jameison (Jean), grandmother of Steve Wright (Cheray), Janine Wright, Tyese Lay and Brook Lay, great-grandmother of Janelle, Jadon, Jordan Melecio, Travis, Damon Wright, Julian Lay and Tristan Leonard, aunt of Timothy, Yvonne, Doreen and Yvette Jameison, and a host of nieces and nephews. A native New Yorker for 86 years before moving to New Jersey. She worked at Royal Globe Insurance Co. as a statistical clerk in lower Manhattan for 30 years. She enjoyed long walks, cooking holiday dinners and going to the movies. Family will receive Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell in (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, 10am, St. Paul the Apostle, interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association of Greater New Jersey Chapter, 400 Morris Ave., Suite 251, Denville, NJ 07834, or online at www.alznj.org

COOPER--David, age 49, of Roslyn Heights, NY passed away on June 23, 2009. It's hard to make a play that's both scalding and beautiful, but Kristin Newbom's ''Telethon'' at the Ohio Theater qualifies, especially in the pitch-perfect staging it is being given by Clubbed Thumb to close its Summerworks festival. Ms. Newbom is in delicate territory with this blazingly original look at a group home for adults with physical and intellectual disabilities: a playwright asks an audience to laugh at people in wheelchairs at her own peril. But instead of mocking or exploiting the disabled characters, she does them a tremendous service by treating them as real people, no kid gloves necessary.
BERRY--Fr. Thomas: CoT Member. Your life and Work will continue to Inspire us all. Board of Trustees & Staff Temple of Understanding

LEATHAM--John T. Anderson, SC, age 72, died June 19, 2009 after a long illness. Born on July 4, 1936 in Chicago, IL, Jack was a graduate of Lawrence University. He served in the United States Air Force as a 1st Lieutenant and was awarded the Air Force Commendation Medal. After retiring from the service he joined the Continental Illinois Bank as a commercial lending officer. In 1968 he became Treasurer, VP-Finance for Leasco Data Processing Equipment Corp., which later became Reliance Group. He left Reliance as Executive Vice President to take over management of Medserco, Inc., an HMO management company. He continued to work in the health care industry until 1998 when he became a full-time consultant with the Common Fund. He retired in 2002. Mr. Leatham served as Director of International Capital Equipment Ltd., Vice- Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. Lukes School (New Canaan, CT), Director and Investor of ORI, Inc., and provided consulting services to the Department of Defense. He served as a Director and Member of SCHUUL's Executive Committee, an off-shore captive reinsurance company. He served on the National Board of Reading Is Fundamental. In addition, he served on the Board of Trustees of Lawrence University for many years and as Chairman of the Board from 1990-1992. He served on the Board of Trustees of the Common Fund for years and as Chairman of the Board of Common Fund Capital. Mr. Leatham is survived by his wife, Sheila Andersen Leatham of Anderson, SC; children Betsy LaFontaine (Jim) of Beverly, MA; Lisa Mason (Bill) of Darien, CT; John Leatham (Susan) of Anderson, SC; Bronwen Gay Dingeman (Jamie) of Grosse Pointe Farms, MI; and Douglas Leatham; brothers Jim Leatham of Ephraim, WI; and Jerry Leatham (Kate) of Chicago, IL; ten grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. He will be remembered as a loving husband, father and friend. Thy will be done. A memorial will be planned at a later date.

Peter Robbins, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert Sirota, President

For one day, users of Windows XP, Windows Vista or Windows 7 could download a beta version of Microsoft Security Essentials, its free service to fight malware like viruses. But on Wednesday, 24 hours after releasing the beta, Microsoft stopped allowing the downloads, having reached its cap of 75,000 beta downloads in a given market. A final version will be available by year-end.

It was exactly three years ago, on June 25, 2006, that Samsung shook up the home entertainment category by shipping the industry's first Blu-ray disc player, the BD-P1000. The price was $1,000, a princely sum in those days. Today, that's still a lot of money.

The threat of a breakaway Formula One series was ended Wednesday after the eight dissident teams and the International Automobile Federation, the sport's governing body, came to an agreement over the sport's future. Max Mosley, the federation's embattled president, said he would not seek re-election when his fourth term ends in October. Mosley, team representatives and Bernie Ecclestone, the sport's promoter, met overnight Tuesday to lay out terms to avoid a breakaway series that 8 of the 10 Formula One teams had threatened to start June 18 after disputing Mosley's attempts to impose budget caps.

ISHAM--Heyward, died June 18 of cardiac arrest, at 82 years of age. Mr. Isham was born in New York City, attended Phillips Academy, earned his BA from Yale and studied at Columbia University's Russian institute in Garmisch, Germany. Mr. Isham had a long and distinguished career in the U.S. State Department, beginning in 1950 with the U.S. Mission in Berlin serving under U.S. High Commissioner John McCloy and rising to Ambassador to Haiti and Assistant Secretary of State and Director of the Office for Combating Terrorism. Mr. Isham also served in the US Embassy in Moscow under Ambassador Charles Bohlen, during the height of the Cold War and US Consulate in Hong Kong where he was one of the first to recognize the emerging Sino-Soviet rift. In 1971-1972 Mr. Isham served as Deputy and Chief of the US Delegation to the Paris Talks on Vietnam negotiating directly with the North Vietnamese which resulted in the Paris Peace Accords signed on January 17, 1973 ending more than 10 years of direct US military involvement in Vietnam. Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger said of Mr. Isham's work, "He made a tremendous contribution." In retirement Mr. Isham became a senior editor at Doubleday publishing the memoirs of Andrei Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister during the more tense time of the cold war and authored two important books in 1995 and in 2001 introducing new Russian writers to the world. In 1990 Mr. Isham became Vice President and Ambassador-in-Residence at the East-West Institute in New York. For the past 15 years, the Ishams' principal home has been in Sagapon- ack where he was a known and loved member of the community. Mr. Isham is survived by his wife of 59 years, the noted artist Sheila Eaton Isham, and two sons Christopher E. Isham, Vice President and Washington Bureau Chief for CBS News, and Ralph H. Isham, Managing Partner, GH Venture Partners, LLC in New York City and nine grandchildren. His daughter Sandra Isham Vreeland died in 1996. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Hopital Albert Schweitzer Haiti, PO Box 81046, Pittsburgh, PA 15217 or visit: www.hashaiti.org

The low-cost, supersimple Flip video cameras are a breakout hit, with more than two million sold since 2007, and the Flip remains a top seller in 2009. Pentax adds to the lineup of swimming snap-shooters with its new Optio W80, which can withstand a dunk off the deep end down to 16 feet. It can shoot underwater photos and high-definition video for up to two hours, according to its maker. The $300 Optio W80 is also ruggedized to handle dust, freezing temperatures down to 14 degrees Fahrenheit and drops of up to three feet.

According to a report released last week by the market researcher DisplaySearch, LCD panels will not show the price erosion that everyone has come to expect for the holidays. TV manufacturers are introducing some sexy new features, like LED-lighted TVs and 120Hz and 240Hz technology, to persuade consumers to pay more. Another factor driving up prices is the cost of the glass, which has risen as TV demand grows in China.

BUTCHER--Susan Elizabeth, November 21, 1960 to April 15, 2009. A light did indeed go out in Santa Fe, when architect and designer Susan Elizabeth Butcher died at her home in Galisteo, N.M. on April 15 at age 48 after a long, courageous battle with cancer, during which she continued her grand humor, her full and contagious laugh and her passion for visiting with friends. Her husband, Henry, never wavered in her difficult care and was always beside her. A 1978 graduate of Sandia High School, she spent her junior year in France as a foreign exchange student. While studying ballet with Lucy Hayden at the Hayden School of Ballet for 12 years, Susan became an accomplished ballet student, a discipline in which she took great pride. A native of Albuquerque, N.M., Susan earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in architecture from Princeton University in 1983 and a Master's of Architecture cum laude from Princeton in 1987. Her talent and sophistication were apparent in her student work. Like Susan herself, her design work and drawings were elegant, delicate, precise, and graceful. She had the confidence and aesthetic vision to find the perfect balance of design elements that made her projects both tasteful and unique. She began her career as a designer at Hardy, Holtzman, Pfeiffer Associates in New York in 1980. While at Hardy, Holtzman, she worked on the feasibility study for the redesign of the Grand Central Terminal. In June, 1983 Susan was hired as a designer by award winning architect Michael Graves in Princeton, and rose to Director of Interiors before leaving in September 1990. Her projects at Graves included the Walt Disney World Swan and Dolphin Hotels, both receiving the AIA Mid-Florida Chapter Design Award, and the Aventine Hyatt Hotel in La Jolla, California. She was also involved in the firm's design work on the Humana Corporate Headquarters in Louisville, KY. and the Emory University Museum of Modern Art in Atlanta, which were recipients of the prestigious AIA National Award. She is acknowledged as a Project Assistant in Grave's book Michael Graves Buildings and Projects 1982-1989. After leaving Graves' firm, Susan served as Director of Architectural Design for Tishman Construction Corp. of New York from 1990-91. While at Tishman she worked on the Chicago Sheraton and the Rio Mar Resort in Puerto Rico. The founder of Susan Butcher Design, Susan was known for her interior design work on hotels, restaurants, and museums, as well as residences. One of her collaborators was her husband, designer Henry Noestheden. She created her eponymous design firm in 1991 in New Mexico where she was a registered Architect. Her major projects included interior design work for the Eldorado Hotel and the Inn of the Anasazi, both in Santa Fe, as well as the Four Seasons, Resort in Nevis, West Indies, The Fairmont at the Plaza in Kansas City, Missouri, and the Westin Hotel in Detroit. Works still in progress were a large vacation home in Anquilla, a mountain home in Vail, Colorado, and a three house ranch complex in Marfa, Texas. "In addition to her passion for architecture, design, and fashion, Susan loved to cook, and even as a student would entertain friends with delicious and beautiful meals. Whether it was an impromptu dinner, or her wedding celebration with Henry, Susan created memorable events where her attention to detail made everyone feel welcome and special. Susan's witty perspective helped her friends and colleagues cope with the pressure of deadlines both in graduate school and the office. But her humor didn't hide her serious approach to her design work, and her solid commitment to her friends." (Nancy Clayton, AIA). "I respected her intelligence, admired her achievements as a professional and was humbled by her generosity, kindness and consideration as a friend. She did touch my life and made a difference in who I am." (designer and childhood friend, Eric Montoya.) Susan is survived by her husband Henry Noestheden, her parents Barry Miller and Elizabeth Anne Butcher of Albuquerque, and two brothers, William Robert Butcher and partner Craig W. Thomsen of Portland, Ore., and James Douglas Butcher, wife Crystal Montgomery Butcher and their three children Anastasia Michelle, Cameron James and Nathan Montgomery. Susan's life will be celebrated on June 27 at 1 p.m. at Galisteo. Guests are asked to RSVP and receive further directions by e-mail to jl@sbdsf.com or by calling Susan Butcher Design at (505) 982-7648. A. scholarship in Susan's memory is being established at the University of Cincinnati, where she mentored Interior Design students, and where her own mentor, Michael Graves, holds an Honorary Doctorate Degree. For those wishing to contribute, further details of the fund will be available at the memorial or by calling Susan Butcher Design at (505) 982-7648. "And ever has it been said that love knows not its own depth until the hour of separation." (The Prophet, Gibran Kahlil).

BIEDERMAN--Morris. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale note with profound sadness the loss of Morris Biederman, who was a stalwart member of the Home's Board of Directors for more than sixty years and also served as the Home's treasurer. It was his vision and fortitude to secure our incredible Riverdale campus which led to the purchase of the Hebrew Home's current property almost 60 years ago. His quiet, modest and sincere leadership were instrumental to the success of the Hebrew Home throughout his tenure. His generosity helped create the Esther and Morris Biederman Library at the Hebrew Home, a facility which he and his beloved late wife Esther worked tirelessly to create. We will sorely miss his wonderful sense of humor, warmth, intelligence and friendship. He was an integral member of the Hebrew Home community and spread joy to all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Greenberg and Biederman families which include his devoted cousins, nieces and nephews. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO
O'BRIEN--Lois. Time passes but our love for you never changes. Rest well. Love, Jack and Jeremiah

BIEDERMAN--Morris E.,loving and devoted husband of the late Esther (Grabelsky) Biederman passed away peacefully in New York City on June 23, 2009 at the venerable age of 102. Morris was born in Poland in 1907 and moved to the US with his family at age 3. He was the devoted and loving son of the late Jacob and Ana (Weber) Biederman and loving brother of the late Solomon, Sarah, and Jerry Biederman. Morris was the founding partner of the accounting firm Biederman, Greenwald, Kresch, and Gerbasi. He was treasurer emeritus of the Hebrew Home in Riverdale New York, and was instrumental in moving the Hebrew Home to its present beautiful location on the banks of the Hudson River. Morris was a WWII Army veteran having served in Europe. He was a proud graduate of New York University. Morris was also an avid golfer. Most of all Morris was devoted to his wife Esther and to the entire family including nephews Neil Greenberg, Michael Biederman, Stephen and Robert Mitchell, niece Irene Glasser, sister-in-law Irma Mitchell and many great and great-great nephews and nieces. Morris was devoted to his family in France that includes Blanka Goldberg, Inka Weber, Simon Weber, Beatrice Rotenberg, their families, and the late Adam Weber. Morris also leaves behind his loyal group of friends including Lillian Krell, Robert Kresch, Nicholas Gerbasi, and Daniel Reingold, Our family thanks the ElderServe home health aides Nancy Odoom and Felicia Azubea for their devotion and kindness to Morris and Esther. We will always admire Morris's sharp mind, humor, generosity, and interest in all of life throughout his 102 years. Funeral will be at Cedar Park Cemetery, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, New Jersey at 1 pm Friday, June 26, 2009.
Visitors to Orchard Beach in the Bronx were greeted by dark clouds and rain on Wednesday. More than nine inches of rain has fallen in the city in the last month.

GOLDEN--Judy, loving mother of Robert, Liz and Danny died peacefully in her 93rd year on June 24th in New York City. She was a devoted grandmother to Eric, Matthew, Danny, Rachel, Katie and Ellery, an adoring mother-in-law to Steven, Kerry, Konrad, Lori, and the late Ray Reider Golden, and a wonderful aunt to her nieces, Judy, Ann and Louise. Though she faced significant adversity in her life, her husband, Monroe, died when she was 43, and chronic physical challenges, she contributed to the political and artistic life of her community. After World War II, she was involved with the civil rights movement and progressive politics. She was a member of the Congress of Racial Equality, Women Strike for Peace, and spearheaded Allard Lowenstein's congressional campaign in the Five Towns on Long Island. She realized her lifelong dream in November, when she voted for Obama and watched with sheer joy as he won the presidential election. Judy was a major supporter of contemporary artists, responsible for bringing major artists from New York to the Five Towns Music & Arts Foundation, and worked at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery and the Martin Gordon Gallery in New York. When she moved to New York City in 1987, she volunteered weekly until late last year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and at the Whitney Museum. She had an uncanny ability of attracting people younger than herself because of her values and spirit. She inspired all of us to live our lives with integrity, commitment and joy. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Studio Museum of Harlem. Funeral service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City on Friday, June 26 at 11:45am. Her life was a blessing.

A TRIP to the High Line, a ribbon of greenery on a former elevated rail line at the western rim of Manhattan, can be a test of patience, to be sure. ''I can't believe you have to wait on line to get into a park,'' said a visitor, Kristina Horton (in the gray trilby, bottom). ''Only in New York.'' But Ms. Horton's mood brightened as she settled into a redwood recliner looking out toward the Hudson. ''You can see tall ships from here!'' she exclaimed. Others on a recent Sunday used the new park as an improvised catwalk, showing off their casual best. Standish Lee (left) ducked out of the late-day sun beneath a gray cloche. Arianne Lapidus (right) swung an outsize tote that complemented her flowery tunic. ''This place is so cool,'' Ms. Lapidus said as her companion chimed in, ''It's everybody's communal rooftop garden.''

A postseason of improbable victories and late magic ended glumly for Texas at the most hurtful time, in the final game of the College World Series. After rallying from an early four-run deficit, the Longhorns disintegrated in a sloppy five-run sixth inning, boosting Louisiana State to an 11-4 victory in Game 3 of the C.W.S. finals at Rosenblatt Stadium. A Texas throwing error, a passed ball and two hit batsmen led to four unearned runs as L.S.U. won its sixth national championship, all since 1991, and its first under Coach Paul Mainieri.

WEEKEND A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday noted that a settlement had been reached in a lawsuit between Karen Kristal and the estate of her late ex-husband, Hilly Kristal, founder of the club CBGB. The report said that Ms. Kristal had said that she was the rightful owner of the club and that she said that she had been tricked into signing the business over to Mr. Kristal. While the first filing against the estate said Ms. Kristal had been ''talked into executing the contract'' and noted that she had memory problems, a subsequent filing left open the possibility that she did not sign and said that if she had signed she had been duped. Ms. Kristal says that she did not sign the document and that she has never said that she had signed it.

BLITZER--Jeremiah, died June 23, 2009. He was 82 years old. He passed away peacefully while listening to classical music, a major interest during his life. His devoted nephew, Paul Thomas, was at his side. Jerry attended the City and Country School in New York City, The Fieldston School in Riverdale, New York and Bard College, Anondale-on-Hudson, New York. He was the author with Werner Renberg of "Making Money with Mutual Funds," John Wiley and Sons, 1988. Jerry was active in supporting the education of the less fortunate through his friendship with the leaders of the West Side School, New York City and with Fern Kahn, Dean of Continuing Education, Bank Street College of Education. He is survived by William F. Blitzer, his brother; Judith Blitzer, his sister-in-law; Nancy M. Blitzer, his sister-in-law; Daniel L. Blitzer and Jonathan B. Blitzer, his nephews and Emily B. Williams, his niece. A memorial service is planned.

UNTIL recently, it wouldn't have occurred to me that gardening would be a popular pastime for the totalitarian set. But a droll little footnote in a recent biography of Josef Vissarionovich Djugashvili -- you can call him Stalin -- set me straight. Or perhaps I should say, it re-educated me. In ''Young Stalin,'' the author Simon Sebag Montefiore travels back to the wild streets of Tbilisi, Georgia, to uncover Stalin the gangster, the extortionist, the bank robber, the poet and the street operator. The biographer's bold ambition is to suggest how this cobbler's son and onetime seminarian could grow up to become perhaps the century's defining dictator. Oh, and incidentally, also an avid gardener.

TWO million Americans ride their bikes to work, says Transportation Alternatives, a New York City-based advocate for biking, walking and public transit; bike commuting in New York City grew 35 percent from 2007 to 2008. And with full-size cycles cumbersome (or forbidden) in apartments, office buildings and subways, folding bikes have become the vehicle of choice for many. ''In 2000, people would stare at you on a folding bike,'' said Hannah Borgeson of Bike New York, which leads the annual Five Boro Bike Tour. ''Now, when you're out riding on the Greenway, practically every third bike is a folding bike.''

All week I’ve been salivating over the delicious vegetable pies featured in this week’s Recipes for Health. I’d prefer to find someone to cook them for me, but Martha Rose Shulman insists they aren’t difficult to make.

The collected edition of “Final Crisis,” the latest event mini-series from DC Comics, tops the hardcover list this week. The story, written by Grant Morrison, was presented as “the day evil wins,” even though we know, c’mon, the heroes are going to be victorious in the end. “Final Crisis” features the return of a long-dead hero, the death of another and a whole lot of parallel earths, where, say, Batman is a vampire; Superman’s rocket landed in the Soviet Union; or Wonder Woman is a villain known as Superwoman. No one handles those endless possibilities better than Mr. Morrison, as he proves again in “Final Crisis” (particularly in the final issue in the collected edition) and in the two-part series “Superman Beyond,” which is wisely included in the hardcover. A peek at some pages from the comic “Final Crisis” is available here. And for a hint at what Mr. Morrison has planned next for the multiverse, click here.

LONDON — And on Thursday I bore witness to man’s inhumanity to animals. I mean, I think that was what I was doing. Does a man having sex with a cat qualify as animal abuse if the cat is the initiator and has a good time? There are many instances of such species-crossing encounters, described with biological exactness, in “Grasses of a Thousand Colors,” Wallace Shawn’s new play at the Royal Court Theater. But now that I think about it, it’s not really fair to use that question to begin a discussion of a cerebral, quasi-pornographic work that is at heart deeply moralistic, since the judgments it passes on its dubious, phallocentric hero aren’t really about his willingness to copulate with cats. I mean, I guess you could say that in symbolic terms.

In the groundbreaking 1983 video for "Thriller," Michael Jackson morphs from the perennial innocent with the angelic voice to a full-flegded freakazoid fashion zombie clad in red leather and armed with an arsenal of dance moves. We may not have known it then, but we were seeing his life flash before our eyes. His personal demons aside, Jackson was the embodiment of fashion's perpetual Peter Pan fantasies. When it came to style, the guy never grew - or gave - up. Over the years, he channeled everyone from Klaus Nomi to Captain Stubing; he dabbled in transvestism and robotics, military paraphernalia and S&M. And all of these looks were custom-made for him, making him perhaps the world's single biggest couture client for over two decades. In recent years, he went ready-to-wear - Balmain, Rick Owens, Givenchy - a sign of the times perhaps, but a weird one considering that all of these designers in some way or another owe him a huge stylistic debt. (Man in the Mirror indeed.) Jackson's love of accessories - gloves, white socks, wrestling belts, military insignias - was legend; in anticipation of his coming tour, he had commissioned a series of masks from the downtown artist Desi Santiago (whose work is now on display at Terence Koh's Asia Song Society). In slide shows above and below, The Moment recaps some of Jackson's more memorable looks, from Bad to Dangerous to quite simply Off the Wall.

Over the course of a six-decade career, the German-born photographer Fritz Henle (1909-1993) turned his twin-lens Rolleiflex on a wide variety of subjects, from fishermen in Hawaii to Frida Kahlo in Mexico. The Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas in Austin is currently showing more than 100 of his images (the center has over 1,300 Henle prints in their archives) in the exhibition "In Search of Beauty," through Aug. 2. An early contributor to Life Magazine, Henle was sent to Paris on assignment for two weeks in the summer of 1938 to capture the daily life of the city. He came back with what he thought was a treasure trove of images, but Life's photo department felt otherwise and decided not to publish the work. But in 1944, when General Charles de Gaulle marched through Paris, liberating the city, Helene Lazareff, the photo editor of The New York Times, called Henle looking for images of prewar Paris. Henle's pictures were quickly published in the Sunday Magazine to celebrate the end of the German occupation. Henle once said, "One thing an artist can do in this world is to remind people that there is so much beauty that you only have to see it." Fitting words for someone whose work captures such a wonderful sense of optimism.

Statistics don't lie, but they also don't always tell the whole truth. Take today's Roger Federer-Phillip Kohlschreiber match, won by Federer in four sets. The official match statistics -- tallied by IBM at Wimbledon -- are startlingly close in terms of winners, unforced errors and first-serve percentage, usually reliable indicators of who won and why. Federer hit 48 winners to Kohlschreiber's 51; Federer's first-serve percentage was 68 percent, just three points higher than his opponent's solid 65 percent; and they were virtually even in unforced errors, with Fed making 21 mistakes to Kohlschreiber's 20.

There aren't many reasons why anyone would want to spend extra time in an airport, but here's one: Jet Blue officially introduces its Live from T5 concert series at its new Kennedy Airport terminal today. At 5 p.m. on select Fridays from now until Nov. 25, the airline will provide a stage for some really interesting indie musical acts including Nicole Atkins (performing today), American Princes (July 3), Alberta Cross (July 10) and Justin Townes Earle (July 24). Jet Blue and its partner on the project, Superfly Productions, will also open the mike for aspiring bands, inviting them to submit an original song in an online contest. The public will decide the winners, who will play an acoustic set at the terminal in August. Go here for more information and a full schedule.

The Small Business Administration has once more turned to its stimulus-supplied toolbox in the effort to open up the blocked spigot of capital. (That's the S.B.A.'s toolbox metaphor, not The Agenda's. We've simply extended it.) On Wednesday the agency gently loosened lending restrictions (pdf) for its underrated 504 loan program. The new policy aims to improve a small company's cash flow by restructuring existing debt - but only if that firm borrows new money to expand. What's unclear is how many firms are brave enough in this economy to take the government up on the offer.

GOLDEN--Judy, loving mother of Robert, Liz and Danny died peacefully in her 93rd year on June 24th in New York City. She was a devoted grandmother to Eric, Matthew, Danny, Rachel, Katie, Amanda and Ellery, an adoring mother-in-law to Steven, Kerry, Konrad, Lori, and the late Ray Reider Golden, and a wonderful aunt to her nieces, Judy, Ann and Louise. Though she faced significant adversity in her life, her husband, Monroe, died when she was 43, and chronic physical challenges, she contributed to the political and artistic life of her community. After World War II, she was involved with the civil rights movement and progressive politics. She was a member of the Congress of Racial Equality, Women Strike for Peace, and spearheaded Allard Lowenstein's congressional campaign in the Five Towns on Long Island. She realized her lifelong dream in November, when she voted for Obama and watched with sheer joy as he won the presidential election. Judy was a major supporter of contemporary artists, responsible for bringing major artists from New York to the Five Towns Music & Arts Foundation, and worked at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery and the Martin Gordon Gallery in New York. When she moved to New York City in 1987, she volunteered weekly until late last year at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and at the Whitney Museum. She had an uncanny ability of attracting people younger than herself because of her values and spirit. She inspired all of us to live our lives with integrity, commitment and joy. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the Studio Museum of Harlem. Funeral service will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City on Friday, June 26 at 11:45am. Her life was a blessing.

SULLIVAN--Audrey Marie, of Bronxville, NY passed away on June 25th after a long battle with cancer. She was 76. She was the loving wife of Barry F. Sullivan for 53 years, who survives, as well as the devoted mother of their five children, Barry Jr., Gerald, Mariellen, Scott and John. The greatest joy in her life was being the grandmother of 17 grandkids, who were always an active part of her life right up until it was time to go home to God. She was a wonderful friend to all, and for those of us who were lucky enough to be with her for all these years, we were blessed. For all of you who were her friends, she felt just as lucky to have you. There will be a wake at the Fred H. McGrath & Son funeral home, Bronxville, 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Monday, June 29 at 10am.

FREEDMAN--Robert N. Born on June 28th, 1922 in New York and died June 23rd, 2009 in Boca Raton, FL with his family by his side. Robert lived a remarkable life. As an engineer, artist, inventor, and entrepreneur he left an indelible impression on all who knew him. He attended Music and Art High School, the University of Lausanne, and studied engineering at Cooper Union. He was admired by all for his keen sense of humor, optimism, and intelligence. Cherished husband of 60 years to Estelle. Adored father of Elise (Steven) and Larry (Kathy). Beloved grandfather of Justin, Adam, Alison, Emily, and Natalie. Loving brother of Betty (Victor) and devoted uncle. Her served in the Army of the United States during WWII. We cannot measure the depths of our loss. Donations may be made to the Christopher and Dana Reeve Foundation.

That Fox is broadcasting ''Virtuality,'' a film meant to introduce a series it has not scheduled, on a Friday night in June -- one week before the Fourth of July -- carries with it the cruel weight of a live burial. While it ought to be said that ''Virtuality'' seems created to alienate any but the pointiest science-fiction fans (civilians might prefer the weekend backup on I-95 just outside New Haven), it is an impressively credentialed and stylish bit of television moviemaking, an exploration not merely of our practical dependence on technology but also of our psychological and nearly eroticized addiction to it. Through Ronald D. Moore, one of the writers and a chief force behind ''Battlestar Galactica,'' and Peter Berg, the director, the film maximizes its collaboration between Mr. Moore's blunt and distinctly masculine vision of a world careering toward apocalypse and the curvier intimacy of Mr. Berg's camera. His artfully melodramatic close-ups (the trademark of Mr. Berg's series ''Friday Night Lights'') are intended to remind us of all the fleshy emotion from which we absent ourselves when we choose to conduct our relationships at almost every level on screens.

HARRIGAN--Arthur W.,former Chief Financial Officer of the Western Electric Company and of International Paper Company, died on June 20, 2009, in Vero Beach, Florida, at the age of 90. Mr. Harrigan graduated from NYU in 1942 while serving in the US Navy, received his MBA from NYU in 1949 and, while employed at Western Electric, earned his PhD in Economics from the Stern School of NYU in 1959. During World War II he first served in Naval Intelligence and, after attending Supply Officers School at Harvard, saw sea duty as an officer on a supply ship carrying landing craft in the Pacific. He recalled the "cheers of the crew when the last B-29 returned from its mission." In 1947 he joined Western Electric, where he served as Comptroller, then Financial VP and, then until 1972 as CFO and a board member. In 1972, he joined International Paper as its CFO and a member of the board. After he retired in 1982, he taught business management courses at the Stern School. He married Margaret Marrin in 1941. During most of their married life, Margaret, who earned her Masters Degree in Social Work from Columbia University, worked as a family counselor, and became a highly sought-after speaker on these subjects. They were a very close couple who excelled at combining family life with two careers long before this life pattern became common. They were happily married for fifty-three years until her death in 1994. Mr. Harrigan was an exceptionally thoughtful, kind and generous man who steadfastly maintained these qualities in his business life as well as in his private life. He was liked and admired by his colleagues and loved by his family. He is survived by his daughter, Patricia Nadosy, of New York City, by his son, Arthur W. Harrigan, of Seattle, Washington, their spouses Peter Nadosy and Carol Wilder, and by four grandchildren, Meghan Magyar, Andrea and Lara Nadosy and Aaron Wilder. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated 10:00 a.m., Thursday, July 23, 2009 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, FL

STEVENS--Lynne. Activist and researcher in the field of violence against women, dies of cancer at 63. Lynne Stevens was Director of the Responding to Violence Against Women Program and an Assistant Professor at the Boston University School of Medicine, Department of Family Medicine. A psychotherapist in private practice in Manhattan for decades, Stevens specialized in improving services for victims of violence. Working with such groups as the International Planned Parenthood Federation/Western Hemisphere and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), she developed and implemented programs in many countries, including Nepal, Venezuela, Sri Lanka, Vietnam and Armenia. Educational materials that she developed have been widely distributed by UNFPA, the CDC, and state anti-violence programs, and been translated into a variety of languages. On moving to Boston University in 2005, she championed evaluating and strengthening services for victims of violence in a variety of settings, including the Family Medicine Department's ambulatory care clinic and other department practices, Manet Community Health Center, Boston University's student health services, and dental clinics. Dr. Larry Culpepper, Professor and Chair of the BU Department of Family Medicine noted, "Her activities led to the recognition of a problem with many silent victims, to its inclusion in medical curriculum, and to the development of clinical models of care. She had the rare qualities of seeing clearly the suffering others overlooked, and of inspiring colleagues to respond." As Stevens traveled in Asia, she fell in love with the bright beautiful fabrics worn by the local women. In 2007, she started designing and selling few-of-a-kind yoga bags under the company name Samadhi. She donated a percentage of profits to yogaHOPE, an organization providing free yoga programs for needy women and girls, where she was a volunteer teacher. Stevens served as a member of the boards of directors of domestic violence organizations the New York State Coalition Against Sexual Assault (NYSCASA), and then (after moving to Boston in 2005) Casa Myrna Vazquez, where she recently became Vice-President of the Board. Contributions can be made in her memory to Casa Myrna at POB 180019, Boston, Massachusetts 02218, or online at www.casamyrna.org. In 2006, Stevens and Deborah Maine, Professor of International Health at Boston University's School of Public Health, were married in Great Barrington, Massachusetts, honoring more than 20 years of love and laughter. Stevens is also survived by her sister, Wendy, of Vermont, her aunt, Sherrey Glickman of New Jersey, and other relatives. Memorial services are being planned in New York and Boston.

BIEDERMAN--Morris. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale note with profound sadness the loss of Morris Biederman, who was a stalwart member of the Home's Board of Directors for more than sixty years and also served as the Home's treasurer. It was his vision and fortitude to secure our incredible Riverdale campus which led to the purchase of the Hebrew Home's current property almost 60 years ago. His quiet, modest and sincere leadership were instrumental to the success of the Hebrew Home throughout his tenure. His generosity helped create the Esther and Morris Biederman Library at the Hebrew Home, a facility which he and his beloved late wife Esther worked tirelessly to create. We will sorely miss his wonderful sense of humor, warmth, intelligence and friendship. He was an integral member of the Hebrew Home community and spread joy to all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Greenberg and Biederman families which include his devoted cousins, nieces and nephews. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

KOCH--Richard H. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of our longtime friend and colleague Richard H. Koch. Dick served as General Counsel, Director of Administration and Secretary of the Museum from 1959-1979. He led the Cesar Pelli expansion and was instrumental in developing legislation which established the Trust for Cultural Resources which has helped MoMA and many other New York City cultural institutions to finance their expansions. MoMA is grateful for Dick's creativity in assisting the Museum in its early expansion efforts. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Joanne, their children and grandchildren. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

CONNETT--Eugene Virginius IV. On June 12, 2009, Eugene Virginius Connett IV, aka "The Kid", passed on. He was born to his proud parents, Eugene V. Connett III and Kathryn Elise Underhill Connett on a snowy morning on January 21, 1920 in South Orange, NJ. His advent was welcomed with open arms by his sister, Elise Migeon Connett. Eugene was privileged to attend St. Paul's School of Concord, NH, graduating in 1939. In the spring, he fished the chalk streams of England with his father, (who was an expert trout fisherman and distinguished author and owner of the Derrydale Press). He spent his autumns shooting with his father in duck blinds on the Chesapeake and the golden grasslands of North America. Immediately following his high school years, Mr. Connett attended Princeton as a 4th generation legacy, where he graduated with a degree in French Literature in 1942. There, he was a member of the Cottage Club and the Princeton Crew Team. With WWII in full swing in 1942, Mr. Connett enlisted as a first lieutenant in the Army Air Corps. His superb language skills were seen as a valuable asset and bought him a classified assignment with the O.S.S. in the Alsace-Lorraine region of France until 1945. Following the war, Connett returned home and took a position with David Ogilvy Associates in NYC, NY as a marketing executive. He met his future bride, Etheldred Slosson McGrew (of Geneva, NY) in an elevator and smitten with her willowy frame and winsome smile, wed her on April 29, 1950. The following spring, the happy couple was blessed with their first child, Stacey Migeon Connett (Spartz). Within the ensuing seven years, his daughters, (Bevan Brecount Connett Kinney and Kathryn Underhill Connett Loh) and his identical twin sons, (Eugene Virginius Connett V and Aubrey Fitzhugh Connett) had joined the family. Mr. Connett was an accomplished sailor who was familiar throughout the great South Bay of LI, NY, where the Connett family summered until the mid 1950's. In the 1960's, Mr. Connett established himself as a small boat racer's worst nightmare, competing around the harbors of Long Island Sound under the burgee of Riverside Yacht Club in Riverside, CT. In 1979, Eugene and his family relocated to Stonington, CT, where he assumed the distinguished status of M.P.S.O. and enjoyed a membership in the Wadawannuck Yacht Club in Stonington, CT. His professional accomplishments included attaining the Vice Presidency of the American Carpet Institute in NYC, NY and ownership of the world renowned Stonington Clothing Ltd., of Stonington, CT. By far, his greatest achievement was being a magnificent father, faithful friend and man of integrity. He was a lovely guy who led a sun-kissed life and was adored by all who knew him. Eugene Connett IV is survived by all his sons and daughters (above), their spouses and partners; Dan Kinney, Rick Loh, Lori Connett, Kim Connett and David Wolodko. He also leaves behind his handsome grandchildren; Matthew Perry, Eric, Mark and Stacey Loh, Emily Connett and Tommy and Andrew Connett, of whom he was unspeakably proud! Services will be held in his honor at Calvary Episcopal Church located at 27 Church Street, Stonington, CT. 06378 at 12:30pm on Sunday, June 28, 2009. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Visiting Nurse Association of Southeastern CT, 403 N. Frontage Rd., Waterford, CT. 06385.

9 P.M. (Science) BUILD IT BIGGER Houston, he's good to go! In this special ''Space Week'' episode, Danny Forster ventures behind the scenes of Mission Control and Cape Canaveral as he examines the Constellation Program, NASA's latest bold foray into the final frontier. The mission: to return to the moon, establish a permanent lunar base and then hop a spacecraft next door to Mars. Mr. Forster looks at the prototype for the new lunar rover; engineering strategies for launching rockets faster and more safely; underwater astronaut training; and preparations for the space shuttle Endeavor's final flights before it is retired after 30 years and more than 100 successful missions. And in what he called ''the coolest boyhood dream to come true thus far in my career,'' Mr. Forster, above right, with the Endeavor, gets to try his hand at piloting the space shuttle inside the official flight simulator. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE VIEW The psychic John Edward gives readings to the ladies and their audience, Joy Behar explores past lives, and Whoopi Goldberg looks at her tarot cards.

During World War II he first served in Naval Intelligence and, after attending Supply Officers School at Harvard, saw sea duty as an officer on a supply ship carrying landing craft in the Pacific. He recalled the "cheers of the crew when the last B-29 returned from its mission." In 1947 he joined Western Electric, where he served as Comptroller, then Financial Vice President and, then until 1972 as CFO and a board member. In 1972, he joined International Paper as its CFO and a member of the board. After he retired in 1982, he taught business management courses at the Stern School. He married Margaret Marrin in 1941. During most of their married life, Margaret, who earned her Masters Degree in Social Work from Columbia University, worked as a family counselor, and became a highly sought-after speaker on these subjects. They were a very close couple who excelled at combining family life with two careers long before this life pattern became common. RICHARDSSON--Richard Long, of Reykjavik Iceland and long time resident of Tuxedo Park, New York. June 24, 2009 of cancer. Mr. Richardsson received a PhD in economics from the University of Reykjavik, and served as a senior financial executive for Icelandic Airlines in both Stockholm, Sweden and New York, as well in the New York offices of The East Asiatic Company, and Douglas Gibbons-Hollyday & Ives, Inc. STAPLETON--Jane Fulton, died peacefully at home on Friday, June 19, 2009. Beloved wife of Benjamin F. Stapleton III and the mother of Benjamin F. Stapleton IV and Sarah F. Stapleton. Born on November 22, 1946, in Jackson, MI. A 1968 graduate of the University of Michigan. She moved to New York in 1972 and was married in 1976. In 1991 she became a docent at The Metropolitan Museum. Mrs. Stapleton was also an accomplished gardener at her home in Lakeville, CT. She was a friend and confidante to a wide array of people of all ages who loved her for her warmth and wit. All who knew her will miss her very much. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Education Department, St. Bernards School, New York, NY or Women's Support Services, Sharon, CT. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 29, at 5pm at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 E. 90th St.

BERLIND--Carolyn Ray (nee Gross), 68, on June 20, 2009, in her sleep, at her beloved home in Pound Ridge, NY. Carolyn was born September 4, 1940 in Dallas, TX, to Ann and Irvin Gross. The family soon moved to Glencoe, Ill and then to White Plains, NY where Carolyn and her sister Barbara were raised. Carolyn attended University of Michigan for three years, and subsequently graduated with honors from Hofstra University. In 1961 she and Jeffrey Berlind were married, and in 1975 they moved to Dix Hills, NY. Carolyn soon co-founded a retail business in Huntington, NY (Peticular Pet) that allowed her to work with exotic animals, one of her great passions. The business flourished, and was sold years later. In 1994 they moved to Pound Ridge, at which time Carolyn did pro bono consulting for a retail shop at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. Carolyn's life was marked by an intense interest in animals and flowering gardens, which she created in abundance at her home in Pound Ridge. Despite serious illnesses, she was a very involved grandmother and planned events with zeal and perfection, only slowing the pace as declining health dictated. She was a fighter extraordinaire, and valiantly battled several diseases, including the chronic pain inducing "small fiber neuropathy," emphysema and heart disease, to the end. Carolyn's amazing well spring of strength was her strong set of values and ethics, which guided her in all decisions. She treated all with kindness and equality, and always seized the opportunity to help others. Carolyn is survived by her husband Jeff, sons Chnoo, David and his wife Ayesha, sister Barbara, and five grandchildren, whom she loved with all her heart: Devon, Samantha, Stephan, Natalya and Shasha. Her laughter, smile, wisdom, spirited way and love lives on in all our hearts.

The fortnight-long poem that is Wimbledon rests today, a caesura that allows us to reflect on what has happened in the first week. Certainly the American qualifier Melanie Oudin's string of upsets after she barely escaped Roehampton has our attention. The slowness of the grass courts and the heavy ball are big topics, with recently retired players like Tim Henman musing aloud how his aggressive serve and volley game wouldn't work at today's Wimbledon. Andy Murray's sterling play, handling the pressure of Britain's hopes with a mixture of elan and Scottish toughness, is a story. And Venus and Serena Williams playing great doubles together, while marching through opposite halves of the singles draw, draws attention to the breadth of Wimbledon.

I was merely warming up, A. Neto, on the subject of Givenchy. It was late when I returned to the hotel, after some midnight scrambled eggs at the Flore following the Raf Simons show, and my thoughts were fresh and not entirely in order. You are not suggesting, A. Neto, that I be concerned about being banned from a fashion show, nor are you saying I should watch what I say. Nonetheless the possibility occurs to you simply because I have said something sharp about Tisci's collection. I have really said nothing. This was a lazy, pretentious, overwrought collection marked with the slight tear stain of Michael Jackson's legacy, since, according to Tisci, he was to make clothes for the pop star's concert series. If other designers, like John Galliano, were asked to make clothes for Jackson, we didn't hear from them. They had enough good sense not to say anything. Besides, many designers are usually involved with making clothes and accessories for a performer's tour.

To the Editor: Joe Nocera’s article “Seeing Provence from the Slow Lane” (June 14) on cycling reminded me of a lovely trip my husband and I took to the region. Using Arles as a base, we easily used buses and trains to reach Les Baux and Avignon, and had plenty of time for long walks. During a meal in Arles, we had an experience I call “Metropolitan Diary Provençal .” We had a view of the Roman arena and a cobalt sky, and across the alley two girls about 5 and 7 were playing. They had a paper crown, a glittery wand and a large faded cloth with a traditional print. They chattered. They sang. They danced. Acknowledging our enchanted faces, our waiter smiled and said: “Ah. Ici gentil carnaval!”Barbara Berman.

To the Editor: J. J. Goode’s “36 Hours: Research Triangle, N.C.” (June 14) claims that those familiar with the Met or Getty “might scoff at the relatively succinct collection at the North Carolina Museum of Art.” In the early ’70s I studied art history under Otto von Simson at Berlin’s Freie Universität. He regarded the North Carolina Museum of Art, above, as “a jewel of a small museum” and during his stints at Harvard made time for excursions to Raleigh. Don’t be fooled, y’all! Good things come in small packages.

Devoted father of Toni Hilton and Meri Halweil, father-in-law of Cliff and Ron and step-father of Kathy Wallack and Susan Sleppin. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer Rose, Brian and Erika Halweil, step-grandfather of Julie and Jamie and great-grandfather of Jacob, Maya, Caroline, Milla, Clio and Cyrus. He was a role model for living life to its fullest, had a grand life and he passed with no regrets. We will sorely miss you. Services Monday 11:45am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

WOODWARD--Woody, activist and community leader, died on June 13, 2009, of ovarian cancer, on the morning of Boston's Pride Parade. The image of Woody with her rainbow-colored mohawk has become synonymous with LGBT pride parades. She taught those around her to be true to themselves, to be proud of who they are, and to live without excuses. "You have to show up and be there for your community," she said. Donna Marie "Woody" Woodward was born in 1944 in Fall River, Massachusetts and graduated from University of Massachusetts Boston. Throughout her 64 years, she combined volunteerism with her passion for motorcycles, traveling over 300,000 miles in the US and six out of the seven continents of the world. To fund her travels, she worked as an archeologist, roofer, chimney sweep, mason, carpenter, limo driver, and English teacher at the Chengdu Institute in China. Woody was a founding member of Boston's Moving Violations Motorcycle Club and a member of New York City's Sirens Motorcycle Club and the Motor Maids. She was a dedicated rider for the Pony Express Rides, raising money for breast cancer research and working as a volunteer organizer for many causes including HIV/AIDS, women's shelters, and the arts. She leaves a trail of inspired friends, family and stories around the globe. She was deeply loved. Donations in her memory may be made to the Gynecologic Cancer Foundation (memo line: Adventure for the Cures--Woody Woodward), 230 West Monroe, Suite 2528, Chicago, IL 60606 www.firstgiving.com/woodywoodward
