MURASE--Dr. Kenji K. January 3, 1920 - June 2, 2009. Died peacefully in San Francisco, at age 89. Born in Parlier, CA to sharecroppers from Japan, Kenji was forced from UC Berkeley due to wartime incarceration of Japanese Americans, but eventually became the first American Fulbright Scholar to Japan. While earning a Ph.D. in social work from Columbia, he worked with clients in the Bowery flophouses, the Mobilization for Youth Program and, later, the American Friends Service Committee. During his long tenure at San Francisco State University School of Social Work, he expanded the field to include the needs of Asian American communities. Predeceased by wife Seiko of 42 years, he is survived by Emily Murase (Neal Taniguchi), Miriam Murase (Greg Zaharchuk), Geoffrey Murase (Christine Miyauchi), and five boisterous grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Nisei Student Relocation Commemorative Fund, 19 Scenic Dr., Portland, CT, 06480.

KUPER--lluminada Landa, Nicknamed "Lumi", died on June 17, 2009 at 87. Mrs. Landa, mother of Joseph C. Landa and Maria Luisa Rego Landa, was born in Oriente, Cuba on November 29, 1921. Her family migrated to New York where she married Jose "Pepe" Landa in 1951. In 1953, combining their talents, the Landas' began a business producing fine home furnishings and custom window treatments for top architects and interior designers of their day. Now a third generation business, Interiors by JC Landa, LLC continues the tradition of excellence as her son's work can be found in the most important house in the world, the Presidential White House in Washington, DC. Lumi Landa is survived by Joseph C. Landa and Maria L. Rego Landa and six grandchildren: Rebeca, Jennifer, Adrianna, Joseph F., Alex and Daniel

EVANS--Faye, born January 3, 1920 in Brooklyn, NY to Yetta and Joseph Furman. Faye was the youngest of five children, older siblings Samuel, Manny, Jack, and Sally are now all deceased. Faye grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Tilden H.S. She married William Evans in May 1942. During WWII she worked on an airplane assembly line while her husband served at the Panama Canal. After the war she and her husband Bill moved to Queens, NY where she raised her three children, Donald, Rene and Nina. She loved her Thursday canasta game and always prided herself in keeping the scores for the games because, as she would boast, "she used to be a bookkeeper and had such neat handwriting." Faye was a most loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. During the last days of her life, seeing a grandchild would always put a joyous look on her face. During the last seven years of her life she took absolute loving care of her beloved husband Bill to whom she was totally devoted. We all loved her so much and will miss her. Faye is survived by her husband Bill, son Donald Evans, New York, daughters Rene Benson, New Jersey and Nina Roth, New York, sons-in-law Phil Benson and Cary Roth, grandchildren Dani Tapper, Florida, Casey Wanderer, New York, Justen Roth and Kyle Roth, and great-grandchildren Sammi Tapper, Avery Tapper, Alex Tapper and Ryan Wanderer. Services will be held Monday, 10:30am at the grave site at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY.

LION--Stephan. Died at his home in Hillsboro Beach, Florida, on February 7th, 2009. Born in Munich, Germany in 1916, he fled to New York in the late 1930s. He pursued a lifelong love of art with passion, as the creator of fine art cultural programs for the Bicentennial, the City of New York, and the Metropolitan Opera, as a design entrepreneur, an advertising consultant, and as a devout collector. He is survived by his wife the former Irene Robertson; children Karina Lion of Solana Beach, California, Nicole Lion of Epe, the Netherlands, Ronald Lion of Aptos, California from his first wife Lilliane Litton of Washington, DC; grandchildren Marc, Alex, Rio, Satish; great-grandchild Luke.

THE BLUE-CHIP BROKER Ann Weintraub owns a boutique real estate agency in Greenwich Village, where she lives. Growing up in Peter Cooper Village, she aspired to be an actress and considered herself the black sheep in a family full of doctors. In 1982, after Ms. Weintraub spent several years trying to figure out what she might do professionally, a friend suggested she try selling real estate. She has been handling expensive apartments in neighborhoods downtown ever since. On the rare weekends she is not working with clients, Ms. Weintraub rides horses; she is learning the equestrian sport of dressage, which is sometimes referred to as ''horse ballet.'' EMILY WEINSTEIN Many of these apartments speak for themselves. When I have the privilege, and it is a privilege, to represent a special apartment -- say a penthouse apartment or something very exciting, very sexy, very beautiful -- the adrenaline is pumping. It's a high. They picked you, and this is your baby. I just have the privilege of opening the door and letting them show themselves off.

BERLIND--Carolyn Ray (nee Gross), 68, on June 20, 2009, in her sleep, at her beloved home in Pound Ridge, NY. Carolyn was born September 4, 1940 in Dallas, TX, to Ann and Irvin Gross. The family soon moved to Glencoe, Ill and then to White Plains, NY where Carolyn and her sister Barbara were raised. Carolyn attended University of Michigan for three years, and subsequently graduated with honors from Hofstra University. In 1961 she and Jeffrey Berlind were married, and in 1975 they moved to Dix Hills, NY. Carolyn soon co-founded a retail business in Huntington, NY (Peticular Pet) that allowed her to work with exotic animals, one of her great passions. The business flourished, and was sold years later. In 1994 they moved to Pound Ridge, at which time Carolyn did pro bono consulting for a retail shop at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center. Carolyn's life was marked by an intense interest in animals and flowering gardens, which she created in abundance at her home in Pound Ridge. Despite serious illnesses, she was a very involved grandmother and planned events with zeal and perfection, only slowing the pace as declining health dictated. She was a fighter extraordinaire, and valiantly battled several diseases, including the chronic pain inducing "small fiber neuropathy," emphysema and heart disease, to the end. Carolyn's amazing well spring of strength was her strong set of values and ethics, which guided her in all decisions. She treated all with kindness and equality, and always seized the opportunity to help others. Carolyn is survived by her husband Jeff, sons Chnoo, David and his wife Ayesha, sister Barbara, and five grandchildren, whom she loved with all her heart: Devon, Samantha, Stephan, Natalya and Shasha. Her laughter, smile, wisdom, spirited way and love lives on in all our hearts.

Brooke Astor would have loved the recent tea-dance-themed picnic on Governors Island, a free five-minute ferry ride from the tip of Manhattan. The fun included live music and a low-tech game, a tug of war. (The women's team won.) Many participants went to Chinatown for their fans and inexpensive lightweight paper parasols, not to be confused with the heavy, oily, smelly rain versions. For a memorable picnic this Fourth of July, dress up in another era.

GOTTLIEB--Morton Edgar, 88, passed away on June 25. Resident of Greenwich Village, Warren, CT and Fire Island. Lovingly remembered by sister-in-law Claire Gottlieb, nieces Wendy Gottlieb and Hildy Gottlieb Hill and several grand and great-grandnieces and nephews. Graduate of Yale, Class of 1941. Tony Award winning Broadway producer of such hits as "Sleuth," "Same Time, Next Year," "Tribute," "Romantic Comedy" and "Enter Laughing." He was associated with over 35 Broadway productions and also produced the motion picture versions of "Sleuth," "Same Time, Next Year" and "Romantic Comedy." A Manhattan bon vivant and an authority on musicals. He also enjoyed being an avid bicyclist. One-of-a-kind, he was much loved and will be missed. He was predceased by brother Henry and nephew Roger Gottlieb. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Actor's Fund Home, 155-175 West Hudson Ave, Englewood, NJ 07631.

St. Louis Cardinals Manager Tony La Russa won his 2,500th game last Sunday, becoming only the third manager to reach that mark. One spot in front of him is the legendary New York Giants manager John McGraw, with 2,763 victories from 1899 to 1932. La Russa may well catch McGraw for second place, but there is little chance that he will surpass Connie Mack, whose 3,731 victories appears to be one of the safest records in baseball.

BLITZER--Jeremiah, died June 23, 2009. He was 82 years old. He passed away peacefully while listening to classical music, a major interest during his life. PETRIE--Donald Archibald. Lazard mourns the passing of Donald Petrie, our former partner, colleague and friend. After a highly successful career with the Hertz Corporation, Donald was hired into Lazard by Andre Meyer in the early 1960s. Throughout his nearly 40-year career at Lazard, he was a loyal and collegial partner and a highly respected counselor to our clients. Donald's warmth, kindness and his engaging personality will be greatly missed. His intellect, passion for history, and advocacy for the environment will live on through his writings and the many causes he shaped and led. We extend our condolences to his wife, children and grandchildren.

ON A FILM SHOOT, KONJSKO, MACEDONIA, OCT. 20, 2008 Will Rosenthal, 52, a Brooklyn social worker, photographs the actress Ana Lukic on the set of a commercial along the edge of Lake Prespa. ''I'm a social worker, but in a previous life I was a filmmaker. My undergraduate degree was in film. I was in Macedonia watching an old friend of mine from film school shoot a commercial promoting travel to Macedonia. So they were shooting different locations around the country, and I just tagged along to all these beautiful places. It reminded me of maybe what Italy was like in the '50s, where it's underdeveloped but has this fascinating culture. It seems like every major civilization has marched through there and conquered it at one time or another, from the Romans to the Byzantines to the Ottomans, the Nazis, the Communists. They've all left their mark. It's much more intriguing than Western Europe. It's the Balkans, you know? It's rich, and it's complicated, and it has this real rugged beauty to it. It's in flux, so that's interesting to see. It hasn't achieved some end state of developed stasis.''
Film Mike Hale

THE Energy Department has released the first third of its $25 billion advanced technology loan fund for automakers to ''create thousands of green jobs while helping reduce the nation's dangerous dependence on foreign oil.'' The agency released about $8 billion last week, with Ford the largest beneficiary, receiving $5.9 billion. Nissan received $1.6 billion and Tesla Motors got $465 million. Sue Cischke, Ford's vice president for environmental affairs, said, ''This is not related to our financial viability. It's very different, and it's what governments do -- assisting the best green technology.''

EKSTROM--Nicolas H.,70, on June 22, 2009, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Anne Lounsbury Ekstrom, son of the late Arne H. and Parmenia Migel Ekstrom, devoted godfather of Oliver Power, Alexandre Sankowski, and Jeremy Lindblad. "Niki" received his early education in France during his father's diplomatic service with the U.S. government in Paris. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Columbia University, and the Institut d'Art et Archeologie of the Sorbonne. He pursued a varied career in archaeology, photography, art, and landscape design. He was co-author, with Ruth Rogers Clausen, of the definitive Perennials for American Gardens, winner of the 1989 Quill and Trowel award from the Garden Writers' Association of America. In 1996, he revived his father's art gallery, Cordier & Ekstrom, renaming it Ekstrom & Ekstrom in his father's honor, and specializing in Dada and Surrealism. A lifelong gourmet and masterful cook, at the time of his death he was writing The Jaded Palate, "gastronomic memoirs" of his childhood in France. He was an avid book collector, a member of the Grolier Club, and a fellow of the Morgan Library. For almost two decades he served as a director of the Horticultural Society of New York. A memorial service will be held in September.

Both Cleveland and St. Louis have proven their dedication to the visual arts with the recent openings of new -- and free -- exhibition spaces. Yesterday, the Cleveland Museum of Art opened the East Wing, above. the first of three new wings, all of which will add 200,000 square feet to the property when they are completed in 2012. The East Wing, made of granite and glass and designed by architect Rafael Viñoly, connects the museum's original 1916 beaux-arts building and Marcel Breuer's 1971 addition. It will provide the exhibition space for the museum's modern and contemporary art collection, which includes paintings like ''Marilyn x 100'' by Andy Warhol, ''La Vie'' by Pablo Picasso, and ''In the Waves'' by Paul Gauguin (www.ClevelandArt.org). And on July 1, a new two-block, three-acre sculpture garden called Citygarden will open in downtown St. Louis. A project of the City of St. Louis, which owns the land, and the Gateway Foundation, which provided the funding, the garden will feature two dozen works, including sculptures by Fernand Léger, Keith Haring, Aristide Maillol and Laura Ford. There will also be a 102-jet ''spray plaza'' that will emit colorful patterns and in which children may play. Citygarden will be within walking distance of the Gateway Arch and the Mississippi River.

The Cardinals traveled to Cleveland a couple of weeks ago, but it was the Lake Erie sea gulls that got all the attention. The day before the Cardinals' arrival, Indians outfielder Shin-Soo Choo lined a base hit to center in the 10th inning of a tie game against the Kansas City Royals. As center fielder Coco Crisp was charging, the ball deflected off a sea gull and bounced past Crisp, allowing Mark DeRosa to score the winning run from second. The gull was among a few dozen in the outfield during the game.

THERE have been studies that compare text messaging on cellphones and other hand-held devices to drunken driving. And several states have already banned texting while driving. But according to Car and Driver, no one has done a real-world test -- until now. In an article that appears in the June issue of the magazine, the editors hooked up a Honda Pilot with a red light on the windshield. Car and Driver's editor and chief, Eddie Alterman, 37, and the magazine's intern, Jordan Brown, 22, took turns behind the wheel on a test track. When the light came on, the drivers hit the brakes.

TEN EYCK--Mills, Jr.,age 89, Southport, CT, died on Thursday, June 25, 2009. Born and raised in Schenectady, NY, Mills attended Schenectady schools including the Mohawk Country Day School. A 1941 graduate of Dartmouth College, he led the Dartmouth Players in his senior year, and wrote many short stories for the Dartmouth Undergraduate Magazine. After serving his country as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy Air Corps' Intelligence Department during WWII, Mills joined The Author's League of America, in New York City. He moved to Southport, where he ran Ten Eyck- Emerich Antiques with his partner, the late Robert Emerich until his retirement in 2004. A private interment will be in Albany Rural Cemetery, Menands, NY. Memorial contributions may be directed to either: The Pequot Library, Southport, CT or The Rensselaerville Presbyterian Church Steeple Fund, Rensselaerville, NY. To sign an online register, please visit www.LeskoPolkeFuneralHome.com

PETRIE--Donald Archibald, long time resident of Wainscott, NY- lawyer, investment banker, publisher and author, died peacefully at his home on Wednesday, June 10, 2009 at the age of 88. Born in Charleston, WV on April 27, 1921 to James and Emma Petrie he was raised in Sea Cliff, NY where his family moved after the sudden death of his father. He attended Hofstra University and the University of Chicago, earning BA and JD degrees. He was a veteran of World War II, having served in China and India as Staff Sergeant in the United States Army Air Corps. Upon graduation from law school he joined the Chicago law firm of D'Ancona Pflaum Wyatt & Riskind. He soon joined The Hertz Corporation as Executive Vice-President and Chief Operating Officer. He later became President of Hertz International. From 1962 to 1965 he was Chairman of the Executive Committee at Avis Rent-A-Car. He joined Lazard Freres as partner in the 1960s and remained a partner until 2000. He served on the first board of the Peace Corps and as Treasurer for the Democratic National Committee in 1972. He played a significant role in financing the construction of the Washington Cathedral, and as a tribute to his work, a gargoyle in his likeness - briefcase in hand - projects from the Southwest Tower of the Cathedral. In 1970 he and his good friend and business partner Robert C. Townsend co-founded Leadership Directories Inc., a publisher of government and business directories. He served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer from 1985 until 2002. A former Chairman of Group for the South Fork, his leadership helped mold the Group into a highly professional and effective environmental advocacy organization, now The Group for the East End. For 20 years he published "The Pond Watchers Almanac", his observations of all that happened in and on Georgica Pond. In the 1980s he joined with others to found the Wainscott Citizens Advisory Committee. His love of history, sailing and the law culminated in the 1999 publication by the Naval Institute Press of his book "The Prize Game - Lawful Looting on the High Seas in the Days of Fighting Sail". He is survived by his beloved wife Mary, two children from his first wife Ruth - Ann Elizabeth Sauter and James MacFarlin Petrie, three stepchildren Ramsay Cook, Clare Nicol and Gillian Quinn, and ten grandchildren Kathleen, Virginia, Madeline, Eliza, Connie, Archie, Peter, Catherine, Ramsay and Elizabeth. A memorial service will be held at Wainscott on August 9th.

IF Meredith German's way with color is a little wild, it's because she learned it from the legendary decorator Dorothy Draper, whose exuberant interiors at the Greenbrier resort near Ms. German's childhood home in Lewisburg, W. Va., made a lasting impression. Now, in a nod to that vibrant work, and after six years of designing accessories for Marc by Marc Jacobs, she has started her own line, called Meredith Wendell (Wendell is her husband's first name). Standouts in the collection include suede belts and evening bags in magenta, teal, Kelly green and charcoal, with adorning glass dots dipped in 18-karat gold. As Ms. German noted, ''They're kind of like candy.'' Meredith Wendell belts, $455, can be ordered at meredithwendell.com; pouches, $375 at Kirna Zabête.

BERNHEIM--Daniel Jr.,passed away on June 27, 2009. Beloved husband of Barbara; Loving father of Susan Winston, Daniel Bernheim III, Linda Truesdale, Debbie Salinger, and Richard Stein. Loving brother and cherished grandfather. He was the former director of Camp Danbee. Services are on Monday at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL.

Summer is turning out to be a season of excellent bargains for tourists heading to New York. NYC & Company, the official tourism organization for New York, is offering its twice-a-year Third Night Free promotion to those staying for two consecutive nights at eight participating luxury hotels, including the Waldorf Towers, between July 1 and Sept. 7 (www.nycgo.com/thirdnight). The MAve, a new boutique hotel at Madison Avenue and 27th Street, is also offering a third night free for two consecutive nights booked through the end of the year to celebrate its July 2 opening. Rates start at $169 and include breakfast (www.TheMAvehotel.com). And for those who like their entertainment alfresco -- and within walking distance of their hotel -- the Buckingham Hotel, above, is offering a special entrance and seating to guests who attend the free (and very popular) Central Park SummerStage events, which include the Metropolitan Opera, hip-hop artist Q-Tip and Dayton Contemporary Dance Company. The package is available through Aug. 17. Nightly rates start at $219 a room (www.buckinghamhotel.com/summerstage).

DAVID LETTERMAN Hey, you know what is going on over in Iran with the election? Have you been following that? Oh, it's crazy. Mahmoud Ahmadinejad has declared himself a winner. Had a victory party. And he came out at the victory party and he thanked the 148 percent of the people who voted for him.

ISIDORE--Nancy, died peacefully at home in Barnegat Light, NJ on June 26, after a long battle with many illnesses. Beloved mother of Chris and Adam Isidore, beloved grandmother of Allison, Katrina, Sophia and Charlotte Isidore, mother-in-law of Elizabeth Birge and Sarah Vogel, all of Montclair, NJ, sister of Margaret Case, aunt of Nancy Palmquist, Laura and Peggy Case, cousin of Bobby Meyer, formerly married to Tony Isidore. Known as "Ms. Is" to hundreds of students she taught and loved as a teacher at Grafflin School in Chappaqua, NY, from 1974-96. Retired to Barnegat Light, returning to the beach that she loved. Admired for her beautiful and creative gardens. Born October 3, 1933, she grew up in Shrewsbury, NJ, the daughter of Phillip and Bella Meyer. BA, in 1955, from Douglas College and Masters, 1959, at Rochester. She was a lifelong fervent Democrat. The family wishes to thank all of her many dear friends who provided such love and care for her through her final days. A memorial service is planned for later in the summer in Barnegat Light.
STERN--Marvin. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Marvin Stern, associated with The New York Times from November 30, 1950 until retiring on November 1, 1988.

THE NEWS Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina admitted that he had been having an affair with a woman in Argentina for the last year. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Sanford's confession ended the mystery surrounding his disappearance over Father's Day weekend (he had been in Buenos Aires) and appeared to scuttle any hope of a Republican presidential bid in 2012. The married father of four sons later acknowledged also visiting his mistress last summer while on a taxpayer-financed trade mission to Argentina. He pledged to pay back the costs, but even fellow Republicans appeared to have had enough. ''I think he's gone; it's over,'' said one top legislator.

OUTPOSTS We are an overwhelmingly urban nation, especially the West -- the most urbanized region of the country, according to the Census Bureau definition. But the will to till has never left us. At the same time, this recession is forcing local governments to abandon traditional services. Cities are becoming robotized and retro at the same time. The last century saw the flowering of the City Beautiful movement -- grand boulevards and parks, Parisian in intent, if not actual design. This century, hit with the worst economic slap since the Great Depression, has brought the self-service city -- shrunken, less personal and meaner on one level, more neighborly on another. In the hardest-hit cities, where big clusters of foreclosed houses sit empty, entire blocks are being returned to nature -- land banks, they call them. There is opportunity in this crisis, as more than one mayor has proclaimed, paraphrasing Rahm Emanuel. City dwellers: this land is your land!

COCKTAIL shorts, the leggy, somewhat louche alternative to a pair of evening pants, made an emphatic appearance on the spring runways, showing up at Lanvin (above right), Yves Saint Laurent, Chloé (above left) and Dolce & Gabbana. Now they're turning up on some of the city's best-dressed young women -- Genevieve Jones (above center), Chloë Sevigny and Lauren Santo Domingo among them. The key to pulling off the look in a sophisticated way is, of course, proper styling. All three women dressed up their skimpy shorts with smart-looking jackets and sky-high heels. In Ms. Jones's case, it was a navy silk bomber and bandeau top by Christian Cota and black satin shoes from Brian Atwood.

My colleague Jonathan Glater has some good news for college students and recent graduates who have taken out federal loans. Under a program that begins Wednesday, they can reduce their monthly payments, depending on their income and family size.

Tuition and fees at private American colleges and universities will increase by an average of 4.3 percent in the new school year when compared to the academic year just concluded — the smallest rise in 37 years, according to a survey of 350 institutions by the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities.

General Motors said Monday that it was pulling out of its joint venture with Toyota, a longstanding partnership between two of the auto industry’s biggest rivals that exposed G.M. to more efficient Japanese manufacturing techniques and produced Toyota’s first American-made vehicles, The New York Times’s Nick Bunkley reports.
What we’re reading on Monday morning.

As the lyrics to a song from the Broadway musical “Avenue Q” point out, nothing lasts, and life, work, happiness and discomfort are only for now. So it goes for the musical itself: the show, an adult themed upgrade of educational children’s programs like “Sesame Street,” will play its last performance on Sept. 13, its publicists said Monday in a news release. The show, which features music and lyrics by Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx and book by Jeff Whitty, taught Broadway a lesson or two when it opened at the Golden Theater in 2003: in a season that also saw the openings of attention-grabbing productions like “Wicked” and “The Boy from Oz,” the scrappy puppet show was the unexpected winner of the Tony Award for best musical. At its closing, “Avenue Q” will have played 2,534 performances and 22 previews.

Even for a satirical show like “The Simpsons,” it was relatively easy to pay a sincere tribute to Michael Jackson: on Sunday, the animated Fox series opened with the video for “Do the Bartman,” a pop song that Mr. Jackson helped write and produce for the show in 1990. But for many comedy performers and late-night hosts whose acts typically thrive on topicality, there was no one solution for addressing the notable deaths that occurred last week — if they acknowledged these passings at all.

As one contemplates the dwindling number of people who could unite an increasingly fragmented popular music landscape, one name that does not come to mind is Philip Roth, the irascible author of “Sabbath’s Theater,” “The Human Stain” and other novels. Yet Mr. Roth has made what we believe is his first foray into pop, as part of a techno song that won’t be hitting the Top 40 chart any time soon.

A man who admitted his role in the theft of the Edvard Munch painting “The Scream” was sentenced Monday to two and a half years in prison by a court in Oslo, The Associated Press reported. The man, Bjoern Hoen, 41, had been found guilty by a Norwegian appeals court of providing the getaway vehicle that was used in the daytime heist. On Aug. 22, 2004, the Munch Museum in Oslo was raided by two armed masked men, who took “The Scream” as well as a second painting, “Madonna,” and drove off in a black station wagon. (Another version of “The Scream” is owned by the National Gallery of Norway.) The works were recovered in 2006 but details on how and where they were found have not been made public. Mr. Hoen had admitted that he provided the car driven by the thieves but said he did not know how the vehicle would be used. Last year, Norway’s Supreme Court sentenced one thief, Stian Skjold, to six years in jail and the getaway driver, Petter Tharaldsen, to 10 years and 6 months. A third suspect, whose name was not given, died of a heroin overdose in 2006.

On Wednesday, Marvel Entertainment will release the first issue of Marvel Divas, a four-part miniseries starring a quartet of its female characters: Black Cat, Captain Marvel, Firestar and Hellcat. The first issue will reveal that Firestar has breast cancer.

Hey, ladies! (And, also, gentlemen.) Jerry Lewis is headed back to Broadway, this time in the director’s chair. The veteran comedian, last seen in 1995 on a Broadway stage as Applegate in the revival of “Damn Yankees,” will direct a musical adaptation of his hit 1963 comedy “The Nutty Professor” that is planned for the 2010-11 season, the show’s publicists said in a news release. That film starred Mr. Lewis as the nebbishy Julius Kelp, who invents a formula that transforms him into the debonair Buddy Love. (A 1996 remake starred Eddie Murphy as the overweight Sherman Klump and his suave alter ego.) The musical adaptation will feature music by Marvin Hamlisch (“A Chorus Line”) and lyrics and book by Rupert Holmes (“Curtains,” “The Mystery of Edwin Drood”). A cast has not yet been announced.

Turns out that backdrop that clocked Bret Michaels at the Tony Awards was only the first surprise to hit “Rock of Ages”: Amy Spanger, who originated the role of the small-town girl turned stripper Sherrie in the Broadway production, has left the show. Ms. Spanger (of Broadway’s “Wedding Singer” and “Kiss Me, Kate”) had been out of “Rock of Ages” since June 8. At that time, its producers said she was on vocal rest at her doctor’s orders but was expected to return to the show on Monday. But on Monday, publicists for the show said in a release that Ms. Spanger had departed due to “personal reasons.” Savannah Wise has been playing the role of Sherrie in Ms. Spanger’s absence. A full-time replacement was not immediately announced, and producers for “Rock of Ages” did not immediately return phone calls.

Though it has been suggested that there is nothing like a dame, we’ll assume that Kelli O’Hara and her husband, Greg Naughton, are equally happy with the baby boy born to them on Saturday. In a news release, Lincoln Center Theater said that the couple has named their child Owen James, and that he weighed 7 pounds, 3 ounces at birth. Ms. O’Hara, who took a maternity leave from the theater company’s production of “South Pacific” in March, is expected to return to the show in October.

Michael Jackson’s mother, Katherine Jackson, has been granted temporary guardianship of the three children left behind by the pop star, who died of undetermined causes last week at the age of 50. Jennifer Steinhauer and Randal C. Archibold have more …
In the midst of the summer movies season, A. O. Scott takes a look back at one of the first summer blockbusters, Steven Spielberg‘s “Jaws.”

Since his death last Thursday, Michael Jackson has been all over the radio. Last week airplay of his songs in the United States jumped 18 times from the week before, Billboard reported, citing data from Nielsen BDS, which monitors airplay. For the week that ended Sunday, 143 songs by Mr. Jackson were played 67,383 times on terrestrial and satellite radio; the previous week, his songs were played 3,671 times. The most popular song last week was “Billie Jean,” with 4,540 spins (the previous week it had been played only 318 times); next was “Thriller,” with 3,570 spins; and third, “Rock With You,” with 3,546. Sales of Mr. Jackson’s music also increased dramatically since Thursday, and are expected to dominate Billboard’s catalog chart — for albums more than 18 months old — when it is released on Wednesday.

The constructor Steve Dobis plays Professor Henry Higgins today, teaching us to properly round our vowels as we carefully intone the standard phrase regarding brown bovines. Presumably his next puzzle will include fun facts about the geographical distribution of Spanish precipitation. Four long answers plus an even longer fifteen-letter explanation across the middle row spell out the theme.

Last Thursday evening I kept popping up from the dinner table each time David Stern, president of the National Basketball Association, strode to the podium to announce that another N.B.A. team had made its selection in the 2009 player-draft. Finally my wife gave in and said, "O.K., let's go sit in front of the T.V.," and so, along with my wife's mother (going on 98), we took the movable feast to the coffee table, and watched while a succession of tall young men donned caps bearing the names of their new teams before shaking hands with Stern, a middle-aged bespectacled Jew who was anything from five inches to a foot and a half shorter than the (usually black) draftee he was congratulating.

The nation's largest public employees union is taking aim at Citigroup, saying it is "dismayed" by the bank's plan to raise salaries for its employees by as much as 50 percent to offset smaller bonuses.

Ford called me recently. Not actually one of Henry's kids, but a big shot. Well, technically not a "big shot," but someone in the marketing department. The company is coming out with a 2010 vehicle that's called the Transit Connect. It gets 22 to 25 miles per gallon, and it's being sold as a small-business delivery van.

of Wisconsin Law School debate Michael Jackson's cultural legacy.

We purchased our bookstore in Maplewood in November, and closed it temporarily in late December to move to a bigger and more prominent location. We moved our old fixtures and our inventory to the new store, and prepared to set up. Before the books were shelved, I wanted to have our numerous bookcases cleaned and polished. Dana, our pro-bono decorator, told me that her nephew Will was home from school for holiday break and might be available to help. One of our staff also volunteered her son.

MILWAUKEE -- Carlos Beltran wanted a second opinion for his ailing right knee. His agent, Scott Boras, favored a particular doctor. That is how Beltran wound up on Monday in Vail, Colo., being examined by Dr. Richard Steadman, who pioneered the technique known as microfracture surgery.

The High Desert Mavericks play in a hitter-friendly park, thanks to the altitude of nearly 2,500 feet as well as the desert heat and thin air in Adelanto, Calif. But no one in Mavericks Stadium on Sunday was quite prepared for what happened: a 33-18 victory by the Lake Elsinore Storm.

Edward Snyder, a cellphone industry analyst with Charter Equity Research, often plays the role of cautious pessimist. For instance, he questions whether smartphones or data services will catch on as much as carriers hope, and he unreservedly criticizes what he characterizes as their underperforming cellular networks.

The streets of the city are a non-stop parade of humanity. It's a kind of grand, unchoreographed ballet of human locomotion. One of the great pleasures and measures of being urban is losing yourself in the crowd, with your feet and mind wandering, alone in your head but elbow to elbow with an inexhaustible supply of strangers.

In today's Well column, I write about the amazing accomplishments of Team Type 1, a cycling team comprised of athletes with Type 1 diabetes that just won the 3,000-mile Race Across America. After writing about the team, several readers asked specific questions about how the riders managed exercise and insulin needs.

Last week I asked readers to pick up the phone and help me test a feature in Google's new phone call management service that automatically transcribes voice mail messages. I encouraged creativity, and I got a lot. People called up and left all kinds of stuff for Google's speech-recognition algorithms to puzzle over.

Summer sequels rarely live up to the original - except, apparently, in the Champagne world. Recently Dom Perignon introduced the first in its Oenothèque series, in which a favorite vintage stored in the cellar master's laboratory - in this case the 1995 vintage, first released in 2002 - is bottled again, several years later, for connoisseurs to enjoy its mature nuances. "It's like putting a magnifying lens on top of it," said Richard Geoffroy, the chef de cave for Dom Perignon, during a recent visit to New York.

Enterprise Products Partners said Monday that it was acquiring Teppco Partners in an all-stock deal valued at $3.3 billion, forming what they said would be the largest publicly traded energy partnership.

(Despite the spelling, Ed finds much to like about a street fair in Marylebone. --MB)One of the many things I dislike about the weekend street fairs that plague Manhattan is their sameness. With a few exceptions - such as the Ninth Avenue Food Festival and some genuinely local block parties - they are dominated by an unchanging roster of vendors, selling sausage sandwiches and zeppole, corn on the cob, irregular-quality underwear and socks, knock-off sunglasses, various Asian snacks and many other things I can't think of because I keep away as best I can, if only to avoid the smell of burning fat and acrid smoke. When you've seen one, you've seen 'em all.
A. O. Scott reviews Steven Spielberg's "Jaws," one of the first summer blockbusters.

Six children sat on the stoop of 40 Tiemann Place on Monday afternoon, just off Broadway and a block south of West 125th Street. They had worked up a sweat from playing, and as usual, there was China Garcia, 50, who lives in the building, handing out ice pops.

I got an e-mail message earlier today from a public relations executive who works for a law firm that is suing the Securities and Exchange Commission on behalf of a small handful of the victims of Bernie Madoff's Ponzi scheme. The legal theory, apparently, is that the agency's negligence in failing to catch the now-famous crook means that it should be legally liable for the victims' losses. Anyway, the executive wanted to know whether my column last week about the man who had been unfairly hounded by the S.E.C. for eight years meant that I was becoming more sympathetic toward the Madoff victims.
How many politicians does it take to change a light bulb?

At the end of their shifts tomorrow, the three newest police officers in the Maplewood Police Department will be out of jobs. The deadline for the layoffs is tomorrow, and, according to Maplewood Mayor Victor DeLuca, no new deal is in sight.

The craze for blank-check companies may have dissipated with the onset of the credit crunch and ensuing market volatility, but the veteran deal-makers running some of the biggest of these vehicles are still seeking to put their money to work.

Nearly three weeks after a pedicab collided with a yellow taxi at the foot of the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn -- leaving the pedicab driver seriously injured -- the City Council's Consumer Affairs Committee met on Monday to consider proposed new regulation of pedicabs.
It's no secret that iPhone and iPod Touch owners like to play games. On average, iPhone and Touch owners have 10 games on their devices.

First lady Michelle Obama visited a local health clinic in Washington on Tuesday in an effort to focus attention on preventable scourges such as obesity, diabetes and high blood pressure that disproportionately afflict African-American and Hispanic communities.
The State Street Corporation, an asset management and servicing company, said Monday that it might face civil charges by securities regulators for exposing investors to losses on subprime mortgages.
The movie "My Sister's Keeper" opened this weekend - a tale about a family who conceives a second daughter in order to save the life of their first.
Chicken that’s been poached and shredded can be used in a variety of healthy dishes.

Bulletproof fortifications around tellers in banks -- known as "bandit barriers" in commercial-banking slang -- have pitted banks and the police against each other in a policy argument over safety, expense and businesses' rights to manage their own security.

The world's attention moved - at least temporarily - to Honduras, where demonstrators protested the coup on Sunday. "One day after the country's president, Manuel Zelaya, was abruptly awakened, ousted and deported by the army here, hundreds of protesters massed at the presidential offices in an increasingly tense face-off with hundreds of camouflage-clad soldiers carrying riot shields and automatic weapons," Marc Lacey and Elisabeth Malkin wrote on NYTimes.com.

Two influential Democrats with close ties to President Obama endorsed on Monday taxing some employer-provided health benefits as part of a $1.2 trillion 10-year framework for financing a health system overhaul, another sign that Mr. Obama may end up accepting a tax that he rejected during his campaign.

In my Findings column, I describe how the patrons of a restaurant in Israel turned out to be surprisingly immune to the experimental manipulations of behavioral economists. And now there's more evidence of sensible shopping behavior from an informal (and unscientific) survey of Lab readers. The push for doctors to convert their patient files to electronic records could spur the creation of dozens of health information technology companies and create thousands of jobs in New York City, according to a study released Monday by a research organization based in Manhattan.

Michael Jackson's sudden death brought back memories of another. Elvis Presley changed my teenage world, and he, too, died too young. Caught up in my own immediate medical events the past week involving pain-killing drugs, I reflected on my own battles with addiction.

Eataly, a giant market for artisanal Italian food products that opened in Turin two years ago, signed a lease this morning for an even larger location at 200 Fifth Avenue.

The Supreme Court's decision earlier today overturning the Ricci ruling -- which reviewed a case involving Judge Sonia Sotomayor on an appellate panel -- has sorted in an expected way, no doubt -- the dividing lines for senators gearing up for her confirmation hearings beginning July 13.

This morning the Supreme Court issued its highly anticipated decision in Ricci v. DeStefano, aka the New Haven firefighter case. It should probably also be known as Ricci v. Sotomayor, given how prominently the case has figured in the nomination of Sonia Sotomayor to the high court.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he thought the project was "cute," and could "inspire and delight New Yorkers and visitors."

The New York area's fabled summer retreats - the Hamptons, Fire Island, etc. - are house-rental places. You either engage a private property for a month or the season, or do a share, but, by and large, you wouldn't want to go for the hotels, which have historically been not very good and ridiculously overpriced. So it's nice to see the recent emergence of some really good-looking properties that could give those who don't want to make a big commitment, or like a bit more service, another option. I haven't yet checked out this new crop personally, but they seem promising. (And if you've been to any of them, let us know what you thought in the comments.)
The novelist Alice Hoffman caused a stir over the weekend when she used Twitter to strike back at a mixed review of her latest novel, "The Story Sisters."

The era of the superskinny hipster jeans is finally over. At Dior Homme, the label that arguably started that trend several years ago, there was nary a tight trouser in sight. The designer Kris Van Assche showed a looser silhouette, in what was probably his strongest collection to date. His ultra-lightweight jackets made references to tailoring construction (and deconstruction) and seemed purposely unfinished; the high-waisted, full trousers alluded to some of Van Assche's previous experiments with volume, but in a more desirable way.
Bernard L. Madoff, who was accused of running one of the biggest Ponzi schemes in history, was sentenced to 150 years in prison.

It's hard to recognize a tennis player in civilian clothes, so it took me a moment to see Brian Baker as he ambled towards me. Tall at 6-foot-3, and built like his former rival Novak Djokovic, Baker looked like a student at nearby Belmont University, which in fact he is. He's also the men's assistant tennis coach at Belmont. I had called Brian to hear his impressions of Wimbledon and to see how his own tennis game was coming along. We had agreed to meet for an iced tea at Bongo Java, a coffee place favored by music-business types housed in a old two story structure across the street from Belmont. Once inside, we ordered our drinks and looked at the "Nun Bun," a pastry now preserved with shellac said to resemble Mother Teresa which created quite a stir back in October 1996, when it was featured in USA Today. Our talk turned to the men's draw at Wimbledon, and specifically to Monday's Round of 16 matchups.

MotoGP: Yamaha rider Valentino Rossi won his 100th grand prix on Sunday, at Assen Circuit in the Netherlands. Rossi, the defending champion, started on pole, but Casey Stoner, of Ducati, the 2007 champion, quickly passed him to take the early lead. Rossi's teammate and perhaps fiercest rival this season, Jorge Lorenzo, was stuck in sixth as Rossi made his move to the front. Lorenzo gave chase but could not get close enough to pressure Rossi, who pulled away in the final laps. "I felt good on the first lap and knowing that Lorenzo is difficult to beat I put my foot down to establish as big an advantage as possible over him," said Rossi, who is only the second rider to score 100 wins. I've always wanted to visit the cafe on the fifth floor of the Museum of Modern Art, but have found it almost as hard to get into as the Modern, its posh sibling on the ground floor: every attempt was thwarted by a long line, since it's first come, first served. (The cafe, called Terrace 5, is open only to museum visitors.) But last week, I finally snagged a table -- on the balcony, which overlooks the museum's sculpture garden, and I can say that the view alone was worth the wait. Since I got there at the end of the day, I almost had the balcony to myself -- and the garden, too, since it had rained on and off all day. A deep overhang shelters the outdoor tables, so when the heavens suddenly opened and the rain cascaded down, I was an enchanted spectator rather than a soggy victim. I ordered an iced latte, and - thank you, Danny Meyer - it arrived with its own little pitcher of simple syrup, so I was spared the frustration of trying to dissolve sugar in a cold drink. Sitting there, gazing at the garden and a slice of cityscape that stretched along West 54th Street from the Rockefeller Apartments to the delectably ornamented Elizabeth Arden building on Fifth Avenue, I felt as if a New Yorker cover had come to life.Pilar Viladas is the design editor of T: The New York Times Style Magazine.

Over the years my boys have tried pretty much every activity they could think of, and then some. Between the two of them they have wrestled, golfed, swam, ice skated, roller bladed, fenced, played tennis, baseball, football, hockey and lacrosse, learned archery, karate and gymnastics. They have taken classes in ceramics and drama, and lessons in the saxophone, guitar and trumpet. Some lasted much longer, and required far more of an investment than others. I am probably forgetting a few. Most fell by the wayside, with the inevitable arguments about how much time is enough time to have given it a try. A few have stuck, and will probably be lifelong passions.

Despite horrendous reviews, Michael Bay's "Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen" roared out of the blocks last week with a huge five-day opening of $201.2 million -- just a hair shy of the $203.8 million earned by Christopher Nolan's "Dark Knight" last summer. It proved, once again, the stubborn power of sequels to draw Americans to the multiplex, especially those sequels that promise to replicate the original rather than striking out in unfamiliar directions. In short, it's not the venal Hollywood executives who keep insisting on shoveling the same thing at audiences time and time again, as critics often charge -- it's audiences that insist upon it.

A new method of attacking cancer cells, developed by researchers in Australia, has proved surprisingly effective in animal tests.

KATZ--Dr. Abraham, 97. Loved and loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle, friend, physician and healer. He was the best of men.

ROFFMAN--Bernard. 94. Passed away June 27, 2009 in peace. Beloved husband of Helen, wonderful father to Herbert (Emma), Linda (Danny) and Bonnie (Norman). Funny and loving Grandpa to Jason (Heidi), Joshua, Matthew (Kristen), Annie (Zach), Adam, Scott and Ali. Great-Grandpa of five. His legacy filters through the generations and we will hold him in our hearts forever and always. Here's to you, Dad, with all our love. Services Tuesday, June 30, 10:30am, at Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.
They are creating a monster they will not be able to contain. MANUEL ZELAYA, on a military coup that ousted him as president of Honduras. [A6]

BARSKY--Leonard (Lenny), 84, died at home on June 28, 2009 in NYC from prostate cancer. Loving husband to Janet (nee Shlansky). Dear father to Gail, Alan and Beth, caring father-in-law to Jon Margolis and fiance John Munroe. Devoted grandfather to Sara, Stephanie, Adam, Ariel, Alexis and Ian. Dear brother to Betty Madison and loyal friend to Naomi Juarez. Respected, caring partner for 37 years to Jerry Kramer and Philip Rothblum. Self taught renaissance man who loved life, family, sports, art and business. His family graciously requests contributions in his honor to Sloan-Kettering Hospital or ADL. Services Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
DURDEN--Jewel Hart Curtis, native New York stage, TV actress, passed away June 22, 2009 in Beverly Hills, CA.

ISIDORE--Nancy, died peacefully at home in Barnegat Light, NJ on June 26, after a long battle with many illnesses. Beloved mother of Chris and Adam Isidore, beloved grandmother of Allison, Katrina, Sophia and Charlotte Isidore, mother-in-law of Elizabeth Birge and Sarah Vogel, all of Montclair, NJ, sister of Margaret Case, aunt of Nancy Palmquist, Laura and Peggy Case, cousin of Bobby Meyer, formerly married to Tony Isidore. Known as "Ms. Is" to hundreds of students she taught and loved as a teacher at Grafflin School in Chappaqua, NY, from 1974-96. Retired to Barnegat Light, returning to the beach that she loved. Admired for her beautiful and creative gardens. Born October 3, 1933, she grew up in Shrewsbury, NJ, the daughter of Phillip and Bella Meyer. BA, in 1955, from Douglas College and Masters, 1959, at Rochester. She was a lifelong fervent Democrat. The family wishes to thank all of her many dear friends who provided such love and care for her through her final days. A memorial service is planned for later in the summer in Barnegat Light.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.17 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.29 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.07 percent.

KOHNSTAMM--Therese Werner, passed away peacefully in her home on June 24, 2009 at the age of 97. She will be greatly missed by her daughter, Jo Ann, her sister, Jean, her nieces and nephews, and their families. Therese (Terry to her friends and family) was born in Manhattan and loved the city. She attended Ethical Culture School and then went on to Barnard College. Terry and her husband, Ed, together with their son, Lee, tirelessly built V&E Kohnstamm, Inc., a flavors and essential oils company. Throughout her life, Terry loved to play golf and travel. Adventurous and energetic, throughout her life, at the age of 77, she took one of the most memorable trips of her life whitewater rafting down the Middle Fork of the Salmon River. Terry was, early on, a firm supporter of women's rights and contributed to a wide range of organizations and institutions. At her request, there will be no services and no flowers.

CHRISTINA COURTIN (Nonesuch) With ''Rainy,'' a shiver of a song that arrives near the close of her self-titled debut, Christina Courtin finally shows her hand. The track's austerely appealing string arrangement, played by the quartet Brooklyn Rider, is her invention from top to bottom. By the time she sings her first dolorous line, more than two minutes in, her erudition is as striking as her composure. Ms. Courtin has been keeping something from us.

LEVON HELM ''Electric Dirt'' (Dirt Farmer Music/Vanguard) Despite the title, don't expect an onslaught of power chords on ''Electric Dirt,'' which is just as likely to deploy a mandolin or a honky-tonk piano. It's the second album made by Levon Helm, who played drums and sang with the Band, since he recovered from throat cancer and started a series of roots-rocking ''Midnight Ramble'' concerts at his barn in Woodstock, N.Y., then took them on the road.
CORDINGLEY--Robert Alan. Retired professor at the School of Architecture City College New York City, died June 21, 2009 in Santa Barbara, CA.
GOLDFARB--Toby D. We mourn the passing of our friend Toby. We'll remember all the laughs and good times since 1958. We offer our sincerest sympathy to Joanne and Sue. Alan, Linda, David and Wendy

OSTROW--Annette. We mourn the passing of Annette Ostrow, mother of our beloved son-in-law Ronald Ostrow, and mother-in-law of our daughter Batsheva Ostrow. We honor her life as the devoted wife of the late Barnet Ostrow, and as a mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and great-grandmother. She has left an indelible mark on a multitude of lives, and will be sorely missed. We grieve along with all of those who loved her. David and Shoshanna Wingate and family.

For people who hope the openness and flexibility of the Internet will come to mainstream television, the deal announced Wednesday between Comcast and Time Warner is great news. They might not yet see how it blows apart the tight bond between cable content and cable delivery. On the face of it, the deal is all about controls, rules and limits. The two companies are going to test a method for people who pay for Comcast cable TV to watch Time Warner's cable networks, starting with TBS and TNT, on the Internet.

EVANS--Faye, born January 3, 1920 in Brooklyn, NY to Yetta and Joseph Furman. Faye was the youngest of five children, older siblings Samuel, Manny, Jack, and Sally are now all deceased. Faye grew up in Brooklyn and graduated from Tilden H.S. She married William Evans in May 1942. During WWII she worked on an airplane assembly line while her husband served at the Panama Canal. After the war she and her husband Bill moved to Queens, NY where she raised her three children, Donald, Rene and Nina. She loved her Thursday canasta game and always prided herself in keeping the scores for the games because, as she would boast, "she used to be a bookkeeper and had such neat handwriting." Faye was a most loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. During the last days of her life, seeing a grandchild would always put a joyous look on her face. During the last seven years of her life she took absolute loving care of her beloved husband Bill to whom she was totally devoted. We all loved her so much and will miss her. Faye is survived by her husband Bill, son Donald Evans, New York, daughters Rene Benson, New Jersey and Nina Roth, New York, sons-in-law Phil Benson and Cary Roth, grandchildren Dani Tapper, Florida, Casey Wanderer, New York, Justen Roth and Kyle Roth, and great-grandchildren Sammi Tapper, Avery Tapper, Alex Tapper and Ryan Wanderer. Services will be held Monday, 10:30am at the grave site at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY.

GARFIELD--Philip, 81, of Forest Hills, NY, Kauneonga Lake, NY, and Netanya, Israel on June 27, 2009. Devoted husband of Faith S. Garfield, his wife of 54 years, loving father of Eve Garfield Lobel and Risa C. Doherty, father-in-law of Bernard M. Lobel and Michael A. Doherty, cherished grandfather of Alec A. Doherty and Melissa L. Doherty, and beloved brother of Arlene Silverberg. Philip served in the U.S. Merchant Marine in World War II, and thereafter in the U.S. Army. He received a BBA from City College and a J.D. from N.Y.U. He was the founder and Senior Partner of the C.P.A. firm of Garfield, Seltzer & Curcio. A man of honor, curiosity and courage, who traveled the world with endless interest and a desire to live life to the fullest: an unforgettable man. Funeral service will be held Monday June 29, at 11am at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels at 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY.

HIGGER--David. The Board, Volunteers and Staff of Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. wish to express our deepest sympathy to the family of David B. Higger, long time volunteer and fundraiser of our special charity. With sympathy, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

LESHEN--Joanne. Friday, June 26th, 2009 of complications due to Leukemia at age 61. Beloved daughter to Evelyn and Adrian Friedman. Loving mother to Craig and Lee. Adoring mother-in-law to Ana Carmen. Cherished sister of Laurie Falcone, and sister-in-law of Michael Falcone. Treasured aunt to Tina, Carrie and Diana. Mom, you will be deeply, deeply missed by any and all lives that you touched. Your entire family, and all of your many friends, will remember your love, laughter, humor, wisdom, your generosity, guidance, passion, grace and creativity. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the ASPCA, The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, or the charity of your choosing. Shiva to be held at her home from 4-8pm, Sunday through Wednesday.

Web sites for buying games, like that of Electronic Arts, and those where visitors can play other users, like FullTiltPoker.com and King.com, dominate the Web in terms of stickiness -- the average amount of time visitors spend on line. Portal sites like Yahoo and AOL rank fairly high, too. The more time visitors spend on a site, the more advertising they are exposed to. Sites with lots of stickiness and many visitors form a small club. Facebook, which was the No. 1 social-networking site in May, and the No. 7 site over all, has definitely earned its membership. SHELLY FREIERMAN

BRAD PAISLEY ''American Saturday Night'' (Arista) It would be fun to borrow Brad Paisley for a bunch of afternoons. Each day you could give him an empty room and a pencil and feed him machine-generated random assignments based on mundane objects or sawed-off bits of sayings: to write a song called, say, ''Chair,'' or ''A Little to the Left,'' or ''Receipt.'' (He likes one-word titles.) In two weeks you might have an album like this one.

LAWRENCE--Florence Gordon Died June 28 at age 96. Devoted wife of John S. of 69 years who predeceased her. Beloved mother of Jim Lawrence and Betsy Pinover Schiff. Adoring grandmother of Justin Lawrence. Mother-in-law of Helene Lawrence and Edward L. Schiff. A role model of strength, energy and dignity. A committed volunteer for many cultural and international organizations. A woman whose love and generosity will live forever in the hearts of her family members and far-reaching circle of friends. Services are private.

ALLEN--Betty. The family of Betty Allen wish to extend their heartfelt appreciation for all who have expressed care and concern during this difficult time. There will be a wake held on Tuesday June 30, 2009 at Benta's Funeral Home, located at 630 St. Nicholas Avenue at 141st Street, 4-8pm.

To get the best predictions about when your company's latest product will ship or how it will sell, you might try asking your employees -- anonymously. A start-up, Crowdcast, began selling corporate forecasting software on Thursday that does just that. The employees on the front lines -- the sales team talking to customers or the people packaging new products -- have first-hand information that could be valuable to executives. But top management does not always get the most accurate information, because employees do not want to tell the boss bad news, or they want to underpromise so the boss thinks they are outperforming.

10:30 P.M. (Sundance) BLOOD, SWEAT + GEARS (2009) In response to the doping scandals rife in professional cycling, Jonathan Vaughters, left, a former racer, founded Slipstream, a team whose members agree to compete without the aid of performance-enhancing drugs. In this documentary Nick Davis chronicles the story of the ''clean team'' as it peddled its way through 2008 and won its first invitation to compete in the Tour de France. The team was led by David Millar, who was in the midst of a comeback after a doping scandal sidelined his career. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOW Megan Fox (''Transformers: Revenge of the Fall'') and Ray Romano (''Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs'') are the guests. Segments look at workout mistakes and affordable ways to dress up a table.

OSTROW--Annette, 92, beloved wife of the late Barnet Ostrow, mother of Ronald and Bono, mother-in-law of Batsheva and Nancy, grandmother of Alonna and Michael Ostad, Sharone and Richard Gilbert, Jonathan and Rose Ostrow, and Juliette Yvertes, great-grandmother of Hannah, Alexandra, Ari, Benjamin, Samuel, Zachary and Emma. She had a wonderful, long life filled with love for her family, support for educational causes, and kindness for others. May her memory be blessed and her good name live on forever.

GOTTLIEB--Morton Edgar, 88, passed away on June 25. Resident of Greenwich Village, Warren, CT and Fire Island. Lovingly remembered by sister-in-law Claire Gottlieb, nieces Wendy Gottlieb and Hildy Gottlieb Hill and several grand and great-grandnieces and nephews. Graduate of Yale, Class of 1941. Tony Award winning Broadway producer of such hits as "Sleuth," "Same Time, Next Year," "Tribute," "Romantic Comedy" and "Enter Laughing." He was associated with over 35 Broadway productions and also produced the motion picture versions of "Sleuth," "Same Time, Next Year" and "Romantic Comedy." A Manhattan bon vivant and an authority on musicals. He also enjoyed being an avid bicyclist. One-of-a-kind, he was much loved and will be missed. He was predceased by brother Henry and nephew Roger Gottlieb. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Actor's Fund Home, 155-175 West Hudson Ave, Englewood, NJ 07631.
General Motors is using its huge pension fund in a way it never intended.

As General Motors and the auto-parts company Magna International struggle to conclude a deal for Opel, G.M. is talking to other potential buyers in a bid to win better terms, according to the officials involved in the negotiations, The New York Times’s Nelson D. Schwartz and David Jolly report.

General Motors went to bankruptcy court on Tuesday to begin the process of selling its best assets to a government-backed company that would become the linchpin of its turnaround plan, The New York Times’s Micheline Maynard and Michael J. de la Merced report.

Raise a glass of seawater for “Disney’s The Little Mermaid,” whose Broadway run will soon dry up. Publicists for the musical adaptation of the 1989 Disney animated feature said on Tuesday that the show would close after its Aug. 30 performance. “The Little Mermaid” opened on Broadway in January 2008 after a 2007 tryout in Denver, with a budget of $15 million, a wardrobe of wheel-heeled shoes to simulate underwater movement, and a score that offered well-known songs by Alan Menken and Howard Ashman as well as new tunes by Mr. Menken and Glenn Slater. But reviews were mixed, evoking Disney’s dutiful Broadway staging of “Beauty and the Beast” more than its imaginative production of “The Lion King.” At its closing, “The Little Mermaid” will have played 50 previews and 685 performances at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. A national tour is planned for fall 2010.
The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts on Wednesday is to announce a national tour for a program it started in February to help struggling nonprofit arts organizations around the country.

The groundbreaking hip-hop trio Run-DMC, which emerged from the streets of Hollis, Queens in the 1980s and shattered musical barriers with their 1986 collaboration with Aerosmith, will be honored with the symbolic renaming of a street corner in Hollis, under City Council legislation adopted on Tuesday.

The Metropolitan Opera, struggling to make headway against large and looming deficits, has won a cost saving from its stagehands. The stagehands union, Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, said on Tuesday the workers agreed to forgo a 3 percent increase in salary and benefit expenses for the 2009-2010 season, the last in its contract. The union and the Met agreed to extend the contract for another year, when the full raise will go into effect.
What we’re reading on Tuesday morning.

The company that was to produce Michael Jackson‘s marathon “This Is It” concert series in London has offered refunds to fans who purchased tickets for the shows. In a news release on Tuesday, the promoter AEG Live said that ticket holders for the 50 sold-out shows that were planned to begin at London’s O2 Arena on July 13 could receive full refunds from authorized ticket sellers. Alternately, customers can receive souvenir tickets for the concerts instead of refunds; the company said that ticket designs and more details on the refund plan would appear on the Web site MichaelJacksonLive.com beginning Wednesday. In a statement, Randy Phillips, the president and chief executive of AEG Live, said, “The world lost a kind soul who just happened to be the greatest entertainer the world has ever known. Since he loved his fans in life, it is incumbent upon us to treat them with the same reverence and respect after his death.”

With the benefit of a weekend to process the news, Stephen Colbert on Monday turned in late-night comedy’s most pointed reaction yet to the death of Michael Jackson (and the news media’s coverage of it). “We’ll always have good memories of the legendary performer,” Mr. Colbert said in his opening remarks, “providing your memories stop around 1989. Let’s say you were hit in the head or something.”
UpdatedPina Bausch, the choreographer and exponent of the Neo-Expressionist form of German dance known as Tanztheater, died Tuesday in Wuppertal. She was 68.

That collective “oooh” you just heard from Broadway is the sound of theatergoers whose solid (or sullied) flesh has melted and resolved itself into a dew after learning that Jude Law is headed their way. Mr. Law, the “Cold Mountain” and “Talented Mr. Ripley” star, will play the title character in a Broadway production of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet” that is transferring from the Donmar Warehouse in London. In a news release Tuesday, publicists for the Broadway run of “Hamlet” said that the play would be directed by the Donmar Warehouse’s artistic director, Michael Grandage (Broadway’s “Frost/Nixon”), and would run for twelve weeks at the Broadhurst Theater. Previews are scheduled to begin on Sept. 12 and an official opening is slated for Oct. 6. Additional actors from the Donmar Theater company are expected to join the “Hamlet” cast, and a production of the play is planned at Elsinore Castle in Denmark from Aug. 25 through 30.

LONDON — Snow! Oh, the bliss of those white, icy flakes falling gently onto the stage, as poor little Oliver Twist was being dragged through the streets to be sold in bondage to an undertaker. I know my heart should have gone out to the underfed urchin, but all I could do was envy him. It was 85 degrees on the streets of London on Monday, and it felt like at least that among the fan-waving, water-gulping capacity audience at the Drury Lane Theater Royal, where the 1960 musical “Oliver!” has been revived (yet again). And all I wanted at that moment was to be standing in a snow shower, even a phony one.

Pina Bausch, who died today at 68, created many pieces throughout her career inspired by her travels to Turkey (“Nefés”), Portugal (“Masurca Fogo”), the United States (“Nur Du (Only You)”) and several other countries. During her company’s last appearance in New York, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in December, she presented “Bamboo Blues,” which grew out of her time in India.
George Clooney is set to leave Warner Brothers for Sony.

In the days that have followed Michael Jackson‘s death, consumers have been flocking to any media featuring the King of Pop. Though final SoundScan sales numbers won’t be available until Wednesday, Billboard reports that at least three of Mr. Jackson’s albums, “Number Ones,” “The Essential Michael Jackson” and “Thriller,” are on track to sell more than 100,000 copies each in the week that ended on Sunday. With the Black Eyed Peas’ “The E.N.D.” likely to sell less than 100,000 units in that same week, it will be the first time that a back catalog album has outsold the No. 1 album on the current Billboard chart.

How much David Mamet can a single theater season accommodate? In addition to his coming pair of one-act plays at the Atlantic Theater Company and the Broadway debut of his new play, “Race,” Mr. Mamet’s play “Oleanna” will be revived on Broadway in the fall. The production, which is transferring from the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, stars Bill Pullman and Julia Stiles as a college professor and a student who accuses him of sexual harassment. In a news release, publicists for the Broadway production said that it would run at the Golden Theater, with previews to begin on Sept. 29 and an official opening scheduled for Oct. 11. It will be directed by Doug Hughes (“A Man for All Seasons”), who directed the Los Angeles production, and produced by Jeffrey Finn. This is the first time that “Oleanna” will be performed on Broadway, as well as Ms. Stiles’s Broadway debut.
Vibe, one of the nation’s leading popular music magazines, is closing immediately, a spokeswoman said Tuesday.

The last time Laura Linney appeared in a play by Donald Margulies, in the 2004 Broadway production of “Sight Unseen,” she picked up her second Tony Award nomination. Now Ms. Linney (of “John Adams” and “The Savages”) is to work with Mr. Margulies (“Dinner With Friends”) again in Manhattan Theater Club‘s coming Broadway production of “Time Stands Still.” In a news release on Tuesday, publicists for the Broadway production said that Ms. Linney would star in the play about a photographer who is tended to by her journalist husband after she is injured covering the Iraq War. The play, previously announced for New York City Center – Stage I, will run at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, with previews to begin on Jan. 5 and an official opening of Jan. 28. It is to be directed by Daniel Sullivan (“Twelfth Night”), who directed Ms. Linney in “Sight Unseen,” as well as the world premiere of “Time Stands Still” at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles earlier this year.

David J. Kahn is the master of special event puzzles. When the particular event is unexpected, he has to do his magic on a compressed time schedule. The entire crossword production staff, including editors, test solvers and fact checkers, has to scramble. It's worth it, though. A tribute puzzle is a rare honor, but the sudden passing of 10/25 Down deserves to be noted. The quicker the better, of course, and amazingly this puzzle appears in print just six days after we first heard the sad news.

"When he's playing like this, he's unbeatable." ) But until the raved-about star faces someone he or she has had trouble beating, it's hard to tell how well the bigger name is really playing.
