In soccer in the Western Hemisphere, North is North and South is South and they shall rarely meet on the soccer field.

The number of agencies that will work on tobacco accounts has dwindled from the heyday of cigarette advertising, when myriad shops fought to create campaigns for brands like Camel, Chesterfield, Lucky Strike and Old Gold. Now, one of the few agencies that still creates such ads is expanding its relationship with a huge tobacco client.

The groundbreaking hip-hop trio Run-DMC, which emerged from the streets of Hollis, Queens, in the 1980s and shattered musical barriers with their 1986 collaboration with Aerosmith, will be honored with the symbolic renaming of a street corner in Hollis, under City Council legislation adopted on Tuesday.

The Glastonbury music festival, which ended this past Sunday, is always a good chance to see what the cool kids are wearing, on stage and off. While Fergie seemed to be trying to doing a mash-up of Lady Gaga and Kayne West (harem pants and quasi shutter shades), and Ms. Gaga herself (she changed five times during her set) donned a flame-shooting bra, the fans were not to be outstyled. Above are some of our favorite looks.
Tanveer Ahmad, a Pakistani man who died in 2005 in a jail in New Jersey, was lost in the snarl of the American immigration system.
It's all in the delivery.

In the past I have written about the declining rate of entrepreneurship in the United States and have shown some charts demonstrating it. In today's post, I want to return to my discussion of this problem and provide evidence of the trend from three different sources.

Thousands of people assembled on West 125th Street on Tuesday afternoon, standing for hours behind metal police barricades and waiting to enter the Apollo Theater where a fond, raucous and occasionally somber memorial was held to honor the memory of Michael Jackson, five days after his death in California at the age of 50.

In Restaurants this week, Frank Bruni reviews Bar Artisanal, Terrance Brennan's downtown outpost. In Briefs, Ligaya Mishan has a Central Park picnic at Public Fare and Frank Bruni checks in on Diner in Williamsburg.

Free music and movies, mostly pirated, abound on the Internet. But Hans Pandeya thinks he has an even better offer than free. He wants to pay Web users to share songs or films - with the full approval of the copyright owners.
Here are some highlights (or low points) in crime in our towns over the past week, taken from the blotters of the three police departments.

Our guest blogger today is the designer and blonde's blonde, Donatella Versace. Versace is in town briefly to host tomorrow's official opening of Art Unites, an initiative created in collaboration with the Whitney's education department. As part of the program, 1,400 children from the Starlight Foundation in the United States and the One Foundation in Asia will be given art supplies to make original drawings that will be fashioned into one-of-kind Versace tote bags and sold worldwide at Versace boutiques and through the Gilt Groupe. Here, la dolce diva muses on her favorite spots in New York.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science opened its ranks to 134 new members on Tuesday. Under academy rules, as many as 166 new members could have been admitted, but the group has been trying to keep the membership trim, at just under 6,000 voting members.
Homes in Spokane, Wash., Lexington, Ky., and in Spanish Lake, Mo.
This more casual, downtown spinoff of Artisanal in Midtown repackages current trends with astonishing thoroughness.
Vibe magazine is shutting down immediately, as Richard Pérez-Peña reported today. Publisher Edgar Hernandez had discussed some of the problems the magazine was having in an interview this month.
The Animal Planet series tells real stories of parasitic infection and detection in a suspenseful, ticking-clock style.
The "BET Awards '09" on June 28, dedicated to Michael Jackson after the "King of Pop" died, delivered the cable channel's largest audience on record.

My friends and I are planning to go to Johannesburg to watch the finals of the Indian Premier League Cricket. We will be there for three days. We wanted some advice on what we could do. Is it possible to do a day trip to the Kruger National Park from Johannesburg?
Fordham University's decade-long efforts to expand its West Side campus moved forward on Tuesday, as the City Council voted to approve the $1.6 billion plan.

If you're one of the thousands of readers who signed up for a Run Well training plan, you'll be interested in some great new features that make it easier to use. And if you're one of the early users who became frustrated by certain features, we encourage you to check out the following changes.

Fox and NBC continued with Michael Jackson commemorations on Monday night. From 8 to 10 p.m., Fox garnered just 4.2 million viewers for a two-hour encore of last season's "American Idol" episode featuring songs by the singer, while NBC's 10 p.m. "Dateline" special, a re-broadcast of Martin Bashir's famous 2003 interview with the performer, attracted a modest 6.7 million viewers, less than CBS's rerun of "CSI: Miami" in the hour (8 million), according to Nielsen's estimates.

It doesn't surprise me how often people order cold noodles with sesame sauce at Chinese restaurants. What is surprising, though, is how few people make the dish at home. It's incredibly easy to prepare, with common ingredients, and you can serve it as a main course or appetizer.

A New York carwash chain agreed to pay $3.4 million in back wages and liquidated damages to 1,187 current and former employees to resolve part of a lawsuit brought by the United States Department of Labor in August 2005.
What? Dawn of the dinosaurs? In the Ice Age? You’ve got to be kidding.

MILWAUKEE -- The Mets getting good news about an injured player? Novel concept, huh? Soon, the Mets are expected to announce that Carlos Beltran's second opinion Monday with Dr. Richard Steadman in Vail, Colo., confirmed that he has a bone bruise in his right knee. More important, Beltran does not need surgery.

Update | 5:06 p.m. A federal judge on Tuesday revoked the bail for R. Allen Stanford, the Texas billionaire accused of masterminding a $7 billion fraud, sending him back to jail to await trial, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss reports from Houston.
While John Tierney is on vacation, other science reporters are contributing to TierneyLab.

Updated, With Latest Developments, 6:30 p.m.: The Minnesota Supreme Court's declaration that Democrat Al Franken has won the state's hotly contested Senate seat produced nearly minute-by minute reactions and news. Featured in the post below are the announcements by Gov. Tim Pawlenty that he would certify the election results for Mr. Franken today; reactions from the national G.O.P. (no congratulatory note from Chairman Michael Steele); Senate Republicans on the Democrats' 60-vote achievement as well as Mr. Franken's list of his new committee assignments, which include the Judiciary Committee.

United States troops completed their withdrawal from most major Iraqi cities today, as per the status of forces agreement between the two countries. Iraq declared Tuesday a holiday -- National Sovereignty Day -- and put on a military parade. Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki went on TV to address his nation.

J. Ezra Merkin, the New York financier who lost more than $2.4 billion of his clients' money in Bernard L. Madoff's Ponzi scheme, agreed to sell his famed art collection on Tuesday for $310 million in a deal that could pave the way for a future settlement with Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo.

South Orange's Smart Growth Historic Commission will be holding a public workshop tonight at 7:30 p.m. at The Baird, 5 Mead Street, in South Orange. If you attend, can you jot down pretty much everything that sounds important or interesting, snap a few pictures if you can, and send us a post based on your notes? It can be anything from a full article to a bulleted list - we're flexible.
The trend of cable news viewers moving away from CNN continued in the second quarter of 2009 with MSNBC beating CNN in weeknights for the first time ever for a full quarter of a year.

The withdrawal of American troops from Iraq's cities and towns was the leading international story of the day, reflected in the first four photographs of the slide show. In contrast to the regimented formality of the scene in Slide 1, photographed by Saad Shalash of Reuters, a far more impromptu - and exuberant - moment was captured at a checkpoint in Baghdad by Moises Saman for The Times (Slide 3).

Forty-one musicians from the Youth Orchestras of Essex County lifted off Friday for their tour of some of Austria's most famous performance venues, including stops in Vienna, Salzburg and Innsbruck. Twenty-six of the players are from Maplewood, South Orange, and Millburn-Short Hills. Here's part one in a blog diary by Mathilda Lombos, a trombonist from Short Hills.
A Caesar salad with moist shreds of chicken, far different from the usual restaurant fare.

There's plenty of opportunity for ogling this week with two New York galleries hosting knockout all-girl shows. Despite the serious-sounding women's studies title, "The Female Gaze: Women Look At Women" Cheim & Read's current exhibition features lots of skin by art world-goddesses like Louise Bourgeois, Lisa Yuskavage, Marina Abramovic and Nan Goldin. Further downtown, at Satori gallery's show "Glam Shackle and Spice," Bettina Sellman makes fairy tale paintings of beautiful women, while Anne Spurgeon explores body image in her own Jane Fonda workout video, in which she accessorizes her leotard with a bottle of beer. Both shows raise interesting ideas about gender, sexuality and female identity, but what's most curious are the similarities between some of the emerging talent at Satori gallery and that of the established players at Cheim & Read.
WIMBLEDON, England -- If Wimbledon is making Centre Court assignments for women's players based on their looks, it's news to Martina Navratilova.
ALBANY -- It all started with a can of Coke.

The Rebus challenge, which was to make words using letters, numbers, symbols and pictures, was well received by some regular enthusiasts, but did not attract as many responses as our usual mathematical challenges. Nevertheless, we had some very interesting and creative entries. Here are some of them:

One important issue of the health care debate is what to do with the employer-based health insurance system. As Uwe Reinhardt has written, nowhere else in the industrialized world does losing your job also mean losing your health care.
To no one's surprise, the Environmental Protection Agency has granted California the waiver it has long sought to regulate tailpipe emissions of greenhousegases.
The Gannett Company, owner of the nation's largest newspaper chain, will go through another round of layoffs soon, with an announcement possible in the next few days, executives said Tuesday.

New York City's thriving black market for illegal food vending permits took a blow Tuesday morning when six people were arrested as a result of multiple sting operations by the city's Department of Investigation. Sotirios "Steve" Econopouly, 71; Fernando Quesnay, 52; Ifigenia "Effie" Tsatsaronis, 40; Jacob Shimon, 46; Nikhli Dhameliya, 23; and Adamadia Arabatzis, 48, were arrested in Queens and Manhattan and charged with multiple counts of fraud.

Theresa Burns, our Garden State blogger, is out of town celebrating her birthday (happy birthday!) this week and next. This Tuesday's gardening blog is written by Clyde Tressler, a Maplewood resident and someone who knows how to put the green in grass care.

President Obama will soon receive a thank-you gift for his speech to the Muslim world in Cairo. Inspired by the address, in which Mr. Obama quoted the Koran, the Council on American-Islamic Relations plans to distribute 100,000 copies of the Koran to national, state and local leaders.

President Obama marked the withdrawal of American combat forces from Iraqi towns and cities with little fanfare on Tuesday, using a ceremony in the East Room of the White House to declare the day "an important milestone'' even as he warned of "difficult days ahead.''

The third amendment to Brooke Astor's will includes a scribbled signature in the bottom right corner of the cover page that sits slightly askew of the signature line. The letters are bold and sharp, and it unmistakably reads, "Brooke Russell Astor."
Update: The official announcement from the Department of Investigation.
ROME | This is the last week to visit "Beato Angelico: the Dawn of the Renaissance" at Rome's Capitoline Museums, an exhibit that's as enchanting as it is frustrating.
With time possibly running out on Roger Federer's and Pete Sampras's shared record of 14 Grand Slam titles, I produced a graphic for Monday's editions that compared the careers of both players.

Chang W. Lee, a photographer for The Times, is exploring transformations in people's lives, in photos and videos. Click here to view this week's video. For some of those profiled, it is their first true chance; for others, their last. Essentially, though, these stories are portraits of journeys to truthful self-existence.

In September 2007, thousands of Buddhist monks led the "saffron revolution," a series of peaceful marches in response to military oppression and a dire economic situation in Myanmar, formerly Burma.

No one is quite certain what might happen tomorrow starting at noon, when N.H.L. free agents are unleashed on the open market. There is some thinking that the league's G.M.'s won't be throwing long-term contracts for big money wildly at players, as they have in the past. They expect league revenues to decline, the salary cap along with it and they'd be stuck with those deals. Of course, such real world dangers might be disregarded by teams with lots of cap space and real needs on their roster.
DVRs, or digital video recorders, first popularized by the TiVo brand, have become an essential part of the TV viewing experience in many American homes.

While LCD TVs take the vast percentage of flat-panel sales, LCD manufacturers have been playing catchup when it comes to picture quality. The industry has been introducing technological tweaks to improve LCD's ability to handle motion, increase contrast, and display colors more accurately.
Thanks a lot, Joe Zarella.
Lee and Linda Bigelow restored an old four-story town house in the historic Alpes Maritimes village of Saint-Jeannet, which has about 3,500 residents.
A three-bedroom house in Selfoss, a 40-minute drive from Reykjavik, is on the market for 60 million kronur ($469,815) .
Update, June 30, 6:35 p.m.: Added link to press release.

A substantial expansion aimed at increasing interest in Hong Kong Disneyland, rumored for months, became a reality on Tuesday with Chinese officials and the Walt Disney Company announcing new attractions that will cost about $500 million.
Prabhu Guptara, a noted business professor and specialist on long-term global trends, offers a wide-reaching plan for overhauling financial regulation.

The Choice typically casts a skeptical eye on efforts to rank colleges in various categories. But we must concede to being intrigued and even amused by Boat U.S. Magazine's attempt to "help students find the top marine programs and extracurricular boating activities offered by four-year schools.''

The Environmental Protection Agency has granted California's long-sought request to tighten tailpipe emission regulations, a key step in the Obama administration's plan to make cars across the nation more fuel-efficient.
Vibe, one of the nation's leading popular music magazines, is closing immediately, a spokeswoman said Tuesday.
After several weeks of hospitalization with a staph infection and recurring fevers, Senator Robert C. Byrd has been released and is recuperating at home, his office announced in a statement today.
How old do you feel? And how old will you be when you reach old age?

The Obama administration sent Congress a detailed proposal on Tuesday to create a consumer protection agency responsible for financial products, a move that marks the first shot in a heated battle with banks and other financial institutions over how to regulate home mortgages, credit cards and other forms of lending, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews reports from Washington.

At approximately 10 a.m., a power transformer blew up and fell to the ground in the parking lot of the Maplecrest Ford Lincoln Mercury Dealership on Rte. 124 in Union, sending billowing clouds of black smoke hundreds of feet into the air. Traffic along Rte. 124 and Springfield Avenue was snarled for over an hour, with police re-routing westbound traffic to Valley Street and Vauxhall Road, because access to Rte. 24 was cut off.

Gov. Mark Sanford of South Carolina disclosed on Tuesday that he had had casual encounters with several other women before starting an affair last year with an Argentinian woman. But Mr. Sanford, in an interview with the Associated Press, said that he only had some physical contact with the other women, and had sex only with the Argentine, Maria Belen Chapur.
(Emily discovers that some things that arrive with the CSA box are challenging - MB)
Three monks living in exile in Utica, N.Y., continue the campaign for their country's democracy.

Forlornly unidentified and altogether forgotten, these sites have been literally lost to history. On Avenue of the Americas, there is a block where the first cellphone call was completed in 1973; on West 125th Street, where the old Blumstein's department store stood, nothing marks the place where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was stabbed in 1958. Then there is the spot on Fifth Avenue where Winston Churchill, crossing against the light, was struck by a car in 1931 and nearly killed.
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

The New York Times Sunday Magazine is going to have a special issue on Aug. 23 devoted to women in the developing world. This is the first time the magazine has done something quite like this, and we're all excited here. The lead article will be an excerpt from "Half the Sky," the book that my wife and I have written about this topic (the book comes out Sept. 8), and everything else in the issue will also be themed to the topic. We're also going to try to highlight, in print and online, some of the aid organizations that do important work in this space, so that readers who want to get engaged will have some ideas about how they can follow up.
First, General Motors discontinued the Pontiac brand and said it would produce the Pontiac Vibe through the 2010 model year -- the last Pontiac Americans would be able to buy.

The Moment sent the style blogger Elizabeth Spiridakis, who's spending the summer biking around Portland, Ore., to check out the next level of burger insanity.When you order the Voodoo Doughnut Burger from the Original, the newish spot in downtown Portland, Ore., that is a super-designy restaurant that wants you to think it's just a hipster diner, you are given the option of a side of soup, salad or fries. Which, let's get real here, is a bit of a joke: if you are committing to consuming a beef patty covered in cheddar cheese and sandwiched between a glazed pastry from Portland's famed all-night doughnut shop, getting it avec greens seems a tad ridiculous. (The fries are excellent - definitely double-fried.)
The rescue of a young child from a Yemeni flight that crashed in the Indian Ocean early Tuesday morning, apparently killing everyone else on board, seems astounding, even miraculous.
The elite marathoner Deena Kastor and Mark Bittman, a food columnist at The New York Times, talk about food and running.

The State Department issued a travel alert on Monday recommending that American citizens defer all non-essential travel to Honduras following the military ousting of President Manuel Zelaya in a coup on Sunday.
The lap feels awfully empty today.
Writing on his Executive Suite blog, Joe Nocera of The New York Times disputes the notion that that the Securities and Exchange Commission should repay victims of Bernard Madoff's fraud:
Crime committed by seniors.
ALBANY -- For the first time in a week, Senate Democrats and Republicans gathered together on Tuesday in the same room, at the same time, in relative peace -- if not quite harmony.
The slowing of the private equity fee machine is sure to be causing some heartache for investment bankers.
George Clooney is in final talks to leave Warner Brothers for a new two-year deal with Sony.

After five years as Royal Dutch Shell's chief executive officer, Jeroen van der Veer, 61, is stepping down today. I wrote on Monday about some of the challenges that his successor, Peter Voser, now faces at Shell.
While John Tierney is on vacation, other science reporters are contributing to TierneyLab.

Quick: Can you name the men's designer whose collection of softened silhouettes for an LVMH-owned label won it accolades for first time since the departure of Hedi Slimane, while failing to generate enthusiasm for his own eponymous line? After a whirlwind final weekend of men's spring 2010 fashion in Paris, it's easy to lose your head. That's why Scorecard is here to bring you up to speed with a handily reductive recap of the critics' parting shots.
Location: Minneapolis.

For die-hard design aficionados who aren't content to view the winners and runners-up of I.D. Magazine's 2009 Annual Design Review in the July/August issue (coming out tomorrow), or in our slide show above, the Manhattan headquarters of Material ConneXion, the global materials consultancy, is hosting an exhibition through August 21. The Design Review, which began in 1954, recognizes the best in design in consumer products, graphics, packaging, environments, furniture, equipment, concepts and interactive, chosen by jurors who are notable in their respective fields. This year's winners include Harry Allen's sleek first aid kit for Johnson & Johnson, the Voodoo Envy laptop by Hewlett-Packard and the new TKTS booth in Times Square. If you can't make it to Material ConneXion but yearn for more, there is a short video of the exhibition below and on the I.D. Web site.
Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.
The older Americans are, the younger they feel, a large new survey found.
Who's next?
In today's Cases column, Well contributor Dana Jennings writes about a surprising "side effect" of cancer treatment.
T Magazine's women's fashion director keeps one step ahead of the trends.
Post updated, 07/01; 4:30 p.m.
The Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, has agreed to hear the eminent domain lawsuit against Atlantic Yards, Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn reports.

People who travel internationally are used to answering routine questions at the border, but John Dinges, a former NPR managing editor for news and a professor at Columbia University's School of Journalism, grew increasingly uncomfortable as a United States Customs and Border Protection agent at Miami International Airport last Saturday grew increasingly detailed in his inquiries.

BG Group said it would pay Dallas-based Exco Resources $1.3 billion for an interest in shale gas resources, The Globe and Mail reported, as oil and gas firms continue to snap up assets before an economic recovery drives prices higher.

The Times reports this morning on new research that has found that 47,000 older Americans are treated in emergency rooms each year following falls associated with walkers and canes. Fractures, bruises and abrasions were the most common injuries associated with the falls. Almost a third of all injuries were to the lower trunk, including the hips.

Your child's end-of-year report card should be arriving home right about now. As you read it, keep this unsettling thought in mind: more than one-third of teens with cellphones (35 percent) admit they have used those phones, at least once, to cheat on tests.
This post will update with news and notes from the four women's quarterfinals from Wimbledon on Tuesday.
In a quest to lower energy prices, some municipalities in the oil-rich state of Alaska are looking to small-scale nuclear power.
Of the four women's quarterfinals, one in particular stands out for me: the Serena Williams-Victoria Azarenka match.
The German government decided on Monday night to grant a 50 million euro loan to Quelle, the home-shopping arm of the bankrupt German retailer Arcandor.
A state judge on Monday ordered the 62 members of the State Senate to convene together on Tuesday morning, backing Gov. David A. Paterson's latest attempt to break the deadlock in the chamber.
With President Obama holding another town-hall meeting on health care this Wednesday in northern Virginia, his push to see the system overhauled moves once again beyond the Beltway.
From 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. EST today, Intrepid Travel, an adventure tour company based in Boulder, Colo., is offering 15 to 60 percent off its 400-plus trips.

We asked for your end-of-the-year pictures in our Be the Journalist section on the top right corner of the blog, and now here's a big thank you to Eutrice McDonald for sending in pictures of her family's activities this spring.

To supplement reporting by our New York Times colleagues inside Iran, The Lede will continue to track the aftermath of Iran's disputed presidential election, as we have since election day, June 12. Please refresh this page throughout the day to get the latest updates at the top of your screen (updates are stamped with the time in New York). For an overview of the current situation, read the main news article on our Web site, which will be updated throughout the day. This week, readers are invited to ask questions of New York Times staff members in our "Talk to the Newsroom" forum.

On Monday, the European Commission, the European Union's executive branch, said that it had reached a voluntary agreement with some of the biggest names in the electronics industry to introduce a common charger for cellphones that fits all models.
Swiss banks are shutting the accounts of Americans as the Internal Revenue Service accelerates the hunt for tax dodgers, Bloomberg News reported.

Sparx Group, Asia's biggest hedge-fund manager, plans to start its first global macro fund, adding a strategy that was among the few winners in 2008, when Sparx posted the first annual loss in its 20-year history, Bloomberg News reported.
Looks from the spring 2010 men’s shows in Paris.
Aston Martin has announced a new compact car concept, the Cygnet. Aston calls the car a "luxury commuter concept," but that wasn't the biggest surprise in the news release.
Carlyle Group, Primus Financial Holdings and MBK Partners may seek to buy American International Group's Taiwan life insurance unit, three people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

China's state-owned mining group, Chinalco, is taking up its full entitlement to preserve its stake in rival Rio Tinto, media reports said on Tuesday, with trade in the rights suggesting Chinalco is far from cutting ties with Rio.

Japan's Shinsei Bank and Aozora Bank, two money-losing lenders backed by United States investors, are likely to announce plans on Wednesday to merge by next year, two sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.
Citigroup has wooed a top equity derivatives salesman away from Morgan Stanley, offering him a guaranteed bonus to join the embattled bank, Forbes.com reports.

Austin Capital Management, a fund of hedge funds that had invested 7.5 percent of its assets with Bernard L. Madoff, is being sued by New Mexico's teacher's union for negligence that caused big losses for the state.

Oracle, the software giant, made no high-profile purchases in fiscal 2009, but it still managed to quietly spend $1.2 billion buying other companies and assets during the period, MarketWatch reported.
John Tierney is on vacation. While he is away other science reporters will be contributing to TierneyLab.

Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Monday urged Russia's state-controlled banks to boost lending to major industries and advised their heads not to take their summer vacations until this was done, The Associated Press reported.

Ooma, which makes VoIP boxes that users can install to make free landline calls, has landed another $14 million in a round of financing led by an existing investor, Worldview Technology Partners, VentureBeat reported.

Japan pledged to prop up the money-losing chip maker Elpida Memory with up to $1.7 billion in public and private capital and loans, the country's first capital injection in a company since the financial crisis.

After hunting for three months, Facebook hired the former chief financial officer of Genentech as its C.F.O., a move that is likely to reignite chatter about a possible initial public offering for the social network powerhouse.
Readers are welcome to share their thoughts on devising a more just and entertaining overtime system:
WIMBLEDON, England - Somewhere south of Melbourne, there's an Australian architect who must be smirking ever so slightly about the roof here at the All England Lawn Tennis Club.
Whether you're young or old, good health, stalwart friends and financial security are the best predictors of happiness, according to a new survey on aging by the Pew Research Center.
Foreign photographers have always been active in photogenic nation but new galleries and festivals have arisen recently to promote work by native residents.
JPMorgan Chase is cutting its ties with a $600 million-plus private equity fund run by two former Citigroup executives, Robert B. Willumstad and Marjorie Magner, The Financial Times reported.
The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to permanently freeze the assets of a California financier accused of bilking investors until his fraud trial is over, The Associated Press said.

Today's idea: The elderly -- a drag on the economy? Think again, a report says: "The United States might be on the cusp of an entrepreneurship boom-not in spite of an aging population but because of it."

With signs pointing to an M.&A. spending spree by Dell, where does storage rank on its wish list? The 451 Group takes a look at public and private storage companies that could be tempting acquisitions for the cash-rich systems vendor.
It took 14 months, but the Carlyle Group has amassed a $1 billion war chest to hunt prey in Asia.

The Justice Department opposes Continental Airlines' request for broard antitrust immunity to work more closely with United Airlines and other carriers in setting prices and schedules for international service, The Associated Press said.
Iraqi citizens and soldiers celebrated the formal pullback of American troops from Iraqi cities.
ISTANBUL | Summer means jazz festivals are sprouting up all over Europe, but only in Istanbul does that mean enjoying cool sounds under the hot Turkish sun aboard a boat on the Bosporus.
In what could be a painful reversal for Canada's Magna International, RHJ International may end up driving off with General Motors's Opel unit.

A London-based hedge fund manager and the fund's chief investment officer have agreed to a nearly $18 million settlement resolving United States regulators' allegations that one of its funds defrauded mutual funds and investors through trading practices like market-timing, The Associated Press reported.

Just 30 days after filing for Chapter 11 protection, General Motors heads into bankruptcy court today to seek approval to sell its best assets to a government-backed corporate entity that is the linchpin of its turnaround plan.

R. Allen Stanford spent Monday night in jail after prosecutors told a federal judge in Houston that the accused swindler would likely flee the country rather than face life in prison if released on bail, Reuters said.
Congress is considering ways to make sure speculative trading helps commodity markets rather than distorting pricing signals, Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack told Reuters Television.

Anglo American is considering finding a partner for its huge iron ore project in Brazil, including from China, but the move is not a defense against an unwanted merger approach from rival Xstrata, according to Reuters, which cited sources familiar with the situation.

Moises Saman does not need a timetable to know that things have changed in Iraq - however tenuously - since his last rotation there a year ago as a photographer for The New York Times. "You hear music on the street sometimes," he said Monday in a telephone interview from Baghdad. He's also noticed that people linger outdoors at night. (Indeed, the music from the park opposite The Times's bureau was so loud last night that it was hard to hear Mr. Saman sometimes.) "I think there's more life on the street," he said. "Without painting too rosy a picture, there's a definite sense that life is moving."
"How much did you lose?"

A Supreme Court case concerning a quirky documentary critical of Hillary Rodham Clinton may result in a major overhaul of rules governing campaign spending by corporations, the court signaled Monday, The New York Times's Adam Liptak reported.

The Supreme Court paved the way on Monday for states to enforce fair-lending laws and other consumer protection measures against the nation's biggest banks, striking down a rule that limited such powers to federal banking regulators, The New York Times's John Schwartz reported.

He grew up in elite circles in Buenos Aires, acquiring the polish and privileged connections that paved the way for him to become a star private banker in New York to wealthy clients at UBS and JPMorgan Chase.

As the world's second-largest and fastest-growing consumer of oil, China is showing increasing interest in oil fields in a country that has until very recently seemed to be firmly in the American sphere of influence for natural resources: Iraq.

Markets rose as higher oil prices lifted energy shares and speculation grew that the recession was easing. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index extended its best quarterly rally since 1998 as investors remained optimistic, analysts said.
Good style mixes high-ticket items with brilliant but affordable gets. In this column, T's fashion team finds the cheap and the chic.
A Korean phrase describing self-indulgent purchases.
Photos from a show in London that is devoted to the music of Michael Jackson.
Ms. Storm, the Texas-born actress, made wholesome perkiness a defining element of television’s golden age on two hit sitcoms.
Mr. Travalena, a comedian and singer, was known for a range of impressions of celebrities like Bugs Bunny, Ted Koppel and singers like Sammy Davis Jr. and Bobby Darin.

Updated, 11:39 a.m. | The senior pastor of Riverside Church, the renowned bastion of liberal theology and social activism on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is resigning after just nine months on the job.
Hal Turner, an Internet radio host who was charged with inciting violence against lawmakers, is described by neighbors in North Bergen, N.J., as polite if somewhat confrontational.
A unit of Johnson & Johnson said that a jury has ordered Abbott Laboratories to pay $1.67 billion in a patent infringement suit over rheumatoid arthritis drugs.
An airliner with 153 people on board and belonging to Yemen’s state carrier crashed in the Indian Ocean, apparently near the archipelago of Comoros.
The coup leaders, who were trying to prevent Venezuelan president Hugo Chávez from bringing Honduras into his fold, may end up giving him more strength in the region.
Leading Democrats seem open to nearly any idea so long as it will lead to passing legislation, perhaps at the expense of passing sensible legislation.

Wednesday, June 30, 1909(use this link to access today's entire issue)

Hyundai Motor America is introducing a promotion centered on lowering gasoline prices for a year to $1.49 a gallon for buyers of certain models. The promotion, called the Hyundai Assurance $1.49 Gaslock program, is to begin on Wednesday when details will be unveiled involving the nuts-and-bolts about how the program will work for buyers. It is presented under the Hyundai Assurance banner, which has served the Korean automaker well in reassuring consumers worried about the economy.

A chart accompanying the Charles Blow column on Saturday incorrectly identified which presidential candidates won Maine and Tennessee in 2008 in a list of states ranked by subscriptions to online pornographic sites. Maine voted for Barack Obama, not John McCain. Tennessee favored Mr. McCain, not Mr. Obama.
A former worker at a turkey plant in Lewisburg has been sentenced to a year of home confinement for stomping on a bird’s head and slamming another to the ground in abuse caught on video.

Monica Conyers, a Detroit city councilwoman, resigned from office, three days after admitting in court that she had accepted bribes from a company in exchange for her vote on a lucrative city sludge-treatment contract.
In its ruling on employment discrimination law, the Supreme Court upended the rules that Sonia Sotomayor and her colleagues previously played by.
An illegal immigrant accused of killing a San Francisco man and his two sons in a drive-by shooting will stand trial for murder.
Part of a six-floor parking garage near downtown Atlanta collapsed, crushing at least 35 cars.
More than 4,000 gray wolves in the western Great Lakes region are going back on the federal endangered species list, at least temporarily.
Mr. Byrd, part of a prominent family in the state, did not follow his father and older brother into politics.
The justices refused to intervene in a case brought by 9/11 victims’ families seeking to sue the Saudi government and the royal family over the attacks.
The Department of Defense has identified 706 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
FRONT PAGE.
Following a voluntary recall, raw cookie dough from a Nestlé plant in Virginia has tested positive for E. coli bacteria.

An article on June 9 about the pending retirement of Mark W. Olsen, chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, misstated the given name of a board member whose second term will expire this fall. He is Willis, not William, Gradison.

An article on Friday about General Motors’ reversal of a decision to close two plants near Detroit misidentified, in some editions, the political party of Congressman Gary Peters, whose district includes both plants. He is a Democrat, not a Republican.

A Bloomberg News article on Friday about a bankruptcy court’s approval of the sale of the Hartmarx Corporation to the British private equity firm Emerisque Brands misstated the position of Wells Fargo, Hartmarx’s biggest creditor, in the case. The bank had argued that Emerisque’s original offer was too low to repay the loans Hartmarx had defaulted on; it did not argue for the company’s liquidation.
The president told an audience of gay men and lesbians that he remained committed to overturning the military’s “don’t ask, don’t tell” rule.
Before its troops leave for good in 2011, the U.S. has a responsibility and a strong strategic interest to help Iraq emerge as a functioning, sovereign and reasonably democratic state.

An article on Saturday about federal prosecutors’ sentencing recommendation for Bernard L. Madoff misstated the amount of a preliminary forfeiture order from the Federal District Court judge handling the Ponzi scheme case involving Mr. Madoff. The order, from Judge Denny Chin, directed Mr. Madoff to pay more than $170 billion — not million — in forfeited assets. (During Mr. Madoff’s sentencing on Monday, the judge put the forfeiture order into effect.).

The Big City column in some editions last Tuesday, about Katherine Russell Rich, whose new book, “Dreaming in Hindi,” recounts her efforts to learn the language, misspelled the surname of the director of the Center for Indian Studies at the State University at Stony Brook, who said the number of universities offering Hindi classes has increased significantly in the past 10 years. He is S. N. Sridhar, not Sribhar.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about South Carolina politics in the aftermath of Gov. Mark Sanford’s affair misidentified the legislative post held by J. Gresham Barrett, a candidate for governor in the 2010 election. He is a United States representative, not a state representative.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about a reunion of police officers who clashed with demonstrators at the 1968 Democratic National Convention misidentified the scene shown in a photograph being held by a protester outside the reunion. The picture showed Chicago police officers after the killing of the Black Panther Fred Hampton in 1969, not police officers at the 1968 clashes.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Michael Jackson’s doctor, Conrad Murray, misidentified, in some editions, Edward Chernoff, whose office said that the doctor had “answered every and all questions.” Mr. Chernoff is Dr. Murray’s lawyer, not his business partner.

An article on Thursday about a 1998 death penalty case handled by Judge Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, referred incorrectly to the case, in which two men were accused of multiple murders. The men were facing the first federal death penalty trial in Manhattan since the days of the Rosenbergs, not the first death penalty trial since then.
The Brewers pounded Fernando Nieve and four relievers for 19 hits in sending the Mets into third place in the National League East.
An obituary on Friday about Michael Jackson misidentified the area of Los Angeles where he was renting a home. It is Holmby Hills, not the adjacent Bel Air.
The in-flight safety instructional video and a companion ad series show employees of Air New Zealand unclothed, concealed only by body-painted uniforms and strategically placed props.
Dr. Gary D. Kao, accused of mishandling treatment for prostate cancer, spoke before a Congressional panel.
“The man who committed this horrible fraud is not the man whom I have known for all these years.”.
Graciela Ocaña, Argentina’s health minister, resigned Monday amid an outbreak of swine flu that has killed 26 people in the country, government officials said.
Markets rose as higher oil prices lifted energy shares and speculation grew that the recession was easing.
Accounts of witnesses suggested that one victim had fallen first to his death and that the other two had followed in successive, futile rescue efforts.
Mohammed Jawad was captured as a teenager in Kabul and tortured in American custody. Now administration lawyers are blocking efforts to secure his freedom.
An image of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, shown recently on government-run television appears to be a doctored version of an earlier photo.
The European Union said 46 countries supported an institute to track the return of Jewish art and property stolen by the Nazis.
President Mamadou Tandja dissolved the Constitutional Court after appointing eight ministers from parties that back his plan for a referendum on extending his term.

The Yankees’ Mariano Rivera, who earned his 500th save Sunday, has been a model of consistency and dominance because of a cutter that has left him a cut above other relievers.

A man who admitted his role in the theft of the Edvard Munch painting “The Scream” was sentenced Monday to two and a half years in prison by a court in Oslo, The Associated Press reported. A Norwegian appeals court had found the man, Bjoern Hoen, 41, guilty of providing the getaway vehicle that was used in the daytime heist. On Aug. 22, 2004, the Munch Museum in Oslo was raided by two armed masked men, who took “The Scream,” as well as a second Munch painting, “Madonna,” and drove off in a black station wagon. The works were recovered in 2006, but details on how and where they were found have not been made public. Mr. Hoen had admitted that he provided the car driven by the thieves but said that he did not know how the vehicle would be used. Two other men have been sentenced in the case, and a third suspect, whose name was not given, died in 2006.

Hey, ladies (and gentlemen)! Jerry Lewis is headed back to Broadway, this time in the director’s chair. The veteran comedian, last seen on a Broadway stage as Applegate in the revival of “Damn Yankees” in 1995, will direct a musical adaptation of his hit 1963 comedy, “The Nutty Professor,” that is planned for the 2010-11 season, the show’s publicists said in a news release. That film starred Mr. Lewis as the nebbishy Julius Kelp, who invents a formula that transforms him into the debonair Buddy Love. (A 1996 remake starred Eddie Murphy as the overweight Sherman Klump and his suave alter ego.) The adaptation will feature music by Marvin Hamlisch (“A Chorus Line”) and lyrics and book by Rupert Holmes (“Curtains”). A cast has not yet been announced.

The contemporary-art auctions in London continued at Phillips de Pury on Monday evening, where that struggling boutique house held a sale of 39 primarily lower-priced works. Bidding was lively, but the sale totaled $8.4 million, shy of the low estimate of $8.7 million. The top seller was “That Was Then This Is Now,” above, a 1989 painting by Ed Ruscha. It brought $1.1 million, just below the high estimate of $1.2 million. A 1963 sculpture by John Chamberlain, “Mr. Moto,” fashioned from painted, crushed steel, sold for $876,443, in the middle of the estimate range of $636,000 to $954,000. But the item pictured on the catalog cover, “Spiritual America IV,” Richard Prince’s 2005 photo portrait of Brooke Shields, failed to sell. Final prices include the commission to Phillips: 25 percent of the first £25,000 ($41,000), 20 percent of the next £25,000 to £500,000 ($41,000 to $825,000) and 12 percent of the rest. Estimates don’t include commissions. The auctions continue on Tuesday night at Christie’s, which is selling 41 works estimated at $28.6 million to $40.9 million.

The sixth annual Fall for Dance Festival at City Center will pay tribute to the 100th anniversary of the Ballets Russes, City Center said on Monday in a news release. The festival, which will run from Sept. 22 through Oct. 3, will open with a Boston Ballet performance of Nijinsky’s “Afternoon of a Faun,” originally created for the Ballets Russes at its Paris premiere. Other highlights are Ballet West’s production of Bronislava Nijinska’s “Biches,” a new production of “Softly as I Leave You” by Morphoses/the Wheeldon Company and a tribute to John Coltrane by Savion Glover & the Otherz. More information is at nycitycenter.org.
The novelist Alice Hoffman caused a stir over the weekend when she used Twitter to strike back at a mixed review of her latest novel, “The Story Sisters.”

As the lyrics to a song from the Broadway musical “Avenue Q” point out, nothing lasts, and life, work, happiness and discomfort are only for now. So it goes for the musical itself: the show, an adult-theme upgrade of educational children’s shows like “Sesame Street,” will play its last performance on Sept. 13, its publicists said on Monday in a news release. “Avenue Q” (the puppet Princeton, above), which features music and lyrics by Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx and a book by Jeff Whitty, taught Broadway a lesson or two when it opened at the Golden Theater in 2003: in a season that also saw the openings of attention-grabbing productions like “Wicked” and “The Boy From Oz,” the scrappy puppet show was the unexpected winner of the Tony Award for best musical. At its closing, “Avenue Q” will have played 2,534 performances and 22 previews.
An episode of the CBS newsmagazine “60 Minutes” featuring a report about online poker cheats legitimately won Sunday night’s largest audience.

Turns out that backdrop that clocked Bret Michaels at the Tony Awards was only the first surprise to hit “Rock of Ages”: Amy Spanger, who originated the role of the small-town girl turned stripper Sherrie in the Broadway production, has left the show. Ms. Spanger has been out of “Rock of Ages” since June 8. At that time producers said she was on vocal rest at her doctor’s orders but was expected to return to the show on Monday. But on Monday, publicists for the show said in a release that Ms. Spanger had departed because of “personal reasons.” Savannah Wise has been playing the role in Ms. Spanger’s absence. A full-time replacement was not immediately announced.

JESSIMAN--Laura Woodberry, passed away last Wednesday near Durness, Scotland after a hiking accident while vacationing with family members near their second home in Scourie. She was 51 years old. She is survived by her husband Alistair, sons Hugh (25) and Andrew (23) and daughter Margaret (19). She was born Laura Lee Woodberry on August 17, 1957 in New York City. She was the eldest child of Paul and Sandy Woodberry of Dallas, Texas and Sea Island, GA. She is survived by her parents and four siblings: Seth Woodberry of Dallas, TX, Sturgis Woodberry of Darien, CT, Lesley Woodberry Robinson of Mumbai, India and Sarah Woodberry of New York City. She was the loving aunt of 18 nieces and nephews on both sides of the family. She grew up in Greenwich and attended Greenwich Academy before graduating from the Madeira School in Virginia. She spent a post-graduate year at the Uppingham School in Rutland, England where she was elected Head Girl. At Dartmouth College, in Hanover, NH, she captained the women's crew team, wrote for the student newspaper, and graduated in 1980 with the highest distinction in Asian Studies. She met her husband Alistair at Dartmouth. The couple married on Nantucket Island in May, 1981, and recently celebrated 28 years of marriage. After college, Laura worked as an associate banker at Manufacturer's Hanover Trust in New York City, where the Jessimans had their first son, Hugh. They moved to Hong Kong for four years in the 1980s, where their second son Andrew was born. Their daughter Margaret was born in 1990, shortly after they moved to Darien, CT. Son Hugh graduated from Brunswick in 2002 and is now a professional hockey player. He was an Ivy League Rookie of the Year while at Dartmouth, and was drafted in the first round by the N.Y. Rangers. He currently plays for the Nashville Predators organization. Son Andrew graduated from Wake Forest University in 2008, and works as a marketing associate at Priceline in Norwalk, CT. Daughter Margaret just completed her freshman year at Dartmouth, where she competes on the figure skating team. Laura's greatest joy was her family. She was a fixture on the sidelines of her children's sporting events, she was a class mother at Greenwich Academy, and she recently took up golf so she could play with her children. She had a passion for cooking and gardening, making those favorite family activities. She loved to visit new places and enthusiastically planned trips with her extended family. She recently returned from a trip to Rome with her parents and sisters, having accompanied them to France and Russia in past years. She also recently traveled with her husband and children to South America, Tuscany and Prague. Laura enjoyed hill-walking, bicycling and spending time with her friends and family. She also played the piano, studied French and Spanish and volunteered at The Waterside School in Stamford, CT. She loved music and attended the ballet and the symphony regularly. Laura was a remarkable wife, mother, daughter, sister, cousin, friend and always a mentor. To so many, she served as the person to whom everyone asked "What would Laura think?" She had a gift for friendship and will be missed dearly. A private funeral Mass will be held on Tuesday, June 30, conducted by family friend Reverend Gerry Murray. A memorial reception for Laura's friends and family will be held from 4 to 7 pm that Tuesday afternoon at the Country Club of Darien, 300 Mansfield Ave. On Wednesday evening, her son Hugh will participate in a benefit for the Obie Harrington-Howes Foundation to be held at the Darien Ice Rink at 7pm. The attendees will observe a moment of silence in Laura's honor. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to The Waterside School, 535 Fairfield Avenue, Stanford, CT 06902.

8 P.M. (TLC) STAGER INVASION In this latest makeover show, pegged to the stagnant real estate market, Lisa Lynch, a ''home staging'' expert, helps frustrated owners make their residences buyer-friendly in just eight hours and on a budget of $1,000. In this series premiere she comes to the rescue of Chris and Michele Tune (above, with Ms. Lynch at left), who will face foreclosure on their country-themed home unless they can sell it immediately. The first step: painting over the chicken mural on the kitchen cabinets. At 8:30, Ms. Lynch focuses on the home of Marlene Federico, who, since her husband's unexpected death, can no longer afford her mortgage payments. The problem spots include a red and blue ''superhero room'' and a hole in the wall. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWJosh Duhamel talks about his latest film, ''Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen.'' Also, a ride with a taxi driver who asks his passengers to create art.

The Apollo Theater, where Michael Jackson (above, in a 1978 photograph) performed several times, will pay tribute to him on Tuesday with a public memorial, beginning at 2 p.m., when the Rev. Al Sharpton will speak. People will be let in, 600 at a time, to pay their respects or to dance to Mr. Jackson's music (or to leave things onstage). On Wednesday Amateur Night will be dedicated to Mr. Jackson and feature a medley of his hits. Audience members will be encouraged to moonwalk.

CAMERON--Juan Mayer, 84, died June 25 at home in Washington from complications following back surgery. He served in the US Navy Pacific Fleet 1945-46 as a fighter pilot on the USS Bennington. A graduate of Harvard and Harvard Business School, he was an economics writer for Time and Fortune Magazines. After retiring he produced niche-market and videos. An avid sailor, he won the 1967 Annapolis-Newport race. He is survived by his wife Nora L. Cameron, their two children, Nora C. BOCOBO--Dr. Florante, MD, died at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, Hamilton, NJ on Friday, March 27, 2009 after a short illness. He was 91. Dr. Bocobo was born on January 20, 1918, in the city of Manila, Philippines to the late Jorge and Feliza Bocobo. He received his medical degree from the University of the Philippines in 1940 and completed his internship and residency at the Manila General Hospital during WWII. In 1946, he immigrated to the U.S. and completed medical fellowships at Duke University, Columbia University, the University of Pittsburg, and the University of Michigan. In 1950 he joined the faculty of the University of Michigan Medical School where he served as professor of medicine until 1969. He then spent several years working for the Food and Drug Administration, reviewing new drug applications. He then continued his work with the World Health Organization as a field researcher in Asia. In 1974, he joined drug maker E.R. Squibb and Sons where he was involved in clinical research and development until retirement in 1993. During a career that spanned over 53 years, Dr. Bocobo was the author of numerous research papers, was instrumental in the development of a number of major drugs, and was influential in the advancement of medical mycology. Besides his passion for medical research, he was an avid collector of memorabilia and was a gifted photographer. He is survived by his wife, Jewel, his daughter, Cristina, his sons, George and David, his grandchildren, Jordan, Felicia and Patrick, his great-grandchild Danielle, his brother, Ariel, and sisters Dalisay, and Malaya. He is further survived by many nieces, nephews and other relatives. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his son, Danny, his sisters, Elvira and Celia, and his brother, Israel. A memorial service for Dr. Bocobo was held Saturday, April 4, at the Mather-Hodge Funeral Home in Princeton, NJ and followed by the interment of his ashes at The Princeton Cemetery.

LONDON — Send in the cartoons. I’ve come to regard this as the new mantra of the National Theater, and I don’t mean the usual business of human actors dressing up like animals and monsters out of Disney and Dreamworks children’s movies. The cartoons I’m talking about are the real thing — proper, two-dimensional drawings that run and wriggle and bend all over stages they graciously share with less supple flesh-and-blood co-stars. The artist Jeff Koons‘s images of Popeye, now on view at the Serpentine Gallery, look sadly earthbound (as well as muscle-bound) compared to these spirited creations.

In one of the oddest displays yet of the global reach that Michael Jackson possessed, residents of the Ukrainian village of Oktyabrskoye are seeking to rename it after the singer, Agence France-Presse reported. Oleg Kislitsyn, a member of the regional parliament, said residents of the village, located in the Zaporizhia region in southeast Ukraine, had approached him with a proposal to change the name of the village to Jackson. “There are many fans of Michael Jackson there,” Mr. Kislitsyn said. He said that villagers wanted to create a Jackson museum in hopes of attracting tourists and that he supported the proposal to change the name. “I am not a fan but I respect his work,” Mr. Kislitsyn said. “He had an iron-clad will for victory.” The village’s municipal council is to consider the plan in August.

The news that Jude Law is coming to “Hamlet” on Broadway this fall, and the buzz about Philip Seymour Hoffman and John Ortiz downtown in “Othello” in September, has obscured the recent chatter about another Shakespeare in town.

It hasn’t been a particularly well kept secret, but now it’s official: the acclaimed production of the musical “Ragtime” that ran earlier this year at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will transfer to Broadway in the fall. Publicists for the Broadway production said in a news release on Wednesday that “Ragtime,” adapted from the E. L. Doctorow novel about three intertwining New York families in the era of Harry Houdini, J. P. Morgan, Henry Ford and Archduke Franz Ferdinand, would be presented at the Neil Simon Theater. Previews are scheduled to begin on Oct. 23, and an official opening is planned for Nov. 15. The Broadway production will be directed and choreographed by Marcia Milgrom Dodge, who handled both duties for the Washington revival. The original Broadway production of “Ragtime,” which opened in 1998 at the Ford Center for the Performing Arts, won Tony Awards for its book writer, Terrence McNally, its composer, Stephen Flaherty, and its lyricist, Lynn Ahrens. A cast for the Broadway transfer was not announced.

Should you happen to be watching Cinemax next week and discover that it isn’t broadcasting images of naked bodies, do not be alarmed. You may be watching one of its many, many showings of “Tropic Thunder,” or — in a rare instance of a cable channel treating a music video like a movie event — you may be tuning into its world premiere of a new video by the rock band Dead Weather. In a news release, the band, whose members include Jack White (of the White Stripes and the Raconteurs), Alison Mosshart (the Kills), Dean Fertita (Queens of the Stone Age) and Jack Lawrence (the Greenhornes and the Raconteurs), said that it would show the video, for its song “Treat Me Like Your Mother,” on Cinemax, whose programming also includes the series “Lingerie,” “The Erotic Traveler” and “Co-Ed Confidential.” The video, directed by Jonathan Glazer (“Sexy Beast”) will have its premiere on July 11 at 9:55 p.m., and will continue to be shown on Cinemax’s various channels for the next five weeks. A preview of the video can be found here at the Dead Weather’s official Web site.

When I was growing up (and for that matter, when my children were, too) family stories, told over dinner, or in a darkened room at bedtime, were among the chief pleasures of life. The teller was my father, and the setting was always the oddly bucolic neighborhood in the Bronx where he grew up in the 1920s. At first the stories were mainly about the creatures that lived under the front porch on Webster Avenue, including a walking, talking honeydew melon named the Growly, and his associate, Black Razz. (I suspect these stories were not politically correct. But happiness sometimes depends on what you are able to forget, or overlook.)

Now, more than six decades later, members of the Women Airforce Service Pilots will receive the Congressional Gold Medal, one of America's highest civilian honors.

ROME | Roman summer nights are famous for offering a sweet and welcome release from the intense heat and humidity of the sweltering days. An excellent way to enjoy those summer evenings is to walk along the banks of the Tiber, where, for the sixth year in a row, a boardwalk has been set up on the Trastevere side of the river. The project calls itself "Lungo il Tevere Roma," a play on words -- the phrase translates as "along the Tiber Roma" and the area is also called il Lungotevere. Lungo il Tevere Roma is part of the "Estate Romana" ("Roman Summer"), the Roman outdoor cultural festival which takes place every summer, June to September, and has become an institution in the city since its creation in 1977.

The other day, Glen Lowry, the director of the Museum of Modern Art, was explaining the connections between Modernism and Primitivism. To conjure a visual, he had to look no farther than his own backyard -- in Long Island City, Queens. That's where Michael Meredith and Hilary Sample, the winners of this year's Young Architects Program at P.S.1, had just erected (with the help of some 40 student volunteers from Harvard and Yale) their design, "afterparty." Part Bauhaus shelter, part Bedouin tent, "afterparty" is a simple construction of silver mesh stretched on a skeleton of standard aluminum poles and brackets and then topped off with a thick brown toupee of ijuk, or palm fibers. Meredith described this material, which is commonly used throughout Indonesia for roofing, as "very Arte Povera." Lowry added, "Never before has P.S.1 looked so hairy," and he wasn't kidding.

You might not be able to own works by Peter Blake, the British Pop Art icon, but now you can wear them. Blake has created a sweetly cartoonish cloud print for the capsule collection that Stella McCartney designed for net-a-porter.com. (This is the second generation of McCartneys Blake has been associated with: he designed the album cover for "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.") The clouds, Blake says in a video on the e-tailer's Web site, were inspired by a famous example -- those of the great landscape painter John Constable. In McCartney's collection, they waft across a dress, blouse, T-shirt, tote bag and espadrilles. But it's not just girls who get to have fun with Blake. His new collection of cuff links, designed for the Louisa Guinness Gallery, is currently on display at Ben Brown Fine Arts in London. The 18-karat-gold cuff links offer an interesting twofer: on the front is a tiny, colorful collage or drawing, and the closure is a miniature spoon.

It's been a crazy week in the bee yard. When we arrived on Sunday morning to check up on the girls, the field was straight out of a horror film. The air buzzed as bees filled the sky--my neighbor's colony had swarmed out. Minutes before, one of the other beekeepers had seen the cloud of bees rise out of the hive and head for a tree several hundred yards away. As we trotted across the field to look at the bees that had taken up residence in 30-ft-high limb, they began to disperse, returning to the hive they'd just abandoned. "Huh. That's interesting. They must not have had the queen with them," our mentor Joe Lelinho surmised. Since the queen does all of the egg laying, a functioning colony can't exist without her, so the workers' flaccid attempt at rebellion was over.

At first glance, it would seem that someone had replaced the security guards down at City Hall with a Playmobil sentry, complete with its own Lego checkpoint. (Hey, we've heard worse ideas for cutting excess fat from the city's budget.) In fact, the cartoon brick facades are the work of the Public Art Fund and the British artist Richard Woods, who back in 2002 "mock Tudorized" the facade of Deitch Projects on Grand Street and "crazy paved" the entire courtyard of a Venice palazzo. As William Shaw wrote in the spring design issue of T, "The irony -- and one Woods clearly enjoys -- is that his signatures, drawn from an era of blue-collar aspiration, are now adding a sheen to the finest architect-designed super-swish floors and walls of the very rich," Mayor Bloomberg now apparently among them. Might we suggest one of Woods's faux brick sofas to match?"wall and door and roof" is on view at City Hall through September.

In 2006, Aaron Smathers, then 29, was a graduate student in the Department of Health and Exercise Science at the University of Oklahoma, gathering data for a study of brittle bones in cyclists. One of his subjects was himself, since he's been a bike racer for years. A recent scan had revealed that his bones were less dense than usual for a man his age. Not long after those results came in, he crashed during a race, snapping his collarbone. Six weeks later, in his first post-injury race, he was engulfed by a multi-rider pile-up, crashed again, and re-broke his collarbone. Worse, he fractured his hip so badly that the ball of the ball-and-socket joint broke off. "Later I thought, well, this reinforces my study," he says.

Many of the reader comments on yesterday's post can be grouped into two long-established philosophical camps. Here's how Steven Lukes, a friend and professor of sociology, describes them in his latest book, "Moral Relativism": "Philosophers draw a distinction between deontological ethics, which is all about following rules and acknowledging rights and duties, and consequentialist ethics, where the point is to produce the best overall consequences."

As the mayor's control over the school expires, a New York Times analysis of seven years of education spending, as it expanded from $13 billion to $22 billion per year, reveals how the Bloomberg administration has reshaped the budget around its priorities. The city has broken up a number of underperforming schools into smaller schools, resulting in 1,075 more principals and assistant principals. There are more administrators, like academic coaches who track test scores, and more support staff, with tasks like patrolling hallways and monitoring attendance.

Until reading Cooper Ray's blog, the Social Primer, some men might not have known the precise guidelines for holding a cocktail party or the danger of double-booking social engagements. Which is why the Alabama dilettante is aiming to school even guys' guys with his lively and opinionated rants on everything from proper text-messaging etiquette to how to handle one's liquor. Since launching the site last fall, Ray (whose alter ego on the site goes by just "SP") says his following of well-mannered men has grown to 10,000 hits a day. And now he's started a product line - gentlemanly gear like embossed stationery inspired by William Faulkner and sterling-silver monogrammed cuff links - that he sells in pop-up shops and trunk shows around the country. The Moment caught up with Ray over e-mail and lobbed him a few questions.

The N.C.A.A. rejected an appeal from the former Indiana Coach Kelvin Sampson, saying that its Division I infractions committee upheld the ruling on violations stemming from more than 100 impermissible phone calls made while Sampson was coaching at Indiana. Sampson received five years of potential penalties when the N.C.A.A. ruled on the case, including an order that could keep him from coaching in college for the next four years. Sampson said that the N.C.A.A. misinterpreted evidence and that the infractions committee was biased against him.

It took longer than expected, but Lance Stephenson, a McDonald’s all-American from Lincoln High School in Brooklyn, finally picked his next basketball team. He signed to play for the University of Cincinnati. A misdemeanor sexual assault charge against Stephenson was one factor that had clouded his college choice. The case has been adjourned until July 15.

An obituary on Monday about the television pitchman Billy Mays misspelled part of the name of the Pennsylvania town where he was born. It is McKees Rocks, not McKees Rock.

An article in the Escapes pages on Friday about people who decide to live full time in their vacation home misspelled part of the name of the town in Florida north of Boca Raton where Eileen and Larry Chimerine bought a condo. It is Highland Beach, not Hyland Beach.

A picture caption in the Escapes pages on Friday with an article about places in Wisconsin where gangsters went for refuge in the 1920s and 1930s misidentified the lodge shown. It is the Barker Lake Lodge in Winter, Wis. — not the Little Bohemia Lodge in Manitowish Waters, which appeared in other editions.

A picture of a spiral galaxy on June 23 with an article about the Vatican Advanced Technology Telescope on Mount Graham in Arizona was published in error. The photograph was taken by the Large Binocular Telescope, also on Mount Graham, not the Vatican telescope.

An article on Tuesday about a new student loan repayment plan by the Education Department that lets graduates reduce their loan payments based on their income misstated the current interest rate on federal subsidized Stafford loans. It is 6 percent — not 6.8 percent, the rate for unsubsidized loans.

An article on Tuesday about the sentencing of Bernard L. Madoff misstated the position of Richard L. Scheff, a lawyer who commented on the length of the sentence. Mr. Scheff is a former — not current — assistant secretary for law enforcement for the Treasury Department.

The first-year coach Michael Curry became the latest Detroit Pistons coach to be fired after the team stumbled to a sub-.500 record and a first-round exit from the playoffs. Joe Dumars, the president for basketball operations, had said Curry would return after the Pistons were swept by Cleveland. Curry replaced Flip Saunders, who went to the Eastern Conference finals in each of his three seasons. In 2005, the Pistons parted ways with the Hall of Fame coach Larry Brown. Brown won a title during his two years with the team.

Tim Finchem, the PGA Tour commissioner, decided not to delay a new rule that will change the grooves in irons and wedges next year. The United States Golf Association notified players and equipment manufacturers last year that, effective Jan. 1, 2010, the dimensions in the grooves would change to create less spin on shots. The idea was to make shots out of the rough more difficult and put more of a premium on driving accuracy. An updated recipe with the Minimalist column, about infused oils, corrects two errors that appeared in the recipe when it was published at nytimes.com on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The online recipe misstated the amount of time the oil should cook after it bubbles and the length of time it is safe to use after being refrigerated. The oil should be cooked five minutes, not “a minute or two,” and it should be kept in the refrigerator no more than a week, not “a month or so.”

ARMOUR--Julia Henry, 90, wife of the late Philip D. Armour, Jr. of Chicago, Illinois, died peacefully in Miami, Florida on June 27, 2009. Mother of Julia A. Walker, Philip D. Armour, III and the late Alexandra Armour, grandmother of C. Carter Walker, III, Julia Walker Robinson, Philip Armour, IV, Maximillan and Nicholas Armour and great-grandmother of Cole, Hart, Julia, Robbie, Malkom, Oskar and Raven. Julia was a life long sportswoman. She and Phil Armour started Armforth Kennels in 1947 and raised champion English Springer Spaniels. Their dogs placed 7 times (6 Firsts), in the National Championships from 1948-1961. Julia Armour was the first woman and first amateur to train, handle and win the National English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Championship in 1960.After Philip Armour died in 1964, Julia moved to Miami and went on to compete all over the world in the Live Pigeon Shooting Championships, where she became a World Champion. On September 14, 2002, Julia was elected to the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Hall of Fame. Born and raised in Chestnut Hill, Pennsylvania, Julia is the daughter of the late T. Charlton and Julia Rush Biddle Henry. Donations may be made in her honor to the North Country Society for the Protection of Cruelty to Animals, 23 Lakeshore Road, Westport, NY 12993 or The American Macular Degeneration Foundation, P.O. Box 515, Northampton, MA 01061-0515.

The Environmental Protection Agency said Tuesday that it had granted California the right to enforce its first-in-the-nation standards controlling greenhouse-gas emissions from cars and light trucks. The move reverses a 2008 ruling by the Bush administration and effectively ends a seesaw political battle between automakers and environmental regulators that began in Sacramento eight years ago when the California Legislature first took up the issue.

EASTON--Kermit (Kim), died peacefully surrounded by his loving family on Monday, June 29, 2009 at Meadow Ridge in Redding, CT at age 90. Formerly of Westport, CT, Kim was born, raised and educated in New York City. He received a BA degree from Columbia College, an MBA from The Columbia School of Business and a JD from Brooklyn Law School. He served in the US Navy in World War II and was assigned to the Japanese Language School as a Naval Intelligence Officer. Kim was a Certified Public Accountant and was a senior partner of SD Leidesdorf & Co. when that firm merged with and became part of what is now Ernst & Young LLP. He retired as a senior partner of Ernst & Young in 1980. Devoted and beloved husband of Freda, his wife of 64 years, cherished father of son, Richard, daughter, Judith Shaw, and father-in-law of Denise. Adoring grandfather of Lauren, Claudia, Aaron and Eric. Beloved cousin of the Kalos and Remick families and uncle of the Taub family. Friend to all who knew him. We will miss his hardy "hello" when he answered the telephone, as well as his infectious smile, good humor and gentle kindness. Services will be held at Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, CT at 1:00pm on Wednesday, July 1, 2009. Memorial contributions may be made to Friends of the Westport Center for Senior Activities, 21 Imperial Avenue, Westport, CT 06880, the Prayer Book Fund of Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Road, Westport, CT 06880 or the Memorial Beautification Fund, Meadow Ridge, 100 Redding Road, Redding, CT 06896. www.greensfuneralhome.com

JACOBSON--Sheldon, M.D. We at the The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and cherished colleague, Sheldon Jacobson, M.D., professor and chair of Emergency Medicine at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. For 35 years, Dr. Jacobson devoted himself to the advancement of emergency medicine training and education and spent the last 15 years of his career at Mount Sinai where he created Mount Sinai's first Department of Emergency Medicine and which has since developed into one of the premier Emergency Training programs in the world. A pioneer in his field, Dr. Jacobson developed the first paramedic training program in New York state which became a model program recognized throughout the country. An innovator and visionary, his contributions were instrumental in the development of the specialty of emergency medicine. His commitment to quality patient care and to education created a standard of excellence. Dr. Jacobson served on a number of prestigious national committees including the National Board of Medical Examiners; he published more than 50 articles and book chapters and served on the editorial boards of many journals. He will be remembered as a role model, mentor, and leader. The Mount Sinai family extends our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Jacobson's loved ones. Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Dean of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs of The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Wayne E. Keathley, President and Chief Operating Officer, The Mount Sinai Hospital. Funeral services will be held Thursday, July 2, 2009 at 11:45 am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, New York, New York. In lieu of flowers, a Sheldon Jacobson, M.D. memorial fund has been set up. Donations can be sent to: The Mount Sinai Hospital Sheldon Jacobson, M.D. Fund, Department of Development, Box 1049, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, New York 10029

The gourmets say there isn't a native Canadian food worth remembering after you've left the country. The gourmets have never bitten into a Coffee Crisp. A Coffee Crisp tastes like Canada to anybody who grew up gnawing on that confection, a memorably crisp blend of coffee cream, cookie wafers and milk chocolate as wholesome and satisfying as the Canadian national anthem. It was a square-edged rectangle, like a brick, wrapped in a yellow-going-to-gold paper that seemed to elevate its value above all rival confections. It was unlike other chocolate bars.

In September 2007, thousands of Buddhist monks led the ''saffron revolution,'' a series of peaceful marches in response to military oppression and a dire economic situation in Myanmar, formerly Burma. Since then, three monks who escaped Myanmar and settled in Utica, N.Y., have been campaigning across the United States for democracy and human rights in their country. U Agga Nya Na, here studying English at a monastery run by the All Burma Monks Alliance, says he wants to study political science. He is confident that he can contribute to democracy in Myanmar, even while he is living in the United States. ''We can make many young students inspired for democracy and human rights for Burma,'' he said. Video of the three monks' campaign and struggle, and of other Second Chance subjects: nytimes.com/cityroom.

In Canada's Pacific Northwest, where I grew up, the beaches were strewn with thousands of fugitive logs that had escaped the water transporters bringing them down toward the prospering lumber sawmills and pulp and paper factories all around Vancouver Island. On our gray sand shores, those shaved logs became home to insects, birds and small rodents and made great hiding places or impromptu tents. A favorite childhood game was to see who could traverse the most beached logs without ever touching the sand.
