GLOVER--Hedy. The Gordon H. Smith Corporation mourns the passing of Hedy Glover, mother of our esteemed colleague James Glover. Our condolences go out to Jim and his entire family.

There is no contest about what I miss most about Canada. It is universal medical coverage. Just thinking about it, and its absence here, can send me into complete despair. But Canada Day is no time for tears, so instead I offer my First Runner-Up of Things Canadian Most Beloved: After Coffee Peppermints from Second Cup, a national chain of coffee shops not unlike Starbucks. I have no idea if the coffee is any good. I've bought only the mints, which come in cunning tin disks that open and close with a satisfying snap. These mints are, in a word, sublime; they are stronger, mintier and more refreshing than anything else on the market. Some of my (American) friends have to spit them out. Even their dimensions are more pleasing than other peppermints. Thicker than average, with mildly pillowed surfaces on top and bottom, they possess a muscularity bordering on belligerence, befitting their palate-cleansing brawn. And so tiny! More pharmaceutical than confection, they feel (almost) medicinal.

FRIEDMAN--Dr. Orrie M. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Dr. Orrie M. Friedman of Brookline, MA, whose nearly three decades of dedicated service have been a source of inspiration. Dr. Friedman served on the ATS national and New England Region Boards of Directors, and was a life trustee of the ATS Board of Regents. An Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors, Dr. Friedman held a deep appreciation of the Technion's role in Israel's current and future development. Together with his wife Laurel, he established the Orrie and Laurel Friedman New England Region Organic Chemistry Floor Project, and the Orrie and Laurel Friedman Visiting Lectureship Fund. A Technion Guardian, he achieved the highest level of commitment. A biotechnology pioneer, Dr. Friedman was a professor of chemistry at Harvard and Brandeis Universities, and founded Collaborative Research Inc. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Laurel, sons Mark and Hank, and stepson David Chase. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joan Seidel, President Dr. Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

I miss the snow. Yes, I know the United States gets snow, but to my Canadian eye, American snow is like American health care: sporadic, unreliable and distributed unevenly among the population. In the heart of Ontario's snow belt, punishing squalls were a fact of life from November through mid-April. One time, 39 inches fell on my hometown in three days -- and school wasn't even canceled. And it wasn't just the quantity of snow -- it's the speed with which it arrived. When I was a child, it wasn't unusual for my 15-minute walk home from school to begin under clear skies and end in a blizzard. I remember once, when I was 8 years old, stumbling into my house, my hair covered in powder and my eyelashes frozen together, and screaming, ''Why do we live here?!'' My mother took my face in her warm hands and said, ''Because it's where people love you.''

In history class, in seventh grade (or as we like to say in Canada, grade seven) we learned the story of the American Revolution -- from the British perspective. Turns out you were all a bunch of ungrateful tax cheats. And you weren't very nice to the Loyalists. What I miss most about Canada is getting the truth about the United States. -- MALCOLM GLADWELL, a staff writer for The New Yorker and the author, most recently, of ''Outliers: The Story of Success''

I miss the Szechuan Chongqing Restaurant in Vancouver. You can't get Dai Ching bean curd or bean sprout chow mein anywhere else. I've looked far and wide. Nowhere to be found. Vancouver nails the Asian food. On the other side of the coin: the city has the worst pizza. To be fair, it's more like a tie for last with every other Canadian city. In fact, I miss how charmingly terrible the pizza is. It's like watching a preschool ballet recital.

MALANG--Robert J.,Jr., 64, of Cortlandt Manor died June 29, 2009 at The Osborn Pavilion after a courageous battle with cancer. He was predeceased by his parents Ermelinda (Babe) Maraventano Malang and Judge Robert Malang. Devoted husband of Janet (nee Schork) and loving father of Elizabeth Malang and Lauren Stanco and father-in-law to her husband Randy. Bob is also survived by his sister Linda Gimlett and her husband Brian, and his three nephews, Brian Jr., Patrick and Matthew Gimlett. Bob graduated from Fordham Prep, Fordham University and Fordham Law School '75. He was a board member of the Enrico Fermi Cultural Center at the Belmont Branch of the New York Public Library. Details of his memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions may be made in his honor to The Osborn, 101 Theall Rd., Rye, New York, 10580 c/o Susan Olson.

I miss the pride and simplicity of a national literature, which probably wouldn't exist without government support. We even have a name, CanLit, that people use without fearing they'll sound like nerds. In America we tend toward novels published specifically for one narrowly interpreted demographic. CanLit is an unassuming place, very welcoming to immigrant writers, and since it doesn't dice up readership according to profile there is a national conversation about literature, like a big book club. And I miss Winnipeg's winters, which any Winnipegger will tell you is ridiculous. Nonetheless, I miss the winter sun on snow and ice, the blue sky too cold for a scrap of cloud, and clear air like a healing draft so strong that too much will kill you. Walking in such weather is necessarily walking meditation, every breath sears with cold, every footfall in the snow crunches and squeaks. My expatriate sorrow is that the weather has become warmer and the government colder since I left.

Living just south of the border, in Upstate New York, I have easy, regular access to the non-pasteurized cheese, veggie pâté and late nights of my hometown, Montreal. But it's the Canadian mosaic, which is fundamentally different from the American melting pot, that I treasure most. That mosaic makes the coexistence of Francophone and Anglophone cultures possible -- and makes me both a proud Montrealer and a patriotic citizen of Canada, as it is the country that has supported Quebec in remaining so unique. -- MELISSA AUF der MAUR, a musician

The 6-foot-5 Stephenson won a record four straight Public School Athletic League Class AA titles and became the state?s career scoring leader with 2,946 points. GREENBERG--Estelle Filker, died on June 30th at the home of her daughter Elizabeth Greenberg, after a two and a half year battle with pancreatic cancer and diabetes. When she died, Dr. Greenberg was the Director of Grants at Hudson County Community College in Jersey City, a pivotal role which brought millions of dollars into the college system during the regeneration of that diverse city. Estelle was born on June 12, 1931 in New York City. She graduated high school valedictorian. She held her doctorate in American Civilization from the Graduate School of Arts and Science, NYU where she graduated with distinction in doctoral orals, her MA from the same institution, and her BA, Magna cum Laude, Honors in English, Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Delta Omicron and Psi Chi. She married Max Greenberg in 1950. They moved to Passaic, NJ in the 1960s and raised their three daughters, Elizabeth, Ann and Charlotte there. She taught at NYU, FDU, and HCCC. In the 1980s Dr. Greenberg began working for the Brookdale Foundation in New York which specialized in gerontology. Estelle was actively involved in developing an innovative respite program for Alzheimer's patients and their caregivers. She was invited to speak internationally on the subject in France, Israel and Japan. Estelle was a remarkable woman, passionately committed to her work, family and friends. Estelle was predeceased by her husband and five brothers and one sister. She is survived by her three daughters, Liz Greenberg, Ann Dery and Charlotte Kerwick, her son-in-law Sean Kerwick, grandchildren; Jeremy Dery, Emily Dery, Jonathan Dery and Max Greenberg. Additionally, she is survived by her sisters-in-law, Sophie Filker and Selma Filker, five nieces, two nephews and their families. Estelle is also survived by her two old dogs Jake and Princess. Chapel services Thursday, July 2nd, at 10am at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ. 973-779-3048 for information.

(If neither of these options are open to you, you can also buy his records.) Talk about meta. Authors have long responded to their critics — in person, through the mail and on the letters pages of book reviews. Now, in the age of online social media, such responses are immediately amplified to the world. The novelist Alice Hoffman discovered last weekend that a few angry outbursts on Twitter could ricochet through the literary biosphere within minutes. Alain de Botton followed suit after posting a harsh comment on the blog of Caleb Crain, who had reviewed Mr. de Botton’s latest work, “The Pleasures and Sorrows of Work,” for The New York Times Book Review. Mr. de Botton didn’t like the review, and fired back: “I will hate you till the day I die and wish you nothing but ill will in every career move you make.” Ouch. The literary blogger Edward Champion gave Alain de Botton ample opportunity to explain himself.

Fourteen works from the antiquities collection of the Cleveland Museum of Art were officially presented to the Italian public in Rome on Thursday, underscoring “the excellent collaboration between the United States institution and the Italian culture ministry,” Attorney General Oscar Fiumara said. The return follows two years of negotiations over their rightful ownership: The Italians maintained that they had been looted from sites in Sicily, Sardinia, Apulia and Campania. An accord between the museum and the culture ministry was signed in November and the artifacts — which date from the 9th century B.C. to the 14th century A.D. — will now be returned to museums in their regions of provenance. The museum will receive long-term loans of similar works in exchange. The returned works include a rare fourth century B.C. Apulian Volute Krater by the artist known as the Darius Painter.

The heat is starting to get to London. People on the streets stagger slowly into one another, like radar-deprived bats. A sweating newspaper vendor handed me as change the exact amount I had just given him. Men of all ages and sizes are seen in Capri pants, while amplified voices boom through the underground tunnels that everyone should be carrying a bottle of water. It’s encouraging to see that the living tennis star Andy Murray has replaced the dead pop star Michael Jackson as the tabloids’ favorite cover boy, but the impression remains that London, for the moment, is a city of zombies.

A medical examiner hired by the family of David Carradine said that an independent autopsy showed that the actor died from asphyxiation but did not commit suicide, Reuters reported. The examiner, Dr. Michael Baden, a forensic pathologist, was hired by the Carradine family following the actor’s death on June 4 in a hotel room in Bangkok where Mr. Carradine was working on a movie. “The cause of death was asphyxiation, an inability to breathe, now why that happened is still what we’re working on,” Dr. Baden said, according to Reuters. He also noted that the actor was found with his hands tied behind his head, adding: “He didn’t die of natural causes, and he didn’t die of suicidal causes from the nature of the ligatures around the body, so that leaves some kind of accidental death.” In June, the authorities in Thailand said it would take a month to know the results of their investigation into Mr. Carradine’s death.

Caroline Baumann has been named the acting director of the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in Manhattan, the museum announced Thursday in a news release. Her appointment will be effective on July 13. Ms. Baumann, who is presently the museum’s deputy director, has worked at the Cooper-Hewitt since 2001, where she has also served as director of development and director of external affairs. She also previously worked at the Museum of Modern Art. Ms. Baumann will succeed Paul Warwick Thompson, who is leaving to become the rector of the Royal College of Art in London. A 10-member committee directed by the Smithsonian Institution‘s Office of the Under Secretary for Art will continue the search for a permanent director for the Cooper-Hewitt.

A lawsuit filed by a former online columnist for Fox News says that Fox and its parent company defamed him in public statements after he was fired, The Associated Press reported. The columnist, Roger Friedman, filed suit against Fox and the News Corporation in a New York court. He was terminated by the company in April after he wrote a column about watching a pirated version of the Fox movie “X-Men Origins: Wolverine” on the Internet. In his suit, Mr. Friedman said that his editors had not objected to the column, and had told him not to worry about his job after Rupert Murdoch, the News Corporation chairman, ordered the column to be taken down. In a public statement after Mr. Friedman’s firing, News Corporation said it had a zero tolerance policy for actions it believes promotes online piracy. Mr. Friedman, who has since been hired by The Hollywood Reporter, said in his suit that the statement libeled him; Fox News told The A.P. it had not been served with the suit and decline to comment further.

The Mayor’s Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting in New York said that as of Tuesday it had used up its full allocation of funds, $192.5 million, set aside for tax rebates for film and television production in the city. In a news release, the office said that its “Made in NY” program, which offers a 5 percent tax credit to qualifying productions in New York City, would have no further funds available until state legislators approve an extension of the program. The office said it would continue to accept new applications for the credit while it awaited passage of the legislation, adding, “However, at this time, it is unclear whether new legislation will cover applications received during the interim.” The “Made in NY” program was announced in 2005 to complement a similar New York State incentive that offers a 30 percent credit for film and television production. A representative for the New York State Governor’s Office for Motion Picture and Television Development said that incentive was still financed.

Update | 12:44 p.m. A number of readers (Comments 2, 4, 6 and 19) have wrestled with the question of whether Mr. Wolf crossed a line of privacy in showing people so recognizably in their homes and offices. As we understand it, the legal question is whether the subject of the photo had a reasonable expectation of privacy. In most states, the courts tend to side with photographers who are on public property, or their own property, and take pictures of things that could be witnessed by any passer-by. The thinking is that people have no expectation of privacy if they have placed themselves where strangers can glimpse them. In the next week or so, we hope to revisit this whole subject in greater depth.

The Andy Roddick-Andy Murray features two of the most improved players on tour. Roddick's work with his coach, Larry Stefanki, is paying off; Roddick is fitter, faster and more versatile in a few short months. His footwork, especially moving wide on the backhand, is much more efficient, resulting in better balance and weight transfer when he hits the shot. Previously, Roddick seemed to tie himself up in knots on some backhands, and the shot would break down under assault. His return game is better, although he still seems uncertain about how to play break points. But at least he's getting some break opportunities.

In recent months, Jenny Staff Johnson has felt like she's been walking a tightrope, balanced precariously between the family she has and the one she is trying to create. On one side, she had her home in Houston with her two boys (Joel, who is six, and Clyde, who soon turns eight) and her husband, Mark, founder of the blog Hometta.com (for which Jenny, who also has her own blog, Axis of Beebles, is an editor.) On the other side is six-year-old Rosemary, the little girl with special needs who the Johnsons have been trying to adopt from China. But foreign adoption -- particularly at a time when borders are being closed for fear of swine flu -- can feel like one step forward then several steps back, and for months the family has been trying to keep balanced while waiting.

Admirers of Marc Newson's streamlined furniture and crisp industrial design may be surprised to see his latest creation -- a strikingly ornate diamond and sapphire necklace he conceived for Boucheron, the French jewelry house. The one-of-a-kind "Julia" necklace, which is being introduced at a couture-week party in Paris tomorrow evening, was inspired by Newson's obsession with fractals -- geometric shapes that can be subdivided into smaller versions of themselves, specifically the Julia Sets of fractals discovered by Gaston Julia in the early 1900s. "Fractals are fascinating, complex and rich," Newson says, "and gemstones really lend themselves to exploiting their beauty." The scientifically-spawned sparkler contains around 2,000 paved stones and took the company's craftspeople 1,500 hours to realize using rapid-prototyping technology and a minimal three-prong setting, so the stones appear to float on the wearer's throat. One thing that won't be floating, however, is the price tag. "I wasn't thinking luxury at all, but the technical rigorousness of the piece, as well as the sheer number of stones that went into it will probably make this one of the most expensive necklaces Boucheron's ever made." Go to boucheron.com.

They'll certainly be in my suitcase for my holiday weekend trip to Greece.

Federal marshals on Thursday took possession of the $7 million Manhattan penthouse apartment of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff, an action that has forced his wife Ruth to move.

In "Notebooks From New Guinea: Field Notes of a Tropical Biologist," originally written in Czech, Vojtech Novotny presents a series of vignettes on life and the jungle in New Guinea. He has a well-developed sense of the absurd, as he shows in comparing some aspects of Czech science to the cargo cults of New Guinea. In these cults natives practice what the developed world would think of as magical rituals to make cargo -- Western technology and goods -- appear.

The Hasidic section of Williamsburg, Brooklyn - roughly bounded by Division Avenue, Broadway, Heyward Street and the Brooklyn Navy Yard - is an anachronistic pleasure. Unlike in the hipster section north of Grand Avenue, the images here - knife-grinders on the street, bearded men in 19th-century frock coats - are not only vivid, they are also apparently lost to time. The neighborhood, which is served by the Marcy Avenue stop on the J, M and Z trains, is home to thousands of Hasidic Jews, mainly of the Satmar sect, which derives its name from the town of Satu Mare in Romania. Be forewarned: some of the residents do not take kindly to intrusion and may greet strangers with a brusque look.

Forgive me for being out of touch. Today is my seventh full day in Spain, and I doubt I've spent even an hour with my computer. Up and out in the morning, not to return until early the next morning. The Spanish do not seem to place much importance on sleep. Still, three days in Galicia and three in Rioja have been most fulfilling, and I look forward to reporting on my visits soon in far more detail.

Despite its bourgeois address in the 16th Arrondissement, the Palais de Tokyo is the coolest museum in Paris: risk-taking, roomy and a little rough around the edges. Now its rooftop has become one of the city's hottest locations. First it hosted a green capsule called the Everland Hotel, where overnight guests could sleep face-to-face with the Eiffel Tower. As of July 1, a new oddity has taken its place.

"Private sector job losses in excess of 400,000 this deep into a recession cannot be viewed as anything but terrible news." So says Joshua Shapiro, an economist, in response to the job report issued this morning, which put unemployment at 9.5 percent, the highest since 1983. Shapiro's remark was one of several rounded up in the Real Times Economics blog at the Wall Street Journal.

The Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting in New York said that as of Tuesday it had used up its allocation of funds, $192.5 million, set aside for tax rebates for film and television production in the city. In 1609, a ship from Plymouth, England, bound for the Jamestown colony in Virginia was damaged in a storm but found refuge on an Atlantic island with pink beaches. The English had discovered Bermuda. Celebrating the 400th anniversary of that event all year, Bermuda, still a British territory, is offering several money-saving packages at some of its most luxurious hotels.

I had dinner last week at the new "fine dining" restaurant SHO Shaun Hergatt (a bit of a mouthful, no?) in the Setai development down in the financial district of Manhattan. Now, I absolutely hate the term "fine dining" but I am a fan of ambitious cooking. And one of the things I was struck by, as a friend and I shared our five-course tasting menu, was how long it's actually been since I'd been in such an establishment - and how much fun it was to be back.To be honest, I haven't really been in the mood for fine dining for a while. The days of eating out on friends' expense accounts ended definitively sometime last year, and ultimately the new restaurants that have seemed most appealing to me have been of the low-fi, locavore, neighborhood variety. Indeed, that's all good; in this economy it's been great to see the proliferation of genuinely interesting places that serve thoughtful food at honest prices.

The Italian fashion house Missoni, known for its kaleidoscopic fabrics, is the subject of the exhibition "Workshop Missoni: Daring to be Different," on view at the Estorick Collection of Modern Italian Art in London through Sept. 20. Curated by Luca Missoni, son of Ottavio and Rosita Missoni, the husband and wife who turned knitwear into wearable art in the 1960s, the exhibition displays both original garments and photographs of several signature pieces, like the spring-summer collection of 1968.

KNOX--William Graham, 91, of Greenwich, CT, on June 26th, 2009. Son of W. Graham Knox, Jr. and Fiona Reardon Knox. He was born on March 18, 1918 in New York City. Survived by his wife, Amie B. Knox, wife of 58 years, and his four children: Graham, Robert (Dorothee), Amie (Jim Kelley), John (Page) and eight grandchildren. Graham's passion was medicine and after graduating from Columbia College in 1939, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942, he joined the staff of St Luke's Hospital in New York, with which he was affiliated for more than 45 years. Graham served in the Navy medical corps from 1944-46, participating in the South Atlantic command and later in the invasion of Okinawa. He spent his entire medical career in New York City, both at St. Luke's and St. Vincent's Hospitals where he served in several leadership positions in their departments of vascular surgery. He was also a professor of Clinical Surgery at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and was chief of vascular surgery emeritus at St. Vincent's Hospital. In addition, he served as president of the New York County Medical Society, the New York Surgical Society and the New York Cardiovascular Society. Dr. Knox took great pride in being a surgeon and commuted six days a week by car to New York City. He established lifelong relationships with many of his patients who later became among his closest friends. Graham continued to be an exceptional diagnostician even after his retirement and used his vast knowledge of medicine to advise friends and relatives on various medical issues. A memorial service will be held later in the summer. Contributions can be made to the Joseph Collins Foundation, 787 Seventh Avenue, Room 3950, New York, NY 10019.

The reign of Sarah Palin, Alaska's governor, as a vice-presidential candidate may have lasted only two full months, but the internecine warfare that her national political debut unleashed among Republicans and within the McCain camp continues to have a life of its own. A new article in Vanity Fair magazine exposes more of the internal upset among her handlers, who were top advisers to her running mate, Senator John McCain, the Republicans' presidential nominee.

Equipment that is supposed to detect stopped trains on Washington's Metro system had been repaired five days before the deadly June 22 crash but still failed to function reliably, the National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday. The board said maintenance records showed that a track-circuit component had been replaced on June 17 and that a review of recorded data furnished by Metro officials after the crash revealed that the circuit ''periodically lost its ability to detect trains after June 17.''

HOW much time and money have I wasted gardening this spring? It depends on how you define ''waste.'' When I started planting seeds in March, I promised in my first article to ''unleash my inner bean counter'' and ''keep a strict account'' of what I invest in home food production. This ledger would tally the dollars and hours that go into my garden, and weigh that against the cash value of what might come out of the ground.

SIMMONS--Barbara Connelly, 91, originally of Chicago Illinois, died peacefully on Monday, June 29, 2009, in Danvers, Massachusetts. Her life was long and blessed. During her marriage of 55 years to the late Willard R. Simmons, she resided in Mamaroneck, New York and raised her family of five children. Her sons; Steven D. Simmons, Peter C. Simmons, William R. Simmons, daughters; Barbara (Simmons), Mass. and Patricia (Simmons) Iorillo, survive her. Baba, as she was affectionately known, was grandmother to six grandchildren, Willard R. Simmons, Catherine Smith, Wendell R. Smith, Robin Smith, Zoe Simmons and Wynn R. Simmons. She is survived, also, by her sister, Elizabeth Louise (Connelly) Stiles of Chicago, Illinois. Barbara and Bill retired to the shores of the Rappahannock River, in White Stone, Virginia in 1983. Barbara began her education at St. Xavier Academy in Chicago; she received a B.A. in social sciences from the University of Chicago and went on to receive a masters degree from Columbia University. She was an educator at St. Xavier in New Rochelle, New York. She practiced social work in Washington D.C. and Richmond Virginia. Barbara will be remembered for her high standards in education, her deep appreciation for American history, her love of sailing, and a beautiful sense of aesthetic that revealed itself in her painting and her gardens. A Catholic Funeral Service will be celebrated at the Crowel Chapel in Manchester-By-The- Sea, Massachusetts on Friday, July 3, 2009 at 5:00. Burial will take place in Kilmarnock, Virginia at St. Francis Catholic Church Cemetery. Please contact curriefuneralhome.net for the forthcoming scheduled date and time.

The Disney NetPal from Asus ($350, coming in early August) is a beefed-up Eee PC Netbook with thicker hinges, a spill-proof keyboard and onboard parental controls, and no shortage of Disney-themed frosting. Once you get past the mouse-ear-shape webcam, this is really just a typical Intel Atom-powered Windows XP netbook. There are three U.S.B. ports and an SD slot, a VGA graphics port for school reports and a headphone jack. The Wi-Fi/Webcam combination could make Skyping with a grandparent an option.

In the beginning, circa 2002, there was Gizmodo, a Web site with news and reviews of mobile phones, digital cameras other electronic toys that became the foundation of the Gawker network of Web sites. In 2004, Gizmodo's founder, Peter Rojas, left to start a rival gadget blog, Engadget, which was later acquired by AOL. Ever since, the two sites have slugged it out, profitably competing for scoops and a growing audience of obsessed gearheads. In the process, similar gadget sites have sprouted like weeds around the Web. (The New York Times has its own site, Gadgetwise.)

Two weeks after escaping the Taliban, who had held him for seven months, the reporter David Rohde, far right, returned to The New York Times on Wednesday. Beside him was Tahir Ludin, an Afghan reporter who escaped with him. Mr. Rohde, 41, thanked The Times's editors and its publisher, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., far left, for their efforts to free him. And, he concluded, ''relish your life.'' An article about the visit is at nytimes.com/cityroom.

BIEDERMAN--Morris. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale note with profound sadness the loss of Morris Biederman, who was a stalwart member of the Home's Board of Directors for more than sixty years and also served as the Home's treasurer. It was his vision and fortitude to secure our incredible Riverdale campus which led to the purchase of the Hebrew Home's current property almost 60 years ago. His quiet, modest and sincere leadership were instrumental to the success of the Hebrew Home throughout his tenure. His generosity helped create the Esther and Morris Biederman Library at the Hebrew Home, a facility which he and his beloved late wife Esther worked tirelessly to create. We will sorely miss his wonderful sense of humor, warmth, intelligence and friendship. He was an integral member of the Hebrew Home community and spread joy to all. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Greenberg and Biederman families which include his devoted cousins, nieces and nephews. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale Jeffrey S. Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

WHILE training for a marathon, it can seem as if a runner has to cover countless miles. But a training log, either paper or virtual, can help tally the workouts. ''A log helps to reinforce what you do,'' said Ryan Lamppa at Running USA, a group that promotes the running industry. ''Seeing workouts on the Internet or on a hard copy at home helps a runner stay focused. It can help a runner do more good training or change workouts during a rough spot.''

It's hard to get excited about a new printer, but the new Hewlett-Packard PhotoSmart Premium with TouchSmart Web might be an exception. The printer (available this fall for $400) has a Web user interface that connects to your PCs and the Web via built-in Wi-Fi. Wireless printing is nothing new, but the way that the printer directly connects to the Web to print photos, coupons, maps, event tickets and more is head-turning.

Pentax adds to the lineup of swimming snap-shooters with its new Optio W80, which can withstand a dunk off the deep end down to 16 feet. 8 P.M. (TCM) 39 FROM 1939: HOLLYWOOD'S GREATEST YEAR Each Thursday in July, Turner Classic Movies will celebrate the 70th anniversary of what is considered by many film experts and fans alike to be a high point in the history of filmmaking. At the heart of the series: the 10 films nominated for the best picture Academy Award that year, starting here with ''The Wizard of Oz,'' above. At 10, ''1939,'' a new documentary narrated by Kenneth Branagh, will chronicle the year when the studio system reached its zenith through conversations with Leonard Maltin, Daniel Selznick, Molly Haskell and Scott Eyman as well as archival interviews with Claire Trevor, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Francis Lederer, Maureen O'Hara, Ann Rutherford, George Cukor and Howard Hawks. Seven films from 1939 will follow: ''The Women'' at 11:15; ''Ninotchka'' at 1:30 a.m.; ''Babes in Arms'' at 3:30; ''The Story of Vernon and Irene Castle'' at 5:15; ''Idiot's Delight'' Friday morning at 7; ''Bachelor Mother'' at 9; and ''The Little Princess'' at 10:30. 7 A.M. The latest deluxe volume of Starman, the DC Comics series about Jack Knight, who inherits the role of his superhero father, arrives on the hardcover list at No. 2. This collection of stories includes a sequence in which Jack risks his life to save the villainous Solomon Grundy, a swamp creature that battled many of his father’s compatriots in the Justice Society of America. The writer, James Robinson, really makes you feel for the monster.

Michael Jackson’s run on the charts is not over. Billboard reported that more than 110,000 Jackson albums were sold on Monday and Tuesday, the first two days of the sales week for music retailers, putting him in a position to again dominate the catalog sales chart. The most popular title was “Thriller,” with 44,000 sales, followed by “The Essential Michael Jackson” and “Number Ones,” Billboard reported, based on early data from stores. Those albums, in the reverse order, were Mr. Jackson’s most popular last week, when he sold a total of 422,000 albums and 2.3 million single tracks online, breaking several records. Because all of Mr. Jackson’s albums are at least 18 months old, they do not qualify for the Billboard 200, the trade magazine’s standard albums chart.

LONDON — A recent story in the style pages of the Evening Standard proclaimed that the ultimate new party accessory for women-about-town was a man in drag, replacing the hitherto indispensable Gay Best Friend. I have yet to spot a transvestite on the arm of any worldly woman I know (though you never can tell, can you?), but I certainly seem destined to spend a lot of time with cross-dressers as long as I’m frequenting the West End.

The Serena Williams-Elena Dementieva match was played at a remarkably high level for close to three hours. Dementieva's serve may be the most improved shot on the tour, and she won a high percentage of both first and second serves against Williams, arguably the game's best returner. Like Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal on the men's side, Serena and Venus Williams have elevated the level of play on the women's tour, with their big serving, aggressive returns and seemingly indomitable wills. Give Dementieva credit for responding to the challenge; she was a shot away from the final, and, for long stretches of the match, outplayed Serena.

By the usual rules of New York Times puzzles, Saturday crosswords are not only the hardest of the week, they also have no underlying theme. Themes greatly constrain the construction. That's why you can end up with far fewer blocks and words in Friday and Saturday puzzles. Some people enjoy themes. Some people enjoy the denser grids with the zippier and more difficult words. It's almost impossible to have both together.

CNNMoney.com reports that Small Business Administration lending in the most recent quarter continued to, well, plummet, compared to the year before. Between April and June, banks made 30 percent fewer loans in the agency's flagship 7(a) program than in the same months in 2008, which were in turn way down from the year before. (Dollar volume is down slightly less, off by 26.5 percent.) In all, 7(a) lending has dropped by more than half - 55 percent - from spring 2007.

Tommy did not go pee-pee at Julia's office. He didn't have to go then and he didn't have to go at 11:30 a.m. on a recent Thursday, when a woman called Mommy asked him. Tommy romped around on a manicured trapezoid of grass in Madison Square Park, across from the Metropolitan Life Building. He whipped his blond head and yardstick-height body into somersaults and handstands, he jumped and rolled and skipped. He did not have to go to the bathroom.

Readers of T are already familiar with the French photographer Jean-Baptiste Mondino, who contributes regularly to our magazine. Fans of his photography and screen work (he has directed videos for David Bowie, Madonna, Sting, Neneh Cherry and Björk, among others) are sure to love "La Danse des Mots," which first appeared in 1983 and was subsequently released by Island Records in 1984. In the video, Mondino directs, sings and acts; in the process, he introduces us to every imaginable subculture of the 1980s, including breakdancers, rappers, taggers and nerds. The fashion is amazing (who doesn't love a good jumpsuit?), but what's most incredible is how contemporary the video feels, especially considering it was done before the era of computer manipulation. Take a look and tell us what you think.

Last September, I wrote about dance music gaining credibility among high-minded indie aficionados, most notably with the critical praise given to the alt-disco bands Hercules and Love Affair, Cut Copy and LCD Soundsystem. Following the unofficial law of pop music that says it takes approximately nine months for a trend to go mass, the beat has officially moved from underground music blogs to the top of the pop charts.Evidence of this is everywhere: Lady Gaga, with her synth-heavy beats and lyrical odes to hedonism, fame and sex, has become something of a poster child for pop music's transition toward clubland. The Black Eyed Peas, a group with absolutely no pretensions toward anything but No. 1 hits, has just released "The E.N.D. (The Energy Never Dies)," a concept dance album that sounds like "Daft Punk for Dummies." The first official leak of Whitney Houston's eagerly anticipated comeback anthem, "I Didn't Know My Own Strength," came through a throbbing house remix courtesy of the D.J. Peter Rauhofer that played at gay pride parties this past weekend from Toronto to New York. "Loba" ("She-Wolf"), the latest single from Shakira, an artist in tune with the international pulse, is a wonderful Giorgio Moroder-influenced dance-floor thumper that sounds like nothing she has put her hips to in the past. And finally, the passing of Michael Jackson was a powerful reminder of his transcendent grooves and otherworldly moves. Last I checked, Jackson had a whopping four of the Top 10 songs and Top 10 albums on iTunes. It's as if the entire globe has just rediscovered that Jackson's unprecedented talent bursts to life only when the bass line drops and we, his adoring audience, snap our fingers to the beat.

All of this follows on yesterday's editorial asserting that the Minnesota senatorial election was stolen.

An analysis by The New York Times of rainfall and homicides for the last six years shows that when it rains substantially in the summertime, there are fewer homicides. When there was no precipitation, there was an average of 17 homicides every 10 days. But when there was an inch or more of rain, the average dropped to 14.

Although they're meant to be helpful, Microsoft Word 2007's ScreenTips (those explanatory panels that pop up when you rest the mouse cursor over onscreen icons and commands) can also get in the way - especially if you know the program and don't need them. To turn off the tips, click on the round Office button in the top corner of the screen and choose Word Options at the bottom of the box. Click on Popular in the left pane and in the ScreenTips Style area, choose "Don't show ScreenTips" from the pop-up menu. Click O.K. to close the box and get back to Word.

Because of an editing error, an article on June 18 about plans by Reader’s Digest to change the editorial focus of the magazine from generic “how-to” articles and celebrity profiles aimed at a broad audience to appeal to a narrower base referred incorrectly at one point to the nature of the change. As the rest of the article made clear, the shift is toward conservative social values, not “to the right” politically.

An article on June 23 about a zoning dispute between neighbors of a landmark Christian Science church on Park Avenue and a catering company that leases the church for high-society events gave outdated information about the New York Landmarks Conservancy’s position on the church’s application to lease its building. In a draft of remarks prepared for a hearing, the group did support the application, but no hearing was ever held, so it never gave any testimony, and ultimately did not take any public position on the matter. The article also provided insufficient context for a comment by the conservancy. In saying it was “no exaggeration to call this a crisis,” the conservancy was referring generally to the plight of churches nationwide with dwindling congregations and resources, not specifically to the Park Avenue church.

An article on Wednesday about a funeral service for two of the three men who died in a toxic well at the Regal Recycling Company in Jamaica, Queens, on Monday erroneously linked Michael Reali, one of the principals of company, to a bid-rigging scheme in 1996 in which several companies were accused of inflating garbage hauling fees at federal buildings. That case involved a different Michael Reali not affiliated with Regal Recycling, who at the time lived in Woodbury, N.Y., and who eventually pleaded guilty to petty larceny and was sentenced to a conditional discharge.

New Delhi's highest court decriminalized consensual homosexual acts on Thursday, in a landmark ruling that could usher in an era of greater freedom for gay men and lesbians in Indian society. The decision applies only to New Delhi but is likely to force India's government to either appeal to the Supreme Court or change the law nationwide, lawyers and advocates said.

Oracle plans to cut as many as 1,000 jobs in Europe, a labor union said on its Internet site. Of the total, about 250 jobs will be lost in France, equivalent to 16 percent of the company's work force there, the CFDT union said, citing meetings between Oracle management and the works committee on June 29 and 30. Oracle had 86,000 employees worldwide as of May 31. Deborah Hellinger, an Oracle spokeswoman, didn't respond to e-mailed requests for comment.

The Onex Corporation, a private equity firm, and Alex Yemenidjian, left, a former president of MGM Mirage, acquired a majority stake in the Tropicana Las Vegas Hotel and Casino after it emerged from bankruptcy protection. Mr. Yemenidjian will become chairman and chief executive of the venture, Onex said. Onex was one of the bankrupt property's biggest secured debt holders. The Tropicana Las Vegas emerged from bankruptcy Wednesday with no debt, more than $10 million of cash, and commitments from Onex and other unidentified equity holders to invest at least $75 million in upgrades for the property, according to the statement. A renovation will begin this year and be completed in 2010, Onex said.

GENDELL--Gerald (Gerry) S.,80, died on June 29 of complications from metastatic melanoma with his wife of 57 years, Marion, by his side. Gerry grew up in Ossining, NY and graduated from New York University in 1949. He was commissioned as a First Lieutenant by the U.S. Army in 1952. After his honorable discharge, Gerry joined the Procter & Gamble Company of Cincinnati, Ohio where he was best known as the brand manager who launched the Pringles potato chip business. He headed P&G's worldwide Public Affairs and Public Relations Operations, and served as president and trustee of the Procter & Gamble Fund, retiring after 39 years at the company. Gerry was active in the Cincinnati community serving as Vice Chairman of the Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, Vice-Chair and Trustee of the Jewish Hospital, and Board member of Hebrew Union College. His greatest joy was raising his seven children who survive him: Carin Gendell of Great Falls, VA; Danna Korell of Naperville, IL; Dr. Adrian Bonser of Dunwoody, GA; Jeff Gendell of Greenwich, CT; David Gendell of Westport, CT; Marc Gendell of Atlanta, GA; and Bradley Gendell of New York City. Upon his retirement, Gerry and Marion relocated to Tucson, Arizona where he served as President of the Jewish Community Foundation of Southern Arizona. In addition to his children, he is survived by his brother, Martin Gendell of New York City, and by 13 loving grandchildren.

Nineteen foreign activists of the pro-Palestinian Free Gaza Movement were being held in Israel on Thursday awaiting deportation, two days after the Israeli Navy seized control of their boat off Gaza. A former United States lawmaker, Cynthia McKinney, and the Irish Nobel laureate Mairead Corrigan Maguire were among those being held. The group's members have sailed boats to Gaza in the past year, saying they wanted to bring aid and challenging Israel's blockade.

NETTER--Richard, Esq. It is with great sadness that the Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges the passing of our dear friend, distinguished colleague and generous benefactor, Richard Netter, Esq. A member of the Board of Trustees of Beth Israel Medical Center for over 50 years, Mr. Netter was the longest serving member of the Board. He served in many leadership positions during his tenure, including Vice Chairman. Helping to build Beth Israel over the past 50 years has been a passion for Mr. Netter, and the hospital has benefited greatly from his leadership. He has served on the Continuum Board since its inception in 1997 and has chaired its Nominating Committee since then. Mr. Netter, along with his beloved wife, Alice, also a Trustee, championed many initiatives at Beth Israel through personal philanthropy and through his involvement as a guardian and board member of several foundations. In 2002, he was recognized for his leadership and many efforts on behalf of the hospital with the Beth Israel Charles H. Silver Memorial Award. He raised money to expand our outstanding music therapy program by establishing the Louis B. Armstrong Center for Music and Medicine. With the generous support of the Herbert and Nell Singer Foundation, Mr. Netter helped establish the Herbert and Nell Singer Division of Perioperative Services at the hospital, supporting major enhancements of the operating room suite. Among his many other philanthropic endeavors was the Thanks to Scandinavia Scholarship Fund, established with his good friend, the late entertainer Victor Borge, as an expression of gratitude to the people and governments of the Scandinavian countries for their rescue of Jewish people from the Holocaust. The Fund provides scholarships and fellowships to physicians, nurses, and other healthcare professionals from Scandinavia to study at Beth Israel and other institutions. Mr. Netter had an abiding love for Beth Israel's rich history and a strong commitment to its successful partnership with the other hospitals in the Continuum network. Most importantly, he was steadfast in his commitment to the collective mission of our institutions to always provide the highest quality, most compassionate care to patients from all walks of life. His wit, wisdom and advocacy will be greatly missed but will remain forever his legacy. This special man will be sorely missed. To Alice, his daughters, Laurie Sprayregen (Philip) and Patricia Shiland, his three grandchildren, and his countless friends and admirers throughout the world, we extend our most heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Morton P. Hyman Chairman Emeritus Alan Mirken Chairman Beth Israel Board of Overseers Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Health Partners Harris M. Nagler, MD Interim President Beth Israel Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President Beth Israel Medical Board

Human Rights Watch said Thursday that recent military operations in the Congo ''have been a disaster for civilians, who are now being attacked from all sides.'' The report accused government troops, who are backed by United Nations peacekeepers, of raping and brutalizing villagers in a large area of eastern Congo. United Nations officials have said that parts of eastern Congo are getting worse, despite efforts to sweep out the rebels.

North Korea fired four short-range missiles from a base near Wonsan, a major city on the North's east coast, a spokesman at the South Korean Defense Ministry said. He spoke on the condition of anonymity because a formal announcement had not been made yet. The launchings raised speculation that North Korea might test-fire a long-range ballistic missile in defiance of a United Nations ban, perhaps over the United States' Fourth of July holiday.

Amnesty International on Thursday accused both Israel and Hamas, the militant movement that controls Gaza, of committing war crimes during the three weeks of fighting there early this year. The human rights group singled out what it called the ''unprecedented'' scale and intensity of the Israeli onslaught and the ''unlawful'' Palestinian use of rockets against Israeli civilians.

Gazprom, the Russian company that ships a quarter of Europe's gasoline, is seeking supply deals in the Caspian region, Africa and around the world to anchor its lead in areas where European buyers may turn to rival producers. European Union countries are seeking to diversify supplies as nations seek to cut reliance on Russia. By forging partnerships and snapping up production assets in gas-producing nations, the company can add alternative sources of fuel. Gazprom held talks in Algeria last month about developing the trans-Saharan pipeline from Nigeria, where it had agreed to bid for gas fields through a joint venture. In the Caspian region, Gazprom signed a deal to buy gas from Azerbaijan, threatening European plans to add the country as a source of gas supply.

The Seven & I Holdings Company, which operates the 7-Eleven convenience stores, said profit fell 28 percent on slumping supermarket and department store sales amid the recession. Net income fell to 23.7 billion yen ($247 million) in the three months that ended in May from 33.1 billion yen, the company said. Sales fell 11 percent to 1.24 trillion yen, from 1.39 trillion yen. Falling gasoline prices in North America, where 7-Eleven outlets sell fuel, and a stronger yen cut Seven & I's sales in the quarter by 110 billion yen, the company said. The average price of gas in the United States dropped 42 percent to $2.1 a gallon in the three months that ended May 31 from $3.49 a year earlier.

NETTER--Richard. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of Richard Netter. Richard was co-founder and president of Thanks To Scandinavia, an institute of AJC, dedicated to the lessons garnered from the rescue of Jews during World War II. Richard was a dear friend, an incredible force for good, and an inspiration to all who knew him. He will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, Alice, his daughters, Laurie and Patricia, and their families, of whom he was so proud. Richard J. Sideman, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir.

KNOX--William Graham, 91, of Greenwich, CT, on June 26th, 2009. Son of W. Graham Knox, Jr. and Fiona Reardon Knox. He was born on March 18, 1918 in New York City. Survived by his wife, Amie B. Knox, wife of 58 years, and his four children: Graham, Robert (Dorothee), Amie (Jim Kelley), John (Page) and eight grandchildren. Graham's passion was medicine and after graduating from Columbia College in 1939, and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942, he joined the staff of St Luke's Hospital in New York, with which he was affiliated for more than 45 years. Graham served in the Navy medical corps from 1944-46, participating in the South Atlantic command and later in the invasion of Okinawa. He spent his entire medical career in New York City, both at St. Luke's and St. Vincent's Hospitals where he served in several leadership positions in their departments of vascular surgery. He was also a professor of Clinical Surgery at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and was chief of vascular surgery emeritus at St. Vincent's Hospital. In addition, he served as president of the New York County Medical Society, the New York Surgical Society and the New York Cardiovascular Society. Dr. Knox took great pride in being a surgeon and commuted six days a week by car to New York City. He established lifelong relationships with many of his patients who later became among his closest friends. Graham continued to be an exceptional diagnostician even after his retirement and used his vast knowledge of medicine to advise friends and relatives on various medical issues. A memorial service will be held later in the summer. Contributions can be made to the Joseph Collins Foundation, 787 Seventh Avenue, Room 3950, New York, NY 10019.

We will remember her always for her commitment to FAI's mission and love for her family. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Sharyn and her husband, Steve; to her grandchildren, Tamara and Joseph; and to the entire family. Molly was a remarkable woman who will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Todd J. Slotkin, Chairman The Food Allergy Initiative

My Sunday column offers my own list of the best children's books ever, as an inducement to summer reading -- and summer reading aloud. If I had had a bit more space, I would have offered a couple more: Winnie the Pooh (the chapter of Piglet trapped in the flood is my favorite); the A to Z Mysteries, which were published in the last decade and were the first chapter books that my daughter read. The A to Z's are short, easy mysteries that are a great way to get a young child engrossed in books. But aaaargh! Somehow I've still left out Pippi Longstocking and Roald Dahl, who are glorious reads....but this list has to come to an end somewhere.

An obituary on May 23 about Robert Furchgott, a Nobel prize-winning scientist who explored the roles of nitric oxide in the body, referred incompletely to the process by which nitric oxide is produced during combustion. Burning fuels like gasoline produces enough heat to break the bonds in nitrogen and oxygen molecules in the air, and the nitrogen and oxygen atoms recombine to form nitric oxide; the nitrogen is not directly burned. This correction was delayed for research.

A court in Britain awarded £120 million ($196 million) in British assets seized in the R. Allen Stanford fraud investigation to liquidators from Antigua, after a court battle with receivers from the United States. Liquidators appointed in the United States and Antigua had failed to agree on who should control the assets held in Britain by Stanford International Bank, based in Antigua. Justice Kim Lewison awarded the assets to Antiguan liquidators who had been appointed to oversee the Stanford International Bank assets, saying ''they should be permitted to remit those assets'' to Antigua. Ralph Janvey, the United States liquidator, said in a statement that the ruling was ''wrongly decided and should be reversed.'' Mr. Stanford was indicted in June in Houston on charges he swindled investors out of more than $7 billion in a Ponzi scheme. He has been in custody since June 18.

An answer in the Q&A column on Page 3 this weekend, about suggestions for sightseeing in Johannesburg, refers incorrectly to the city. While it is considered the financial capital of South Africa and is the country's largest city, Johannesburg is not the capital. (Pretoria is the administrative capital; Cape Town is the legislative capital; and Bloemfontein is the judicial capital.)

SNOW--Judy Schwamm. Died on July 1st, 2009, at age 75. Beloved mother of Erica Arbron and fiance Marc Goldstein, David and Selena Snow, Harvey-Skip Snow and fiance Alix Juhasz and Linda and Barrett Gross. Proud grandmother of Travis and Eric Snow, Alyson and Jake Arbron, Peter and Emily Gross and Zoe Ford Snow. Cherished sister of Jay Schwamm. Proud alumna of the Fieldston School, Northampton School for Girls and Sarah Lawrence College. Judy's passions were her family, the sea and learning. Judy lived her life on her own terms. Having married Robert Snow in 1955, and then living as a homemaker, caterer, and sailor for many years. Judy divorced and spent the next 13 years sailing through Europe, the Caribbean, South America and the east coast of the US on her beloved Snowbird as a great matron and friend to her cruising colleagues who confided in her and sought her wisdom, wit and passion day in and day out. Judy was a renowned cook, hostess and entertainer. She spent the last decade of her life pursuing Jewish adult education, and being at the center of the vital family life she loved so well, and in addition pursuing philanthropic causes. Donations in her memory may be made to the Stamford United Jewish Federation's Board of Jewish Education Continuing Education Fund, (UJF-BJE-CEF). Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Dr., Stamford, CT (203) 322-1649 on Monday, July 6 at 11am, Rabbi Marc Disick will officiate.

Doctors have determined that John Demjanjuk, who is accused of complicity in atrocities as a guard at a Nazi death camp, is fit to stand trial, prosecutors said Friday in Munich. Mr. Demjanjuk, 89, a retired autoworker, was deported from the United States in May. He is expected to stand trial this fall in connection with the deaths of 29,000 Jews at the Sobibor death camp in Nazi-occupied eastern Poland. He and his family say bone-marrow and kidney diseases have made him too ill for trial. But doctors said he was capable of two 90-minute sessions a day, the prosecutor's office said.

The Shenzhen Stock Exchange in China will impose price limits on first-day trading in shares of smaller companies, seeking to protect investors and control speculation after the nation lifted its nine-month ban on initial public offerings of stock. The exchange, the second-largest in China after the Shanghai Stock Exchange, said it would suspend trading of debut stocks for 30 minutes if they rise or fall 20 percent from their opening price. First-day shares may be halted for another 30 minutes if they fluctuate 50 percent or more. The 76 companies that sold first-time stock in China last year rose an average 152 percent on debut even as the wider market was tumbling, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The Blackstone Group, the buyout firm that owns Hilton Hotels, sold a golf resort near Carmel, Calif., to an investment firm led by John Pritzker for $20 million. Mr. Pritzker, the founding partner of Geolo Capital of San Francisco and son of the late Hyatt Hotels founder, Jay Pritzker, said his company would spend about $25 million to upgrade the resort, Carmel Valley Ranch, during the next 18 to 24 months. The resort is spread over 400 acres, and Mr. Pritzker's plans include room renovations and a spa. ''We'll spend whatever we have to do to execute our concept,'' Mr. Pritzker said. ''As it stands now, there's kind of no 'heart' to the property.'' Luxury-hotel revenue has dropped for 12 months, including 28 percent in April from a year earlier, according to Smith Travel Research. Blackstone bought Carmel Valley Ranch in 2005 as part of its acquisition of Wyndham International, valued at $3.24 billion including assumed debt.

NETTER--Richard. The family of Leonard and Sophie Davis mourn with deep sadness the passing of our great and true friend Richard Netter - a philanthropist in every way, at all times, with all people. His departure of this world marks for us the end of an era - his effervescent wit and drawings, humor and good cheer sparkled generations. His struggles for justice and the welfare of others were quiet and determined. He taught us about friendship. We love him and miss him. Alan, Mary Lou, Jaimee, Greg, Paul, Michael, Jyll, Nettizanne and Nyracai.

WHEATLAND--Richard II, 85, died peacefully on June 26th, 2009 at his home in Boston. Born in Boston, he was the son of Stephen and Dorothy Parker Wheatland of Sorrento, Maine. Father of Sarah W. Fisher, father-in-law of David Fisher, brother of Sarah W. Richards, Mary W. Schley, Alice N. Wellman, brother-in-law of Bradford S. Wellman and Miss Marguerite de H. McAdoo, grandfather of Thea and Otto Fisher. He was married in 1954 to Cynthia McAdoo, who predeceased him in December 2008. He served in the Navy on the USS Harry S. Bauer in the Pacific during World War II. He graduated from Harvard in 1945, and received his JD from Columbia University in 1949. He served in Paris under the Marshall Plan 1950-53. He was then Vice President of New York Airways, a pioneering helicopter company in New York from 1953-68. He was President then Chairman of Acadia Management Co. in Boston. He had many philanthropic interests, none of which he valued more than the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, MA, of which his ancestor Richard Wheatland was a founding member in 1799. He worked tirelessly for the museum for many years, serving as Chairman of the Board for nine years and raising millions of dollars. Under his leadership, the Peabody Museum and the Essex Institute were merged in 1992. He was also an active board member of the Museum Trustee Association, the Penobscot Marine Museum of Searsport, ME, the Friends of the Public Garden, Boston, the Boston Natural Areas Fund, Boston, and the Beacon Hill Civic Association, Boston. He was a member of the Tavern Club and the Club of Odd Volumes, amongst others. He was a devoted jogger, running races into his seventh decade, and he adored skiing, sailing, and traveling. A memorial service will be held on August 8th, 2009 at 5 o'clock at the Church of the Redeemer, Sorrento, Maine. A reception will follow. A celebration of Richard Wheatland II's life will be held in Boston, date to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, MA.

Strabag, Central Europe's biggest construction company, withdrew from buying Austrian and Hungarian assets of Cemex after failing to gain Austrian antitrust approval. Cemex, the largest cement maker in the Americas, agreed in July 2008 to sell the assets to Strabag, which is based in Vienna, for 310 million euros ($434 million). The two companies agreed neither side could back out before June 30 this year. Cemex Austria and Cemex Hungaria Epitoanyagok employ 1,012 workers and had revenue of 257 million euros in 2007, according to Strabag.

POLLIN--Burton Ralph, of Bronxville, NY, died June 30, 2009. He was 93. Prof. Pollin was born in Worcester, MA, on May 8, 1916. He was graduated from City College of New York and received his Ph.D. from Columbia University. Prof. Pollin had a long career in education and was Professor Emeritus of English, City University of New York. He was the author of more than 12 books and more than 140 articles on many subjects, including William Godwin, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Edgar Allan Poe. He was one of the world's most prominent Poe scholars, and he continued the critical editions of Poe's works of Mabbott and Ostrom. He was a frequent lecturer and subject of press interviews, the recipient of numerous grants and fellowships and a member of numerous scholarly organizations. Prof. Pollin and his wife, Prof. Alice M. Pollin, moved to Bronxville from Manhattan in 1978 and were co-founders of the Bronxville Beautification Committee, among other civic activities. He was an accomplished amateur pianist and had a wide range of interests in the arts and public affairs. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, a daughter, Diana C. Pollin, of Marseilles, France, a son, Myles C. Pollin, of Manhattan, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister, Gladys Bunim, of Miami Beach, FL.

It's a kind of calligraphy, these ringlets and waves, hair combed, twisted and pinned. A first lady's coiffure is a pattern, chosen as deliberately as the White House china, but prey to wind and rain, especially on cold Inauguration Days. It's also prey to public opinion, should she dare to make quixotic changes in her 'do -- a sign of flippancy and flip-flopping. Notice there are no flips. In the beginning, we see a newborn empire in those Josephine curls. The mid-20th century is marcelled. And in recent decades, increasingly liberated first ladies sport more leonine locks. Interestingly, there are no bangs. Perhaps this has less to do with hair and more to do with campaign promises of marital harmony and world peace. -- LAURA JACOBS, the author, most recently, of ''The Bird Catcher''

General Motors said the Beijing Automotive Industry Holding Company had submitted an offer for its Opel division, giving the bankrupt automaker more options if negotiations with Magna International failed. Beijing Automotive made the nonbinding proposal after examining Opel's books, Chris Preuss, a G.M. spokesman in Zurich, said, declining to provide details. Magna, Canada's biggest auto parts manufacturer, was chosen in May by the German government as the preferred bidder for Opel, which has its headquarters outside Frankfurt. In Britain, where Opel owns two factories that make vehicles under the Vauxhall brand, the government may lend money to help complete the sale to Magna, the business secretary, Peter Mandelson, above, said. ''We are prepared to financially underwrite that deal,'' Mr. Mandelson told reporters after a meeting at Vauxhall's factory in Luton, England. Potential government aid would include loans and loan guarantees ''for which we have to have interest paid and some securities.''

When the Czech Republic unveiled an avowedly satirical artwork to mark the beginning of its European Union presidency last January, neighboring Slovakia was depicted as a giant Hungarian sausage. It was a stinging humiliation for many Slovaks, who have spent centuries struggling to assert their own sense of nationhood, first as serfs under the Hungarian Kingdom in the 19th century and then as the poorer segment of the former Czechoslovakia.

As expected, Chien-Ming Wang was placed on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right shoulder and bursitis on Sunday. Wang will not throw until after the All-Star Game break, a stretch of 12 days. The Yankees hope the extra rest will allow Wang to strengthen his injured shoulder, but they offered no timetable for his possible return.

To the Editor: Regarding your Q&A column on what to do on Cape Breton Island (June 21): Music is the heart of Cape Breton and is found everywhere. No visitor should miss out on a ceilidh, or a barn dance, like the ones at the Normaway Inn, Margaree or in churches. Young fiddlers like Natalie MacMaster, who performs for sold-out houses throughout North America, keep the centuries-old culture fresh and alive. Charles G. Lief.

I was very unhappy to learn that you are not planning to run the variety puzzle every week in the print edition of the magazine. I look forward to them all week, much more so than the regular crossword or, indeed, any other feature of the Sunday Times. I hope you can find a way to continue them weekly, regardless of advertising volume or any other criterion.Annandale, Va.

If an issue “devoted to architecture and infrastructure would be incomplete without architects,” the vision of future infrastructure offered in the June 14 issue is curiously lacking. The most exciting infrastructure advances today are not being developed by architects. Urban designers and landscape architects are creating public spaces that double as water-treatment facilities; new businesses are using cars to transform energy distribution and storage; artists are rethinking municipal waste facilities; product designers are making it possible to aggregate individuals’ choices to create real change; and engineers are inventing transformative technologies right now.

The Hyatt hotel chain’s “random acts of generosity” program represents a lottery, not a gesture of gratitude (Rob Walker, Consumed). A thoughtful guest who had received one of these favors would be unlikely to choose to book a room at a Hyatt, versus another hotel, just because they had won a hotel-spa massage the last time. Statistically, I would guess that the chances of the guest getting another favor are pretty small. That’s the nature of lotteries. It’s equally hard to imagine why that Hyatt customer would recommend the Hyatt to a friend. Odds are the friend wouldn’t win a favor; so imagine the potential for envy and resentment in that friendship. The Hyatt may pick up a few more guests because they like to gamble but not because they are grateful.

Cynthia Gorney’s timely profile of Rafael Nadal on the eve of his Wimbledon withdrawal underscores his marquee importance to professional tennis. Surely television ratings for the 2009 Wimbledon final will diminish with no Federer-Nadal rematch. But having these two likable role models at the top of the tennis world is rare and should be celebrated. Young athletes need more examples of superstars that exude humility, respect and a willingness to put in the hard work and “earn it.” Vamos Rafa! Short Hills, N.J.

In 1609, a ship from Plymouth, England, bound for the Jamestown colony in Virginia was damaged in a storm but found refuge on an Atlantic island with pink beaches. The English had discovered Bermuda. Celebrating the 400th anniversary of that event all year (www.bermuda2009.bm), Bermuda, still a British territory, is offering several money-saving packages at some of its most luxurious hotels. Cambridge Beaches Resort and Spa (www.cambridgebeaches.com) is offering a $400 credit to guests who stay four nights or longer through Aug. 21 (travel must be booked by Aug. 15). Nightly rates start at $470 and include daily breakfast and afternoon tea.

''This agency will have only one mission to protect consumers.'' Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, on President Obama's proposal to create a consumer protection agency that would regulate home loans, credit card fees, payday loans and other forms of consumer finance. ''It's going to be a huge fight.'' Edward L. Yingling, president of the American Bankers Association. Banks and mortgage lenders oppose a new consumer protection agency, saying its powers would be too broad.

SNOW--Judy Schwamm. Died on July 1st, 2009, at age 75. Beloved mother of Erica Arbron and fiance Marc Goldstein, David and Selena Snow, Harvey-Skip Snow and fiance Alix Juhasz and Linda and Barrett Gross. Proud grandmother of Travis and Eric Snow, Alyson and Jake Arbron, Peter and Emily Gross and Zoe Ford Snow. Cherished sister of Jay Schwamm. Proud alumna of the Fieldston School, Northampton School for Girls and Sarah Lawrence College. Judy's passions were her family, the sea and learning. Judy lived her life on her own terms. Having married Robert Snow in 1955, and then living as a homemaker, caterer, and sailor for many years. Judy divorced and spent the next 13 years sailing through Europe, the Caribbean, South America and the east coast of the US on her beloved Snowbird as a great matron and friend to her cruising colleagues who confided in her and sought her wisdom, wit and passion day in and day out. Judy was a renowned cook, hostess and entertainer. She spent the last decade of her life pursuing Jewish adult education, and being at the center of the vital family life she loved so well, and in addition pursuing philanthropic causes. Donations in her memory may be made to the Stamford United Jewish Federation's Board of Jewish Education Continuing Education Fund, (UJF-BJE-CEF). Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Dr., Stamford, CT (203) 322-1649 on Monday, July 6 at 11am, Rabbi Marc Disick will officiate.

ODEN--Erica E.,a resident of Riverdale, NY, died on May 22, 2009, at 5400 Fieldston Rd., her home of 66 years. She was 102. Born July 14, 1906 in Germany, a promising performance career in Modern Dance was cut short in 1933 when she fled to Turkey. In 1937, she immigrated to the US. Here, she taught modern dance and gymnastics, and, after the death of her husband, Walter, joined the faculty of the Riverdale Country School and later the Girls' School, teaching physical education. She is mourned by two sons, Peter and Neal, and three grandchildren.

COHEN--Harvey B.,died on the morning of Saturday June 27th at the age of 62, after a seven month courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He was surrounded by family at the time of his passing. Mr. Cohen was the founder of Finders, Inc., Focus Capital Markets and Insight. He was an avid, ranked tennis player, Karate hall of famer, and professional, published sleight of hand magician, who had worked as one of the technical advisors to David Blaine. He was an exceptional husband, son, father, and grandfather. With his huge heart and charming charismatic personality, he was loved by all who knew him. He is survived by wife, Chenqin Shen; mother, Florence Cohen, three daughters, Jena Kingsley, Brett Sundheim and Katie Cohen; two grandsons, James Kingsley and Brody Sundheim and newborn granddaughter Ryan Sundheim.

HE economy lost 467,000 jobs in June, a deeply discouraging number at a time when other indicators have suggested the recession may be ending. But economic turning points are notoriously hard to identify, especially when a parade of data can seem to contradict itself. After the 2001 recession, 20 months passed before the National Bureau of Economic Research officially determined its endpoint. To get a feeling for how cycles are evolving, economists at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have been watching a chart of industrial production, based on data from manufacturers, miners and utility companies. (In the United States, industry's share of the economy has fallen to about 20 percent, but it still moves roughly in step with the economy as a whole.) The chart, explained below, currently suggests that the economy is poised to turn around, but that the climb out will be a long one.

WHEATLAND--Richard II, 85, died peacefully on June 26th, 2009 at his home in Boston. Born in Boston, he was the son of Stephen and Dorothy Parker Wheatland of Sorrento, Maine. Father of Sarah W. Fisher, father-in-law of David Fisher, brother of Sarah W. Richards, Mary W. Schley, Alice N. Wellman, brother-in-law of Bradford S. Wellman and Miss Marguerite de H. McAdoo, grandfather of Thea and Otto Fisher. He was married in 1954 to Cynthia McAdoo, who predeceased him in December 2008. He served in the Navy on the USS Harry S. Bauer in the Pacific during World War II. He graduated from Harvard in 1945, and received his JD from Columbia University in 1949. He served in Paris under the Marshall Plan 1950-53. He was then Vice President of New York Airways, a pioneering helicopter company in New York from 1953-68. He was President then Chairman of Acadia Management Co. in Boston. He had many philanthropic interests, none of which he valued more than the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, MA, of which his ancestor Richard Wheatland was a founding member in 1799. He worked tirelessly for the museum for many years, serving as Chairman of the Board for nine years and raising millions of dollars. Under his leadership, the Peabody Museum and the Essex Institute were merged in 1992. He was also an active board member of the Museum Trustee Association, the Penobscot Marine Museum of Searsport, ME, the Friends of the Public Garden, Boston, the Boston Natural Areas Network, Boston, and the Beacon Hill Civic Association, Boston. He was a member of the Tavern Club and the Club of Odd Volumes, amongst others. He was a devoted jogger, running races into his seventh decade, and he adored skiing, sailing, and traveling. A memorial service will be held on August 8th, 2009 at 5 o'clock at the Church of the Redeemer, Sorrento, Maine. A reception will follow. A celebration of Richard Wheatland II's life will be held in Boston, date to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers to the Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, MA.

WIMBLEDON, England -- Nighttime tennis has arrived on Centre Court, but the long American tradition of Breakfast at Wimbledon is not endangered. Such was the claim of Ian Ritchie, the chief executive of the All England Club, in an interview about the future effect of the new Centre Court roof. ''Building the roof was never done on the basis of, here's a great commercial opportunity,'' Ritchie said, noting that the plan for the project predated his arrival as the chief executive in 2005. ''It was built as an insurance against the weather and, to a lesser extent, the light.'' In other words, there is no intention to create separate day and night programs, as there are at the United States and Australian Opens, or to move the women's and men's finals into a prime-time night slot. ''We have said pretty consistently that it is not something that is attractive to us, and that we consider Wimbledon to be a summer, outdoors event,'' Ritchie said. ''We don't want to have what they have in the U.S. and Australia.'' He acknowledged that the fourth-round match between Andy Murray and Stanislas Wawrinka that was played under the roof and lasted until 10:39 p.m. had drawn what he called an ''astonishing'' audience on BBC. Ritchie said the number of viewers for Murray-Wawrinka peaked at 12.6 million for a 56.4 percent audience share, which he said was comparable for the 2008 Champions League soccer final between Manchester United and Chelsea. The five-set match was so electrifying it immediately set off speculation that scheduled night tennis at Wimbledon was an inevitability. Ritchie said, ''We have no intention of doing that.'' He said that adding a night session would not be as lucrative an arrangement aspeople may believe because ''ticket revenue is a relatively small proportion of the overall gross'' at Wimbledon. In addition, he said the tournament must always be mindful of its grass courts, unlike the hardcourts, where, he said, ''you can play all day and night.''

AS the story goes, technicians from Mercedes-Benz stripped the white paint off its grand prix cars at the 1934 International Eifel race at the Nürburgring track in Germany to bring the cars below the maximum weight permitted by a new racing formula, 750 kilograms, or 1,650 pounds. True or not, the Silver Arrows were born. Manfred von Brauchitsch won in the debut of the W25 racecar at the Nürburgring. And until 1939, the Silver Arrows were dominant, matched only occasionally by racecars from its competitor, Auto Union.
