PAYARD PATISSERIE AND BISTRO, a boom-time institution with gravity-defying chocolate confections and wedding cakes crowding its cases, has fallen victim to the recession. Known to non-New Yorkers as the bakery in ''Sex and the City,'' the shop, on Lexington Avenue between 73rd and 74th Streets, drew skeletal socialites and already high-strung locals to feast on its Napoleons and Notre Dames; among the regulars were Dr. Ruth Westheimer, and me: I visited as many Saturdays as I could over the past nine years, including for lunch with my father the day my husband asked for his blessing. On the final Saturday, after a dozen years, the owner, François Payard, wept behind a case of macaroons. By Monday morning, a single white rose and a sign had been taped over the entrance: ''Sorry, but Payard will be closed. Thank you.''

KOHNSTAMM--Therese Werner, passed away peacefully in her home on June 24, 2009 at the age of 97. She will be greatly missed by her daughter, Jo Ann, her sister, Jean, her nieces and nephews, and their families. Therese (Terry to her friends and family) was born in Manhattan and loved the city. She attended Ethical Culture School and then went on to Barnard College. Terry and her husband, Ed, together with their son, Lee, tirelessly built V&E Kohnstamm, Inc., a flavors and essential oils company. Throughout her life, Terry loved to play golf and travel. Adventurous and energetic, throughout her life, at the age of 77, she took one of the most memorable trips of her life whitewater rafting down the Middle Fork of the Salmon River. Terry was, early on, a firm supporter of women's rights and contributed to a wide range of organizations and institutions. At her request, there will be no services and no flowers.

Baseball released another All- Star balloting update Tuesday, and the Yankees' DEREK JETER leads all A.L. players in votes, with the Cardinals' ALBERT PUJOLS leading the N.L. It's a pastime for people to complain about the fans' choices, but fans are not obligated to vote for the players having the best seasons. They are supposed to vote for the players they want to see. This holds true even though, since 2003, the league that wins the All-Star Game has been rewarded with home-field advantage in the World Series. Teams with home-field advantage are 3-3 in the World Series since the adoption of the new rule. The fans deserve credit for their selections so far. They have recognized the surprise season of RAUL IBANEZ by making him the top vote-getter among N.L. outfielders. And despite ALEX RODRIGUEZ's celebrity, the fans have gone for EVAN LONGORIA in a rout at third base in the A.L. Other than JOSH HAMILTON, who has been injured most of the season, all the other selections appear to be legitimate. Take first base in the A.L.: MARK TEIXEIRA leads in extra-base hits, KEVIN YOUKILIS in on-base percentage. Both are stars, either would be a good choice.

CONWAY--Mary Catherine A.,77, of Woodstock, NY died November 4, 2008. Born in Kingston, September 29, 1931. Daughter of the late Hon. J. Edward and Catherine Conway. She attended St. Ursula's Academy and graduated with highest honors from Holy Names Academy. A professionally-trained concert pianist she performed briefly as a soloist with the Albany Symphony Orchestra, and graduated from Fordham University in journalism. She began her broadcasting career as both on-air and behind-the-scenes assistant to Mary Margaret McBride, known as the First Lady of Radio, on nationally-syndicated Radio NBC in New York City, and on WGHQ, Kingston when McBride moved to Shokan. For over 15 years Ms. Conway produced her own daily hour-long radio program, "The Cay Conway Show", on WKNY, Kingston, NY. She was a contributor to "Monitor" on NBC. She worked in advertising for many years as well. She is survived by daughters Mara and Deirdre Di Donna, sisters-in-law Frederica Conway and Pat Conway, many nieces, nephews and cousins. She was predeceased by brothers James E. and John Conway.

REMEMBERING A BROTHER LOST AT SEA, GUADALCANAL, SOLOMON ISLANDS Ann Stack Natuzzi, right, 80, a Queens native now retired in Sonoma, Calif., with her daughter Dr. Eileen Natuzzi, Nov. 15, 2008. ''My brother Billy was 17 years old when he shipped out of the Brooklyn Navy Yard on the U.S.S. Quincy. They went off to the Pacific and on Aug. 9, 1942, he was in Savo Bay off Guadalcanal. It was a very tragic battle that night, not only for the family, but for the U.S. Navy. It was an unbelievable thing to see the monument with the word Quincy on it. Had my mother and father been alive today, they would have been quite taken aback with the whole thing. Eileen made the arrangements for a boat to take us to where the Quincy sank, and off we went on a very choppy day. My brother Jack had passed away recently and his son gave us a little container with some of the ashes. A sister had a Boy Scout badge of Billy's, with the troop number, which she pasted on a rock so that it would sink. We dropped the rock and scattered the ashes and the remark was, 'Well, two boys from Queens and they're together again.' '' As told to Seth Kugel

Tiger Woods took a swing at the Yankees and their pricey seats while explaining why he has family-affordable ticket prices for his PGA tournament in Bethesda, Md. Woods had tickets for $25 for the first two rounds of his event at Congressional Country Club, with children able to attend at no cost. Free tickets were also made available for military personnel. It is a sharp contrast to the new Yankee Stadium, where the top-priced seats were cut in half to $1,250. ''We don't want to have what happened at Yankee Stadium; tickets are so overpriced, you can't bring the family,'' Woods said after the second round. ''We want to have everyone come out and enjoy being in a family atmosphere, walk around, have a good time and not have it cost an arm and a leg.''

FLEMING--Phyllis J.,Sarah Whiting Francis Professor of Physics, Emerita, at Wellesley College, died after a long illness on June 23, 2009. A physicist, she dedicated her life to the enhancement of opportunities for women in science as a pioneer in teaching, research and service. She believed to know a subject one must teach it. Thirty of her Wellesley students completed doctorates in physics including Persis Drell, the Director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center. Among the countless others she inspired with her wit and wisdom was Pamela Melroy, the astronaut. As Dean of Wellesley from 1968-1972, she organized the MIT-Wellesley Exchange and the Continuing Education Program which enabled women whose education had been interrupted to complete their degrees. After her return to full time teaching, she wrote a successful textbook and served as Department Chair and Director of the Science Center. Born in Shelbyville, Indiana, she was graduated from Hanover College in 1946 and earned her M.S. and Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1948 and 1955 respectively. She was the recipient of many awards. Hanover honored her with an Alumnae Award in 1963 and an Honorary D.Sc. in 2003. In 1982 at Wellesley, she was the first scientist to win the Pinanski Prize for Distinguished Teaching. Later she also was the first winner of the Janet Guernsey Award for Exceptional Lifetime Achievement for her service to faculty, students and alumnae. More recently, she was named a 2009 Alumni Fellow of the UW Physics Department. In addition to her 50 year Wellesley career, she also taught at Mt. Holyoke College from 1948-1950. She completed her career by tutoring at Cape Cod Community College for five semesters. She is survived by her sister, Helen Lorenz, her brother-in-law, two nephews and two great-nephews and her life partner, Linda B. Miller, South Wellfleet, Mass. Services and internment were held in Shelbyville on June 29 and 30. Donations in her honor may be sent to: The Phyllis J. Fleming Scholarship, Cape Cod Educational Foundation, 2240 Iyannough Road, West Barnstable, Mass. 02668 or the Phyllis J. Fleming Scholarship Fund at Hanover College, P.O. Box 108, Hanover, IN 47243.

It's doubtful that Landon Donovan will be hosting a welcome-back dinner in Beverly Hills when his Galaxy teammate David Beckham returns to Los Angeles this month. In a new book, Donovan, the American midfielder, questioned Beckham's commitment, his leadership and his motivation for playing soccer in the United States. ''When David first came, I believed he was committed to what he was doing,'' Donovan is quoted in ''The Beckham Experiment,'' by the Sports Illustrated writer Grant Wahl. ''He cared. He wanted to do well. He wanted the team and the league to do well.'' But something changed, according to Donovan, and Beckham decided soon after Coach Ruud Gullit was fired that it was not worth his time. ''He just flipped a switch and said, 'Uh-huh, I'm not doing it anymore,''' Donovan said. ''I can't think of another guy where I'd say he wasn't a good teammate, he didn't give everything through all this, he didn't still care.'' The relationship appeared amiable in public but was rife with tension, some jealousy and suspicion, according to Wahl's account, due out July 14 and excerpted in Sports Illustrated. The relationship between Beckham, Major League Soccer's most expensive player, and Donovan, its most successful American star, had a rocky start when Donovan was pressured to give up the captaincy. ''Let him be the captain; you be the star,'' the team's former general manager Alexi Lalas reportedly told Donovan at the time. But what the club's brass did not tell Donovan, according to Wahl, was that the request did not come from the team's leadership, but from Beckham's camp. ''He didn't have a problem with someone else being captain, least of all a player with Beckham's credentials, but he did have an acute sense of being disrespected,'' Wahl wrote. That feeling, and questions about Beckham's attitude, persisted as Donovan grew weary with his teammate and Beckham grew weary of M.L.S. When Beckham went to A.C. Milan, Donovan was left with a team bereft of talent. With Beckham's return scheduled for July 16 -- against the Red Bulls -- one has to wonder how the two will get along. ''Donovan had wanted the Beckham Experiment to work, and there was no reason in his mind that it still couldn't be successful in 2009,'' Wahl wrote. ''But not if Beckham continued acting the way he had during the last half of 2008.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Much of the attention in this year's All-Star balloting has focused on the race for the American League's starting first baseman. In each of the last four weeks of voting results, the top spot changed hands between MARK TEIXEIRA of the Yankees and KEVIN YOUKILIS of Boston. Separated at one point by as little as 1,209 votes in Teixeira's favor on June 9, the two were 40,047 apart in Youkilis's favor in the last round of published results Tuesday. When the starters are announced Sunday, it will be either the bulky Red Sox folk hero or the player that spurned them for their bitter rival. Regardless of that outcome, all of the attention has benefited Boston in another way, with DUSTIN PEDROIA, Youkilis's teammate, making a dramatic comeback in the balloting for starting second baseman. On June 9, IAN KINSLER of the Texas Rangers had a comfortable lead of 250,078 votes. By June 16, Pedroia had narrowed it to 200,238. On June 23, it was 58,390; in the last set of results Tuesday, it was just 6,830. With the polls closed, fans will have to wait to see if the race is able to rival the closest of all All- Star votes, when MANNY TRILLO of the Philadelphia Phillies edged STEVE SAX of the Los Angeles Dodgers by 1,625 for the National League's starting spot at second base in 1982.

EHRE--Milton. Translator of Chekhov and Gogol and University of Chicago Professor Emeritus, died on Tuesday from complications of Parkinson's disease. Ehre, 76, known as Milt, was born to immigrant parents and grew up speaking Yiddish in the Bronx. He received his Bachelor's degree from the City College of New York and taught English in the New York City schools, enrolling in a Russian language course at night. His wife, artist and arts educator Roberta, also taught in the city schools. After Milt received a PhD from Columbia University, they moved to Chicago, where he became a much-loved professor of Russian literature. Milt was a down-to-earth guy who cared about people. He loved the Bulls and the Bears, movies and jazz. He was passionate about teaching young people and received the University's Quantrell Award in 1999. He was devoted to Roberta and their daughters, and he delighted in his grandchildren. Ehre published books on Goncharov and Babel and translated plays of Chekhov and Gogol, which were performed at Chicago's Goodman and Court theaters. He survived leukemia only to be inflicted with Parkinson's, but his will to live was inspiring -- he spent his declining days re-reading the collected works of Shakespeare. Ehre is survived by his loving wife of 46 years, Roberta, daughters Julieanne and Joelle, and their husbands, Hans and Peter, and grandchildren, Esther, Avi and Milo. Donations can be made to The Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

GOLDENBERG--Rose, 90. Beloved mother of Judy Stone and David Goldenberg, adored grandmother of John Stone, Maggie Stone and Cara Goldenberg, great-grandmother of Abigail and Sam Stone passed away on July 3rd, at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, New York after a lengthy illness. The family would like to extend its deepest thanks to the loving and dedicated staff of the Hyatt Classic, Yonkers, New York, who did so much to comfort her in her most difficult days. She was pre-deceased by her husband Dr. Leon N. Goldenberg. She will be greatly missed by all. Donations may be made in her honor to: Crohns and Colitis Foundation of America 386 Park Ave South, 17th floor, New York, New York 10016.

SCHNITZLER--Tom. Jackson Lewis LLP is saddened to learn that Thomas P. Schnitzler passed away peacefully at his home in Long Beach, New Jersey on June 28, 2009. Tom was hired by founders Louis Jackson and Robert Lewis and joined the Firm in its New York City offices on September 11, 1959. From 1964 until 2002, the Firm was known as Jackson Lewis Schnitzler & Krupman. In 1982, Tom helped to open the Firm's office in White Plains, where he practiced until his retirement in 2003. Tom occupied a "corner office" at Jackson Lewis in more ways than one. He devoted his legal career to helping clients preserve their management rights. In all labor relations matters, he provided counsel and representation in a professional, ethical, and common sense manner, with a style at once strident yet gentlemanly. His partner of more than 30 years Patrick Vaccaro, chairman of Jackson Lewis, praised Tom as "a fine gentleman, a wonderful lawyer and partner and, most especially, for possessing more common sense than any lawyer I have ever met." Educated at St. John's University in Queens, Tom remained active in educational life in New York City. He served as an advisor, counselor, teacher, friend and member of the Board of Trustees at Monroe College in the Bronx for over 40 years. In 1998 the College honored him by dedicating the Thomas P. Schnitzler Library at its Bronx campus. Tom will be sorely missed by his partners, colleagues, friends, and family, including his wife Eileen and their five children and nine grandchildren.

UNIQUE BOUTIQUE, a thrift store on Columbus Avenue at 84th Street, injects a note of economy into a neighborhood more readily associated with the Dolce & Gabbana-crammed racks at BÖC or the kaleidoscope of Hamptons-ready cashmere throws at Schweitzer Linen. This third in a chain of Manhattan stores -- the first on the West Side -- offers a loosely edited inventory of bric-a-brac, books, furniture, clothing and jewelry that is updated daily with (tax-deductible) donations and bulk purchases of merchandise from charities. According to the store's managers, Adam and Zachary Hassan, the best donors so far have also been shoppers. Leonid Shulov, 75, a neighborhood resident browsing with his wife, Nelli, picked up a tarnished silver sugar bowl for $4.99 on assurances that it would polish up like new, and eyed a colorful beer stein ($14.99) that he said he would buy once good customers are ''eligible for discounts.''

FRANKLIN--Herbert P.,Born on October 09, 1921 in Blairmont, Guyana, passed away peacefully on June 11, 2009, at the age of 87. Herby embraced life with style and vigor and enjoyed having fun until the end. He is survived by his wife Jean of almost 50 years; children June, Keith, Deborah, Gillian, Kay and Shawn; 14 grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Herby will be dearly missed by family and friends.

THE MATURE ACTRESS Joy Seligsohn, 82, majored in theater at New York University (class of 1949) but quickly abandoned acting for more lucrative jobs: writing comic books and novels, hosting a radio talk show and working in advertising and public relations. She and her husband moved around because of his work at I.B.M., living in several states and overseas. Eight years ago, she returned to acting after being approached by a woman on a bus who was looking for people with gray hair for a commercial. Since then, Ms. Seligsohn has played, among other roles, a cranky librarian on ''The Electric Company,'' the Little Old Lady in the 2005 film version of ''The Producers'' and a tourist who was eviscerated by a vampire in a German horror movie. ''He cut my belly right open and then my insides were falling out,'' she said. A mother of two and grandmother of four, Ms. Seligsohn lives on the Upper West Side with her husband, Zeke, and their dog, Frisky. She rides the bus almost daily, and always talks to strangers. SARAH KRAMER I always warn people if I meet a friend and they say, 'You taking the bus? Let's go together?' You better not go on the bus with me because something always happens on a bus or subway.
COMEDY BAY SHORE Boulton Center for the Performing Arts David Brenner. July 11 at 8 p.m. $40. Boulton Center for the Performing Arts, 37 West Main Street. boultoncenter.org; (631) 969-1101.

TALK SHOW Fireworks! The word still raises the hair on my arms. (The lower arms, mainly.) Fireworks were legal back then in Nebraska, and the opening of the first stand at the edge of town meant infinitely more to me than the first crocuses did to the flower-worshipper, the robin to the bird-lover . . . well, you get the point. I didn't like fireworks. I loved them. (Pyrotechnomania?) And I mean the big stuff. The heavy ordnance. Cherry bombs, torpedoes, aerial bombs, two-, three- and even six-inchers (jumbo firecrackers). And once, a 12-shot repeater aerial bomb.

POLLIN--Burton Ralph, of Bronxville, NY, died June 30, 2009. He was 93. Prof. Pollin was born in Worcester, MA, on May 8, 1916. He was graduated from City College of New York and received his Ph.D. from Columbia University. Prof. Pollin had a long career in education and was Professor Emeritus of English, City University of New York. He was the author of more than 12 books and more than 140 articles on many subjects, including William Godwin, Percy Bysshe Shelley and Edgar Allan Poe. He was one of the world's most prominent Poe scholars, and he continued the critical editions of Poe's works of Mabbott and Ostrom. He was a frequent lecturer and subject of press interviews, the recipient of numerous grants and fellowships and a member of numerous scholarly organizations. Prof. Pollin and his wife, Prof. Alice M. Pollin, moved to Bronxville from Manhattan in 1978 and were co-founders of the Bronxville Beautification Committee, among other civic activities. He was an accomplished amateur pianist and had a wide range of interests in the arts and public affairs. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, a daughter, Diana C. Pollin, of Marseilles, France, a son, Myles C. Pollin, of Manhattan, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister, Gladys Bunim, of Miami Beach, FL.

An answer in the Q&A column on Page 3 this weekend, about suggestions for sightseeing in Johannesburg, refers incorrectly to the city. While it is considered the financial capital of South Africa and is the country's largest city, Johannesburg is not the capital. (Pretoria is the administrative capital; Cape Town is the legislative capital; and Bloemfontein is the judicial capital.)

Jon Bon Jovi, along with his bandmate Richie Sambora, was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame recently for writing songs like ''Livin' on a Prayer.'' The song could be used to describe one of Bon Jovi's other business ventures. Bon Jovi, left, is a coowner of the Arena Football League's Philadelphia Soul, the 2008 ArenaBowl champion. The league's board, citing debt and higher expenses, canceled the 2009 schedule in December and hopes to play again in 2010. ''We get to keep the trophy for two years because we're in suspension,'' Bon Jovi said, smiling. He added: ''But here's the truth. If we come back, we will set a new benchmark for what is sports ownership. ''This is more than a lockout. We're on the brink of the abyss. I can tell you thousands of man-hours are spent trying hard to keep those players employed and keep our fans satisfied.'' Bon Jovi said the league's chances for survival were 50-50. He added that he would like to explore ownership of an N.F.L. team. ''Yeah, why do you think I'm getting this education?'' he said about his A.F.L. experience. Bon Jovi is a longtime Giants fan and a season-ticket holder. ''One of the things I hang my hat on as a sports owner is that I'm looking for men of character,'' he said. When wide receiver Plaxico Burress shot himself in the thigh with an unlicensed handgun on Nov. 29 in a Manhattan nightclub, he put the Giants' season in disarray and reaffirmed Bon Jovi's philosophy as an owner: ''Not characters. I want role models for our kids, who are also great athletes. Like Phil Simms. When he led the Giants, he was my kind of guy. Bill Belichick is my kind of guy.'' Feedback

The New York Times reporter Juliet Macur is in Europe to cover the Tour de France, cycling's biggest race, which will take place from July 4 to 26. Macur answered readers' questions about the Tour, the issues facing cycling, the top riders in this year's race and what it takes to win the coveted yellow jersey. The complete Q&A is available at nytimes.com/sports. Q: Will Lance Armstrong concede the leadership role to Alberto Contador without making a fuss? A: Whether Lance Armstrong, the seventime Tour de France champion, will lead Astana or not is the biggest question of the race right now. He has said that the race itself would decide which rider will be the leader and that he will accept whatever happens. At the team presentation, he told the crowd that his most important goal of his race was to help Astana win. I don't think Armstrong will make a fuss about the battle, at least through the news media. So far, he has played down his chances to beat Contador, saying his age, his midseason injury and his time off the bike has put him at a disadvantage. The odds are, however, that he will do his talking on his bike. Beating Contador may just be his biggest challenge at the Tour -- ever. Q: Is Christian Vande Velde deliberately flying under the radar, or is his star, like many others, eclipsed by Armstrong?

MIDDLETON--Margaret. Graduate of Eastman and Juilliard. Studied at the NY Restaurant School and NY School of Interior Design. Known as Migret to musician colleagues, she enjoyed a long career as a freelance violist in New York City and from 1981, Chapel Hill, NC. In Salzburg from 1970-1972 she played with the Mozarteum Orchestra and principal with Camerata Academica Chamber Orchestra. She became famous as Maggie in 1987 as chef and owner of Maggie's Cafe & Espresso Bar Carrboro, NC until 1997. Survived by Jane Hamborsky, and Wheaten Terrier, Murphy. Contributions to livestrong.org. Celebration of Life 3pm July 10, Chapel of the Cross, Chapel Hill, NC.

The Italian fashion house Missoni, known for its kaleidoscopic fabrics, is the subject of the exhibition ''Workshop Missoni: Daring to be Different,'' on view at the Estorick Collection of Modern Italian Art in London through Sept. 20. Curated by Luca Missoni, son of Ottavio and Rosita Missoni, the husband and wife who turned knitwear into wearable art in the 1960s, the exhibition displays both original garments and photographs of several signature pieces, like the spring-summer collection of 1968, above. ''The designs created by the Missonis drew inspiration from European art of the Modernist era,'' said Roberta Cremoncini, director of the Estorick Collection (www.estorickcollection.com). In support of this theory, works by modern artists like Gino Severini, Sonia Delaunay and Tancredi, all featuring boldly colored geometric patterns -- and are on loan from the Missonis' private art collection -- are part of the show. The exhibition also explores the processes involved in producing the designs. Drawings and sketches are on view, as well as photographs and a 30-minute documentary film. Two videos show designs in progress from conception to realization, and an installation focuses on a loom while it produces a typical striped material. Admission is £5, or $8.40 at $1.68 to the pound. The Estorick Collection is at 39a Canonbury Square, London N1; (44-20) 7704-9522.

TAMARKIN--Theodore (Ted), 79, of Naples, FL, formerly of Sagaponack, NY, passed on July 3, 2009 with his loving wife of 30 years, Michele, by his side. Ted is also survived by his son Cary and daughter Leslie, his sister Marilyn, daughter-in-law Mindy, son-in-law Marc, and four grandchildren. Ted will be lovingly remembered for his keen humor, quick wit and endless creativity. We will miss him forever. The family will hold a private celebration of his life in Naples on July 5, 2009.

To the Editor: Re ''Evening Hours'' by Bill Cunningham (Sunday Styles, June 28):

Every so often a baseball player does something that gets people talking about the unwritten rules of baseball. Earlier this season, Detroit's GERALD LAIRD attempted a bunt in the sixth inning of a game in which Boston's JOSH BECKETT was pitching a no-hitter. According to the unwritten rules of baseball, it is not acceptable to bunt in order to break up a no-hitter. Laird did not get a hit, but the no-hit bid was broken up the next inning. Two weeks ago, Kansas City's BRAYAN PENA was chewed out by Houston catcher IVAN RODRIGUEZ, who thought that Pena was peeking at signs and location from the batter's box. Again, that is a no-no according to the unwritten rules of baseball. Pena hit his first home run of the season later in the at-bat. So where do these unwritten rules of baseball come from, and why has no one bothered to write them down? First of all, they have been written down. In 1986, Baseball Digest published a fairly comprehensive list that can still be easily found on the Internet. The list, titled ''The Book of Unwritten Baseball Rules,'' originally appeared in The Orange County Register and was written by PETER SCHMUCK (who now writes for The Baltimore Sun) and RANDY YOUNGMAN, who still writes for The Register. The list consisted of 30 items, but was heavy on strategy with suggestions like, ''Never throw behind the runner'' and ''Don't hit-and-run with an 0-2 count.'' It does not say anything about shouting to distract a player who is settling under a pop-up, which ALEX RODRIGUEZ did in 2007. It also does not mention swinging at a 3-0 pitch or not stealing a base when your team is way ahead late in a game. But do not worry, baseball fans; many of those unwritten rules have now been written down as well. In 2008, ROSS BERNSTEIN wrote, ''The Code: Baseball's Unwritten Rules and Its Ignore-at-Your- Own-Risk Code of Conduct.'' This March, PAUL DICKSON wrote more simply, ''The Unwritten Rules of Baseball.'' There are more unwritten rules other than not bunting to break up a no-hitter, or not peeking, or not shouting or not stealing with a big lead. There is no crying in baseball (that one comes from the classic baseball movie ''A League of Their Own''). There is no showboating, no headhunting and no sign stealing. Everyone leaves the bench during a fight, and it is bad form to show up an umpire over balls and strikes. Many of these rules are broken all the time, and they can begin to get confusing, as when Tampa Bay's B. J. UPTON stole second and third base with his team down nine runs against the Indians earlier this season. Cleveland's VICTOR MARTINEZ and KERRY WOOD took exception, even though the Rays ended up scoring seven runs before finally losing, 11-7. ''If you're going to get respect, show respect,'' Martinez told reporters after the game. Like the Mafia, it seems, baseball is all about respect and not writing things down. Later in the series, Wood was brought in to face Upton and threw a pitch behind him (which is often the way these unwritten rules are enforced) before tempers flared and the benches cleared. When Rays Manager JOE MADDON was asked about the book of unwritten rules after the game, he responded, ''There's a lot of pages out of the book that need to be burned.''

FORBES--The Rev. Dr. William Ross, died June 30. He served the Presbyterian Church for 37 years with pastorates in Princeton, Atlanta, Houston, and Westfield, NJ. As VP/Corp. Sec., Presbyterian Board of Pensions, he wrote, "None of us knows how many days we will be granted. Look into the mirror each and every day, and take time to marvel that you have been created in the image of God. Count your blessings often, share yourself abundantly, keep a twinkle in your eye, and help the world learn to laugh. May God continue to bless you and keep you as you claim the gift of life each day!" Survivors include wife Patty Forbes, children Kristy Vits, W. Ross Forbes, Jr., Philip Forbes, and grandchildren Will and Lily Forbes and Nathan Vits.

BACK in the mid-1980s, some of the best T-shirts with shoulder pads were found at Ann Taylor. But that does not explain why the label is having a sudden revival among fashion editors. These jeweled sandals ($39.99), as well as chunky rhinestone necklaces and other of-the-moment accessories, might have something to do with it. KARLA M. MARTINEZ

Tommy did not go pee-pee at Julia's office. He didn't have to go then and he didn't have to go at 11:30 a.m. on a recent Thursday, when a woman called Mommy asked him. Tommy romped around on a manicured trapezoid of grass in Madison Square Park, across from the Metropolitan Life Building. He whipped his blond head and yardstick-height body into somersaults and handstands, he jumped and rolled and skipped. He did not have to go to the bathroom. I was sitting outside the green expanse, on a bench, with a container of unwashed blueberries. The man next to me was reciting Hamlet, to no one in particular.
Film Manohla Dargis

WHO says print is dead? Koji Suzuki, the best-selling author of Japanese horror novels like the ''The Ring,'' has found a new publishing medium: toilet paper. Mr. Suzuki has teamed with Hayashi Paper to manufacture rolls of toilet tissue stamped with a nine-chapter horror novella called ''Drop.'' The story, about a goblin living in a public restroom, places the reader at the center of the tale, and each roll contains several copies of the story so you can easily pick up the narrative where you left off. (A friend in Tokyo said it was so scary, she was frightened to be alone in the bathroom.) A roll of ''Drop'' costs 210 yen, which, at just over $2, is a fair price for disposable art. ROCKY CASALE

HOLOBER--Hilda. Longtime resident of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully on July 2, 2009, at the age of 90. She was the loving wife of the late Samuel Holober, the devoted mother of her sons George and Michael, the caring mother-in-law of Frieda and Melissa, and the beloved grandmother of Jacob. Her family and the many friends she made over the years will miss her. Services will be held on Monday, July 6, at 1pm at the Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. Contributions can be made to the American Cancer Society.

GOTTLIEB--Brenda S.,70, of New York City and Bondville, Vermont, died on July 3rd after a year and a half long battle with Brain Cancer. Brenda was born in Brooklyn, New York to Esther and Jack Schnair. She was the beloved and adored wife of Paul Gottlieb. She was the loving mother of Jeff and Colette Gottlieb, Sari and Brian Gottlieb Kornfield and Addie and Andrew Shafran. She was the cherished grandmother of eight: Jordanna, Meg, Emma, Jonah, Lucas, Annie, Ethan and Dylan. She attended Tilden High School, Brooklyn, NY, received her Bachelor of Arts from Douglas College, NJ and her Masters Degree from New York University. Brenda had a passion for life and an ever-present smile on her face. She was an avid skier and golfer, loved horseback riding. She thoroughly enjoyed her life in Vermont. She committed herself to charitable causes in Vermont, where she was on the Board of Directors of the Stratton Foundation. She enjoyed traveling and exploring with her husband Paul. Brenda had a unique zest for life and touched everybody she met. She was incredibly loved by her family and friends and will be forever missed by all. A funeral service will be held on Sunday July 5th at 10am at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue between 75th and 76th Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Pax Christi Hospice, 227 East 19th Street, New York, NY 10003 (212) 995-6480 or to the Have A Chance Foundation, 26 School House Lane, Morristown, NJ 07960. www.haveachancewalk.org

The Manhattan skyline was dwarfed by the Macy's Fourth of July fireworks, which lit up the Hudson River Saturday night in a nod to the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson's voyage. The display, seen here from Weehawken, N.J., featured more than 40,000 shells fired from six barges between 24th and 50th Streets.

TECHNICALLY not an alley but the nickname for the stretch of West 28th Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, where several sheet music publishers had offices in the late 1880s until the early 1930s. It got the label because the chaos of sound produced by so many pianos, playing at the same time on one street, was said to sound like the clanging of pots and pans, which at the time were made of tin. ''Jewish immigrants, many of them experienced salesmen, figured out if you can sell neckties, you could sell songs,'' said Philip Furia, a professor of creative writing at the University of North Carolina at Wilmington and an author of ''Irving Berlin: A Life in Song.'' ''They opened up sheetmusic publishing houses where they created the songs in their offices. They had composers, arrangers and lyricists, and they ground out songs almost assemblyline.'' Irving Berlin 1888-1989 Famous Songs: ''God Bless America'' ''White Christmas'' ''Easter Parade'' ''Alexander's Ragtime Band'' ''Cheek to Cheek'' Famous Stage Musicals: ''Annie Get Your Gun'' ''Call Me Madam'' Why He's Important: Born in Russia and raised in poverty on the Lower East Side, Berlin had a long and varied career as a composer and lyricist, writing for Tin Pan Alley, Broadway and Hollywood. ''He was the most versatile songwriter,'' Mr. Furia said. ''Whatever happened in music, Berlin was at the forefront of it, unlike other composers who were good at one kind of thing. He was so long-lived. He was popular until rock 'n' roll. He just couldn't make that transition.''

NETTER--Richard, Esq. It is with great sadness that the Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners community acknowledges the passing of our dear friend, distinguished colleague and generous benefactor, Richard Netter, Esq. A member of the Board of Trustees of Beth Israel Medical Center for over 50 years, Mr. Netter was the longest serving member of the Board. He served in many leadership positions during his tenure, including Vice Chairman. Helping to build Beth Israel over the past 50 years has been a passion for Mr. Netter, and the hospital has benefited greatly from his leadership. He has served on the Continuum Board since its inception in 1997 and has chaired its Nominating Committee since then. Mr. Netter, along with his beloved wife, Alice, also a Trustee, championed many initiatives at Beth Israel through personal philanthropy and through his involvement as a guardian and board member of several foundations. In 2002, he was recognized for his leadership and many efforts on behalf of the hospital with the Beth Israel Charles H. Silver Memorial Award. He raised money to expand our outstanding music therapy program by establishing the Louis B. Armstrong Center for Music and Medicine. With the generous support of the Herbert and Nell Singer Foundation, Mr. Netter helped establish the Herbert and Nell Singer Division of Perioperative Services at the hospital, supporting major enhancements of the operating room suite. Among his many other philanthropic endeavors was the Thanks to Scandinavia Scholarship Fund, established with his good friend, the late entertainer Victor Borge, as an expression of gratitude to the people and governments of the Scandinavian countries for their rescue of Jewish people from the Holocaust. The Fund provides scholarships and fellowships to physicians, nurses, and other healthcare professionals from Scandinavia to study at Beth Israel and other institutions. Mr. Netter had an abiding love for Beth Israel's rich history and a strong commitment to its successful partnership with the other hospitals in the Continuum network. Most importantly, he was steadfast in his commitment to the collective mission of our institutions to always provide the highest quality, most compassionate care to patients from all walks of life. His wit, wisdom and advocacy will be greatly missed but will remain forever his legacy. This special man will be sorely missed. To Alice, his daughters, Laurie Sprayregen (Philip) and Patricia Shiland, his three grandchildren, and his countless friends and admirers throughout the world, we extend our most heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Board of Trustees Morton P. Hyman Chairman Emeritus Alan Mirken Chairman Beth Israel Board of Overseers Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO Continuum Health Partners Harris M. Nagler, MD Interim President Beth Israel Louise M. Klebanoff, MD President Beth Israel Medical Board

MUNROE--Henry Whitney, 87, died peacefully at home in Westport, CT on July 3, 2009. Son of John Munroe and Adelaide Sedgwick Munroe (Princess Kyril Sherbatow), Munroe attended Buckley School, St. Mark's, and graduated from Harvard University in 1943 and received a masters of arts degree from Columbia University in 1947. He served in the US Air Force, Signal Intelligence Service. In 1950, he married the artist Enid Campbell Hughes of New York. From 1947 until 1983, Munroe, was an international pharmaceuticals executive with Richardson-Vicks, Inc. in the Latin American and Far East divisions. He was the executive director of the World Federation of Proprietary Medicine Manufacturers which he helped found in 1970. He was an elected member of Westport Representative Town Meeting throughout the 1960s; president and trustee, Pequot Library, Southport; trustee, Silvermine Guild of Artists, New Canaan. He was a lifelong student with a keen understanding of the sweep of history and the dynamics of culture, religion, and power, and was beloved for his gentle manner and elegance of thought and language. A jazz enthusiast and amateur poet, his collected verses impart love, life and wisdom. He is survived by his beloved wife; his four daughters, Victoria Sedgwick Munroe (Saltzman) of Boston and New York; Antonia Hughes Munroe (Fischer) of Camden, ME; Olivia Clark Munroe of Bridgeport, CT; and Alexandra Kneeland Munroe (Rosenkranz) of New York; and his eight grandchildren, Theodosia, Julia, Turner, Gabriel, Gordon, Michael, Adelaide and Fiona. A memorial celebration will be held July 25, 11am at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT.

SALKIN--Herbert M.,81, of Manhattan and Saltaire, NY, died peacefully at home after a long illness surrounded by his loving family. Born to Lou and Ruth Salkin in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated Music and Art High School in 1946 and received his Bachelor of Arts in 1949 from Brooklyn College. He served in the Korean War before working as Art Director for Computer Profile Marketing in Manhattan. He had many philanthropic interests including the NY Hall of Science. He was married to Nancy Mazur in 1957, son-in-law to the late Dolph and Paul Mazur of Lehman Brothers and Allied and Federated Department Stores. He was widowed in 1990. He leaves behind a son Jeffrey and daughter-in-law Sheila of Old Lyme, CT, a daughter Jennifer of Redding, CT and six grandchildren Bianca, Francesca, Gabriella and Andre of Old Lyme, CT and Alex and Cara of Redding, CT. His brother Gerald of Bondville, VT and loyal cousin Thelma Rubman of Manhattan. He loved the beach and traveling to exotic places with his friends and companion, Edith Burns. He will forever be in our hearts. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the NY Hall of Science.

THE performance artist Nao Bustamante has a knack for using her body. In one breathtaking video, she rescues herself from a bag of water she has taped around her head. Like a frock-wearing Andy Kaufman, she also once faked her way onto the ''The Joan Rivers Show'' pretending to be an exhibitionist. On Sunday Ms. Bustamante pays homage to María Montez, the 1940s Dominican film star, also known as the Queen of Technicolor. Draped in gauzy robes as a kind of ballerina-beekeeper, she'll be wandering through a verdant landscape of lilacs until she meets a shimmering presence. KEVIN McGARRY Hot! Festival, 8 p.m. at Dixon Place 161A Chrystie Street.

Last fall, The New York Times Magazine commissioned Edgar Martins, a 32-year-old Portuguese photographer based in London, to capture on film the physical evidence of the real estate bust in the United States. Martins, who creates his images with long exposures but without digital manipulation, traveled from rural Georgia to suburban California, visiting large construction projects that began during the speculative boom years and then came to a sudden halt, often half-finished, when the housing and securities markets collapsed. The abandoned or stalled developments -- and Martins's photos of them -- can be seen as signs of the hubris (and occasional criminality) that typified the boom and the economic and human damage that remained in its wake. ''The sudden shift in the economy unmasked such excess,'' Martins says, reflecting on the sites he visited. ''People are present in these images, but not physically. You trace their action, the destruction they left behind.'' Photographs by Edgar Martins
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

From the banjo and guitar face-off near the Chattooga River, where ''Deliverance'' was filmed, to Marilyn Monroe's billowing dress over a subway grate at Lexington Avenue and 52nd Street in New York in ''The Seven Year Itch,'' movie scenes often evoke a strong sense of place. The creators of ''Museyon Guides' Film + Travel,'' a new travel guide trilogy, have taken this idea and run with it, locating some of the most memorable scenes from the movies and organizing them into books focusing on North and South America (198 films, including ''Gone With the Wind'' and ''The Official Story'' from Argentina); Europe (199 films, including ''Lawrence of Arabia'' with its desert scenes done in Spain); and Asia, Oceania and Africa (139 films, including ''Mad Max'' and ''Lost in Translation''). Chapters are introduced by writers, producers, directors and historians and are full of color photography, history and trivia. Each book costs $15.95. In September, ''Museyon Music + Travel'' ($17.95), a travel guide for those seeking out the best in global music, will hit the stores (www.museyon.com).

TO those who know Michael Kenneth Williams as the skulking, avenging Omar of ''The Wire,'' perhaps the most surprising thing about him is that at one point in his life he got up, put on a pair of khakis and a tie, and went to work a desk job at Pfizer. But that was short lived. After working as a backup dancer for music videos, he has been acting steadily since. Now he is appearing in ''The Philanthropist'' on NBC as an all-business bodyguard and right-hand man for Teddy Rist, played by James Purefoy. And this fall he will appear in two movies, ''The Road'' with Viggo Mortensen and ''Life During Wartime,'' directed by Todd Solondz. What follows are excerpts from a conversation with Danielle Mattoon. Q. What was it like going from HBO to network television?

THE NEWS Iraq celebrated the withdrawal of American troops from its cities on Tuesday with parades, fireworks and a national holiday. BEHIND THE NEWSPresident Obama called it ''an important milestone,'' and Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki proclaimed himself the proud leader of a country independent at last. But nearly 130,000 American troops remain in the country, and Mr. Obama warned of ''difficult days ahead'' as Iraqi troops and security forces find themselves on their own, prepared or not. As if to underscore Mr. Obama's concerns, the day was marred by a suicide bombing in Kirkuk that killed 33 people. More bombings followed through the week.

New York City is well-known for dense skyscrapers and gritty neighborhoods, but it also has 578 miles of coastline. Some of that coastline is also gritty (Gowanus, anyone?), but there are plenty of peaceful and pristine spots. The city's smallest beach, at 40.4 acres, is Manhattan (which is actually in Brooklyn), and its largest is Coney Island, at right, with 107.12 acres; Coney's beach and Boardwalk ranked ninth last year in attendance among the nation's 75 urban parks. JENNIFER MASCIA SADDEST BEACH Lonelyville, on Fire Island. The origins of the name, in use since the 1880s, are a mystery. GEEKIEST BEACH Gilgo, in Babylon (Suffolk County). Gilgo is the fictional meeting place -- in the year 2354 -- of Capt.Benjamin Sisko and his wife, Jennifer, in ''Star Trek: Deep Space Nine.'' SCARIEST BEACH Atlantic Avenue, in Amagansett (also in Suffolk County). During World War II, a secret United States Navy communications post there tracked German U-boats. Then, on June 13, 1942, four Nazi spies landed a mere 200 yards away. Awkward! But neither group knew that the other was there. The spies buried their uniforms in the sand, dressed as fishermen and hopped a train to Manhattan. They were apprehended three weeks later.

LAMBERT--Saul, noted illustrator and artist, died in New York City June 30 at 81 of pancreatic cancer. Lambert illustrated for publications including The New York Times, Sports Illustrated, Newsweek, Life Magazine, Esquire and the Washington Post. He designed covers for Elie Wiesel's first two books, Night and The Accident, and hundreds of other books. He authored children's books, Mrs. Poggi's Holiday and The Man that Drew Cats (Harper & Row), and won over 40 national illustration awards. Lambert graduated from Brooklyn College (1949) and studied art with Ad Rhinehardt, Burgoyne Diller and Robert Wolfe. As an artist since 1985, his paintings have appeared in galleries in Tel-Aviv, New Jersey, New York City, Hudson, NY and Washington, DC. Lambert is survived by his second wife, Joanna Underwood, and two children, Katherine and Jonathan, from his first marriage. A Memorial Service is planned for 4:30, July 30 at the New York Friends Meeting house, 15 Rutherford Place in New York City.

KUPER--lluminada Landa, nicknamed "Lumi", died on June 17, 2009 at 87. Mrs. Landa, mother of Joseph C. Landa and Maria Luisa Rego Landa, was born in Oriente, Cuba on November 29, 1921. Her family migrated to New York where she married Jose "Pepe" Landa in 1951. In 1953, combining their talents, the Landas began a business producing fine home furnishings and custom window treatments for top architects and interior designers of their day. Now a third generation business, Interiors by JC Landa, LLC continues the tradition of excellence as her son's work can be found in the most important house in the world, the Presidential White House in Washington, DC. Lumi Landa is survived by Joseph C. Landa and Maria L. Rego Landa and six grandchildren: Rebeca, Jennifer, Adrianna, Joseph F., Alex and Daniel.

McNamara, the former defense secretary who died Monday at 93, was a significant cinematic presence in “The Fog of War,” the Academy Award-winning documentary by Errol Morris, which in a series of first-person interviews recounts Mr. McNamara’s trajectory from an automobile executive to defense secretary (under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson) and his oversight of the Vietnam War.

As comic book crossovers go, this one may have a longer lasting impact than Superman’s face-off with Muhammad Ali. DC Comics is planning a miniseries in which some of its most recognizable characters will join forces with a team of Islamic heroes whose adventures are produced by an Arabic publisher, The Guardian reported. On its official blog, The Source, DC Comics announced that the miniseries would see its Justice League, whose lineup includes Superman, Batman and Wonder Woman, cross paths with the 99, a team of heroes charged with collecting gems that contain the power and wisdom of Baghdad’s ancient Dar Al-Hikma library. The 99, whose membership includes Jabbar the Powerful and Noora the Light, was created by Dr. Naif Al-Mutawa, the founder and chief executive of Teshkeel Media Group in Kuwait.

The pages of a Bible more than 1,600 years old have been published on the Internet, The Associated Press reported. Nearly 800 pages from the Codex Sinaiticus, a Christian Bible dating to the 4th century, written in Greek and containing the oldest complete copy of the New Testament, were posted Monday at the Web site codexsinaiticus.org, coinciding with a conference on the book at the British Library in London. The original manuscript, containing about 1,460 pages written on prepared animal skin, was discovered in 1844 at the Monastery of St. Catherine, a Greek Orthodox shrine in the Sinai Peninsula, by the German Bible scholar Constantine Tischendorf. Its pages were split among Britain, Egypt, Russia and Germany. Scholars from the four nations worked on the restoration of the Bible, which also includes substantial portions of the Old Testament and Apocrypha. Forty-three pages of the manuscript are at the University Library in Leipzig, Germany, and six fragments are at the National Library of Russia in St. Petersburg.

If Anthony Mackie can handle “The Hurt Locker,” he can handle Central Park. Mr. Mackie, who can currently be seen detonating I.E.D.’s in that Kathryn Bigelow movie about the war in Iraq, will enjoy some extended shore leave in New York next month when he joins the cast of the Public Theater‘s Shakespeare in the Park production of “The Bacchae.” In a news release on Monday, the Public said that Mr. Mackie, whose recent films also include “Notorious” and “We Are Marshall,” will portray the role of Pentheus in the play. The previously announced cast for “The Bacchae” includes Jonathan Groff and André De Shields. The play is to be directed by JoAnne Akalaitis with original music by Philip Glass and translation by Nicholas Rudall. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Aug. 11, with an official opening of Aug. 24. Its run concludes on Aug. 30.

The last time Jerry Springer appeared on the stage of the Cambridge Theater, four or five years ago, he died and went to hell. I mean the mythic title character who presided over “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” who was based on the tabloid television host but was played by an actor. Now, reminding us that show biz spins dizzy karmic circles, the real Mr. Springer is appearing at the Cambridge in the long-running musical of “Chicago,” where I caught him this weekend. And the location now seems less like hell than purgatory, an uncomfortable place where people mark time while waiting to move on somewhere else.

Though it’s generally not good news for sensitive single women (or crystalline animals) when gentleman callers show up at the Wingfield residence, their loss is New York theater’s gain: Roundabout Theater Company said on Monday that it would transfer the production of Tennessee Williams‘s “The Glass Menagerie” that ran earlier this year at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, Conn., to its Laura Pels Theater next year. In a news release, Roundabout said that its production of “Glass Menagerie,” starring Judith Ivey, Patch Darragh and Keira Keeley, would begin previews on March 5, with an official opening scheduled for March 24. The play will be directed by Gordon Edelstein, the artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater, who directed the production that ran there from May 13 through June 7. The actor Josh Charles (of “In Treatment” and “Sports Night”) played the role of the gentleman caller Jim O’Connor in the Long Wharf production; an actor for that role in the Roundabout transfer was not announced.

Casey Kasem, the radio host who told listeners for decades to “keep your feet on the ground and keep reaching for the stars,” has finished his “American Top 20” song countdown. “This will be our final countdown,” Mr. Kasem, 77, said over the weekend on “American Top 20,” ABC News reported. Mr. Kasem’s weekly playlists of the country’s most popular songs started in 1970 with “American Top 40,” and have been a radio staple since. While he passed the “Top 40” mic to Ryan Seacrest in 2004, he continued to host two abridged versions of the show. Mr. Kasem said in a statement that he “loved every minute” of the countdowns, but that the final countdown would “free up time I need to focus on myriad other projects.” His wife indicated to ABC that he may write a memoir.

My friend and fellow New York Times columnist David Carr had a piece this morning arguing that there is really no need for Apple or the company's board to disclose information about the health of its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, because we already know everything we need to know to make an informed decision about Apple's stock. Mr. Jobs has had cancer, a disease where, as Mr. Carr puts it, "the prognosis is always unknowable." Then, a few months ago, while taking a leave of absence related to his health, Mr. Jobs had a liver transplant. Mr. Carr also points out -- touché -- that for all the talk about Mr. Jobs's indispensability, Apple's stock rose $50 a share while he was gone.

There is rising concern among polar bear biologists that the big recent summertime retreats of sea ice in the Arctic are already harming some populations of these seal-hunting predators. That was one conclusion of the Polar Bear Specialist Group, a network of bear experts who met last week in Copenhagen to review the latest data (and data gaps) on the 19 discrete populations of polar bears around the Arctic. The group, part of the International Union for Conservation of Nature, includes biologists in academia and government and at nonprofit conservation organizations. Only one bear population is increasing (in the Canadian high Arctic), while eight are declining in numbers, the scientists said. At its last meeting, in 2005, the group concluded that five populations were in decline. Three populations appear to be stable and seven are too poorly monitored to gauge a trend.

The George Washington Bridge has become the first bridge in the New York metropolitan region to fully convert its light necklace to L.E.D.'s -- light emitting diodes -- a move that officials say will save an average of $5,000 a month in lighting and maintenance costs.The 156 L.E.D.'s -- which provide the glittery aesthetics along the drape of the suspension cables and do not light the roadway -- have an estimated life expectancy of 15 years, compared with the one-year lifespan of the mercury vapor lights.

After rereading my earlier post, it occurred to me that it might be useful to lay out the logic of the argument. What we observe is that private insurers spend a much larger fraction of their receipts on administration than Medicare does. Heritage asserts that this is because administration costs are proportional to the number of beneficiaries, not spending, so Medicare has low percentage costs because its elderly beneficiaries are so much more expensive than average.

Keeping with the idea that good habits are formed young, Knoll, the company that has been churning out modern design classics since 1938, has just introduced a collection of furniture for kids. Among the diminutive versions of design greatest hits are the Jens Risom Amoeba Table and webbed side chair, the Harry Bertoia Diamond chair, and, appropriately, Eero Saarinen's 1948 Womb Chair. The prices for the pieces are also scaled down -- but only slightly. The grown-up Womb chair starts at $2,803; the child's size starts at $2,380. We suggest splitting the difference and investing in the size Medium -- which provides your burgeoning modern design addict room to grow.

An obituary on Thursday about the boxer and politician Alexis Argüello misidentified a weight class in which he won a title. It was featherweight, not flyweight. The obituary also misstated part of another name for the junior lightweight division, in which Mr. Argüello also won a title. It is super featherweight, not super flyweight.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about Fayette Pinkney, an original member of the singing group the Three Degrees, misstated the year the movie “The French Connection,” in which the group appeared, was released. It was 1971 — not 1975, which is the year “French Connection II” was released.

A Sports of The Times column on June 23 about the retirement of Donald Fehr of the baseball players union misidentified the person he succeeded as executive director 26 years ago, and a correction in this space on June 27 misspelled that person’s surname in a second reference. Mr. Fehr replaced Ken Moffett (not Moffet); Mr. Fehr did not succeed Marvin Miller. (It was Mr. Moffett who succeeded Mr. Miller.).

Because of an editing error, an article on June 22 about criticism directed at a Fox News anchor, Shepard Smith, misstated the subject of a comment by Bill Shine, Fox’s senior vice president for programming. When Mr. Shine referred to “the voice of the opposition on some issues,” he was talking about Fox News, not Mr. Smith.

An article on Wednesday about the resignation of the senior pastor at Riverside Church in Manhattan described the church’s affiliation incorrectly. While Riverside accepts worshipers of all faiths and describes itself as “interdenominational,” it is officially affiliated with the United Church of Christ and the American Baptist Churches; it is not nondenominational.

An article on Wednesday about the aftermath of the murder of four girls in Austin, Tex., 17 years ago referred incorrectly to the scene of the crime. There is, in fact, a nearby plaque marking the girls’ deaths; the site is not unmarked.
Mr. Bowman dazzled crowds with fancy gunplay and came to embody a vanishing cowboy culture.

A reporting credit on Wednesday with an article about the withdrawal of American combat troops from Iraqi cities misstated the surname of a New York Times reporter who contributed. He is Campbell Robertson, not Robinson.

An article on June 20 about the problems confronting deepwater search teams in finding the flight data and cockpit recorders of Air France Flight 447, which crashed off northern Brazil on June 1, misidentified the jetliner model in a 2007 crash off Indonesia’s coast that presented searchers with similar problems. That plane, operated by Adam Air, was a Boeing 737, not a 747. The article also misstated part of the name of an airline that lost a Boeing 747 in a November 1987 deepwater crash en route to Johannesburg from Taiwan. It is South African Airways, not South African Airlines.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a federal advisory panel’s recommendation to ban the painkillers Percocet and Vicodin misstated the surname at one point for a professor of anesthesiology who said, “When you’re using controlled substances, you want to err on the side of safety rather than convenience.” As the article correctly noted elsewhere, he is Dr. Scott M. Fishman, not Fisher.

Advertising in baseball games broadcast nationally runs into the billions, led by commercials for car companies and products like Viagra (from Pfizer) and Spiriva (from Boehringer Ingelheim). The cost of a commercial in a given advertising spot, including those run by Major League Baseball, is calculated using rate card and other information, according to Nielsen. Last year, Chevrolet led all advertisers, with many food and drink companies, including Taco Bell, Anheuser-Busch, Burger King and Pepsi, in the top 10. SHELLY FREIERMAN

NETTER--Richard. It is with great sadness and a deep sense of personal loss that we mark the passing of our beloved friend and partner of so many years. He was truly a one-of-a-kind man who enriched the lives of all who knew him, and whose philanthropic activities enriched those of thousands who never had the pleasure. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Alice, his daughters, Laurie and Patricia, and their families. Hector G. Dowd & Edward M. Berman Singer Netter Dowd & Berman

ROB THOMAS ''cradlesong'' (Emblem/Atlantic) Thirteen years ago Rob Thomas muscled through ''Push,'' the first significant pop hit by his band Matchbox 20. It was an easy ramble, no rougher than anything by Counting Crows, and its harmlessness almost succeeded in diluting Mr. Thomas's threats: ''I want to push you around/I want to push you down/I want to take you for granted.''

MURPHY--Thomas W. Jr, of New York, NY, formerly of St. Tropez, France. Beloved brother and uncle passed away Thursday July 2, 2009. Age 89 years. Tom was born on July 19, 1919 in Poughkeepsie, NY. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy and Williams College. He was a veteran of the US Navy serving in WWII. A memorial service will take place at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 1076 Madison Ave and 81st between the hours of 4:00 and 7:00 Wednesday July 8th. A brief service will be performed at the Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery at 11:00am July 9th. Those planning an expression of sympathy may make a contribution in Tom's memory to The Recording for the Blind & Dyslexic 20 Roszel Rd Princeton, NJ 08540 866-RFBD-585.

F.L.Y. (FAST LIFE YUNGSTAZ) ''Jamboree'' (Def Jam) F.L.Y. has clearly studied at the altar of other rough but musical Atlanta rappers: the Shop Boyz, Dem Franchise Boyz and Soulja Boy. But what about some older boys, namely the Fat Boys? In 1987 that group teamed with the Beach Boys for ''Wipe Out,'' hip-hop's earliest acknowledgment of beach culture and a collaboration that remains bizarre even by hip-hop's ever-loosening standards.

Cappie Pondexter scored 21 points and Diana Taurasi added 20 for the Phoenix Mercury in a 104-89 victory over the Sparks in Los Angeles. Candace Parker scored 6 points of the bench in her return to the Sparks' lineup; she gave birth May 13 to a daughter, Lailaa.

As news of Michael Jackson's death began to spread June 25, the crush of people flocking to the Web for information overloaded several sites and services, causing AOL's instant messaging service, news sites, Twitter and Wikipedia to buckle under the strain. But just how much traffic are we talking about? Compete, a Web analytics firm based in Boston, crunched some numbers and came up with a few data points to help illustrate the surge.

Microsoft is dipping its toe into the hot new area of real-time search. The company said last week that Bing, the search engine it unveiled a month ago, would begin including the latest output of popular Twitter users in its search results. ''There has been much discussion of real-time search and the premium on immediacy of data that has been created, primarily by Twitter,'' wrote Sean Suchter, general manager of Microsoft's search technology center in Silicon Valley, in a blog post about the feature. ''We've been watching this phenomenon with great interest and listening carefully to what consumers really want in this space.''
MORRIS--Allen E. Today is your birthday. Your loving baby sister, Linda Joy

Joost, an online video company, is starting over with a new service and business model, the third in three years. The company, which will continue to offer free television shows and movies online, announced last week that it would shift its energies to providing an online video platform that other media companies could use -- essentially licensing its technology to broadcasters and other media companies that want to offer video on their sites.

Dear sister of Edythe Rosner. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Tuesday July 7th at 11:30am at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

Allen Klein, a music executive who managed the business affairs of Sam Cooke, the Rolling Stones and, for a short time, the Beatles, and who was both admired and feared for his reputation as a fierce negotiator, died on Saturday in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 77. The cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease, said Bob Merlis, a spokesman for Mr. Klein's company, Abkco Music and Records.

FOSTER--Charles G.,87. Beloved husband of Marilyn, adored father of Andrew (Marci), dearest brother of Henry (Michelle), brother-in-law of Barbara (Noah), devoted uncle. Funeral 10am Tuesday, at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills, NY.

KLEIN--Allen. We mourn the loss of our wonderful Uncle Allen who taught me the music business and showed me the world. He gave me every opportunity and never forgot his roots or his family. His genius was legendary, but it is his love, loyalty and generosity that will be his true legacy. Our deepest condolences and love go out to Iris, Robin, Jody, Beth, Betty and his four amazing grandchildren. The Kramers- Michael, Paula, Elisabeth and Samantha

SON VOLT ''American Central Dust'' (Rounder) Movement and stasis face off in bitter opposition throughout ''American Central Dust,'' the stoic but sympathetic new Son Volt album. For Jay Farrar, the band's lead singer and songwriter, stillness equals sickness, and locomotion means release. ''Lonely roads and freight trains/Will keep us sane,'' he sings on ''No Turning Back,'' a tribute to restless determination. He paints a more complicated picture elsewhere on the album, but always in the same rustic and square-jawed style.

WALKWITZ--William R.,PhD. Devoted and beloved husband of Joyce. Professor Emiritus, New York City College of Technology, CUNY. 35 Years of dedicated service including Chairman of the Department of Biological Science. Teacher and Inspiration to all. Alumnus of New York University where his teaching career began. Served in the U.S. Air Force Reserves. Gourmand, Traveler Extraordinaire, a true renaissance man with a special passion for opera and the beauty of nature. Passed away after 71 years of a glorious life on July 2, 2009. Viewing at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St., New York, NY. Funeral Mass at Jean Baptiste Church on Wednesday July 8 at 10am 184 E. 76th St New York, NY. Contributions in his memory can be made to: Doctors Without Borders, PO Box 5022, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5022

NETTER--Richard, of New York and East Hampton, on July 2, 2009, at age 90. Beloved husband of Alice, devoted brother of Edward Netter, cherished father of Laurie Sprayregen (Philip) and Patricia Shiland, loving grandfather of Jim, Devon, and Dale. Partner of Singer Netter Dowd and Berman; past vice chairman and longest standing trustee of Beth Israel Medical Center; co-founder with Victor Borge of Thanks To Scandinavia, a scholarship fund for Scandinavian and Bulgarian graduate students, in gratitude for the heroic rescue and protection of Jews in Europe during WWII. Contributions can be made to Beth Israel Medical Center, Development Department, 555 West 57 St., New York, NY 10019. Funeral Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, on Tuesday, July 7th at 11:30am.

LAVEMAN--Irving C. Passed away peacefully on July 5, 2009. He was a beloved husband, father and grandfather. A graduate of CCNY and a educational administrator with the NYC Board of Education. A veteran of WWII. His grieving family and friends are bereaved at his loss. He was splendor in high places. He was lovely in life, he will never depart from us. Wife Rose, children Robin and Irwin, Larry and Marlene, grandchildren Sara, Joshua and Daniel.

BEBE ''Y.'' (EMI) ''I was sleeping six feet underground,'' the Spanish songwriter Bebe quietly announces to begin ''Y.,'' her second album. ''Now I've decided to sleep aboveground.'' She may be hinting at her temporary retirement from pop, for nearly three years, in the wake of ''Pafuera Telarañas,'' her internationally successful 2004 debut album.

The rate on the six-month issue was 0.29 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.17 percent.

SALKIN--Herbert M.,81, of Manhattan and Saltaire, NY, died peacefully at home after a long illness surrounded by his loving family. Born to Lou and Ruth Salkin in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated Music and Art High School in 1946 and received his Bachelor of Arts in 1949 from Brooklyn College. He served in the Korean War before working as Art Director for Computer Profile Marketing in Manhattan. He had many philanthropic interests including the NY Hall of Science. He was married to Nancy Mazur in 1957, son-in-law to the late Dolph and Paul Mazur of Lehman Brothers and Allied and Federated Department Stores. He was widowed in 1990. He leaves behind a son Jeffrey and daughter-in-law Sheila of Old Lyme, CT, a daughter Jennifer of Redding, CT and six grandchildren Bianca, Francesca, Gabriella and Andre of Old Lyme, CT and Alex and Cara of Redding, CT. His brother Gerald of Bondville, VT and loyal cousin Thelma Rubman of Manhattan. He loved the beach and traveling to exotic places with his friends and companion, Edith Burns. He will forever be in our hearts. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the NY Hall of Science.

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME-TIME FEATURE: MERYL STREEP The talented Ms. Streep turned 60 on June 22. This belated birthday tribute looks at the early work that captured the attention of critics, starting with Woody Allen's ''Manhattan'' (1979), in which she played the Allen character's former wife, intent on exposing their love life in a book. In ''Kramer vs. Kramer'' (1979), at 10, Ms. Streep portrayed another former wife, this time battling for custody of her child, and won her first Oscar, for best supporting actress. In ''Sophie's Choice'' (1982), at midnight, Ms. Streep (above with Kevin Kline) demonstrated her gift for accents -- and won a best-actress Oscar -- as a concentration camp survivor who can't escape her past. And in ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' (1981), at 2:45, she played an actress whose love affair with a co-star (Jeremy Irons) mirrors a doomed one in the film they're making. 7 A.M. (BBC America) CONDITION: CRITICAL In a three-part series ''BBC World News America'' examines the Obama administration's battle for health-care reform. In this first installment, Matt Frei interviews Kathleen Sebelius, secretary of health and human services. Katty Kay visits McAllen, Tex., whose doctor-owned hospital has become a symbol of the country's health-care woes.

COHEN--Robert I. Age 78, passed suddenly at his home on July 1, 2009. He was the devoted husband of Barbara with whom he lived in Greenwhich Village for 25 years. Bob worked at NYU for many years as Director of Community Relations. He was associated with numerous organizations including Board of Directors of the Caring Community and a member of Community Board Two. He served on the Boards of Directors of the Washington Square Music Festival and also the Washington Square Association. He was a respected and admired member of his community, and will be sorely missed by his family and friends.

GOLDBERG--Irma. To our beloved Nana and GiGi. So beautiful, so loved, so special. You will remain in our hearts forever. Danielle and Ed Reyman Shelley and Tony Writer Lauren and Matt Friedman Michael Goldberg, Zachary, Matthew, Milo and Sydney

YOUNG--Joan Soo, died of natural causes on July 1, 2009 at the Peconic Medical Center, Riverhead, Long Island, NY. She was residing at the Westhampton Care Center, Westhampton, NY, and previously with her husband, Frank T.F. in West Palm Beach, Fl and New York City. She was 100 years old. Reposing at Towers Funeral Home, Inc. Oceanside, NY on July 7, 2009 at 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Funeral at Towers at 10am and interment at Flushing Cemetery, Queens New York City on July 8, 2009 at 11am. Joan Young is survived by four children, Frank, Joanna (Vincent) Weirs, Philip (Janice) and Lincoln; nine grandchildren, Gregory Weirs, Alan Weirs, Kim Kassin, Philip, Joel Kaye, Janine Sas, Colin, Christopher and Catherine and five great-grandchildren, Alex and Kate Kassin, Michael and Dylan Sas and Jacob Kaye.

WEINER--Neil. We mourn the sudden loss of our research director. We will miss Neil's knowledge and long experience in criminal justice research, his mentoring of younger colleagues, and his warmth and wit. Our trustees and staff extend our deepest sympathy to Pam and their sons. John Savarese, Chair Michael Jacobson, President and Director Vera Institute of Justice

SNOW--Judy Schwamm. Died on July 1st, 2009, at age 75. Beloved mother of Erica Arbron and fiance Marc Goldstein, David and Selena Snow, Harvey-Skip Snow and fiance Alix Juhasz and Linda and Barrett Gross. Proud grandmother of Travis and Eric Snow, Alyson and Jake Arbron, Peter and Emily Gross and Zoe Ford Snow. Cherished sister of Jay Schwamm. Proud alumna of the Fieldston School, Northampton School for Girls and Sarah Lawrence College. Judy's passions were her family, the sea and learning. Judy lived her life on her own terms. Having married Robert Snow in 1955, and then living as a homemaker, caterer, and sailor for many years. Judy divorced and spent the next 13 years sailing through Europe, the Caribbean, South America and the east coast of the US on her beloved Snowbird as a great matron and friend to her cruising colleagues who confided in her and sought her wisdom, wit and passion day in and day out. Judy was a renowned cook, hostess and entertainer. She spent the last decade of her life pursuing Jewish adult education, and being at the center of the vital family life she loved so well, and in addition pursuing philanthropic causes. Donations in her memory may be made to the Stamford United Jewish Federation's Board of Jewish Education Continuing Education Fund, (UJF-BJE-CEF). Funeral services will be held at Temple Sinai, 458 Lakeside Dr., Stamford, CT (203) 322-1649 on Monday, July 6 at 11am, Rabbi Marc Disick will officiate.

UELAND--Jill (Nee Lubin) Roth, Ueland on July 4th. Beloved wife of the late Albert Roth and John Ueland. Devoted aunt of Ben and Marie Lubin, Eda and IrvingEffross. Reposing Wednesday 5-7pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Private Funeral.

MUNROE--Henry Whitney, 87, died peacefully at home in Westport, CT on July 3, 2009. Son of John Munroe and Adelaide Sedgwick Munroe (Princess Kyril Sherbatow), Munroe attended Buckley School, St. Mark's, and graduated from Harvard University in 1943 and received a masters of arts degree from Columbia University in 1947. He served in the US Air Force, Signal Intelligence Service. In 1950, he married the artist Enid Campbell Hughes of New York. From 1947 until 1983, Munroe, was an international pharmaceuticals executive with Richardson-Vicks, Inc. in the Latin American and Far East divisions. He was the executive director of the World Federation of Proprietary Medicine Manufacturers which he helped found in 1970. He was an elected member of Westport Representative Town Meeting throughout the 1960s; president and trustee, Pequot Library, Southport; trustee, Silvermine Guild of Artists, New Canaan. He was a lifelong student with a keen understanding of the sweep of history and the dynamics of culture, religion, and power, and was beloved for his gentle manner and elegance of thought and language. A jazz enthusiast and amateur poet, his collected verses impart love, life and wisdom. He is survived by his beloved wife; his four daughters, Victoria Sedgwick Munroe (Saltzman) of Boston and New York; Antonia Hughes Munroe (Fischer) of Camden, ME; Olivia Clark Munroe of Bridgeport, CT; and Alexandra Kneeland Munroe (Rosenkranz) of New York; and his eight grandchildren, Theodosia, Julia, Turner, Gabriel, Gordon, Michael, Adelaide and Fiona. There will be a memorial celebration on August 1 at 11am at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT.

As I mentioned last week, I've recently returned from Australia. While I was there, I visited a eucalyptus forest that, in February, was the scene of an appalling wildfire. Perhaps naively, I had expected to find that many trees had been killed. They hadn't. They had blackened bark, but were otherwise looking rather well, many of them wreathed in new young leaves. This prompted me to consider fire and the role it plays as a force of nature.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics today released its Job Openings and Labor Turnover report for May. The Cartier Foundation in Paris is the kind of gallery that offers continuous surprises, so whenever I am in town I try to find time to visit. You may happen upon an American artist Sarah Sze showing massive installations made from all sorts of detritus or a Brazilian photographer named Alair Gomes who captures Ipanema beach in all its beefcake glory; or you may discover a talent aside from the obvious ones in multifaceted artists like David Lynch and Patti Smith. It was here at the Cartier Foundation that I first encountered Takashi Murakami's boyish pop world and the magic of contemporary African art.I'm also always impressed by ability of the foundation director Herve Chandes and his staff to adapt Jean Nouvel's beautiful but impractical glass building (with Patrick Blanc's hanging garden on the facade, no less) to different artists' demands - creating temporary walls, obscuring the transparent rooms, bringing in massive objects like Marc Newson's prototype "Kelvin 40" airplane for one show.

There's a batch of new proposals for breaking the persistent global deadlock over dealing with global warming, all coming as world leaders prepare to meet at the Group of 8 summit in L'Aquila, Italy, and in parallel sessions of the biggest emitters of greenhouse gases. The passing of a celebrity starts many of us who are not celebrities thinking of our own mortality. About the things we can do to live longer, and then to live on, and about the things we can't. Among those thinking deeply lately are Diana Oliva Cave and her husband Damien Cave, both Times journalists, who went from covering Iraq to the (somewhat) quieter life as parents of five-month-old Balthazar, known as Baz. As they have done here before, they describe their thoughts in tandem, with Damien in Roman typeface, and Diana in italics. But first, a personal plea from me -- Damien and Diana, PLEASE go buy life insurance.

The Moment is a big fan of Alexander Girard's work (see "Alexander Girard Shines Again").
