The Girard Collection at Urban Outfitters includes both well-known designs and those that have not been seen since the 1950s, like "Multiform." Just about everyone who loves fashion has seen those black and white images from Paris dressing rooms in the 1950s, when models stood around in their bras and girdles. The intimacy and nonchalance of such scenes provided John Galliano with a narrative for his fall Dior couture show. He has used underpinnings before. In fact, some of his first Paris collections, before he joined Dior, used lingerie, or at least gave a feeling of elegant dishabille. He mined the Dior archive for photos of Christian Dior and his muse Mitzah Bricard as they presided over fittings. It's the sort of history that Mr. Galliano is comfortable with, the story of a couturier who captured the world's attention for a brief space of time, all of 10 years. (Chanel, by contrast, worked in fashion nearly 50 years.)

President Lee Myung-bak announced Monday that he would donate $26 million, the bulk of his personal fortune, to create a scholarship fund to help ease growing strife between the rich and poor in his country. Mr. Lee, left, a former executive of the Hyundai conglomerate, vowed to give away his personal wealth during his 2007 election campaign when he faced allegations that he had accumulated it illegally. Mr. Lee has since been cleared of those charges. On Monday he followed through on his pledge, saying his journey from rural poverty to the top of the corporate world would not have been possible without the help he had received while struggling at menial jobs to pay for his tuition.

SCHLESINGER--Norman E.,89, died on July 5, 2009 at his home after a long battle with heart disease. Friends and family are invited to a brief memorial service at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue in Short Hills on Wednesday, July 8 at 3:00pm. Born in East Orange, Mr. Schlesinger had lived in Livingston since 1955. After graduating with a Bachelor of Science degree from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania in 1941, he became a Certified Public Accountant. Mr. Schlesinger served in France in the U.S. Army finance department during WWII. He received a Juris Doctor degree from Rutgers University Law School and a Masters Degree in Taxation from New York University Law School. He was a founding partner of the NewRk law firm, Saiber, Schlesinger, Satz and Goldstein, now known as Saiber, LLC. He was the author of articles on Federal Taxation, published in leading tax periodicals. He lectured at the New York University and Miami University Institutes on Taxation, as well as the Institute of Continuing Legal Education and the Practicing Law Institute. He served as President of Mountain Ridge Country Club and as Vice President and Treasurer of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun. Mr. Schlesinger is survived by his wife Carol and sons Robert of Portland, Oregon and John of San Francisco, California. Donations in his memory may be sent to St. Barnabas and Palliative Care Center or to a charity of your choice.

Mexico, which has won the Gold Cup four times, most recently in 2003, has scored the most goals (90) and has the best goal differential (plus 68) in the history of the tournament, which dates to 1991.

De PERALTA--Armando Rene Grave Sr.,a resident of La Jolla California and a former resident of New York for most of his life, died on July 3, 2009 at the age of 94 years. Mr. de Peralta was born in New Orleans on November 8, 1914, the son of Pedro Grave de Peralta, who was the then Argentinean Ambassador to the United States and Adele Gloria de Peralta who was actively involved in New York society. Mr. de Peralta began his business career as the leader of his band "Armando and his Ambassadors" and as the owner of the Pago Pago Club, a popular nightclub frequented by New York society in the 1930s and 1940s. Mr. de Peralta himself had the reputation of being a bon vivant and was frequently included in society columns. During his military service as a Corporal with the 375th Field Artillery Battalion, Mr. de Peralta was injured by a misplaced land mine resulting in the total paralysis of his legs. Fortunately, Mr. de Peralta had not allowed his military injury to deter him from commencing a new career in the shipping industry where he started as an employee for 26 years with Thor Eckert & Co. prior to founding his own shipping company, Peralta Shipping Corporation which became the exclusive transatlantic shipper of the paper products of International Paper Company and the St. Regis Paper Company. After Mr. de Peralta sold his shipping business, he commenced several new careers as a real estate investor and developer, a co-producer of a variety of Broadway musicals, an author of eight published books of romantic poetry, and as a philanthropist. Mr. de Peralta's life was the subject of an improvisational ensemble play "Life Game" at the La Jolla Playhouse Forum in 2000. Mr. de Peralta is survived by his wife, Rosalba Roca Grave de Peralta and their children Frederic de Peralta and William Adams de Peralta, and by Joyce Patafio and their children, Rene Armando de Peralta and Marcello de Peralta. His first wife Marcia de Peralta died on September 17, 2007 and their son, Armando de Peralta Jr., also died on August 17, 2004. Visitation will be held Tuesday, July 7, 2009 from 4 to 6pm and 6 to 8pm at Mr. de Peralta's home, 9882 La Jolla Farms Road, La Jolla, CA 92037, with a prayer service beginning at 6:30pm. Committal service will take place Wednesday, July 8, 2009 at 10am at Greenwood Memorial Park, 4300 Imperial Avenue, San Diego, CA 92113. Services have been trusted to Greenwood Mortuary, (619) 264-3131.

KAPLAN--Sadie, age 106, on June 30th, left five children, 14 grandchildren, 12 great-grandchildren. Her influence was felt throughout the generation. She led by example by always displaying tolerance, kindness and unconditional love. Her presence will be sorely missed and cannot be replaced.

BEGELL--William, 82, died Saturday, July 4, 2009 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was born May 18, 1928 in Vilnius, Poland, presently Lithuania. After escaping from a German concentration camp he entered the United States at age 17. He had a long and distinguished career as a chemical-nuclear engineer, researcher, and publisher. Dr. Begell taught at Columbia University and was the Engineering Director of its Heat Transfer Research Facility. His position at Columbia involved him in a US Air Force intelligence project that culminated in the cofounding of Scripta Technica (1962). Building on his experience and reputation, Dr. Begell was a founder of Hemisphere Publishing Corp. (1966) and in 1991 he established Begell House Inc. Dr. Begell was one of the founding members of the Society of Scholarly Publishing and was nominated and granted many awards for his achievements. He was awarded the 2005 ASME Heat Transfer Division Distinguished Service Award. William Begell is survived by his wife Yelena Shafeyeva Begell, Redding, Connecticut. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by his son Freddie, his daughter, Alysia, and his first wife Ester.
The New Old Age Sarah Arnquist posted at nytimes.com/newoldage.

REINFELD--George, of Glassboro, NJ, died Thursday, July 2, 2009 in Doylestown, PA. He was 81. Born in Newark, NJ, George was the son of the late Abraham and Grace Paritz Reinfeld. Mr. Reinfeld graduated from Thomas Jefferson High School in 1945. Two days after graduating, George was inducted into the Navy Air Corp V-5 unit at Mercer University. In 1946 he was honorably discharged and in 1950, he graduated from Montclair State Teachers College. George taught for four years at Westwood High School and for two years at North Arlington High School, where he also served as advisor to the school newspapers. In 1956 he was appointed to the faculty of Glassboro State Teachers College (now Rowan University) where he taught for 46 years. He was appointed as a full professor in 1970. While at Glassboro State, Professor Reinfeld founded the Department of Communications, which is now the College of Communication. At the time of his retirement in 2002, Professor Reinfeld had the longest record of service at Glassboro State. George is survived by a son, Larry Reinfeld, his wife, Liz McMahon, of Doylestown, PA; and a daughter, Frances Lubin, her husband, Peter Lubin, of Beverly Hills, CA. He is also survived by his brother, Morton Reinfeld, his wife, Eva, of Roselle Park, NJ. Services and interment will be held privately at the convenience of the family. Memorials may be made, in memory of George Reinfeld, to the Rowan University Foundation, 201 Mullica Hill Road, Glassboro, NJ 08028-1701. Reed and Steinbach Funeral Home, Doylestown, PA. www.reedandsteinbach.com

WIGHT--Anthony Read, died of prostate cancer at his home in Croton-On-Hudson, NY on July 3rd. Tony was born in Evanston, IL on November 19th, 1939 to Read H. and Florence Wight. They moved to Rye, NY in 1943, where Tony attended grammar school. He went on to the Taft School and Dartmouth College. Upon graduation, Tony enlisted in the U.S. Army and was sent to the language school in Monterey, CA where he became fluent in Serbo-Croatian. After service in Europe, Tony began a long career in advertising. He was an executive at Foote, Cone and Belding, Papert, Koenig and Lois, Ketcham, MacLeod and Grove, and Needham and Grohman. His first wife Catherine McHugh died in 1998. He is survived by their daughter, Alison Read Wight, his wife, Susan Salzburg and his sister, Judith Werben. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Three separate episodes in different parts of the country made Monday the deadliest day for American forces in Afghanistan in nearly a year. In all, seven United States soldiers were killed, said Capt. Jon Stock, an American military spokesman. Four of the Americans and two Afghan bystanders were killed when a roadside bomb exploded in Kunduz Province in northern Afghanistan, and two American soldiers were killed in an explosion in southern Afghanistan.

HARRIGAN--Arthur W.,former Chief Financial Officer of the Western Electric Company and of International Paper Company, died on June 20, 2009, in Vero Beach, Florida, at the age of 90. Mr. Harrigan graduated from NYU in 1942 while serving in the US Navy, received his MBA from NYU in 1949 and, while employed at Western Electric, earned his PhD in Economics from the Stern School of NYU in 1959. During World War II he first served in Naval Intelligence and, after attending Supply Officers School at Harvard, saw sea duty as an officer on a supply ship carrying landing craft in the Pacific. He recalled the "cheers of the crew when the last B-29 returned from its mission." In 1947 he joined Western Electric, where he served as Comptroller, then Financial VP and, then until 1972 as CFO and a board member. In 1972, he joined International Paper as its CFO and a member of the board. After he retired in 1982, he taught business management courses at the Stern School. He married Margaret Marrin in 1941. During most of their married life, Margaret, who earned her Masters Degree in Social Work from Columbia University, worked as a family counselor, and became a highly sought-after speaker on these subjects. They were a very close couple who excelled at combining family life with two careers long before this life pattern became common. They were happily married for fifty-three years until her death in 1994. Mr. Harrigan was an exceptionally thoughtful, kind and generous man who steadfastly maintained these qualities in his business life as well as in his private life. He was liked and admired by his colleagues and loved by his family. He is survived by his daughter, Patricia Nadosy, of New York City, by his son, Arthur W. Harrigan, of Seattle, Washington, their spouses Peter Nadosy and Carol Wilder, and by four grandchildren, Meghan Magyar, Andrea and Lara Nadosy and Aaron Wilder. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated 10:00 a.m., Thursday, July 23, 2009 at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach, FL

For much of the 1990s, when the phrase “adapted from the ‘Saturday Night Live’ sketch” was applied to a comedy feature film — think “A Night at the Roxbury,” “It’s Pat” or “Stuart Saves His Family” — it was usually a sign that that movie would end up as ill-fated as Mr. Bill. Now, The Hollywood Reporter says, plans are rapidly falling into place for the first “SNL” skit-to-movie screen transfer since “The Ladies Man,” to be adapted from the recurring “MacGruber” comedy sketches featuring Will Forte.
So who was that well-behaved young British man talking to David Letterman last night?

LONDON — When Stephen Sondheim wrote that “children will listen,” for the fractured-fairy-tale musical “Into the Woods,” he probably didn’t mean at the theater. Rapt silence was not the state of the very young people seated behind me at the new family-courting production of “Peter Pan,” in a specially created tent Kensington Gardens, and “Carrie’s War,” a tale of city child evacuees in Wales during the Second World War.

At a sentencing hearing on Tuesday in Toronto, the theater producers Garth H. Drabinsky and Myron I. Gottlieb proposed that they undertake a lecture tour of Canadian schools as part of their punishment for fraud convictions, Bloomberg News reported. In March, Mr. Drabinsky, the founder of the Broadway production company Livent, and Mr. Gottlieb, his business partner, were convicted of forgery and defrauding shareholders of more than $400 million. The company’s Broadway productions included “Ragtime,” “Kiss of the Spider Woman” and “Showboat.” At the hearing Tuesday, Mr. Drabinsky’s lawyer, Edward Greenspan, proposed that in lieu of a prison sentence his client visit 65 Canadian schools to teach theater students about “discipline in the craft” and “avoidance of unethical conduct,” according to Bloomberg; Mr. Gottlieb proposed visits to six universities to discuss business ethics. Prosecutors called the proposals “a drastic departure” from traditional punishments. The defendants could be sentenced to up to 10 years for fraud and 14 years for forgery at a hearing on Aug. 5.

LONDON — The plucky American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato triumphed over a fractured right fibula at the Royal Opera House here on Tuesday night, by all reports, and won an enormous ovation. As the entire opera world seems to know by now, on Saturday night, at the opening of a six-performance run of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia,” Ms. DiDonato slipped onstage just after her Act I aria and broke her right leg. Somehow, she carried on, hobbling, limping, using a crutch in Act II and gamely trying to ignore the pain.

The last time Robin Williams tried to go on tour, the actor and comedian was sidetracked by some pesky open-heart surgery. Now that he’s recovered and preparing to hit the road again, he’s getting an HBO special for his troubles. On Wednesday, HBO said in a news release that in December it would broadcast “Robin Williams: Weapons of Self-Destruction,” a comedy special filmed during his tour of the same name. The special, Mr. Williams’s fifth for the cable channel and his first since “Robin Williams: Live on Broadway” in 2002, will be recorded during his performances in November at DAR Constitution Hall in Washington. Mr. Williams is slated to resume his tour in Bloomington, Ind., on Sept. 30. He had surgery in March to replace his aortic valve, repair his mitral valve and correct his irregular heartbeat. The show was to have come to the Neil Simon Theater on Broadway in April and May, but no alternate dates for those performances have been announced.

Despite the announcement by Trent Reznor, the Nine Inch Nails front man, at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in June that fans there were witnessing “our last show ever in the United States,” the band has decided to hammer out a few more American tour dates. Billboard reported that Mr. Reznor said that Nine Inch Nails would play a “handful of shows” in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles beginning Aug. 22. Though the band’s recent tour with Jane’s Addiction was meant to be its swan song, Mr. Reznor wrote on the official Nine Inch Nails Web site, nin.com, that “many shows were in daylight — it just didn’t feel right to end NIN that way.” Dates for specific shows were not announced, but Mr. Reznor wrote that the New York performances would take place at Bowery Ballroom, Webster Hall and Terminal 5. A Chicago show will be held at the Aragon Ballroom, and Los Angeles performances are planned for the Wiltern, the Henry Fonda, the Palladium and the Echoplex.

Fans of Michael Jackson who have sought a place in New York to worship the fallen King of Pop have recently been short one shrine: for several days, the wax figure of Mr. Jackson that stood at Madame Tussauds New York — a rendering arguably as haunting as the person it depicts — has been absent from that Times Square attraction. A spokeswoman for Madame Tussauds said that the wax figure of Mr. Jackson, who died on June 25, was loaned on July 2 to the museum’s Washington branch for the singer’s fans in the nation’s capital who had requested it. She said that the wax figure was due to return to the New York location on Friday, adding, “Sometimes with shipping, sometimes there’s delays.” In the meantime, admirers of pop icons can still find wax renditions of Jimi Hendrix, Biggie Smalls and Elvis Presley at the New York museum.

Tonight he’s gonna rock you. Tomorrow, Michael McKean is headed back to Broadway. Mr. McKean, the actor, comedian and satirical heavy metal musician, will reprise his role as the doughnut shop owner Arthur Przybyszewski in the Tracy Letts play “Superior Donuts” when it transfers to Broadway in the fall, its publicists said Wednesday in a news release. The actor originated the character (whose last name, according to the release, is pronounced “(p)Shub-er-shef-ski”) when “Superior Donuts” made its debut last year at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago. Mr. McKean last appeared on Broadway in the 2007 revival of Harold Pinter’s “The Homecoming,” though he is perhaps best known for portraying David St. Hubbins, the singer and guitarist of the mock rock band Spinal Tap. The Broadway production of “Superior Donuts” is to be directed by Tina Landau, who also directed the Steppenwolf production. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Music Box Theater on Sept. 16 and open on Oct. 1.

For the second week, the real action in music sales was to be found on Billboard’s catalog album chart, for albums released more than 18 months ago: the top 10 slots were occupied by records featuring Michael Jackson, and two of Mr. Jackson’s albums outsold the No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart. According to data from Nielsen SoundScan, Mr. Jackson’s “Number Ones” sold 339,000 copies and “Thriller” sold 187,000 for the week ending July 5. (Each album sold just over 100,000 copies in the week ending June 28, three days after Mr. Jackson’s death.) By comparison, the top album on the Billboard 200 chart, the 31st installment of the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” compilation series, sold 169,261 units. Among the more unusual beneficiaries of the Jackson sales boom, Agence France-Presse reported, has been the Dutch pension fund ABP, which in 2008 purchased the rights to several of Mr. Jackson’s songs, including “Remember the Time” and “You Are Not Alone.” The top five positions on the Billboard 200 chart were rounded out by Brad Paisley’s “American Saturday Night,” Rob Thomas’s “Cradlesong,” “Wilco (The Album)” by Wilco and “The E.N.D.” by Black Eyed Peas.

To be fair to the numerous candidates and also to be politically correct, consider this from Webster's: "The history, development and origin of the word Ugly: Middle English, from Old Norse uggligr, from uggr fear; akin to Old Norse ugga to fear 13th century."

My sister and I had inklings of a slow atrophying of my mother's mind, perhaps of her very self, before she was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in April, 2008. And yet, strangely, I'd also noticed around that time she'd seemed to be more "herself." So I felt oddly reassured at the news. The diagnosis seemed to explain something about who my mother was, perhaps who she'd been most of my life. Due to its seeming genetic component, we believed the type to be early-onset. It could have started when I was still a kid.

Just weeks after the disputed presidential election in Iran, outside observers find themselves in a somewhat familiar situation: trying to piece together a sense of what is happening in China's Xinjiang Province in the aftermath of anti-government protests that turned violent. In China, as in Iran, state-controlled media has called the protesters "rioters" and the violence on the streets "terrorism" rather than characterizing it as a spontaneous reaction by demonstrators confronted by security forces.

Physical education in Maplewood and South Orange is about to go high tech. The South Orange-Maplewood School District today announced that it has been awarded a federal grant worth more than $1.4 million from the Department of Education's Carol M. White Physical Education Program. According to the school district, the money will go toward an expansion of the high-ropes course program, a state of the art fitness center for both the middle and high schools, laptops and pocket computers for gym teachers to be used for assessment, and the purchase of Dartfish Assessment Software. The software is a computer program that allows video analysis of a student's movement, like having a golf swing analyzed or a dance routine compared to former rehearsals. It appears the grant money, aside from the new fitness center, will be predominantly used for teacher training. -- ALEX LOWTHER

PARIS - On Tuesday night, under the majestic glass roof of the Grand Palais, Karl Lagerfeld took Chanel back to basics - if you define basics as allover sequined gowns that cost as much as a Miami luxury condo. For Lagerfeld it was more a matter of returning to Coco's roots - a point made clear in the stage set, featuring four supersize Chanel No. 5 bottles (each 500 kilograms and over 6 meters high) and in the sofa seating that was modeled on furniture from Coco's apartment. Flapper-era references were obvious in the surplus of sequins, tiered hemlines and cloche hats, but the spangled nude bodysuits and the occasional tail feathers brought to mind nothing more than a flock of Vegas showgirls strutting their elegant stuff like a bunch of fashion peacocks.

Armed with buckets of ink, water, a large brush and a strobe light (calibrated to a very high speed), the photographer Shinichi Maruyama creates graphic swirls of liquids colliding in midair or on white paper. The New York-based artist, who studied Chinese calligraphy as a youth in Japan, will show his "Kusho" series ("writing in the sky") at the Donna Karan store on Madison Avenue starting tomorrow, July 9, through Aug. 18. For Maruyama, the spontaneity of the process is what he finds most exciting. "Each stroke is unique, ephemeral. I can never copy or recreate them," he says. "I know something fantastic is happening, but I can't fully understand the event until I look at these captured afterimages."

David Brooks: Gail, the death of Robert McNamara has me thinking about ruling classes. On the one hand there was the Best and the Brightest ruling class of which McNamara was a part. These were men (I guess they were all men) educated at the high water mark of technocratic self-confidence.

As the lead singer of Missing Persons, whose hits included "Words" and "Destination Unknown," Dale Bozzio ruled the airwaves in the early '80s. Her D.I.Y. sci-fi persona, a cross between peroxide rock chick and futuristic Playboy bunny (Bozzio actually worked as one of Hef's girls prior to her singing career), also spawned countless heavily-macquillaged imitators. In fact, her sequined bras, skintight lamé leggings, crystal-embroidered broad-shouldered jackets and clear plastic bubble coats bring to mind the ultramodern styling of a certain Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta, better known as Lady Gaga. After her initial success with Missing Persons, Bozzio went solo with a little help from Prince. Her single "Simon Simon" from 1988 (above) may have been only a minor hit, but Bozzio's Angelyne-meets-leather-fetish-gym look was a major fashion statement no less.

The annual G-8 summit of world leaders kicks off today in L'Aquila, Italy - the epicenter of April's devastating earthquake - with a small amount of controversy, over everything from the club's membership to poor planning to the location (since the area is still experiencing aftershocks). The world's attention will be on important agenda items like trade, food safety and climate change, but one minor detail caught my eye: the Italian luxury linen company Frette is providing each leader with a monogrammed set of Egyptian cotton sheets, towels and his-and-hers bathrobes. Now, it's important to note that, in conjunction with this promotional vehicle, Frette has made a charitable donation to support those affected by the earthquake, a commendable effort. But while I'm all for showcasing Italian craftsmanship, and I'm sure Barack and Angela and Dmitri are going to be much more productive after sleeping like babies on their 600-thread-count sheets and swaddling post-shower in plush terry robes, I still have to wonder: Does anyone think that they really need such swag? (No regifting, world leaders, what with those monograms!) And, of course, which lucky lady will be the recipient of Berlusconi's "hers" bathrobe?

Ankles provide a rare opportunity to recreate a seminal medical study in the comfort of your own home. Back in the mid-1960s, a physician, wondering why, after one ankle sprain, his patients so often suffered another, asked the affected patients to stand on their injured leg (after it was no longer sore). Almost invariably, they wobbled badly, flailing out with their arms and having to put their foot down much sooner than people who'd never sprained an ankle. With this simple experiment, the doctor made a critical, if in retrospect, seemingly self-evident discovery. People with bad ankles have bad balance.

In May, Svandís Svavarsdóttir became Iceland's Minister for the Environment, setting her squarely in the middle of a debate over whether Iceland should use its world-renowned geothermal energy resources to continue to build up its power-intensive aluminum industry (see related post).

The tiny nation of Iceland is often cited as a model for the world in its use of renewable energy. Virtually all of its electricity comes from dams or geothermal power plants. Drive around the countryside, as I did last month, and you will see billows of steam coming from some hillsides, a sure sign of a geothermal operation with the occasional hot springs attached.

With the audience singing along, he brought his tune "What Will My Girlfriend Say?" to a dramatic crescendo, his voice echoing both Conor Oberst and Jack White, before ending it suddenly and silently. After the applause, he issued a polite request: "Please buy my album so that I can eat."

In 2000, a U.N. combat unit entered a deserted village near Shegbwema in eastern Sierra Leone - territory then held by the Revolutionary United Front, a rebel group infamous for its use of child soldiers and widespread amputations. The abandoned buildings were covered with cryptic and deranged drawings. Here and there were sentences, names, questions and statements - all of which made no sense to me at that time. Empty of life, the village was an eerie and suffocating place, and the drawings hinted at a deeper psychosis.

A picture on Monday with an article about Le Théâtre du Soleil, which is performing at the Lincoln Center Festival, was published in error, and the caption misidentified the woman on the right. The picture showed a professor of theater at Brooklyn College and Liliana Andreone, the director of public relations for Le Théâtre du Soleil, not Ariane Mnouchkine, the troupe’s founder.

The On Par column on Monday, about strategies for avoiding golf injuries, misstated a medical credential of Dr. Vijay Vad, a physician at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan who studied PGA Tour players with bad backs. He is a sports medicine specialist, not an orthopedist.

An article on June 9 about the pending retirement of the chairman of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board misstated the given name of a board member, and a correction in this space on June 30 misspelled the surname of the chairman of the oversight board. The board member is Willis Gradison, not William. And as the article correctly noted, the chairman is Mark W. Olson, not Olsen.

An article on Monday about energy-efficiency innovations in incandescent light bulbs misstated the name of the university with which Chunlei Guo, an associate professor of optics who is using laser technology to increase bulb efficiency, is affiliated. It is the University of Rochester, not Rochester University.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the increasing amount of time Major League Baseball players are missing because of injuries included an erroneous example of a contract incentive designed to protect teams when players are hurt. Baseball does not permit certain incentives for statistical accomplishments, like hitting more than 30 home runs in a season. (As the article noted, incentives for games played are allowed.).

An article on Monday about the effect of volatile prices on the oil industry misstated the status of the United States economy last year. The country was in a recession that started in December 2007; it did not go through 2008 without a recession.

An article on June 30 about new state laws that encourage the recycling of old electronic equipment overstated what is currently known about whether toxic metals from nonrecycled electronics in American landfills leach into soil and groundwater. While many scientists and state environmental agencies warn that the potential for such leaching exists, the federal Environmental Protection Agency says it has identified no instances of soil or groundwater contamination attributed specifically to electronic waste in landfills.

An article on Sunday about Iranian clerical leaders who called the presidential election and the government illegitimate misstated the history of their religious organization, the Association of Researchers and Teachers of Qum. It was formed in the late 1990s and included some members of a rival group, the Society of Seminary Teachers, also based in Qum, Iran’s holy city. It was not formed by the founder of the Islamic Revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died in 1989. The article also overstated what is known about the group’s influence within Iran’s clerical establishment. That influence is a matter of debate; the association is not necessarily “the most important group.”.

GALBAN--Leandro S.,Jr. It is with great sadness that the family of Mr. Leandro (Pedro) S. Galban, Jr. announces that he passed away on July 5, 2009. Mr. Galban joined Credit Suisse First Boston in 2000 and at the time of his death was Chairman of Global Financial Services for DLJMB in Alternative Investments, based in New York. He was internationally respected in the business community, especially for his integrity and expertise relating to the insurance industry. Mr. Galban is survived by his wife Beverley and three sons. Services will be held on Saturday, July 11, 2009, 10:00am, at Queen of the Most Holy Rosary Church, Bridgehampton, NY. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall. Instead of flowers, the family asks that donations be given to the Peconic Land Trust.

The Toronto Blue Jays are taking offers for starter Roy Halladay, the Yankees' longtime nemesis and possibly the best pitcher in baseball. The Yankees will mull the idea, but several factors make Halladay more likely to wind up elsewhere. Halladay is making $30 million for the 2009 and 2010 seasons, and is unsigned past that. He has veto power over trades, but Toronto General Manager J. P. Ricciardi said Halladay was ''open to listening,'' according to ESPN.com.

De PERALTA--Armando Rene Grave Sr.,a resident of La Jolla California and a former resident of New York for most of his life, died on July 3, 2009 at the age of 94 years. Mr. de Peralta was born in New Orleans on November 8, 1914, the son of Pedro Grave de Peralta, who was the then Argentinean Ambassador to the United States and Adele Gloria de Peralta who was actively involved in New York society. Mr. de Peralta began his business career as the leader of his band "Armando and his Ambassadors" and as the owner of the Pago Pago Club, a popular nightclub frequented by New York society in the 1930s and 1940s. Mr. de Peralta himself had the reputation of being a bon vivant and was frequently included in society columns. During his military service as a Corporal with the 375th Field Artillery Battalion, Mr. de Peralta was injured by a misplaced land mine resulting in the total paralysis of his legs. Fortunately, Mr. de Peralta had not allowed his military injury to deter him from commencing a new career in the shipping industry where he started as an employee for 26 years with Thor Eckert & Co. prior to founding his own shipping company, Peralta Shipping Corporation which became the exclusive transatlantic shipper of the paper products of International Paper Company and the St. Regis Paper Company. After Mr. de Peralta sold his shipping business, he commenced several new careers as a real estate investor and developer, a co-producer of a variety of Broadway musicals, an author of eight published books of romantic poetry, and as a philanthropist. Mr. de Peralta's life was the subject of an improvisational ensemble play "Life Game" at the La Jolla Playhouse Forum in 2000. Mr. de Peralta is survived by his wife, Rosalba Roca Grave de Peralta and their children Frederic de Peralta and William Adams de Peralta, and by Joyce Patafio and their children, Rene Armando de Peralta and Marcello de Peralta. His first wife Marcia de Peralta died on September 17, 2007 and their son, Armando de Peralta Jr., also died on August 17, 2004. Committal service will take place Wednesday, July 8, 2009 at 10am at Greenwood Memorial Park, 4300 Imperial Avenue, San Diego, CA 92113. Services have been trusted to Greenwood Mortuary, (619) 264-3131.

SCHNELLING--Anthony (Tony) H. N.,Founder and CEO of Bridge Associates LLC, died July 7, 2009 at the age of 62. Beloved husband of Battina M. Whyte. Loving Son of Emily Leeser. Services by Hufcut Funeral Home, Dover Plains, NY (845)877-1400.

The N.B.A.'s salary cap will decrease next season for only the second time in its 26-year history. The league announced Tuesday that the cap for 2009-10 will be $57.7 million, a 1.6 percent decrease from last season. The cap is generally tied to leaguewide revenues, which increased by 2.5 percent in 2008-9. However, the cap decreased based on a formula set by the collective bargaining agreement. The last time the cap dipped was between the 2001-2 and 2002-3 seasons, dropping to $40.27 million from $42.5 million. It increased for six consecutive years, growing to $58.68 million last season.

Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother to Susan and Jay, Janie and Frank, Howard and Jo Ellen, Lee and Raquel, Andrew and Lisa, Robert, Danny and Liz, Jackson, Madison, and Hannah. She was a wonderful sister, aunt, and friend and will be missed by all.

FEINERMAN--Samuel L.,age 86, passed away at home in Boca Raton, FL, Monday, July 6th, 2009. He was married to his adored wife Adele for 62 years. He leaves behind his son Bennett Feinerman and daughter Fara Love and son-in-law Jerry Love, and his much beloved granddaughter Devon Leigh Love. He started with his father, Stanley Structural Steel Co. and moved on to many successful real estate ventures in New York, Connecticut and Florida. His love of life, and his battle to live will always be remembered. He will forever be missed. The Feinerman and The Love Family

ROSENFELD--Arthur H.,age 79, died peacefully surrounded by his wife and three daughters on July 7, 2009. Beloved husband of Lois, father of Felicia, Carolyn and Sara; father-in-law of David, Ari and Kurt. Devoted and beloved grandfather of Jess, Adam, Isaac, Julia, Miranda and William. Born in Brooklyn, Arthur graduated from Union College and Harvard Law School. He was an esteemed publisher in the field of professional reference publishing, most recently as the Chief Executive Officer of Civic Research Institute. Previously he served as Chairman and Founder of Rosenfeld, Emanuel Publishers; President of International Thomson Professional Publishing; President of Warren, Gorham & Lamont; President of Prentice-Hall Tax & Professional Reference Publishing; and General Counsel for the Ronald Press Company. He served at various times as a Member of the Board on six of the leading legal publishers in his profession. He loved the beaches of eastern Long Island and was an avid member of the Harvard Club, a lifelong learner and devotee of American History, and a cycling and running enthusiast. He was a kind, generous man who loved his family and friends unconditionally and who was loved by them. A funeral will be held Thursday, July 9, 2009, at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Arthur's name to the American Civil Liberties Union.

MARGOLIS--Barbara Long. Before governments or the public recognized the need to help prisoners re-enter society, Bobbie founded Fresh Start at Rikers Island. As a trustee of the Vera Institute of Justice from 1980 to 2000 (and then an honorary trustee until her death) and a trustee of two Vera spinoffs, she provided ideas, enthusiasm, and support for innovative programs that reach out to society's most vulnerable individuals. John F. Savarese, Chair Michael Jacobson, President

''My body started to leave my spirit. Endoscopy, cancer surgery, chemotherapy. My body no longer belongs to me.'' Wonjun Park, a young artist in South Korea, came to America in 1973, and he worked at many different jobs to make a living while pursuing his art whenever he could. In January 2008, Mr. Park learned he had gastric cancer, which had spread to his liver. He underwent surgery to remove parts of his stomach and liver in March, and he began 10 months of chemotherapy in May. His battle with cancer has caused him to question his beliefs, and to discover a desire to live on through his art, even after his death. ''Art was something I had to do all the time to feel I am alive,'' Mr. Park said. But his experience led to a reassessment. ''Have I created art just to satisfy and to console myself, who has been overwhelmed by uncertainty and death?'' Mr. Park wrote on his blog in Korean. ''After I was sentenced to death and my mind was jailed in my own body,'' as he describes his cancer in his blog, he realized his desire to live on through his art. ''Art is not just to satisfy oneself,'' he said. ''Art is not just to express oneself. Art is also my instinct to protest death, and the will to live through it.'' Video of Mr. Park, and of other Second Chance subjects: nytimes.com/cityroom.

10 P.M. (13) HEART OF JENIN In 2005 Ahmed Khatib, a 12-year-old Palestinian from the West Bank city of Jenin, was killed by Israeli soldiers when they mistook his toy gun for a real one. In their grief, his parents decided to donate their son's organs to six Israeli children facing death. Ahmed's kidneys went to an Orthodox Jewish girl and a Bedouin boy. Ahmed's heart, which his parents had initially been reluctant to donate, now keeps a Druze girl alive. ''Wide Angle'' follows Ismael Khatib, above, Ahmed's father, on his journey from northern Israel to the Negev desert and finally to Jerusalem to visit these three recipients two years later. ''I see my son in these children,'' he says. 9 A.M. KING--Lawrence S. March 11, 1944 - July 3, 2009. Lawrence King, an Emmy award winning set designer, died on Wednesday at his home in Milford, CT after a long battle with cancer. He was 65. He designed "As the World Turns" for 13 years and was awarded a Daytime Emmy for his work in 1990. He left the show in 1995 to work full time with set designer and life partner, Michael Yeargan, on many plays on Broadway (The Light in the Piazza, South Pacific, Awake and Sing, Joe Turner's Come and Gone) and operas at the Met and in Europe. Raised in Wichita, Kansas, as a teenager, he became known for his puppetry work on the local television station, KAKE, and was active in the community theater. He attended Wichita State University and was a classmate of renowned opera bass Samuel Ramey. Upon graduation, he was accepted into the Yale School of Drama as a set and costume designer. While a student, he designed the first production (The Rivals, directed by Alvin Epstein) of the Yale Repertory Theatre in its current space, a renovated church, on Chapel Street. After Yale, he designed many productions for the Hartford Stage Company and co-designed many shows (Bad Habits, The Ritz) and operas with Mr. Yeargan before joining As The World Turns. He is survived by his life partner of 40 years, Michael Yeargan. A private memorial gathering is pending and, in lieu of flowers, donations are requested to go to the American Cancer Society. The arrangements are in the care of Smith & Sefcik Funeral Home, 135 Broad St., "On the Green", Milford. To leave condolences, please visit our website at: www.georgejsmithandson.com

Unanticipated events in politics -- say, for example, Sarah Palin's announcement that she was quitting as governor of Alaska -- tend to be overanalyzed, imbued with more motive, forethought and political calculus than might really be there. That could have been the case with the storm of interpretation that greeted Ms. Palin's announcement -- running the gamut from her preparing a run for the 2012 presidential nomination, to laying the groundwork for a lucrative career as a conservative commentator, to making a pre-emptive step in anticipation of an embarrassing disclosure.

To bring Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman together in a movie would probably require a budget of hundreds of millions of dollars and, perhaps, a screenplay about secret agents and mutants. To get the actors together on Broadway, it just took a story about Chicago cops. Mr. Craig, the star of the James Bond movies “Casino Royale” and “Quantum of Solace,” and Mr. Jackman, who plays Wolverine in the “X-Men” movies, will star in the Broadway production of the Keith Huff play “A Steady Rain” for a limited run this fall, its publicists said Thursday in a news release. The play, to be directed by John Crowley (“The Pillowman”), will run at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, with previews scheduled to begin on Sept. 10 and an official opening of Sept. 29. Its limited run is slated to end on Dec. 6. The play will mark the Broadway debut of Mr. Craig, who has previously acted at the Royal National Theater (in “Angels in America”) and in the Peter Hall Company at the Old Vic (in “Hurlyburly”). Mr. Jackman won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical in 2004 for his portrayal of Peter Allen in “The Boy From Oz.”

Savannah Wise, who has been playing the character of Sherrie in the Broadway musical “Rock of Ages” since the departure of Amy Spanger, will take over the role permanently, the show’s producers announced Thursday. Ms. Wise, whose Broadway credits also include “Les Misérables,” had been understudying the role of Sherrie, the aspiring actress from Kansas whose road to Hollywood glory includes a brief detour in a Los Angeles strip club. Ms. Spanger, who originated the role in the Broadway production, had been out of the show since June 8. On June 29, publicists for the show said that Ms. Spanger had departed due to “personal reasons.”

MANCHESTER, England — The Manchester Peace Garden is a cozy park and plaza right near this central English city’s magnificent 19th-century gothic City Hall. In the center of the garden stands an outdoor artwork installed for the Manchester International Festival, which began on July 2 and runs through July 19. The piece, “Flailing Trees” by the artist Gustav Metzger, and the way it causes you to alter perceptions reflect one aim of the festival: to alter common perceptions about this city, once a gritty industrialized metropolis, now a cosmopolitan center of media, culture and commerce.

When Lance Armstrong heads into the final stretch of the Tour de France race at the end of the month, he’ll have support from an unexpected fan: Damien Hirst has created a design that will appear on Mr. Armstrong’s bicycle during the 21st stage of the race, Bloomberg News reported. On his Twitter feed, Mr. Armstrong wrote that he was “speechless” after seeing the design for the Trek Madone bicycle that Mr. Hirst, the Turner Prize-winning artist known for his displays of animals in formaldehyde, “put his touches on.” Mr. Armstrong usually rides a black-and-white bike with the logo of his Livestrong charity and yellow detail on the wheels. A business manager for Mr. Hirst told Bloomberg that his artwork on the bike would feature butterflies, one of Mr. Hirst’s signature motifs. Mr. Armstrong is a seven-time winner of the Tour de France; this year’s race is scheduled to end in Paris on July 26.

The Valentino designers Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli got serious for their second couture outing, staging their show in the darkly romantic Couvent des Cordeliers and setting the mood with black-and-white projections of curling smoke on transparent scrims. The noir inspiration was spelled out in the program notes, which cited Edward VII's death in 1910, and took form in an all-black collection lavishly stitched from lace, mousseline and fur and embroidered with jet beads. Audience members who weren't as up-to-snuff on their royal history were able to draw their own interpretation: some of the models resembled Marie Antoinettes in mourning, while others had the seductive appeal of belles on their way to a Venetian masked ball. And come to think of it, one amazing gown would make the ideal wedding dress for Helena Bonham Carter if she ever marries Tim Burton.

Skinny-tie-wearing, hair-slicking urban dudes (like me) who've come to regard the show as a weekly primer on gentlemanly style will probably be compelled to add the four-DVD collection (cleverly packaged to look like a shirt box) to their curated bookshelves.
The G8 nations have agreed that by 2050, developed nations will reduce emissions by 80 percent and they are committed to limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius.
The Democratic and Republican leaderships in the House used the health care debate to revive an old argument this week - whether legislation gets debated vigorously enough before heading to a vote.
The long runways, old hangars and waterfront at Brooklyn’s Floyd Bennett Field, New York City’s first municipal airport, are far from idle.

Before Hendrick Ramaala became a marathon champion, he tried out for the soccer team at his university in Johannesburg, South Africa. When he didn't make the squad, he ran on the school's grass track to stay in shape while studying for a law degree. But instead of practicing law, he dedicated himself to elite distance running, preferring to train without a coach.

Watching the Valentino show last night, I couldn't help but think of the lovely dresses Alessandra Facchinetti had in her one couture collection before she was dismissed from the house. I remembered the delicate fabrics, the cream tones and splurge of red, though wisely not a Valentino red. I don't know anything about Ms. Facchinetti's work habits or her personality (beyond what I could observe in a few brief meetings), but I thought her clothes were charming, and not determined to be youthful just for the sake of it.

On a recent trip to Italy, Jackie and I ate at the trattoria Antiche Sere (9 via Cenischia, Turin; +39 011 385 4347), where the nice-weather dining room out back was over-canopied with grape vines and where for part of the evening the electricity repeatedly and somehow charmingly gave out. One element of the generous house antipasto -- which pretty much everybody in the nearly all-local crowd ordered -- was an inch or so of what looked like soft salami. Well, it was soft salami, or sausage at any rate, but with the difference that it hadn't been aged much; hardly at all, in fact, just long enough to let the salt and pepper settle in. The raw pork, a nice balance of fat and lean, was highly seasoned and impeccably trimmed and chopped -- you can imagine that running into any strands of connective tissue in a thing like this could ruin the effect, if not the evening. It was flavorful and great fun to eat, either alone or smeared on bread.

LONDON | A garden center may not be the most obvious place to find one of London's most desirable eateries, but the restaurant and cafe at Petersham Nurseries (off Petersham Road; 44-20-8605-3627) has won several awards and an enviable reputation. Nestling between a meadow besides the Thames, part of an area known as Arcadia, and the boundary of Richmond Park (one of London's Royal Parks), it serves delicious seasonal food, teas and coffee, and housemade cakes.

MINNEAPOLIS -- It's hard to be too sentimental about the Twins leaving the Metrodome. It is a dome, after all, with artificial turf and a giant curtain covering thousands of upper-deck seats. As the ads at the Metrodome say, the open-air Target Field will have skyline sunsets, real grass stains and starry nights. Nothing wrong with that.

The American Davis Cup team will face the only country it has never beaten, Croatia, when the world group quarterfinal begins Friday in Porec, Croatia. The match will take place on a temporary indoor red clay court, the Americans' most problematic surface, at Zatika Sports Hall.

When a medical mistake happens, a patient suffers. But what many of us don't think about is the toll a medical mistake can take on the doctor who made it. In today's Doctor and Patient column, Dr. Pauline Chen writes about the "vicious cycle" of medical errors that can occur when doctors are under stress. She writes of a brash young medical student whose confidence was shattered by a series of small mistakes.
Errors affect doctors too, increasing the risk of burnout and depression and harming subsequent care.

A story in the Thursday Styles section asks: Is rampant baby consumerism out of style? Some experts say the recession is causing formerly free-spending parents to reflect on how much their babies really need. No longer is it necessary to buy a $1,000 changing table in order to prove your parental savvy and breadth of love; if anything the opposite is true. One social scientist says, "The recession has liberated us from a lot of the consumer expectations so that we can have a big enough space to feel really comfortable just giving our kids a pot and a spoon." Read more here.

The Local is starting an occasional feature, Sale of the Week, about interesting real estate sales that went well, from either the seller's point of view or the buyer or the real estate agent. The first post was provided by Stephanie Mallios, a real estate agent.

The single most persistent and complex problem with criticism of art, in any medium, is arguably the problem of historical context. In what era and under what aesthetic was the object created? And how, then, can we critique it, given that it was conceived for people whose sensibilities differed from ours? Is it successful because it speaks to us now or because it spoke to them then?

The personal is political, the saying goes, but often the political feels very personal -- such as when political marriages unravel in front of the television cameras. In an essay in this week's New York Times Magazine I explore why women in particular are transfixed by these stories. After you read it, come back and talk about whether the affairs of the powerful have anything to do with you.

Google's new Chrome operating system is a challenge to Microsoft in several ways. It will offer a free rival to Windows, which can add $25 to $100 to the price of a computer. But it also represents a conceptual slap at the elaborate array of features that make up the soon-to-be-unveiled Windows 7.

Peter Wheeler, the former owner of TVR of Blackpool, England, died last month at 65 after an illness, and it is worth noting here how remarkable his tenure was. He was a chemical engineer who actually took over a car company. He embodied a spirit of individualism that gave TVR its spark, and although he made the company only a modest success, he produced some exciting cars, like the Tuscan, Cerbera and Griffith.

Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, Alistair Darling, presented long-awaited plans for new financial regulations to the Parliament on Wednesday, but sidestepped a turf battle between the Bank of England and the Financial Services Authority and put off any limits on executive pay, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier writes.

A picture essay in The Times Magazine on Sunday and an expanded slide show on NYTimes.com titled “Ruins of the Second Gilded Age” showed large housing construction projects across the United States that came to a halt, often half-finished, when the housing market collapsed. An article last Thursday about the way Graydon Carter seats guests at the Monkey Bar, a restaurant that he co-owns, misstated its location. It is on East 54th Street, not West 54th.

A headline on a brief report in the Skin Deep column on June 25 about a cellulite severity scale that was published in May in the Journal of the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology referred incorrectly to the scale’s measurements. While it has five measurements, each is graded from zero to three, so the headline should have said “On a Scale of 0 to 15, Ugh,” not “On a Scale of 1 to 5, Ugh.”.

Michael McKean, perhaps best known for portraying David St. Hubbins, the singer and guitarist of the mock rock band Spinal Tap, will reprise his role as the doughnut-shop owner Arthur Przybyszewski in the Tracy Letts play “Superior Donuts” when it transfers to Broadway in the fall, its publicists said on Wednesday in a news release. The Broadway production of “Superior Donuts” is to begin previews at the Music Box Theater on Sept. 16 and open on Oct. 1. It had its debut last year at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago.

Despite the announcement by Trent Reznor, the Nine Inch Nails front man, at the Bonnaroo Music and Arts Festival in June that fans there were witnessing “our last show ever in the United States,” the band has decided to hammer out a few more American tour dates. Billboard reported that Mr. Reznor said that Nine Inch Nails would play a “handful of shows” in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, beginning on Aug. 22. Though the band’s recent tour with Jane’s Addiction was meant to be its swan song, Mr. Reznor wrote on the Nine Inch Nails Web site, nin.com, that “many shows were in daylight — it just didn’t feel right to end NIN that way.”.

For the second week, the real action in music sales was to be found on Billboard’s catalog album chart, for albums released more than 18 months ago: the top 10 slots were occupied by records featuring Michael Jackson, and two of Mr. Jackson’s albums outsold the No. 1 album on the Billboard 200 chart. According to data from Nielsen SoundScan, Mr. Jackson’s “Number Ones” sold 339,000 copies, and “Thriller” sold 187,000 for the week ending on Sunday. (Each album sold about 100,000 copies in the week ending June 28, three days after Mr. Jackson’s death.) By comparison, the top album on the Billboard 200 chart, the 31st installment of the “Now That’s What I Call Music!” compilation series, sold 169,261 units. The top five positions on the Billboard 200 chart were rounded out by Brad Paisley’s “American Saturday Night,” Rob Thomas’s “Cradlesong,” “Wilco (The Album)” by Wilco and “The E.N.D.” by the Black Eyed Peas.

At a sentencing hearing on Tuesday in Toronto, the Canadian theater producers Garth H. Drabinsky and Myron I. Gottlieb proposed that they undertake a lecture tour of Canadian schools as part of their punishment for fraud convictions, Bloomberg News reported. In March Mr. Drabinsky, the founder of the Broadway production company Livent, and Mr. Gottlieb, his business partner, were convicted of forgery and defrauding shareholders of more than $400 million. The company’s Broadway productions include “Ragtime,” “Kiss of the Spider Woman” and “Show Boat.” At the hearing on Tuesday Mr. Drabinsky’s lawyer, Edward Greenspan, proposed that in lieu of a prison sentence his client visit 65 Canadian schools to teach theater students about “discipline in the craft” and “avoidance of unethical conduct,” according to Bloomberg; Mr. Gottlieb proposed visits to six universities to discuss business ethics. The two could be sentenced to up to 10 years for fraud and 14 years for forgery at a hearing on Aug. 5.

The American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato, above, triumphed over a fractured right fibula at the Royal Opera House in London on Tuesday night. On Saturday night, at the opening of a six-performance run as Rosina in Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia,” Ms. DiDonato slipped onstage just after her Act I aria and injured her leg. Somehow she carried on, hobbling, limping, using a crutch in Act II and gamely trying to ignore the pain. On Tuesday Ms. DiDonato, with a cast on her leg covered by a pink stocking, performed from a wheelchair, winning admiration from her colleagues and bravos from the Covent Garden audience. Ann Richards, a spokeswoman for the Royal Opera House, reported that Ms. DiDonato had “managed brilliantly.”.

MARGOLIS--Barbara Ann, on July 3, at age 79. Born in Malden, MA, the daughter of Eli and Shirley Schneider. She was an alumna of Simmons College. Barbara was New York City's Chief of Protocol under Mayor Ed Koch. Starting with her association with the Vera Institute of Justice in the mid-1960s, she developed a passion, a base of knowledge, and a group of like-minded friends and colleagues that allowed her to effect considerable positive change for the incarcerated in New York City. In 1980, she started the Rikers Review, a publication written and produced by inmates on Rikers Island. Nine years later, she created Fresh Start, a program that brought many of New York's best chefs and restaurateurs to Rikers Island to teach inmates about the industry and train them to work as food professionals. She served on the Board of Trustees of the Vera Institute of Justice, was a member of the Board of Corrections, served on the Board of the Osborne Association, and was a founding member of the Board of Trustees of the New York Correction History Society. She received the Correctional Association of New York's highest honor, the 1844 Medal Award, in recognition of her outstanding activism to advance the well-being and rehabilitation of prisoners. The Horticultural Society of New York was another singular source of joy in her volunteer life, combining her passion for prison reform issues (through its Rikers Island "Green Team" program) and a commitment to cultivating beauty for its own sake. She joined the Board of the Horticultural Society in 1989 and was named Chairman of the Board in 2007. She was married for fifty years to David I. Margolis until his death in December 2008. She is survived by her four children: Brian, Robert, Peter, and Nancy; five grandchildren: Porter, Sophie, Delphine, Harry, and Maximilian; and one sister, Arline Guefen. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: The Horticultural Society of New York, 148 West 37th Street, 13th Floor, New York, NY 10018-6909.

SCHNELLING-Anthony. It is with deep regret that we mourn the passing of Anthony Schnelling, husband of Board of Trustees member Bettina Whyte. The staff of The Animal Medical Center wishes to extend our heartfelt sympathies to Bettina and the entire Schnelling family. Mr. Schnelling fought a valiant battle against cancer and will be dearly missed by all who knew him.

MARGOLIS--Barbara A. The Horticultural Society of New York mourns the loss of Barbara Margolis, our dear friend and Board Chair, our beloved "Bobbie." She joined our board in 1989 bringing with her a love of horticulture, deep concern for the underserved, and decades of experience working with the city's incarcerated populations. Bobbie helped expand The Society's mission to include vocational training for individuals in need through our urban gardening teams. She was a strong proponent for the use of therapeutic gardening techniques and a major supporter of our Horticultural Therapy Rehabilitation Programs on Rikers Island. In 2007, Mrs. Margolis was elected Chair of the Board and she founded an annual art auction to raise money for The Society's outreach programs. She skillfully led The Society as acting president between 2008 and 2009. Devoted mentor and friend, Barbara Margolis was loved by the staff and friends of The Horticultural Society and will be greatly missed. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Margolis family. The Margolis family requests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to: The Horticultural Society of New York, 148 West 37th Street, 13th floor, New York, NY 10018.

According to a new study by DisplayMate Technologies and supported by Insight Media, LCD televisions continue to come up short when compared with their competitors. DisplayMate tested LCD sets from Samsung, Sharp and Sony, and a plasma display from Panasonic. The company's aim was not to single out specific models but to look for issues common across the technologies.

SHELLEY--Joseph Francis, Ph.D.,P.E., of Princeton, died on Monday, June 29, 2009. He was 76. An Emeritus Professor of Mechanical Engineering at The College of New Jersey (formerly Trenton State College), President of the engineering consultancy Technalysis, Inc., and author of several McGraw-Hill textbooks, he is survived by four children (Stefanie, Suzanne, Matthew and Meredith), four grandchildren, a brother John L. Shelley (Orlando), and his companion Marian K. Green (Princeton). A memorial service will be held Saturday, July 11, at 11am, at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Princeton (www.uuprinceton.org).

HIGH-CALORIE sports drinks can satisfy thirst, but they do little for the figure. They are ideal for athletes who do long or intense workouts, but can be counterproductive for people exercising to lose weight. For the latter group -- or others who need to hydrate but don't want extra calories -- there is a growing range of options. Monique Ryan, a sports nutritionist in Evanston, Ill., recommends a low-calorie electrolyte drink with more sodium than water and less sugar than conventional sports drinks. Such products, she said, are excellent for summertime exercise.

The European Commission said Wednesday that it had fined the German utility E.On and its French rival, GDF Suez, 553 million euros ($772 million) each for refusing to compete. The commission, the European Union's competition regulator, said an E.On unit, Ruhrgas, and GDF Suez had agreed in 1975 not to sell imported Russian natural gas to each other's home markets after jointly building a pipeline from Russia to Western Europe.

Taylor; six grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A service will be held at Beaumont, 601 Ithan Ave., Bryn Mawr, Pa. at 4 p.m. Thursday, July 16, with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to United Way of Southeastern Pa., Seven Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

Muslims rioted Wednesday in Srinagar, in the Indian-administered part of Kashmir, over claims that an Islamia College student who had been missing since Friday, Asrar Mushtaq Dar, died in police custody. The police denied that they had detained Mr. Dar, who was 20 years old.

The Swiss government, vowing to protect its vaunted bank secrecy laws, said on Wednesday that it was prepared to seize UBS client data rather than allow the bank to hand it over to the United States to settle a tax case. The dispute, which is playing out in federal court in a Miami, has become a test of Washington's efforts to pierce Swiss banking laws as it tries to crack down on wealthy Americans who avoid taxes by hiding money in secret offshore accounts.

WOOD--Marion Geer, 90, wife of 66 years of William Lawrence Wood, on July 1st, 2009 on Hilton Head Island, SC. Despite a long, stoic bout with Alzheimer's, Missy retained her capacity for joy and friendship and her gift for making those in her orbit feel they were the center of her universe. Besides her husband, Bill, she is survived by her daughter, Marion Canfield Wood, her son-in-law, Frank Ahmed, her beloved grandson, William L.F. Ahmed, her in-laws, John and Denise Wood, her stepbrother, John Winslow (Helen), nieces, Margo Walker, Rose Thorne (David), Elizabeth Hammill (Tom), and nephews Charles Geer and John Masten (Marcia), her step-niece, Sybil Carton, and a wondrous array of cousins and those who called her their "second mother." Private service on Hilton Head on July 9th, to be followed by a Memorial Service on Long Island at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Community Foundation of Oyster Bay, 200 Sunset Rd., Oyster Bay Cove, NY 11771 or to The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, 1 Bungtown Rd., Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. The Island Funeral Home and Crematory is in charge of services.

If you want to quickly understand Sony's PSP Go ($250, coming Oct. 1), just think of the rule of two. Compared with the regular PSP, it is 50 percent smaller, but it costs twice as much as Nintendo's DS, which is outselling it by 100 percent. At the center of Sony's PSP thinking is Media Go, Sony's iTunes-like content manager. You can drag and drop movies, songs and videos onto the Go's 16 gigabytes of memory, and archive your big files on your Windows computer's hard drive.

Ms. Davis was the Executive Assistant to Donald McGraw Jr. at McGraw Hill in NYC for 35 years, retiring 11 years ago. Services are being held by Mastapeter Funeral home, 400 Faitoute Ave., Roselle Park, NJ. 908-245-1558

TOBIN--Gary. The Board and Staff of The Andrea and Charles Bronfman Philanthropies mourn the loss of our friend and colleague. His research, policy development and perspective on contemporary Jewish life was an invaluable contribution that will live on. Charles R. Bronfman, Chair Jeffrey R. Solomon, President

WALLACE--Doris B.,of New York City, died on July 4, 2009. She was 81. Born in Hanover, Germany, she immigrated to England with her family in the 1930s. She studied at the Royal College of Music and Edinburgh University. In 1959, Doris came to the United States and married Warren Wallace. She first worked on a Yale University project and then accepted a position at Bank Street College, where she stayed for 25 years becoming a Senior Research Associate and publishing a number of papers. During these years, she completed her undergraduate degree at the City University of New York and doctorate in Psychology at Rutgers University. Doris subsequently married Howard Gruber, attended the Ackerman Institute and became a clinical Psychologist with a private practice in New York City. She continued her academic work by writing articles and editing books on the creative process. Doris was a beloved and loving mother to Amelia and Lucy, devoted grandmother to Alfie, Violet, Pearl and George, and a cherished friend to many. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Best Friend's Animal Society at bestfriends.org. A memorial will be held at Frank E. Campbell on Sunday, July 12, at 6pm.
KNELLER--John W. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of John W. Kneller, who served as president from 1970 to 1979 during a turbulent decade. He is remembered with much respect.

MARGOLIS--Barbara A. Equal parts statesman, mother, friend and mentor, Bobbie rallied people to care for individuals and communities. She treasured her children, their individuality and independence, and felt honored by their loving support. She admired her friends and colleagues, whose good work she promoted. She generously mentored those around her. I was one of those fortunate people with whom she shared her wisdom, her joys and her challenges. I will strive to keep her spirit and intentions alive. Sara Hobel, Executive Director, The Horticultural Society of New York

As a freshman at Ohio State University, and the only black student on his floor, Sam Boakye was determined to get good grades -- in part to make sure his white roommate had no basis for negative racial views. ''If you're surrounded by whites, you have something to prove,'' said Mr. Boakye, a rising senior who was born in Ghana. ''You're pushed to do better, to challenge the stereotype that black people are not that smart.''

JACOBSON--Daniel, a resident of Santa Fe, NM, passed away at the age of 80 on July 6, 2009, after a long illness. Dan was a graduate of the Birch Wathen School, Yale University and Columbia Law School. A CPA, Dan had a long, distinguished career at firms including Laventhol & Horwath and KPMG, and was a director of Barnwell Industries. He served on the Boards of the Lexington School for the Deaf and the American Jewish Committee. Dan is survived by his wife of 26 years, Jenne K. Britell; his sister, Carolyn Neustadt and her husband David; his children, Deborah Jacobson and David Weinberg, Theodore Jacobson and Robin Mize, James Jacobson and Melody Carroll; stepchildren Samantha Britell and Jeffrey Levine, and Penny and Seth Sanders; and grandsons: Austin and Sam Jacobson, Max Weinberg, and Beckett and Duncan Levine. Dan is also survived by his brother-in-law, James Katz, and his wife Susan. Dan's intelligence, wit, style, enthusiasm, and sense of humor will be greatly missed and lovingly remembered by his family and friends. A private family service was held. Expressions of sympathy in Dan's memory may be made to the Fox Chase Cancer Center, 333 Cottman Avenue, IA Department, Philadelphia, PA 19111-2497, to support the Lymphoma Research of Dr. Mitchell Smith.

9 P.M. (CNBC) INSIDE TRACK: REFUELING THE BUSINESS OF NASCAR Its roots are in Southern bootlegging, but in the last decade Nascar has become the fastest-growing sport in the country, routinely filling speedways that seat up to 200,000 fans. But what happens when the automobile industry implodes and sponsorship budgets shrink? Darren Rovell investigates the state of racing through interviews with Tony Stewart, above, the two-time Sprint Cup Series Champion; Kyle Busch, the driver of the No. 18 M&Ms car; and Brian France, the chairman and chief executive of Nascar, whose family has sole control over the sport. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Rupert Grint talks about his latest stint as Ron Weasley, in ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.'' Sugar Ray performs, and Regis Philbin gets a sleep analysis.

I'm not afraid of death. Even when I was dying, I wasn't afraid of it. You just get a feeling within yourself at a certain point. You know when to let it be. SISTER DOROTHY QUINN, 87, who was near death from heart disease. [A18]

DELFINO--Catherine, on July 8, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Sweet, dear and devoted mother of Joseph, Marylou Berk and KC, and mother-in-law of Allen Berk, Marshall Levinson and Cyndy Marchese. Adoring grandmother of Fiona, Morgan, Pam, Valerie and Melissa. Loving sister of Rose Difato and the late Alfred. Service Thursday, 1pm, at St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. A Celebration of Life Memorial will be held at a later date.

The ability to check news at any time is one of the joys of the mobile phone, but trying to read tiny type and busy layouts on a two-inch screen isn't. A new free iPhone app called Fluent News addresses that problem (a mobile Web version is available to any phone with a browser at fluent news.com). It aggregates news, collecting only stories that are formatted for the mobile phone, then recasts them into its easy-to-use news browser.

MacCRACKEN--Harriet L.,96, of Meadow Ridge, Redding, CT, passed away on July 4, 2009. Harriet was born in New York City on January 13, 1913. Daughter of Wallace Foster and Jesse Burke Lyons. Growing up Greenwich, CT, she attended the Greenwich Academy and later Miss Hall's School, Class of 1931. In 1941, she married J. Franklin Van Deren. Mr. Van Deren passed away in 1974. She was predeceased by her husband, Constable MacCracken of New Caanan, CT in 1995. She was an extraordinary lady of many talents, a member and judge of the Greenfingers Garden Club, the New Caanan Sewing Group, and the North Woods Club of Minerva, NY. A cherished mother to Nancy Van Deren (James Burnett) of Spencertown, NY and John F. Van Deren III (Jane) of Montpelier, VT, her stepchildren Thomas MacCracken (Alexandra) of Oakton, VA and New York City and Linda MacCracken of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY. Loved and fondly remembered for her generosity, spirit and devotion to her grandchildren, Jessica Van Deren Herlihy (Daniel) of New Haven, CT and John F. Van Deren IV of New York City, and her step-granddaughters Paige Ioppolo of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY and Annie Hults and Caitlin Ryan both of New York City. A memorial service will be held on July 22, 3pm at Meadow Ridge, 100 Redding Rd., Redding, CT 06896. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

ROSENFELD--Arthur H.,age 79, died peacefully surrounded by his wife and three daughters on July 7, 2009. Beloved husband of Lois, father of Felicia, Carolyn and Sara; father-in-law of David, Ari and Kurt. Devoted and beloved grandfather of Jess, Adam, Isaac, Julia, Miranda and William. Born in Brooklyn, Arthur graduated from Union College and Harvard Law School. He was an esteemed publisher in the field of professional reference publishing, most recently as the Chief Executive Officer of Civic Research Institute. Previously he served as Chairman and Founder of Rosenfeld, Emanuel Publishers; President of International Thomson Professional Publishing; President of Warren, Gorham & Lamont; President of Prentice-Hall Tax & Professional Reference Publishing; and General Counsel for the Ronald Press Company. He served at various times as a Member of the Board on six of the leading legal publishers in his profession. He loved the beaches of eastern Long Island and was an avid member of the Harvard Club, a lifelong learner and devotee of American History, and a cycling and running enthusiast. He was a kind, generous man who loved his family and friends unconditionally and who was loved by them. A funeral will be held Thursday, July 9, 2009, at 1pm at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Arthur's name to the American Civil Liberties Union.

That digital photo frame seemed like a really great holiday gift. But by now you're probably tired of driving to your parents' house to deliver a new SD card that refreshes the photos. Soon, you won't have to. In mid-October, Isabella Products will introduce a service called Vizit that will let you send photos to its 11-inch LCD digital photo frame remotely, using a cellular network.

GOLDBLATT--Stuart Samuel, born June 25, 1918, passed away July 7, 2009. Survived by his devoted wife, Jane; loving children, Donald, Nick and Florence; son-in-law, Steven; daughter-in-law, Carol; five beloved grandchildren, Elana, Diana, Rebecca, Daniel and Peri; nieces and nephews. Stuart served in WWII from February 1942 - October 1945 with the 183rd signal repair company in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. He was awarded a good conduct medal and granted an honorable discharge. Upon returning from Italy, Stuart went to Columbia University where he received his BA and MA. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa and received the first scholar-athlete award from General Dwight D. Eisenhower. Stuart married Jane Sybil Ullmann in 1949. Since the 1960s he was active with the Huntington Democratic Party. He served on the library board for Northport-East Northport for more than twenty years with a period as chairman. Stuart taught American history for more than 35 years, first at Cranford High School in NJ, then at Northport High School where he also served as chairman of the Social Studies Department and was the school's first ombudsman. He worked as a tennis pro for 14 summers in Norfolk, CT, was a tennis coach at Northport High School and a longtime member of the Northport Tennis Club. He was a gentleman and a scholar who will be missed.

SISTO--Frank. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Frank Sisto, beloved father of Daniel Sisto, President of the Healthcare Association of New York State. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Sisto family and their friends. Linda Brady, M.D., Chair Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA
Marines slept in holes in a compound Wednesday night in the Nawa district of Helmand Province in Afghanistan. A Marine offensive against the Taliban began last week in the province.

Corn has finally arrived at my favorite farm stand in New Jersey. It’s sweet and perfect cooked on the cob, but this week, Martha Rose Shulman offers five creative ways to get the most out of the all-too-short corn season.

For the last few days, a resort in Idaho has been awash in media bosses, tech entrepreneurs, bankers and the occasional sports star, as Allen & Company held its latest invitation-only gathering in Sun Valley. There was chatter about Twitter, some updates from AOL, and JPMorgan Chase‘s James B. Lee Jr. had some thoughts on the deal markets. And, of course, plenty of mogul sightings along the paths and by the duck pond.

The latest deal rumor to bubble up from the Allen & Company‘s media gabfest in Sun Valley is that French media giant Vivendi may be mulling a move to buy NBC Universal, according to a report in The New York Post.

MANCHESTER, England — There are abundant events to take in at the Manchester International Festival, but as a fan of Joe Wright’s 2005 film version of “Pride and Prejudice,” I took a detour to Pemberley, or at least its stand-in in the movie. The estate of the haughty, handsome Mr. Darcy was embodied by Chatsworth, the estate of Peregrine Cavendish, the 12th Duke of Devonshire since 2004, and the Duchess, Amanda Heywood-Lonsdale.
