In February, Andrew Kuo announced The Top Three Albums of 2009,* which included works by Antony & the Johnsons, Bonnie “Prince” Billy and Morrissey. Well, you can forget that because he’s changed his mind. Here is his new top three (as of July 10, 2009). Enlarge here.

A new art and antiques event is planned for next summer in London to take the place of the Grosvenor House Art & Antiques Fair, which announced that it was going out of business, Bloomberg News reported. The new event, to be called Masterpiece 2010, is scheduled to take place from June 25 to June 30, and its organizers are presently reaching out to art and luxury goods dealers to secure their participation. Simon Phillips, the chairman of the antiques dealer Ronald Phillips, which was formerly an exhibitor at the Grosvenor House fair, told Bloomberg that locations including the Royal Hospital Gardens in Chelsea were being considered for the Masterpiece 2010 event, but cautioned that permissions had not yet been secured. “There is a real need for this event if London wants to be capital of the art world,” Mr. Phillips said, according to Bloomberg. Last month, organizers of the 75-year-old Grosvenor House fair said it was being discontinued, citing declining profits and increasing costs.
A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

This week: Arianne Cohen, author of “The Tall Book”; Howard Blum on Richard Rayner’s “Bright and Guilty Place”; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

Assuming Trent Reznor doesn’t change his mind again, his band Nine Inch Nails has announced the dates and locations for what will be its final 10 live shows. After these concerts, “the NIN live experience will go on indefinite hiatus,” the band’s publicists said Friday in a news release. The shows are to begin on Aug. 22 at the Bowery Ballroom in New York and conclude on Sept. 6 at the Echoplex in Los Angeles. A full list of shows follows below.

It’s only July, but already one of the new fall shows is facing a long delay. NBC said Friday afternoon that its new series “Parenthood,” about the reunion of a multi-generational family in California, would be delayed until early 2010 because Maura Tierney, one of its stars, had been sidelined by an illness. The network said production would be postponed for eight weeks “due to medical evaluation” that Ms. Tierney is undergoing. Ms. Tierney was expected to play a cash-strapped daughter who returns home to live with her parents in the series, which is loosely adapted from the 1989 film of the same name. On NBC’s fall schedule, “Parenthood” will be replaced by “Mercy,” a medical drama that had been scheduled for midseason. The stars of “Mercy” “have been summoned to start work on the series early to have it ready for a September debut,” The Hollywood Reporter said.

LONDON — Oh, Gawd, the Yanks are here. Talking loudly, radiating rude good health and generally missing the point, Americans are behaving badly, though (sometimes) with good intentions, this summer in London theaters. (I mean on stage, never mind in the audience.) Even when they’re pretty, they’re ugly.

Updated | 3:52 p.m. Two new books on the hardcover list this week show how easily superheroes migrate from sci-fi to spy. “Green Lantern: Rage of the Red Lanterns” is by Geoff Johns, who continues to expand the lore of Hal Jordan, one of Earth’s representatives from the interstellar space corps known as the Green Lantern Corps. Mr. Johns has revealed that there are power rings of nearly every color stripe, including red, orange, yellow, blue and indigo. It could’ve been hokey, but it works thanks to a legion of new characters and the well-defined motivation of each new corps. It’s all leading up to “Blackest Night,” an eight-issue miniseries that begins next week.

LONDON — All through the mostly pleasurable experience of seeing “La Cage Aux Folles” at the Playhouse Theater, I found myself annoyed by a persistent, mosquito-like sound in my right ear. I identified its source as a tanned young woman in a sundress who was waywardly humming along with the songs, even the solos.
What we’re reading on Friday morning.
Which of the following stories did we completely make up?

Just when it looked like the television airwaves in Russia were safe for foul mouthed, crudely animated American children, an episode of the animated series “South Park” has been censored there to omit a scene that poked fun at the Russian prime minister Vladimir V. Putin, The Associated Press reported. On Friday, a spokesman for the Russian cable channel 2×2 said that an episode of “South Park” it had shown on Tuesday night had omitted a scene in which the show’s young characters phone Mr. Putin, seeking his help to launch a dying whale to the moon. (In the cartoon, Mr. Putin concludes that he is receiving a prank call from President George W. Bush.) The 2×2 spokesman did not indicate whether the 2×2 channel or television regulators had made the cut, telling The A.P., “the given scene in this version was absent.” Last year, Russian prosecutors issued an official warning to 2×2, saying that its broadcast of the “South Park” episode “Mr. Hankey’s Christmas Classics” promoted “hatred between religions,” but in June, a Moscow court canceled that warning.

If you had millions of dollars to spend on a tribute to Michael Jackson, what would you use it for? A museum? A statue? How about a scaled-down replica of the singer’s Neverland Ranch? A group of Chinese developers are pursuing that third option, with plans to build it on an island off Shanghai as a shrine for fans of the King of Pop, Reuters reported. Citing the China Daily newspaper, Reuters said that the developers planned to build their replica of the whimsical, Los Olivos, Calif., property on Chongming island, at a cost of about $15 million, to be completed by the 2010 Shanghai World Expo next July. Qiu Xuefan, an investor in the project, told China Daily that it was a tribute to Mr. Jackson that would “offer the Chinese people an outlet for expressing their love toward him.” Mr. Jackson lived at the Neverland Ranch until 2005. It was purchased last year by Colony Capital L.L.C. as a joint venture between that company and Mr. Jackson.
Bogotá‘s new public public transportation network, a system of sleek red buses, has improved traffic flow and reduced smog at a fraction of the cost of building a subway.
In the last 30 years, the Blackstone River has shrugged off centuries of pollution.

G.M.'s balance sheet: any color you like, as long as it's black? Maybe not yet, but the big news out of Motown is that the automaker is emerging from bankruptcy today. Will the company be able to -- in the words of chief executive Fritz Henderson -- "repay the trust and the money that so many have invested in G.M."?

The Obama Administration is considering diverting some of the $700 billion in bank bailout money to the Small Business Administration's 7(a) loan program, according to a report published Friday evening by The Washington Post. In the 7(a) program, the S.B.A. offers banks a guaranty - temporarily raised to 90 percent in the 2009 stimulus package - for loans to small firms. Borrowers get long-term loans with low monthly payments; the proceeds can be used for most business purposes.

For the last month or so I have been at the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center, drawing the performers, staff and crew of American Ballet Theatre as they go about the business of filling an empty stage. I draw in pen and ink, with no rough drafts and no starting over. Each drawing is a live reaction to the moment, a surprise to me as it appears, a trust exercise and attempt to make something ephemeral and fleeting last.

To pay for a sweeping overhaul of the health care system, House Democrats will propose a surtax on individuals earning $280,000 and up and couples earning more than $350,000, the chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee said on Friday.

We all enjoy going to the farmers markets and getting fresh produce. Now, thanks to a pilot program launched by the state Department of Human Services, families who receive food stamps can use them to pay for produce at participating farmers markets.

In a swap of under-performing right fielders, the Mets acquired Jeff Francoeur from the Atlanta Braves on Friday for Ryan Church. The Mets entered Friday five-and-a-half games behind the first-place Phillies in the National League East, and General Manager Omar Minaya said he made the trade as much to improve the team as to jolt the status quo.

There was a new air of sobriety in the beaded and brocaded world of haute couture this week, as even the daughters of oil oligarchs began to adopt the virtues of recession chic. From skirts of darkest tulle, to melancholic point d'esprit, the erstwhile master of French fancy and the latest victim of the global economic crisis, Christian Lacroix, pulled together an autumn collection on a shoestring (relatively speaking) thanks to the pro bono services rendered by loyal embroiderers, feather suppliers and shoemakers. As ever, Scorecard tallies the critics' votes. The verdict? Chapter 11 has never looked so good.

If you've heard of the Spanish city of Pamplona, it's probably because of its annual "running of the bulls" event each July - a wild free-for-all in which thousands of visitors test their survival skills against these massive and yet surprisingly fleet-footed animals. But in this weekend's Travel section, Lionel Beehner suggests that a better way to experience Pamplona is to go any other time than during the bull run - that the charms of this ancient city are best experienced when you aren't trying to dodge a bull with mayhem on his mind. Based on this past week's events, that's probably good advice. As The Times's news blog, The Lede, pointed out earlier today, a 27 year-old man was gored to death by a bull on the fourth day of the week-long festival, a tragic event captured in this explicit, grisly video. Better to take Mr. Beehner's advice: Skip the bulls and hit the tapas bars instead.

It's hard to imagine that 40 years ago, when the first Rencontres d'Arles photo festival was held, photography didn't get much love as a serious art form. Now the yearly festival, taking place this year from July 7 to Sept. 13, sees around 60,000 visitors, with 60-odd exhibitions.

President Obama received a warm welcome at the Vatican on Friday in his first meeting with Pope Benedict XVI. Indeed, the Vatican has generally seemed more eager to form a relationship with Mr. Obama than many American bishops, who have been cooler because he differs from the church on abortion and other reproductive issues. The invitation Mr. Obama received to deliver the commencement speech at the University of Notre Dame, for instance, triggered strong public condemnation from conservative bishops.
Christie’s and Sotheby’s sold 101 paintings worth £53.54 million, or about $86.7 million, in their Old Master paintings evening sales held last week.

Beckham 3.0 will launch in the United States when the Los Angeles Galaxy plays the New York Red Bulls in a Major League Soccer match Thursday at Giants Stadium. Two days before, and not by coincidence, "The Beckham Experiment: How the World's Most Famous Athlete Tried to Conquer America," by the Sports Illustrated senior writer Grant Wahl, will be available in bookstores. Wahl had unparalleled access to Beckham, his legion of austere and demanding handlers, and Galaxy players and officials since Beckham 1.0 descended on America in 2007. Wahl, who recently returned from a seven-month stay in South Africa, where his wife was working as a doctor specializing in infectious diseases, spoke with Jack Bell about Becks and the book.

For something that nobody seems to be considering anymore, there was a lot of talk Friday morning about merging the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. It came early in a hearing before two Congressional panels about regulatory changes to the complex, and often opaque, derivatives market.

These days my favorite chocolate isn't U.S.D.A. organic certified and it's not Fair Trade or Rainforest Alliance stamped. It's Madécasse, made from cacao grown in Madagascar's naturally organic forests. It's traded fairly and is environmentally friendly. Best of all, the new Madécasse 63% and 70% chocolate tastes so good -- a refreshing anomaly in a sea of astringent bitter chocolates with trendy (and often misleading) labels.

Joe Sakic unwittingly helped change the course of hockey history and the business of the game. His three-year $21 million deal in 1997, the result of an offer sheet from the Rangers that the Avalanche matched, was one of the major huge contracts that helped doom the N.H.L.-N.H.L.P.A.'s 1995 collective bargaining agreement. That pact ended the first lockout of the players by ownership in 1994, a deal that eventually sent salaries spiraling out of control and led to the second lockout, the lost season of 2004-05 and the salary cap settlement that followed.

As the new owner of Words, Maplewood's bookstore, I recently attended a week-long training course for new independent bookstore owners. When I signed up for the class, I expected a one-on-one (or perhaps a two-on-one) training. After all, even before the economy tanked, the number of these marginally-profitable (at best) businesses appeared to be dwindling. So when I received word that after my registration the class was full, I was skeptical.

The White House has described Sotomayor & Associates, the former solo law and consulting practice of the Supreme Court nominee Sonia Sotomayor, as an informal business. It operated out of her house, offering legal advice to family and friends, during a four-year period, 1983 to 1986, when she was working full-time, first as a prosecutor, then as a young associate in a Manhattan law firm, according to accounts given by the White House and the judge.

When we bought our co-op, it came with a washer and dryer. During a board-approved renovation of our apartment, we replaced the machines with newer models. Recently, new house rules were issued that say no new washers or dryers may be installed in any apartments after Dec. 31. Existing machines can remain, but if they become inoperable and cannot be repaired, they may not be replaced.

If you're heading out to Long Island this weekend, take a quick and worthwhile detour to The New General Store in Yaphank (right off Exit 67 on the L.I.E.). Tricia Foley, the interior designer and author ("At Home With Wedgwood: The Art of the Table" is her latest), has created a three-day-only summer festival of sorts, today through Sunday. Stroll through her utterly charming collection of lakeside cabins stocked with a carefully curated selection of local produce, garden supplies and all kinds of artisanal goods, from cheese and candles to aprons and bread from the celebrated hangout the Bellport. Then head down to the dock on Lily Lake for a locavore lunch from noon to 2 p.m. and a late-afternoon Long Island wine tasting from 4 to 6 p.m. Part of the proceeds from the event will go to Yaphank's Mary Louise Booth House Museum.

A good bet for enjoying Paris sans traffic congestion is to venture out on Sunday, when the city restricts many major thoroughfares to taxis and emergency vehicles, clearing the way for pedestrians and cyclists. Traffic is also down throughout August, when many Parisians are away on vacation. Paris also has nearly 200 miles of dedicated bicycle paths. And through Sept. 30, the Hilton Arc de Triomphe and Hilton Paris La Défense will do their part to encourage more cycling by offering either a guided bicycle tour or a bike rental to any guest who reserves the Go Green package. Nightly rates start at $303 (www.hilton.com).For those more interested in seeing Paris through its art museums, Hotel Jules, which bills itself as "bohemian-chic," in the Ninth Arrondissement, is including two two-day museum passes for every two nights booked. Museums accessible with the pass, which usually costs 32 euros, include the Louvre, the Musée d'Orsay, the Rodin and more than 30 others. Rates at the 100-room hotel start at $152.

PARIS - Another Hollywood moment at the couture, this one spelled out in black-and-white. At the Gaultier Paris show, the seating was designated not by number but rather by studio name. On the runway, against a backdrop of massive floodlights, ensembles inspired by some of the silver screen's greatest hits paraded by. Gaultier, of course, filtered it all through his own lens, so there were plenty of trenches, padded waists and corsets. Still, we suspect that some of the pieces he conjured could work as costumes if the studios ever decide to remake classics like Barbarella and Sunset Boulevard. It all added up to a tour of Gaultier's own private Planet Hollywood -- indeed, that was Mickey Rourke in the front row.

Classical music fans visiting Japan in late summer might be interested in the 18th annual Saito Kinen Festival from mid-August to mid-September. Founded by Seiji Ozawa, the festival was created to honor Mr. Ozawa's mentor, Hideo Saito, a cellist, composer and educator who was devoted to promoting Western classical music in Japan and who was a co-founder of the Toho Gakuen School of Music in Tokyo.The festival is in Matsumoto, home of the Matsumoto Castle, in the foothills of the Japanese Alps. It will feature performances by the Saito Kinen Orchestra, with Mr. Ozawa conducting most of the works. The performances will include Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem," with the soprano Christine Goerke and the tenor Anthony Dean Griffey. Information on Matsumoto, including lodging options, are at welcome.city.matsumoto.nagano.jp.

Savannah Wise, who has been playing the character of Sherrie in the Broadway musical “Rock of Ages” since the departure of Amy Spanger, will take over the role permanently, the show’s producers announced Thursday. Ms. Wise, whose Broadway credits include “Les Misérables,” had been understudying the role of Sherrie, the aspiring actress from Kansas whose road to Hollywood glory includes a brief detour in a Los Angeles strip club. Ms. Spanger, who originated the role in the Broadway production, had not been in the show since June 8. On June 29 the show’s publicists said Ms. Spanger had departed because of personal reasons.

Fans of Michael Jackson who have sought a place in New York to worship the fallen King of Pop have recently been short one shrine: for several days the wax figure of Mr. Jackson that stood at Madame Tussauds New York — a rendering arguably as haunting as the person it depicts — has been absent from that Times Square attraction. A spokeswoman for Madame Tussauds said the figure of Mr. Jackson, who died on June 25, was loaned on July 2 to the museum’s branch in Washington branch because fans there had requested it. She said that the wax figure would return to New York on Friday, adding, “Sometimes with shipping, sometimes there’s delays.”.

On Wednesday all four major broadcast networks posted ratings highlights that they could brag about. While NBC garnered the largest audience with “America’s Got Talent” at 9 p.m. — an average of 11.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates — Fox’s two-hour installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” (7.5 million) lifted that network to No. 1 among adults 18 to 49. And although ABC and CBS finished in a virtual tie for third place, both claimed the lead during one time slot each with ABC’s “Wipeout” ahead during the 8 p.m. hour (8.1 million) and CBS’s repeat of “CSI: NY” on top at 10 (7.2 million). Opposite “Wipeout,” NBC’s encore showing of “America’s Got Talent” drew just 6.2 million viewers while CBS’s repeats of “The New Adventures of Old Christine” and “Gary Unmarried” averaged about 4 million each. NBC’s new show “The Philanthropist” struggled at 10 p.m. with 5.1 million viewers, finishing third in that time slot behind ABC’s “Primetime: Crime” (6 million).
On Wednesday, HBO said that in December it would broadcast “Robin Williams: Weapons of Self-Destruction.” a comedy special filmed during the tour of the same name.

To bring Daniel Craig, below left, and Hugh Jackman, below right, together in a movie would probably require a budget of hundreds of millions of dollars and, perhaps, a screenplay about secret agents and mutants. To get them together on Broadway it just took a story about Chicago cops. Mr. Craig, the star of the James Bond movies “Casino Royale” and “Quantum of Solace,” and Mr. Jackman, who plays Wolverine in the “X-Men” movies, will star in the Keith Huff play “A Steady Rain” for a limited run this fall, its publicists said Thursday in a news release. The play, to be directed by John Crowley (“The Pillowman”), will run at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, with previews scheduled to begin Sept. 10 and an official run of Sept. 29 to Dec. 6. Mr. Craig, who has acted at the Royal National Theater (in “Angels in America”) and in the Peter Hall Company at the Old Vic (in “Hurlyburly”), will be making his Broadway debut. Mr. Jackman won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical in 2004 for his portrayal of Peter Allen in “The Boy From Oz.”.

WEIL--Ira Ira Weil, a scientist who worked on the Manhattan Project in World War II, died after a brief illness June 20 at his home on Manhattan's Upper West Side. He was 87. As a research chemist at several companies, he held patents for innovations in a number of areas, including detergents and skin treatment products. Ira was born in the Bronx on October 19, 1921 and grew up in Brooklyn. He graduated from New Utrecht High School and earned a BA in chemistry from Brooklyn College in 1942. While still an undergraduate, he was recruited into the Manhattan Project, where he joined his brother Lester and also met his first wife, fellow scientist Adele Rubenstein. After the war, he completed his doctorate in physical chemistry at Columbia University and moved to Cambridge, MA, where he was an instructor in chemistry at Harvard University. Following Adele Weil's death in 1950, he returned to New York and spent the rest of his career as a research chemist in the private sector, briefly as head of his own company and later at Lever Brothers (now Unilever) until his retirement in 1986. In 1958 he married Alice Ehrenfeld of New York, a lawyer, who as Alice E. Weil rose to be the highest-ranking woman to serve in the United Nations, as Assistant Secretary General for General Services. An outspoken, independent-minded liberal and veteran of many peace and civil rights demonstrations, Ira grew increasingly pessimistic about his country's direction in recent years, but happily, he lived to witness and thoroughly relish the Democratic landslide of 2008. In retirement, he maintained a decades-long enthusiasm for opera and theater and added new interests, including birding in Central Park and, until her death in 1996, frequent overseas trips with Alice, whose work required extensive foreign travel. We will remember him warmly as a wise and steadfast friend and as an engaging and cheerfully opinionated raconteur and conversationalist, with a rich fund of memories from his boyhood in Depression-Era Brooklyn as well as some alarmingly colorful tales from the realms of science and industry. Ira is survived by a sister, Edna, of Fort Worth, TX; two brothers, Lester, of Menlo Park, CA, and Sanford, of Canton, NY; a son from his first marriage, Eric, of Newton, MA; two children from his second marriage, Jonathan, of Seattle, and Ann, of Walpole, NH; and his beloved grandchild, Ann's daughter Alice. He was a member of Sigma Xi, Phi Lambda Upsilon and the American Chemical Society. A private burial service was held at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, on June 22.

MARKS--David V. P.,54, of Manhattan, passed away on July 8, 2009. Beloved son of the late Margaret and John Marks, he was the cherished brother of Michael Marks and the late Laura Marks, the brother-in-law of Jill Darrow, and the loving uncle of Katie and John Marks, whom he adored. David was privileged to attend The Dalton School; Harvard College, where he studied economics under Nobel laureates Kenneth Arrow and Wassily Leontief and graduated summa cum laude; Harvard Law School, where he received his J.D. degree, cum laude; and the Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, where he studied under Nobel laureate Thomas Schelling and received his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees in economics. David's scholarly publications include "Competition in the Investment Banking Industry" (Harvard University Press), co-authored with Harvard Business School Professors Samuel L. Hayes, III and A. Michael Spence, and "Signposting: The Selective Revelation of Product Information" (Harvard Business School Press), co-authored with Kennedy School of Government Professor Richard J. Zeckhauser. David was a member of the bar in Massachusetts and New York. David began his business career as President of The GMS Group, Inc., a strategic consulting firm that he formed with two Harvard Law School professors to furnish advice to firms in the financial services sector. Later, David was President of an independent music publishing company, St. Nicholas Music Inc., and was a private investor in intellectual property, securities, fine art and other assets. David's interests were numerous and varied. He studied and collected Renaissance and 19th century Renaissance revival decorative arts, arms and armor, and furnishings. He was a longtime student of the history of New York architecture, especially its residential architecture. He served on the boards of various preservation organizations including Carnegie Hill Neighbors, the Defenders of the Historic Upper East Side, and the Historic Neighborhood Enhancement Alliance. David was active in The Episcopal Chaplaincy at Harvard for 30 years, including serving as Finance Committee Member, Treasurer, Vice President and, most recently, President. David's quest for perfection in everything he did was an inspiration to all who knew him. He also encouraged and cultivated perfection in all of those around him, the end result of which was a litany of enduring friendships. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, July 13, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in David's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue New York, NY 10065, www.mskcc.org.

TOBIN--Gary. The faculty and Board of CLAL-The National Jewish Center for Learning and Leadership extends its deepest condolences to Diane, Adam, Amy, Sarah, Aryeh, Mia, Jonah, and Josiah on the terrible loss of Dr. Gary Tobin, loving and dedicated husband, father, and grandfather. The Jewish people has lost one of its most visionary, courageous, creative, wise, passionate, and loving scholar- activist- community builders. No one in Jewish life has done more to nurture a more inclusive paradigm of Jewish peoplehood for the 21st Century. Gary was not only a leader and our teacher, he was our dear friend. We honor his memory by continuing his work, bringing every Jew, wherever they live, however hidden or disconnected and however they practice, into the one Jewish People Gary so loved. Rabbi Irwin Kula, President Rabbi Brad Hirschfield, President Larry Gellman, Chairman

SCHNELLING--Anthony (Tony) H. N.,Founder and CEO of Bridge Associates LLC, a Noted Turnaround and Restructuring Firm, dies at 62. Tony Schnelling spent his life crossing and then creating bridges. He rode through the Khyber Pass at 12 and when he was 42, he spent three months riding horseback in Mongolia, ultimately convincing the herders that American men could not only ride but also wrestle. He spoke six languages fluently. His facility with languages, including multiple dialects of German, allowed him to bring a bit of home to a German woman who found herself waiting tables in Boise, Idaho. While at college, he bridged the chasm between athletics and academia by graduating from Swarthmore College while being recognized as an All American soccer player. After earning an MBA from Harvard University in 1972, he built a bridge to renewed profitability for the faltering family printing business. Tony then realized he needed a new challenge and went to Fordham Law School at the age of 41, graduating cum laude. After law school, Tony joined the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan, where his practice encompassed both general corporate and insolvency law. He represented corporate debtors, secured lenders and creditors in bankruptcy cases and out-of-court restructurings in a variety of jurisdictions and industries in the United States and Europe. But again he saw another path. In 1997, he founded a boutique financial consulting firm aptly enough named Bridge Associates LLC specializing in advising businesses in all aspects of financial restructuring. Over the next decade, he built the firm into a leading professional services organization focused on providing advisory, crisis and interim management and litigation support. He also acted as a trustee in a number of cases, leading the recovery of tens of millions of dollars for creditors. Tony's engagements as a turnaround and restructuring specialist included such high profile cases as Refco, Heilig-Meyers and Conseco Finance to name just a few. But even as a re-structuring professional, Tony continued to build bridges, including one in Calpine, Inc., where he was retained as a Court appointed expert by the Honorable Burton Lifland and eventually bridged the seemingly insurmountable gap between the numerous constituencies leading to a consensual resolution. At the time of his death, the firm had seven partners and 40 professionals in offices located in New York, NY; Tulsa, OK; Chicago, IL; Dallas, TX; Cleveland, OH; Nashville, TN and Tampa, FL. Tony never stopped tapping out messages and making calls on his omnipresent Blackberry. From his beloved home in Amenia, New York, he worked on client and firm matters until the time of his death, taking conference calls from his bedroom, and continuing to provide sage counsel and strategy to clients and colleagues until the end. When long time friend and partner, Carl Young, asked Tony to take it easy, Tony's answer was, "Carl, I am going to be asleep for a long time - this is more fun." David N. Phelps, another of Tony's partners, stated, "Not only in business, but in every aspect of his life, he was loved by a wide range of people and admired by an even bigger circle. I know I speak for all of his partners, colleagues, clients and friends when I say we will miss him dearly." Tony was described by those who were close to him as a visionary who warned about the current economic crisis, but who also had a gift to see novel and innovative solutions, where others saw problems and roadblocks. "He could look at an abandoned paper mill sitting on top of a toxic waste site and could see a recreational marina," said Louis Robichaux, a partner of Tony's. Even after leaving the practice of law, Tony continued to strengthen the connection between law and business, becoming an Adjunct Professor at Fordham University School of Law, as well as a member of the School's Board of Directors. Additionally, he founded the Anthony Schnelling Scholarship Fund, awarded to students entering law school after being in the workforce for several years. He also taught at Columbia University's School of Business in New York and at the Jones Graduate School at Rice University in Houston. He served as the Vice President of Development for the American Bankruptcy Institute and was a member of the organization's Board of Directors. He was recently elected by his peers as a Fellow of the American College of Bankruptcy. Tony is a past member of the Board of Directors of The Pomfret School and was also a long-term supporter of Canine Companions for Independence, which honored him with their Hearts and Heroes Award for his fund raising efforts. There are many words to describe Tony but his wife, Bettina Whyte put it best. "Tony was amazing. In his life, in his work, in his intellectual abilities, in his compassion, in his commitment to friends and family - he was simply amazing." He is survived by his wife, Bettina M. Whyte, and his mother, Emily Leeser. He also leaves behind his half-sister, Eva Claire Schnelling of Houndstooth, England. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that donations be made to The Anthony Schnelling Lectureship Series in Commercial Bankruptcy at Fordham University School of Law.

8 P.M. (TCM) MEMORIAL TRIBUTE: KARL MALDENTurner Classic Movies salutes Mr. Malden, who died on July 1, by screening films with three of his most memorable roles. First up: ''On the Waterfront'' (1954), for which he earned a supporting-actor Oscar nomination for his portrayal of the militant priest Father Barry (above left, with Marlon Brando and Eva Marie Saint), who urges Terry Malloy, Brando's boxer turned longshoreman, to testify against the corrupt union boss Johnny Friendly (Lee J. Cobb). In ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' (1951), at 10, Mr. Malden also appeared with Brando and won the supporting-actor Oscar for his lovelorn Mitch, a bachelor who looks after his mother. And in ''Birdman of Alcatraz'' (1962), at 12:15 a.m., he plays Harvey Shoemaker, a prison warden and the nemesis of Burt Lancaster's Robert Stroud, a lifer who becomes an expert on birds. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The actors Daniel Radcliffe and Rupert Grint (''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince'') are guests; Rascal Flatts performs; discussions about shopping and the brain, dogs at work, and food storage.

Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan said Thursday that Turkey would grant a visa to Rebiya Kadeer, a Uighur political activist, if she wanted to travel to Turkey. On Wednesday, Ms. Kadeer said in an interview that her visa applications to visit Turkey in 2006 and 2007 had been denied, an assertion that Mr. Erdogan did not address on Thursday. Turkey has been active in supporting Uighurs in western China, where deadly clashes broke out this week between Uighurs, who are Muslim, and Han Chinese. About 300,000 Uighurs live in Turkey, Foreign Ministry figures show.

GAGE--Alan Kenneth, age 91, passed away at home in Manhattan on July 8, 2009. Born September 3, 1917 he was a lifelong resident of New York City. Alan was a 1935 graduate of Riverdale Country School and the longest serving class agent, receiving several President's Cups for enlisting the highest percentage of donors of any class. A 1939 graduate of Yale University, he served as chair of the class agents and on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund. In 1954 he began a career on Wall Street, later becoming president of Parrish & Company. He was most recently a Senior Vice President - Wealth Management/ Senior Portfolio Manger at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. He also served as President of the Wall Street Financial Forum. He was a member of The Brick Presbyterian Church since 1962, serving as a Deacon and Trustee and spear headed its Evangelism Outreach Program, leading many to a relationship with Jesus Christ. He was also a member of the Yale Club, the Colony Club and the Dancers. Alan is survived by his daughters Heidi Jenkins and Victoria Rose, and their husbands Robert Jenkins and William Rose, four grandchildren Anabelle and Lucas Jenkins and Douglas Rose and Courtney Jeffus and their spouses Kaitlin Rose and Tyson Jeffus. Also surviving are his sister-in-law Suzanne Gage and niece and nephew Linda O'Connor and Thomas Gage, and three stepchildren; Bonnie Weyher McLamb, Harry Weyher and Laura Hall. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 2pm Monday, July 13, 2009. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

MacLAURY--Ian. Ian Geoffrey Robin MacLaury - artist and illustrator of great whimsy, and prolific philatelist - had his final closing in the morning of Monday, July 6, 2009, at the Westerly Hospital, surrounded by family, dear friends, and life companion, Kathleen Harkins. His struggle with cancer was conducted with great courage and stoicism, greater, perhaps, than loved ones may have wished. Born on Jan. 6, 1952, in Charlottesville, VA, Ian grew up in Manhattan, attended some of the best preparatory schools on the east coast, and cemented his calling at the Art Student's League of New York. A member of MENSA, the Salamagundi Club of New York, Westerly Artist's Cooperative, and the Association of Marine Artists; he was also listed in the New York Social Register. His vast body of work included the design and illustration of more than 500 postage stamps for 17 different countries, as well as hundreds of paintings, marked by exhaustive research and painstaking detail. Ian's art has appeared internationally, in galleries, books, magazines, and newspapers. His recent works centered around his eccentric humor and delight in puns. Gorillas, tropical fish, and Barbie dolls were highly recognizable at art shows from Maine to Florida, including the annual Mystic Outdoor Art Festival. Ian was much loved and admired for his prodigious talent, uncommon intellect, and quirky humor. Blending easily in all crowds, whether wearing paint splattered shorts, seersucker or a tuxedo, he found the words to engage any individual into detailed, knowledgeable conversation. He is survived by his mother, Daphne Riley, of Santa Fe., N.M.; his sister, Timothea Sampson, her husband, David, and children, Travis Comstedt, Ben and Jeremy Sampson; his sister, Celia Strebendt, and her family Chuck, Nicolas, Christoher and Robert Strebendt. Ian also leaves behind his life's love, Kathleen Harkins, and a myriad of friends encompassing artists, sailors, and admirers from all elements of society. Ian was predeceased by his sister, Diana Johnson, and step-father, Edgar Riley. Please join us for a service at 2pm on Friday, July 10, at the Calvary Church, 27 Church St., Stonington, followed by a celebration of his extraordinary life, from 4 to 8pm at the LaGrua Center, 32 Water St., Stonington, CT.

Growing up Greenwich, CT, she attended the Greenwich Academy and later Miss Hall's School, Class of 1931. In 1941, she married J. Franklin Van Deren. Mr. Van Deren passed away in 1974. She was predeceased by her husband, Constable MacCracken of New Caanan, CT in 1995. She was an extraordinary lady of many talents, a member and judge of the Greenfingers Garden Club, the New Caanan Sewing Group, and the North Woods Club of Minerva, NY. A cherished mother to Nancy Van Deren (James Burnett) of Spencertown, NY and John F. Van Deren III (Jane) of Montpelier, VT, her stepchildren Thomas MacCracken (Alexandra) of Oakton, VA and New York City and Linda MacCracken of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY. Loved and fondly remembered for her generosity, spirit and devotion to her grandchildren, Jessica Van Deren Herlihy (Daniel) of New Haven, CT and John F. The Obama administration warned Americans on Thursday to be ready for an aggressive return of the swine flu virus in the fall, announcing plans to begin vaccinations in October and offering states and hospitals money to help them prepare. ''The potential for a significant outbreak in the fall is looming,'' President Obama said by telephone link from Italy to the White House's H1N1 Influenza Preparedness Summit, held at the National Institutes of Health.

PERRON--Dorothy, Ph.D. A vibrant woman of boundless energy, she loved life and loved her children. She was a dancer, artist's model, teacher, peace activist, epidemiologist, and gerontologist. She opened a dance school and founded Salute to Women in the Arts in NJ, and founded Seniors Reaching Out in Santa Fe. One of her many jobs was assisting Margaret Mead; another was working to prove that asbestos workers were at risk for cancer. She taught us to fearlessly follow our interests and to value art and culture. Her passionate engagement in life inspired everyone around her. She is survived by her children: Reed, Wendy, Pamela, and Margot and their spouses; her grandchildren: Deborah, Catita, Isabel, Nicholas, C.J., Beryl, Levi, Shayna, Opal; and her great-grandchild, Lucia. We all stand stronger because of the love she lavished on us.

ANAHEIM, Calif. -- Joba Chamberlain has made 29 starts in his major league career. He has 10 decisions. According to the Elias Sports Bureau, that is the fewest decisions through a pitcher's first 29 starts in history.
Instead of developing, Joba Chamberlain seems to be regressing, as he gave up five runs in five innings before being removed in the Yankees’ loss to the Angels.

ANAHEIM, Calif. -- There were two things Friday I've never seen before, both involving Jorge Posada. After he drew a walk as a pinch-hitter in the seventh inning, the Yankees pulled catcher Jose Molina for another pinch-hitter, Hideki Matsui. That meant Posada would be staying in to catch. So when the Angels changed pitchers, Posada left the base, grabbed a glove, and played long toss for a few minutes to loosen his arm. Nothing too special, just odd -- a base runner pausing to sneak in a few practice throws.

An article on Page 36 this weekend about David Cameron, the Conservative Party leader in Britain, refers incorrectly to a coal miners’ strike there in 1974. The strike did not in fact involve “violent protests.” (A miners’ strike in 1972 had sporadic violence.).

An article on Tuesday about new structural uses of glass referred incorrectly to glass staircases that are a feature of Apple Stores. While many high-profile Apple Stores have such a staircase, there is not one in every store. And a graphic with the article misidentified a substance used as a layer between some joints in the glass observation boxes at the Sears Tower. It is silicone, a rubberlike compound containing silicon — not silicon itself, a nonmetallic chemical element. A corrected version of the graphic can be found at nytimes.com/science.

Because of an editing error, an art review on Thursday about the exhibition “Living and Dreaming,” at the Bronx Museum, referred incorrectly to the artist whose sculpture “Lawn” is in the show. The artist, Jessie Henson, is a woman.

An article on Wednesday about Boeing’s purchase of a plant that makes a critical part of its 787 Dreamliner erroneously attributed a distinction to the aircraft in some copies. While it will be the company’s most sophisticated plane, it will not be the largest. That distinction will belong to the Boeing 747-8, which is also under development.

An article on June 29 about the difficulties of fairly calculating the value of claims by victims of the Bernard L. Madoff Ponzi scheme — the task of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation and of Irving H. Picard, the court-appointed trustee overseeing the claims process — erroneously attributed a paraphrase of an opinion to one victim. That investor, Sherry Morse, avoided commenting directly about S.I.P.C. or Mr. Picard; she did not liken Mr. Picard’s definition of net equity, a key component in determining losses, to class baiting.

An article on Friday about gifts totaling $96,000 given by the parents of Senator John Ensign to his former lover and three members of her family referred incorrectly to taxes on individual gifts over $12,000. Any tax obligations are the responsibility of the donors, not the recipients of gifts.

If you had millions of dollars to spend on a tribute to Michael Jackson, what would you use it for? A museum? A statue? How about a scaled-down model of the singer’s Neverland Ranch? A group of Chinese developers is pursuing that option, with plans to build it on an island off Shanghai as a shrine for fans of the King of Pop, Reuters reported. Citing the newspaper China Daily, Reuters said that the developers hoped to build it on Chongming Island at a cost of about $15 million, to be completed by the 2010 Shanghai World Expo next July. Qiu Xuefan, an investor in the project, told China Daily that it was a tribute to Jackson that would “offer the Chinese people an outlet for expressing their love toward him.” Jackson lived at Neverland, in Los Olivos, Calif., until 2005. It was purchased last year by Colony Capital as a joint venture with Jackson.

GAGE--Alan Kenneth, age 91, passed away at home in Manhattan on July 8, 2009. Born September 3, 1917 he was a lifelong resident of New York City. Alan was a 1935 graduate of Riverdale Country School and the longest serving class agent, receiving several President's Cups for enlisting the highest percentage of donors of any class. A 1939 graduate of Yale University, he served as chair of the class agents and on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund. In 1954 he began a career on Wall Street, later becoming president of Parrish & Company. He was most recently a Senior Vice President - Wealth Management/ Senior Portfolio Manger at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. He also served as President of the Wall Street Financial Forum. He was a member of The Brick Presbyterian Church since 1962, serving as a Deacon and Trustee and spear headed its Evangelism Outreach Program, leading many to a relationship with Jesus Christ. He was also a member of the Yale Club, the Colony Club and the Dancers. Alan is survived by his daughters Heidi Jenkins and Victoria Rose, and their husbands Robert Jenkins and William Rose, four grandchildren Anabelle and Lucas Jenkins and Douglas Rose and Courtney Jeffus and their spouses Kaitlin Rose and Tyson Jeffus. Also surviving are his sister-in-law Suzanne Gage and niece and nephew Linda O'Connor and Thomas Gage, and three stepchildren; Bonnie Weyher McLamb, Harry Weyher and Laura Hall. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 2pm Monday, July 13, 2009. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

AUGUST--Ralph H.,age 77, of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ died Thursday, July 9, 2009 surrounded by his family. Born in the Bronx, NY he lived in Franklin Lakes, before moving to Ho-Ho-Kus 16 years ago. Ralph was owner of August Fabrics, Fairview, NJ. He was a dedicated Giants fan and enjoyed driving high performance boats and cars. He was a member of the S. Minneford Yacht Club, City Island, New York. He shared his passion for life with his beloved wife of 43 years, Susan (nee McAuley) August, his loving children, Nina August, Cathy Blaustein, Andrea Smith, Robert August, John August and Kristi Lowenthal as well as his eight grandchildren. The family will receive friends on Sunday, July 12 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, www.vpfh.com, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. A Service of Remembrance will be held on Monday, 11am at the Funeral Home. Private cremation was held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, New York 10087, for Prostate Cancer.

BABBIN--Malcolm J.,on July 10, 2009. Loving father of Jennifer and her husband Bill Clark and James Babbin. Adoring grandfather of Ben and Stephanie Clark. Devoted brother of Chester Babbin and Norma Horowitz. Beloved companion of Joan Greene. Husband of the late Fredlyn Goodman. He will be deeply missed by all who loved him. Funeral service Sunday, July 12th, 1pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

Firefighters extinguished a fire that ignited about 5 a.m. Friday on scaffolding on the Throgs Neck Bridge. Officials said a work crew had been using welding equipment there, but no cause was immediately cited. Bridge traffic was closed for much of the day.

NOWAK--Milton, on July 10, 2009. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Judi and Alan, Eddie, Ken and Joan. Adoring grandfather of Evan, Gabriel, Alex and Sam. Service Sunday, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

FRIEDMAN--Priscilla A.,66, passed away on July 9, 2009. It was my privilege to love and be loved by her. Priscilla was beautiful not only of body but of mind and spirit. She brought a special light into a room with her quick wit and energy. She touched so many lives and was loved by so many. She valued each and every friend. She will be remembered and missed by all. She is survived by her loving husband, Sol; children, Jordan Seth and Jill Victoria, Carrie, son-in-law Rob, Steven, daughter-in-law Rachel; mother, Helen; sister, Lynn; brother-in-law, Joel; grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Priscilla and I laughed, cried and shared over 30 years of friendship. Those memories are cherished and I will miss her forever, Monica.

FRIEDMAN--Priscilla, passed away on July 9, 2009 after a courageous battle with cancer. She was a radiant beauty whose warmth, wit, intelligence and compassion endeared her to all who knew her. She will be sorely missed by her family and many friends. Priscilla is survived by Sol, her husband of 43 years, her children Jordan, Jill, Stephen (wife Rachel), Carrie Megan (husband Rob), her grandchildren Andrea, Lydia and Elyse Friedman, and Emma, Julia and Evan Megan, her mother Helen Michelson and her sister Lynn l'Hommedieu; as well as her beloved brother-in-law Joel Friedman. Service will be on Monday, July 13 at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

PERRON--Dorothy, Ph.D. A vibrant woman of boundless energy, she loved life and loved her children. She was a dancer, artist's model, teacher, peace activist, epidemiologist, and gerontologist. She opened a dance school and founded Salute to Women in the Arts in NJ, and founded Seniors Reaching Out in Santa Fe. One of her many jobs was assisting Margaret Mead; another was working to prove that asbestos workers were at risk for cancer. She taught us to fearlessly follow our interests and to value art and culture. Her passionate engagement in life inspired everyone around her. She is survived by her children: Reed, Wendy, Pamela, and Margot and their spouses; her grandchildren: Deborah, Catita, Isabel, Nicholas, C.J., Beryl, Levi, Shayna, Opal; and her great-grandchild, Lucia. We all stand stronger because of the love she lavished on us.

MacCRACKEN--Harriet L.,96, of Meadow Ridge, Redding, CT, passed away on July 4, 2009. Harriet was born in New York City on January 13, 1913. Daughter of Wallace Foster and Jesse Burke Lyons. Growing up Greenwich, CT, she attended the Greenwich Academy and later Miss Hall's School, Class of 1931. In 1941, she married J. Franklin Van Deren. Mr. Van Deren passed away in 1974. She was predeceased by her husband, Constable MacCracken of New Caanan, CT in 1995. She was an extraordinary lady of many talents, a member and judge of the Greenfingers Garden Club, the New Caanan Sewing Group, and the North Woods Club of Minerva, NY. A cherished mother to Nancy Van Deren (James Burnett) of Spencertown, NY and John F. Van Deren III (Jane) of Montpelier, VT, her stepchildren Thomas MacCracken (Alexandra) of Oakton, VA and New York City and Linda MacCracken of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY. Loved and fondly remembered for her generosity, spirit and devotion to her grandchildren, Jessica Van Deren Herlihy (Daniel) of New Haven, CT and John F. Van Deren IV of New York City, and her step-granddaughters Paige Ioppolo of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY and Annie Hults and Caitlin Ryan both of New York City. A memorial service will be held on July 22, 3pm at Meadow Ridge, 100 Redding Rd., Redding, CT 06896. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

CALAMITA--Frank, died peacefully in his sleep in Warwickshire, England on Sunday, June 28, 2009. Born in Brooklyn to Nicola and Grace Calamita, Mr. Calamita moved to Manhattan as a young man and joined CBS Records in 1962. On September 3, 1966 he was married to Alyda Jansen. Their only child, Nicolas Jansen, was born in 1968. In his career of over 40 years Mr. Calamita was a senior executive with CBS Records and later with Sony Music Entertainment, and served on the boards of numerous charitable organizations including The American Management Association and the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center. The Calamita's maintained homes in Manhattan and Bellport, LI. Alyda Jansen Calamita was deceased on April 27, 2000. Mr. Calamita is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Nancy S. Eisenhauer, who are both academics in Oxford, England and their son, Nicolas Johannes Ides Calamita. In addition he is survived by the families of his late sister Angela Schiralli and Ann Iorio. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, July 13, 2009 at 10:30am at Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church, 113 Baxter St., NYC. Burial will be private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in Mr. Calamita's memory to The Association for Children with Down Syndrome (ACDS), 4 Fern Place, Plainview, NY 11803-4725 or Cancer Research UK, Halifax Road, Melksham, SN12 6YY, United Kingdom. A web page at Cancer Research UK has also been created in Frank's memory.

STEIN--Sophie, 98, of White Plains, NY died peacefully on July 9, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Cherished mother of Stuart and Rhona (Ronald Noll). Doting grandmother of Dr. Rachel Noll (Jeremy Bastacky) and Robert Noll. Predeceased by her parents, Louis and Ray Lertzman, and sisters Ida Lertzman and Katy Rosenthal (Buddy). Loved and respected by all who knew her. Shiva will be observed at the Noll home in New York. A graveside service will be held on Sunday, July 12 at 11am in the Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, Farmingdale, NY.

My Sunday column is focused on one man's efforts to build a new aid group, charity: water, but more broadly it's about how we can connect those who want to give with those who need the help. It's this great abyss in modern life: So many people in rich countries would like to help but fret about corruption, waste and aid bureaucracies, and so their money doesn't find its way across the chasm to those who desperately need the help. And as I've argued in the past, I think the messaging from aid groups is often strikingly ineffective.

To the Editor: I just read “The Soaring Cost of Car Rentals” (June 28) and find it hard to understand. I rented a car from June 17, 2009, and returned it on June 23. Without any coupons or special deals and including picking up the car at one airport and returning it to another 800 miles away, I paid $113. This included all taxes, fees and whatever else was tacked on. The car was a Chevrolet Impala. I did turn down all the voluntary charges.

Peggy Orenstein fears that Skype will rob relationships of the intimate quality afforded by traditional means of communication. This need not be the case. Our daughter attends college in a remote area where cellphone service is unavailable. With Skype we enjoy real-time communication that is no more invasive than a phone call and far more satisfying than e-mail. I have not abandoned note-writing, e-mailing or telephone chats with friends and family. I simply choose which mode suits the occasion. I text my teenage son to come downstairs for dinner, since that seems to work best. Then we sit around the kitchen table and talk.

I’m grateful to Jonathan Mahler for showing the real people behind the American auto industry. Both sides of my family were brought out of poverty with the help of G.M. and the rest of the auto industry; I grew up in relative privilege, with good health care, access to a state-university education, even a reliable car. My parents and grandparents were able to retire. I can only hope that those Americans who have begrudged such hardworking families their middle-class lifestyles and the ability to send their children to college will read this story of one family and see that the collapse of American industry affects us all.Dallas.

DIVING INTO A CENOTE ON HER 30TH BIRTHDAY, VALLADOLID, YUCATÁN, MEXICO, FEB. 22, 2009 Jenny Ivansson, a lighting designer from Vaxjo, Sweden, now living in New York. ''The plan was to get away from New York in February. We had gone to Chichén Itzá, the Mayan ruins, and ended up somewhere in between there and Tulum. From what I understand, cenotes are formed when underground water breaks down the stone to create these sinkholes. I had never heard of them before, but they turned out to be everywhere. People even had them in their backyards. This one was in the middle of a sleepy little Mexican town. I just decided to jump in. You know when you've been in the sun all day, your body is sort of swollen and you're exhausted? It felt liberating, the end of a nice birthday -- which I normally spend in Sweden or New York, where it's freaking cold. When we were leaving, I recognized some Norwegians arriving -- the language is very easy for us to understand. But you just pretend you don't know what they're saying. I said ''Enjoy'' in English. They arrived the same way as I did -- thinking it was incredibly exotic and special -- and I didn't want to ruin their moment.'' As told to Seth Kugel

BALCHUN--George Jacob, Jr.,67, passed away on June 20, 2009. Born October 18, 1941, he was the son of the late George Jacob Balchun and Betty Niven Balchun, Shickshinny, PA. George attended Wilkes College and New York University and was employed for 27 years at NBC, where he was in business management with NBC Sports. He is survived by his brother Barry D. Balchun of Los Angeles, CA and companion of 47 years Peter F. Hanes of Westbrook, CT. He was predeceased by his brother Kerry B. Balchun of East Hampton, NY. Burial service and interment at 3pm on Saturday, July 25th at St. Bartholomew's Church in New York City. In lieu of flowers, it is suggested that contributions be made to St. Bartholomew's Church, 325 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10022

SALTZ--Ruth. It is with great sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of Ruth Saltz, July 9, 2009. Beloved wife of Sam Saltz, mother of Marcella Saltz and Gail Snyder, proud grandmother of Gambrelle Snyder. A well-known handbag designer and artist. warm, loving, generous, she was a source of great delight to all who knew her. She took pleasure in all of her moments. Ruth Saltz will be deeply missed.

One of our readers put us to work with ''Assign the Journalist,'' a regular blog feature. The reader was curious about the designated ''low-speed vehicle'' parking near the Maplewood train station. Here's what we discovered: This initiative, by the Maplewood Township Committee, was intended to encourage residents to consider buying a low-speed vehicle rather than a regular car.

LARKIN--Lawrence F.,Jr., of Collier Township, PA, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, passed away peacefully on June 12, 2009. A lifelong educator, his work changed the lives of generations of school children and was cited on numerous occasions in oral argument before the US Supreme Court. Mr. Larkin's career in education began in the classrooms of NYC and took him to the NYC Board of Education where for 35 years he sought to improve the educational prospects of children from underserved communities. He retired as the Director of Special Projects in 1993. Born on April 8, 1937, the beloved son of Lawrence and Antoinette Larkin, he was a 1954 graduate of All Hallows High School, received his BS from Fordham University in 1958 and his MS from Yeshiva University in 1967. He was the adoring husband of Rita J. Larkin; the proud and loving father of Kristen (Brian) Stewart and Ann (Bill) Fichter, the devoted brother of Ellen M. Lane and the late Patricia A. Larkin; the doting grandfather of Caroline Stewart; and a cherished uncle of many nieces and nephews. A Mass of Christian Burial was celebrated on June 16th at St. Barbara Church in Bridgeville PA, where he was laid to his final rest.

FREEDMAN--Henry H.,died June 19, 2009 in Princeton, NJ. Born in New York City, he retired from AstraZeneca as Corporate Vice-President for Pharmaceutical Research and Development, and Regulatory Affairs. He was previously employed at Warner-Lambert, and also served as President of the Reticuloendothelial Society. He is survived by his wife, Barbara W. Freedman, of Princeton, his son, Jonathan E. Freedman, of Boston, and his sister-in-law, Gabriella Freedman, of West Palm Beach, Florida.

SUSSILLO--Gerard F.,on July 11, 2009. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:30am Our Lady of Angels Church, burial Calverton National Cemetery.

WITH its ample supply of moody, somewhat amorphous clothing, Oak tends to cater to experimental individuals. A.OK, its cleverly named new auxiliary shop, is decidedly more accessible. Housed in the basement of the Oak boutique in NoHo, and in the back of the Williamsburg shop, it is stocked with playful, predominantly 1980s-leaning pieces (some vintage and some from lesser-known designers): cotton bandage dresses, denim button-downs, Indian beaded clutches, Guatemalan jazz shoes. Best yet, prices top out at $275. A.OK, 28 Bond Street (between Lafayette and Bowery); 208 North Eighth Street (between Driggs Avenue and

MANN--Paul Jay, son of the late Ruth Mann and late jazz flutist, Herbie Mann, passed away Friday, July 3rd, while stand up paddling on the Columbia River in Hood River, Oregon. Paul was an avid windsurfer and sportsman with an infectious smile, a quick mind and wit, and boundless energy who inspired loyalty and laughter in those around him. He was also a lover of fine music and wine. Truly, he was too many different things to too many different people to list them all properly, but the common thread that ran through was that, above all, he was a "loved one". He will be sorely missed. Paul is survived by his aunt Judy Bernstein, his sisters, Claudia and Laura, his brother, Geoffrey, his stepmothers, Jan and Janeal, his girlfriend, Michelle, and numerous other friends and family. A memorial service will be held in San Francisco on Sunday, July 19th. For more information, please visit www.paulmann.typepad.com

ANN ZIEBELL, a former antiques dealer, has seen a lot of spectacular collectibles over the years. But nothing quite like a 1930s Austrian crystal shoe buckle she found in a little shop in St. Petersburg, Fla. ''I thought, this is something I can make modern,'' she said. And so began her line of dazzling costume jewelry, fashioned from Art Deco brooches, buckles and fur clips, affixed to heavy copper chains. Guilty pleasure? Not necessarily. As Ms. Ziebell put it, ''You get a whole lot of bang for your buck.'' Ann Ziebell jewelry, $500 to $2,000 at kirnazabete.com.
GRAU--Gideon, violinist and symphony conductor, died June 29, 2009, at 86. Admired as a keen intellectual and great musician. Contact son: JonGrau@comcast.net

I was standing against the door of a No. 1 train one recent evening around 7 as it moved downtown from 79th Street. A young woman, maybe 18, was standing against the opposite door. She slapped her daughter, who looked to be about 4. I looked away. Then she hit the child again. And again, and again. Are these beatings? Are they discipline? What's the difference?

When the Mets rookie Fernando Martinez went on the disabled list last week, it might have been the best thing for his career. Martinez, 20, in the majors only because of a raft of injuries, was hitting .176 and swinging at balls at his eyes. Manager Jerry Manuel said that if Martinez's struggles continued, the organization risked damaging his confidence for the long term. The Marlins found themselves in a similar position with outfielder Cameron Maybin, a top prospect. Maybin, 22, was hitting .202 in May when he was sent to Class AAA New Orleans. It was his second failed trip to the big leagues; he hit .143 in 24 games for Detroit in 2007.

No business wants to invest in a place where the government skims 20 percent off the top, or the head of the port authority is corrupt. No person wants to live in a society where the rule of law gives way to the rule of brutality and bribery. That is not democracy, that is tyranny, and now is the time for it to end.

The adage ''sell in May and stay away'' has been a sound guide to the stock market so far. For the fourth consecutive week, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined, and it closed on Friday down more than 7 percent since peaking on June 12. Until that point, the market had surged 40 percent above its March lows, although it remained far below its levels of the previous year.

THE TREASURE HUNTER Jack Fortmeyer, 69, a retired firefighter, began collecting old bottles in the 1960s when he bought a box full at an upstate yard sale for $5. Ever since, he has been foraging in Brooklyn backyards in search of 18th- and 19th-century specimens tossed into abandoned outhouses, which he calls ''pits.'' He gets a rush of anticipation that can keep him awake the night before a dig. After identifying a promising location, Mr. Fortmeyer begins the excavation process by probing the soil with a pointed steel pole to locate the cistern or privy. In the early days, a fellow collector showed Mr. Fortmeyer how to make probes from scrap metal found in abandoned cars; he now buys them from a steel manufacturer. He digs in private yards and offers the homeowners their pick of the artifacts he finds, but he said they rarely keep any because ''they see how hard we work.'' Mr. Fortmeyer is known to his fellow bottle diggers as ''Fireman Jack.'' He and his wife, Delores, raised their children on Long Island but moved to Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, after Mr. Fortmeyer retired, for the digging.

The All-Star break offers a chance to evaluate the standings and consider how the playoff races may shape up. Most fans want to believe their teams are still in the hunt, but the numbers wizards at CoolStandings.com offer a dose of reality. If their calculations are correct, it should be a good summer to be a Dodgers fan. The site, which uses a complex formula to simulate the rest of the season one million times, chose Los Angeles as the team most likely to make the playoffs. With a 55-31 record entering Saturday, the Dodgers were given a 95.1 percent chance of winning the N.L. West or the wild card. The team's expected win total is 101, making it the only team that the site predicts will break 100.

To the Sports Editor: With a combined 77 aces and their maximum serve speeds reaching 143 and 135 miles an hour, Andy Roddick and Roger Federer succeeded in robotizing tennis and making it look like a video game during the Wimbledon men's final. Tennis will die if the pace of the game is not significantly decelerated. Yann Meunier

AFTER 50 years in the United States, the Honda name has blended into the culture alongside Sony, Nestlé and Adidas, another foreign brand now embraced as a reliable provider of high-quality, well-conceived products. That is a noteworthy achievement for a company that made its name selling a puny plastic-clad motorcycle just as Detroit was birthing its most flamboyant whales. For a broad swath of American consumers, Honda -- a brand applied not only to cars and motorcycles but also to generators, lawn mowers and anything else the world's largest engine maker could power -- is the maker of unpretentious good stuff at accessible prices. Usually without flashy or distinctive styling, Honda's products can be said to define the leading edge of ordinary.

BLOOM--Joel W.,93, camp director, died on July 6th, leaving his wife Evelyn (Kerner), of Otisfield, ME, two sons, Mark, of Worcester, MA and Charles, of Lafayette, CO, a daughter, Jane Ira, of New York, NY and three grandchildren: Michael, Amanda and James. Raised in Manhattan, he later lived in Newton, MA and Otisfield, ME. He graduated from the University of Arizona and earned a masters and doctorate from Columbia. In World War II he was a PT Boat skipper. From 1947 to 1996 he ran Camp Powhatan for Boys in Otisfield, ME. He pioneered diversity in camping, starting a scholarship fund at Powhatan and helping found Camp Susan Curtis for underprivileged Maine children. In 1993 he assisted in starting Seeds of Peace, a camp to empower young leaders from conflict regions with skills to advance coexistence. He was President of the New England Camping Association, the Maine Camp Directors' Association, and the Pleasant Lake and Parker Pond Association and Vice President of the American Camping Association. Donations to the Joel W. Bloom Campership Fund, Seeds of Peace, 370 Lexington Ave., Ste. 401, New York, NY 10017 or online.

Dinara Safina has never won a Grand Slam tournament, most recently losing in the semifinals at Wimbledon to Venus Williams, 6-1, 6-0. Yet Safina continues to retain the No. 1 world ranking, leaving many in the tennis world scratching their heads. She has held the top spot since April, when Serena Williams lost in the first round at Marbella and fell from No. 1 despite winning the two previous Grand Slam tournaments.

The Mets lack a lot of things these days. Home runs. Victories. Intelligent base running. The ability to catch pop flies. But what is also missing is Banner Day, the annual on-field parade that allowed fans to comment, with humor, on the Mets' often miserable state of affairs. Back in 1993, for example, Banner Day was a nice antidote for an incomprehensible season in which the Mets finished 44 games under .500, threw firecrackers at fans and sprayed bleach at reporters.

PETER WHEELER, the former owner of TVR of Blackpool, England, died last month at 65 after an illness, and it is worth noting here how remarkable his tenure was. He was a chemical engineer who actually took over a car company. He embodied a spirit of individualism that gave TVR its spark, and although he made the company only a modest success, he produced some exciting cars, like the Tuscan, Cerbera and Griffith. His type of ownership is fading quickly from the automotive scene.

It was Saturday morning, Louis Armstrong was growling a jazz standard, and sunlight sneaked in through golden-draped windows. Inside the Speakeasy, early risers found refuge from the humidity, awakened by pots of French pressed coffee and potent brunch cocktails like the Fire on the Bayou, a Cajun take on the Bloody Mary. From the kitchen emanated a steady stream of powdered doughnuts known as beignets, sumptuous bananas Foster waffles and a masterful shrimp po' boy.

COCO CHANEL was not known for her warm personality. But then, few were privy to the Coco that Douglas Kirkland saw in the summer of 1962. On assignment for Look magazine, the American photographer spent a day documenting the designer as she prepared for her couture show. The results, which are the subject of ''Mademoiselle,'' a new book published by Steidl, include expected images of her (striking a meditative pose, a Kent cigarette dangling from her mouth) and some rare moments of charm: smiling from behind a screen, joking with one of her models; sharing a cocktail with her staff. ''There are hardly any photos of her -- even when young -- with such a winning smile, with such a lightness in her expression,'' Karl Lagerfeld, who conceived and designed the book, writes in the foreword. ''It's a reduction of all clichés concerning Coco Chanel to immediate appreciation, sympathy and nearly cheerfulness.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Putting Face on Future of U.S. Women,'' June 28: After losing to 17-year-old Melanie Oudin in the third round at Wimbledon, Jelena Jankovic said with uncommon candor that Oudin ''can play if you let her play'' but ''doesn't have any weapons, you know, from what I have seen.''
To the Editor: Re ''Hello to Underachieving,'' (Sunday Styles, July 5):

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Baseball Injuries Rise, and Reason Is a Mystery,'' July 7: Actually there is no mystery as to why baseball injuries have risen exponentially in recent years. Today players have become pampered, spoiled celebrities for whom every waking moment is programmed by nutritionists, personal trainers and various coaches, psychologists, interpreters and technological whizzes who record pitch counts and apply a dizzying array of useless and meaningless statistics.

GAGE--Alan Kenneth, age 91, passed away at home in Manhattan on July 8, 2009. Born September 3, 1917 he was a lifelong resident of New York City. Alan was a 1935 graduate of Riverdale Country School and the longest serving class agent, receiving several President's Cups for enlisting the highest percentage of donors of any class. A 1939 graduate of Yale University, he served as chair of the class agents and on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund. In 1954 he began a career on Wall Street, later becoming president of Parrish & Company. He was most recently a Senior Vice President - Wealth Management/ Senior Portfolio Manger at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. He also served as President of the Wall Street Financial Forum. He was a member of The Brick Presbyterian Church since 1962, serving as a Deacon and Trustee and spear headed its Evangelism Outreach Program, leading many to a relationship with Jesus Christ. He was also a member of the Yale Club, the Colony Club and the Dancers. Alan is survived by his daughters Heidi Jenkins and Victoria Rose, and their husbands Robert Jenkins and William Rose, four grandchildren Anabelle and Lucas Jenkins and Douglas Rose and Courtney Jeffus and their spouses Kaitlin Rose and Tyson Jeffus. Also surviving are his sister-in-law Suzanne Gage and niece and nephew Linda O'Connor and Thomas Gage, and three stepchildren; Bonnie Weyher McLamb, Harry Weyher and Laura Hall. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 2pm Monday, July 13, 2009. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

She was an extraordinary lady of many talents, a member and judge of the Greenfingers Garden Club, the New Caanan Sewing Group, and the North Woods Club of Minerva, NY. A cherished mother to Nancy Van Deren (James Burnett) of Spencertown, NY and John F. Van Deren III (Jane) of Montpelier, VT, her stepchildren Thomas MacCracken (Alexandra) of Oakton, VA and New York City and Linda MacCracken of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY. Loved and fondly remembered for her generosity, spirit and devotion to her grandchildren, Jessica Van Deren Herlihy (Daniel) of New Haven, CT and John F. Van Deren IV of New York City, and her step-granddaughters Paige Ioppolo of New Castle, WA and Amagansett, NY and Annie Hults and Caitlin Ryan both of New York City. A memorial service will be held on July 22, 3pm at Meadow Ridge, 100 Redding Rd., Redding, CT 06896. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

Titans quarterback Vince Young speaking at the funeral for the ex-N.F.L. quarterback Steve McNair on Saturday in Hattiesburg, Miss. Nearly 5,000 turned out to mourn McNair, who the police said was shot by a girlfriend, who then shot herself.

The city has a stylish new promenade, the High Line, a former elevated railroad in the West Village. The first section opened last month as a wild garden path, calling to mind the tidier Promenade Plantée in Paris. The Chelsea version, which was the idea of Robert Hammond and Joshua David, was designed with amazing sensitivity to the site, down to the hardy plants that thrive along abandoned tracks. Below, the suggested route. Strollers proceed through an old factory, the broken windows replaced with 700 glass panels, each one a color taken from the Hudson River; they also go under a new hotel and other buildings. There's a surprise at 17th Street, an amphitheater suspended over 10th Avenue, the traffic viewed through plate-glass windows. Forget the fashions of Fifth Avenue -- the High Line's young crowd floats along in summer's look: minimalist dresses, short and long.

BOIGON--Helen Wasserman, M.D.,died on July 8, 2009 at home after a long illness. She was 87 years old, the widow of Melvin Boigon M.D., mother of Seth, LMSW and Margot, M.D.; mother-in-law of Jody Berg, and grandmother of Justin and Madeleine Boigon Berg. A graduate of Bryn Mawr College and The Women's Medical College of Pennsylvania, she trained as a psychoanalyst at the Karen Horney Institute, and practiced in Manhattan for 60 years. A great believer in the psychoanalytic process, Dr. Boigon taught for many years, without remuneration, at the Horney Institute and the Postgraduate Center for Mental Health.

Proof of Nicaragua's developing tourism industry can be seen in the recent opening of a sleek boutique hotel about seven miles outside of Managua. The 18-room Hotel Contempo (www.contempohb.com), which opened in May, has a clean and modern design, featuring guest rooms outfitted with white marble and local white travertine tile, a wine bar and a minimalist lobby piano lounge and bar with ultrahigh ceilings. The hotel's restaurant serves Mediterranean cuisine with a Nicaraguan touch, while a business center and meeting space that holds up to 300 people caters to business travelers. There is also a pool. A spa and 18 more rooms are scheduled to be in place by the end of the year.

LOCKARD--T. Swift, Jr.,long-time publishing and marketing executive died on June 6, 2009 at his home in La Quinta, CA. He was a Naval Aviator in WWII and a jet night fighter in the Korean Conflict, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Mr. Lockard was Associate Advertising Sales Director of Sports Illustrated. In 1966 he was founding Advertising Sales Director of New York Magazine, then moved to Los Angeles as publisher of New West. At Knapp Communications he oversaw work activities with the LA Olympic Committee for the '84 Olympic Games. He continued publishing activities when he moved to the desert area in 1989. Lockard is survived by his wife Tommy, daughters Andy, Becca, Kate; sons-in-law Ben Chaput, Dr. Jeffrey Heilpern, five grandchildren, and two brothers.

He raised funds for the Hunger Project and other related organizations. He is survived by his wife, Abby, his children Andy and Rebecca, their spouses Doris and Mitchell, and grandsons Matthew, Ethan, Michael, and Christopher.

A good bet for enjoying Paris sans traffic congestion is to venture out on Sunday, when the city restricts many major thoroughfares to taxis and emergency vehicles, clearing the way for pedestrians and cyclists. Traffic is also down throughout August, when many Parisians are away on vacation. Paris also has nearly 200 miles of dedicated bicycle paths. And through Sept. 30, the Hilton Arc de Triomphe and Hilton Paris La Défense will do their part to encourage more cycling by offering either a guided bicycle tour or a bike rental to any guest who reserves the Go Green package. Nightly rates start at $303 (www.hilton.com). For those more interested in seeing Paris through its art museums, Hotel Jules (www.hoteljules.com), which bills itself as ''bohemian-chic,'' in the Ninth Arrondissement, is including two two-day museum passes for every two nights booked. Museums accessible with the pass, which usually costs 32 euros, include the Louvre, the Musée d'Orsay, the Rodin and more than 30 others. Rates at the 100-room hotel, above, start at $152.

NIETHAMER--Marion. The Three Arrows Cooperative Society mourns the loss of Marion Niethamer, who died on July 5, 2009, after a courageous battle with cancer. Our loving sympathies to Harvey, Diana, Felicia, Jonah, and Jackie. She was a kind and brave soul.
