SHARP--William L.,84, beloved Professor of Acting, Dramatic Literature and Theory and former Chair of the Theater Arts Department at Emerson College, died unexpectedly on Friday, May 29, 2009 at his residence in Swampscott, MA. He was born in Chicago and served with the 381st Engineer Combat Battalion in France and Germany during WWII. He completed his MA at the University of Chicago. He received his Ph.D. in Theater and Drama from Stanford University and taught at UC Riverside, where he was the Chairman and Creator of the Drama Program from 1954-1964. He co-founded the Stanford Repertory Theater, and was Director of the Theatre Program at the Breadloaf School of English (at Middlebury College) from 1966-1976. He a faculty member at Emerson College from 1970-1994 and was named Professor Emeritus of the Performing Arts. Dr. Sharp truly loved teaching. He inspired many students who are now successful writers, directors, actors, educators and performing arts professionals. His impact on the lives of his students was profound and he will be greatly missed. Dr. Sharp is survived by his children Arthur, Kate and Liz Sharp, and grandchildren Laura and Sam Polstein and Alison Buckley as well as his sister Darlene Fiske and brother Don Sharp. He was also lovingly tended in his later years by close family friends Melanie and Marcus Ransom and the late Jen Waterkotte. A memorial service will be held on July 25 at 2pm at Semel Theatre of Emerson College. Please send donations in lieu of flowers to Emerson College Performing Arts, c/o Robert Ashton, Emerson College, 120 Boylston Street, Boston, MA, 02116, noting his name.

CALAMITA--Frank, died peacefully in his sleep in Warwickshire, England on Sunday, June 28, 2009. Born in Brooklyn to Nicola and Grace Calamita, Mr. Calamita moved to Manhattan as a young man and joined CBS Records in 1962. On September 3, 1966 he was married to Alyda Jansen. Their only child, Nicolas Jansen, was born in 1968. In his career of over 40 years Mr. Calamita was a senior executive with CBS Records and later with Sony Music Entertainment, and served on the boards of numerous charitable organizations including The American Management Association and the Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center. The Calamita's maintained homes in Manhattan and Bellport, LI. Alyda Jansen Calamita was deceased on April 27, 2000. Mr. Calamita is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Nancy S. Eisenhauer, who are both academics in Oxford, England and their son, Nicolas Johannes Ides Calamita. In addition he is survived by the families of his late sister Angela Schiralli and Ann Iorio. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday, July 13, 2009 at 10:30am at Most Precious Blood Roman Catholic Church, 113 Baxter St., NYC. Burial will be private. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be made in Mr. Calamita's memory to The Association for Children with Down Syndrome (ACDS), 4 Fern Place, Plainview, NY 11803-4725 or Cancer Research UK, Halifax Road, Melksham, SN12 6YY, United Kingdom. A web page at Cancer Research UK has also been created in Frank's memory.
SEMEL--Edmond Charles. Beloved father of Margaret and John. We will miss him dearly.

Classical music fans visiting Japan in late summer might be interested in the 18th annual Saito Kinen Festival (www.saito-kinen.com/e) from mid-August to mid-September. Founded by Seiji Ozawa, the festival was created to honor Mr. Ozawa's mentor, Hideo Saito, a cellist, composer and educator who was devoted to promoting Western classical music in Japan and who was a co-founder of the Toho Gakuen School of Music in Tokyo. The festival is in Matsumoto, home of the Matsumoto Castle, above, in the foothills of the Japanese Alps. It will feature performances by the Saito Kinen Orchestra, with Mr. Ozawa conducting most of the works. The performances will include Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem,'' with the soprano Christine Goerke and the tenor Anthony Dean Griffey. Information on Matsumoto, including lodging options, are at welcome.city.matsumoto.nagano.jp.

These Hondas aren't so much collectibles as simply used cars and motorcycles. And that just makes them better. CALAMITA--Frank. It is with great sadness that the Board of Directors, volunteers, medical staff and employees of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital Medical Center mourn the passing of our longtime friend, benefactor, and member of the Board of Directors, and the New Yorkers for Brookhaven, Frank Calamita. Frank and his late wife Alyda were devoted supporters of the hospital. Frank governed with compassion, humor, and dedication. We will sorely miss the wonderful stories from this world-renowned traveler. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son Nicolas Jansen (Jan) Calamita, his daughter-in-law Nancy, and his grandson Nicolas Johannes Ides Calamita, who was the joy of his life.

STEPHENS--Claude Odell, affectionately known as "Claude O. Stephens," the former President and Chief Executive Officer of Texas Gulf Sulphur Co. (TGS), died peacefully at his home on Thursday, July 9, 2009. He was 100 years old. Stephens was born to Buford Dured Stephens and Carrie Madeline Collins Stephens on October 6, 1908 in Darbun, Mississippi. He graduated from Bay City (Texas) High School where he played football and basketball. He obtained a degree in Petroleum Engineering from Louisiana State University (LSU). In his senior year at LSU, he was a cadet colonel; he commanded the LSU ROTC Regiment and received the Kemper Williams Sabre. At the outbreak of World War II, Stephens was commissioned as a second lieutenant of Infantry in the U. S. Army. He received additional training at the Infantry School in Fort Benning, GA. Stephens later rose to the rank of major and served in Japan as the War came to a close. He was awarded the Bronze Star. While still in college, Stephens' father died. As the eldest son in the family, he took on the responsibility of providing for the family. Stephens obtained employment with TGS as a driller's helper and assisted his mother with raising his younger siblings. As a result of his hard work ethic, skill, and intelligence, he quickly rose through the ranks and became rig supervisor. Stephens became an engineer for TGS in 1938 after he graduated from LSU. Ten years later in 1948, he was assigned to head the TGS office in Worland, Wyoming where he and his crew revolutionized the sulphur extraction process. This process permitted sulphur to be produced from sour natural gas. In 1952, Stephens was appointed as a Vice President of TGS and assigned to its New York office. He became a director of TGS in 1956. Stephens was named President and CEO of TGS in 1958 and assumed oversight of sulphur production facilities throughout the United States and Canada. Under his leadership in the 1960s and through the early 1970s when he retired, TGS diversified its operations and substantially increased its stock value. Stephens was greatly respected and admired by all who worked for and with him. LSU honored Stephens as "Alumnus of the Year" in 1968. In 1970, he was awarded the Distinguished Alumni Award and the President's Award. He was a Diamond Life Member of Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity and a 32 Degree Mason, Siloam Lodge No. 276 (Oklahoma). Stephens is survived by his wife of forty-nine years, Lois B. Stephens; brothers Charles Stephens of Odessa, Texas and Fred Stephens of Sun City, Texas, and a host of nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. He was preceded in death by his brother, Buford Aubrey Stephens and his sister, Doris Kathleen Stephens. For memorial service information, please contact Marilyn J. Ford at marilyn.ford@quinnipiac.edu.

FASHION'S infatuation with all things studded may have started two years ago, but Bartholomew Dougherty's began in high school with the discovery of early 1980s Scandinavian and Japanese hard-core bands. ''They wore the most insane studded things,'' said Mr. Dougherty, who now works as a sales associate at Seven New York. ''Jackets covered in metal, with tight jeans, boots, bullet belts -- the severity of the look just moved me.'' Radioactive Flesh, his new line of reworked vintage leather jackets and denim vests, mines the bands' aesthetics, minus all that angst. Each piece is tailored, painted and studded by hand, and takes up to a week to finish. Wear with tight jeans and boots. Forgo the bullet belt.

MUMBAI: GYM BOLLYWOOD Staying fit in Mumbai, with its heat, humidity and lack of green space, can be a challenge. Enter a new way to stay in shape: Bollywood dance. Gyms and dance studios across Mumbai are now offering Bollywood-inspired fitness classes as a way to lose pounds and beat gym fatigue.

KELLER--C. Lawrence, 87, passed away in his sleep in his beloved Green Mountains, VT on July 7, 2009 after a brief illness. A longtime resident of Short Hills, NJ and Londonderry, VT he graduated from The Taft School in 1941 and served in World War II as a commissioned officer in the Coast Guard for 4 years. He began his real estate career with his father, Charles G. Keller in New York City where he worked until 1968 when he established Keller Realty Associates Inc. in Hackensack and Princeton, NJ specializing in industrial and commercial real estate. The company was active for over thirty years. A pioneer in environmentally responsible development, Keller was instrumental in developing the Princeton Forrestal Center and was founding partner of the Carnegie Center also in Princeton, NJ. He was the former director of the Real Estate Board of New York, past president of IREBA and served as an officer of SIOR. Keller was a philanthropist and avid environmentalist. He was a former Chairman of the Board of McBurney YMCA of New York, on the Board of Directors of Presbyterian Homes Foundation of NJ and active with Cheshire Homes. In Milburn Township he served as President of the Board of Adjustment and as a member of the Planning Board. Committed to the preservation of New Jersey forestlands he served on the board of the NJ Conservation Foundation for 18 years and served as the Board President. Most recently he served on the Foundation's Advisory Council and the Strategic Planning Committee. He was a longtime member of Baltusrol Golf Club, the Short Hills Club, Ekwanok Country Club in Manchester, VT, Sankaty Head Golf Club in Nantucket, MA and the Tuscarora Club in Margaretville, NY. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Barbara, four children: Cord Keller of Los Angeles, CA, James Keller of Brooklyn, NY, Linny Andlinger of Upper Montclair, NJ and Nicholas Keller of Washington, DC, and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the St. Stephen's Church in Milburn, NJ with a reception to follow on September 12, 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers he would like his friends to consider a donation to the New Jersey Conservation Foundation.

GOSIER--Lester James, Sr.,born, January 31, 1916, in Oswego, New York, died on July 9, 2009 in Bay Shore, New York. He was predeceased by his wife, of 55 years, Carolyn H. Teetsel Gosier; his parents, Mr. Austin W. Gosier (father); Mrs. Bessie C. Green Gosier, (mother); family members Mrs. Louise Gosier Westcott, (sister); Mrs. Lynn Lynes (daughter-in-law); and Mr. Frederick F. Fenter, (son-in-law). His surviving family includes Mr. Thomas C. Lynes of New Jersey; Ms. Carol Ann Fenter of New York; Mr. L. James Gosier of Maryland; Mrs. Mary Jane Gosier Rowlette of Wisconsin; Mrs. Janette Louise Gosier Foley of Colorado; Mrs. Margaret E. Gosier Hauptfleisch of New York, their spouses, and numerous grandchildren and great-grand children. Mr. Gosier was educated at the Oswego Normal School, now SUNY Oswego; SUNY Albany; New York University; and the New School for Social Research. Mr. Gosier was a retired lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army reserve; a founding member of the Teachers Federal Credit Union, serving on the board of directors continuously since its founding, and recently became a trustee emeritus. He was a science teacher for 42 years. Mr. Gosier was on the advisory boards of Southside Hospital and the Bay Shore Public Library. He was on the boards of the SUNY Oswego Alumni, South Shore Symphony, Long Island Teachers Association, and a member of the Bay Shore United Methodist Church. A memorial service will be held Thursday, July 16, 2009, 1:00 pm, at the United Methodist Church, 107 E. Main Street, Bay Shore, New York 11706. A reception will immediately follow in the fellowship hall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be given to the Bay Shore Public Library 1 South Country Club Road, Brightwaters, New York 11718 or to an organization of your choice.

Harrison Barnes, the top-ranked basketball player in the rising senior high school class, did nothing to hurt his reputation at the LeBron James Skills Academy and King City Classic last week. Barnes, a 6-foot-8 wing, has a game that is polished beyond his years. His feathery jump shot is as impressive as his ability to elevate and snatch rebounds above the rim. But perhaps even more sophisticated than his game is his demeanor. Barnes has a 3.6 grade point average at Ames High School in Iowa and will most likely be a sophomore academically when he arrives at the college of his choice. He will have completed nine Advanced Placement classes before graduating high school.

HONDA announced last week that a new body style would be added to the Accord lineup this fall: a crossover. The new vehicle will be called the Accord Crosstour. In spy photos, it looks similar to the Acura ZDX concept that was introduced at the New York auto show in April. But Mike Spencer, a Honda spokesman, assured me that one had nothing to do with the other. ''They actually are completely different and do not share anything,'' he said in a text message.

When President Obama throws out the ceremonial first pitch before Tuesday's All-Star Game in St. Louis, he will probably be thinking mostly about getting the ball to the catcher, just as most nonathletes do when asked to perform in front of an audience of millions. But unlike most first-pitch throwers, he will have to live up to some of his predecessors, as the research team at Major League Baseball uncovered. In 1937, during the Great Depression, President Franklin D. Roosevelt made a grand entrance from right field in an open car, then threw out the first pitch from his front-row box.

John F. Savarese, Chair Michael Jacobson, President

MEADES--Gertrude Webb, the wife of the late Harry Meades, military hero who served as a Royal Air Force Officer and was decorated four times and held five Combat Medals. She was the granddaughter of former Mayor William J. Gaynor of New York City, NY. Gertrude passed away peacefully Saturday, May 9, 2009 at her home in Naples, Florida. She was raised in Manhasset, New York and known to her family and friends as "Punchie." Gertrude Webb Meades was born February 28, 1925 the fourth child of five children whose parents were William Seward Webb, Jr. and Gertrude Gaynor Webb. Her father was the founder of Webb and Knapp, real estate agent, and son of the late William Seward Webb, railroad builder and his mother was the late Mrs. Eliza Osgood Webb, a daughter of William H. Vanderbilt. Mrs. Meades mother was the late Gertrude Gaynor Webb, daughter of William J. Gaynor and Elizabeth Handwright. Her parents' fortunes enabled the Webbs and Vanderbilts to be among the earliest to enjoy summers in Shelburne, Vermont and go on to create the world renowned "Shelburne Museum". (The Shelburne Museum was founded by Electra Havemayer Webb and her husband J. Watson Webb whose parents were Dr. William Seward Webb and Lila Vanderbilt Webb. Their 19th century lakeside estate would become Shelburne Farms.) Gertrude (Punchie) Webb Meades, longtime character of life, regaled in living life to the fullest with long freighter trips to exotic ports of call, the love of animal husbandry, she had a passion for reading and enjoyed the solitude of needlepoint. She spent many productive years as a volunteer with the Naples Community Hospital Blood Bank. There was no one else like this woman, lovingly known as Punchie. She will be remembered for her love of family, her dear friends, her zest for life, and her elegantly gentle kind outlook on life, graceful manners, wit and warmth. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by Emma II, her "Pug", her two sons, Michael Harry Meades of Apopka, Florida and Jamie Seward Meades of Sarasota, Florida, three granddaughters, Heather Portanova, Meredith Magennis and Mindy Meades and great-grandchildren, Caitlin Magennis, Caleb Portanova and Kayli Portanova. In addition, she is survived by her sister Frederica Webb Gamble of Westwood, MA, her nieces, Frederique Gamble, Susan Webb Porter and nephew W. Seward Webb. Memorial service was conducted Saturday, May 16, 2009 at the St. John's Episcopal Church, Naples, Florida. In lieu of flowers, family and friends may make contributions in Punchie's name to Vitas Innovative Hospice Care: Naples, Florida, Animal Refuge Center of Fort Myers: North Fort Myers, Florida or the Naples Community Hospital Blood Center: Naples, Florida.

AL QAEDA IN NORTH AFRICA The News Al Qaeda's affiliate in North Africa appears to be extending its reach across the continent's northern tier, counterterrorism officials said. Behind the News The group has carried out a string of slayings, bombings and other lethal attacks against Westerners and African security forces in recent weeks. Still, assessing the extent of the threat has been difficult. Some counterterrorism experts say the group is little more than a criminal gang. But others point to the attacks as evidence of the group's intent to expand its antigovernment insurgency in Algeria to other North African countries and possibly Europe, where it has financial and logistical supporters.

MARKS--David V. P.,54, of Manhattan, passed away on July 8, 2009. Beloved son of the late Margaret and John Marks, he was the cherished brother of Michael Marks and the late Laura Marks, the brother-in-law of Jill Darrow, and the loving uncle of Katie and John Marks, whom he adored. David was privileged to attend The Dalton School; Harvard College, where he studied economics under Nobel laureates Kenneth Arrow and Wassily Leontief and graduated summa cum laude; Harvard Law School, where he received his J.D. degree, cum laude; and the Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, where he studied under Nobel laureate Thomas Schelling and received his A.M. and Ph.D. degrees in economics. David's scholarly publications include "Competition in the Investment Banking Industry" (Harvard University Press), co-authored with Harvard Business School Professors Samuel L. Hayes, III and A. Michael Spence, and "Signposting: The Selective Revelation of Product Information" (Harvard Business School Press), co-authored with Kennedy School of Government Professor Richard J. Zeckhauser. David was a member of the bar in Massachusetts and New York. David began his business career as President of The GMS Group, Inc., a strategic consulting firm that he formed with two Harvard Law School professors to furnish advice to firms in the financial services sector. Later, David was President of an independent music publishing company, St. Nicholas Music Inc., and was a private investor in intellectual property, securities, fine art and other assets. David's interests were numerous and varied. He studied and collected Renaissance and 19th century Renaissance revival decorative arts, arms and armor, and furnishings. He was a longtime student of the history of New York architecture, especially its residential architecture. He served on the boards of various preservation organizations including Carnegie Hill Neighbors, the Defenders of the Historic Upper East Side, and the Historic Neighborhood Enhancement Alliance. David was active in The Episcopal Chaplaincy at Harvard for 30 years, including serving as Finance Committee Member, Treasurer, Vice President and, most recently, President. David's quest for perfection in everything he did was an inspiration to all who knew him. He also encouraged and cultivated perfection in all of those around him, the end result of which was a litany of enduring friendships. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Monday, July 13, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in David's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue New York, NY 10065, www.mskcc.org.

Sort of Collectible Hondas These Hondas aren't ''collectibles,'' but used cars and motorcycles. And that just makes them better. None these eight is so valuable that it can't be driven (or ridden) regularly and rugged enough to run without constant attention. Honda has produced limited production near-racing motorcycles like the RC45 and RC51, but even those are more likely to be used than displayed. JOHN PEARLEY HUFFMAN

The images of the Dodgers' Hiroki Kuroda that appeared in The New York Times last week with an article about Kuroda's somewhat peculiar injury problems raised the question: Where have all the drop-and-drive pitchers gone? The pitching motion made popular by Tom Seaver and his dirty knee has largely gone the way of bullpen cars. Kuroda, with his bent front leg and rear foot dragging over the mound -- the presumed cause for the troublesome blisters on the top of his right foot -- appears to use the motion. Bartolo Colon, trying to hang on to his career, is also a drop-and-drive pitcher. The Phillies prospect Kyle Drabek fits the mold. But most pitchers throw more upright, with a straight front leg that they use to develop torque in their hips.

DEL ROSSI--Lynda F.,passed away on July 7, 2009. Dear sister of Elaine Peters and cherished daughter of the late Mollie and George Schlossberg. Graveside service 11am, Monday at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

The United States men's national team's 2-0 victory over Honduras in the Concacaf Gold Cup in Washington on Wednesday gave American soccer another heartening story line: Santino Quaranta, who is coming back from injuries and drug addiction. In his first appearance for the national team since 2006, Quaranta scored by rocketing a low shot from the top right of the penalty box past Honduras goalkeeper Donis Escobar.

FRIEDMAN--Priscilla A.,66, passed away on July 9, 2009. It was my privilege to love and be loved by her. Priscilla was beautiful not only of body but of mind and spirit. She brought a special light into a room with her quick wit and energy. She touched so many lives and was loved by so many. She valued each and every friend. She will be remembered and missed by all. She is survived by her loving husband, Sol; children, Jordan Seth and Jill Victoria, Carrie, son-in-law Rob, Steven, daughter-in-law Rachel; mother, Helen; sister, Lynn; brother-in-law, Joel; grandchildren, nieces and nephews. Priscilla and I laughed, cried and shared over 30 years of friendship. Those memories are cherished and I will miss her forever, Monica.

AUGUST--Ralph H.,age 77, of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ died Thursday, July 9, 2009 surrounded by his family. Born in the Bronx, NY he lived in Franklin Lakes, before moving to Ho-Ho-Kus 16 years ago. Ralph was owner of August Fabrics, Fairview, NJ. He was a dedicated Giants fan and enjoyed driving high performance boats and cars. He was a member of the S. Minneford Yacht Club, City Island, New York. He shared his passion for life with his beloved wife of 43 years, Susan (nee McAuley) August, his loving children, Nina August, Cathy Blaustein, Andrea Smith, Robert August, John August and Kristi Lowenthal as well as his eight grandchildren. The family will receive friends on Sunday, July 12 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, www.vpfh.com, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. A Service of Remembrance will be held on Monday, 11am at the Funeral Home. Private cremation was held. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, PO Box 27106, New York, New York 10087, for Prostate Cancer.

ROME: TIBER BOARDWALK Roman summer nights are famous for offering a sweet and welcome release from the intense heat and humidity of the days. An excellent way to enjoy those summer evenings is to walk along the banks of the Tiber, where, for the sixth year, a boardwalk has been set up on the Trastevere side of the river.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended June 27, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

Update | 6:33 p.m. The head of the Obama administration’s auto task force, Steven Rattner, is stepping down from the post after the rapid reorganizations of Chrysler and General Motors.
Maybe it’s the rough economy, but the quotient of former media moguls seemed to be especially high at last week’s exclusive schmoozefest in Sun Valley, Idaho.

A planned strike by stagehands and other workers could roil the upcoming Bayreuth Festival, the annual celebration dedicated to the music of Richard Wagner, The Times of London reported. A spokesman for the festival, held in the Bavarian city of Bayreuth at a festival house designed by Wagner, told The Times of London that 60 stagehands and lighting engineers and 100 freelance workers for the event would likely go on strike to demand better pay. Barbara Schneider, a union activist, said that the pay rate for festival stagehands works out to about $5.59 an hour, given the lengthy hours they work. The festival’s longtime director, Wolfgang Wagner, had paid these workers non-union rates but offered them other perks. The coming festival, the first to be directed by Wolfgang Wagner’s daughters Katharina Wagner and Eva Wagner-Pasquier, is scheduled to open on July 25 with a production of “Tristan and Isolde.”

Brüno may have offended Hollywood agents, hunters, Jews, Palestinians, focus groups and Paula Abdul, but for now he is no longer being sued for assault. On Friday, The Hollywood Reporter said, a woman who was suing Sacha Baron Cohen who stars as the title character, and NBC Universal, which released the movie “Brüno,” amended her lawsuit to drop causes of action for assault and battery while preserving a claim that she suffered emotional distress. In her suit, the woman, Richelle Olson, said that she was injured at a charity bingo game in May 2007 in Palmdale, Calif., when she struggled with Mr. Baron Cohen after she tried to take a microphone from him. Later, Ms. Olson said, she fell and hit her head on a concrete slab and sustained bleeding in her brain. Universal said that footage of the scene showed that no assault took place, and the sequence did not appear in the “Brüno” movie.
MANCHESTER, England — Many arts festivals try hard to be engaging for young people. Over the weekend the Manchester International Festival went all out.
Full story: TV Journalist Wounded in Iraq Returns to the War

A long-in-the-works film adaptation of the David Foster Wallace book “Brief Interviews With Hideous Men” will be released in American theaters in September. On Monday, IFC Films said in a news release that it had acquired U.S. distribution rights to the movie, and that it would open in theaters and appear on video-on-demand services on Sept. 25. The film, which had its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival, marks the directorial debut of the actor John Krasinski (of NBC’s “The Office”) and stars Julianne Nicholson (“Law & Order: Criminal Intent”) as a graduate student who is interviewing men for a thesis project, as well as Will Arnett, Dominic Cooper, Timothy Hutton, Christopher Meloni and Mr. Krasinski as the subjects of some of those interrogations. Mr. Krasinski has said he first got the idea for the film as a student at Brown University, where he acted in a staged reading of the book, a collection of short stories and monologues.

A beach in Cornwall, England, that is believed to have inspired the Virginia Woolf novel “To the Lighthouse” was sold Monday at an auction for about $128,000, BBC News reported. The 76-acre Upton Towans beach in Gwithian, at the southwest tip of Britain, was sold by the auction house Colliers to a private buyer who was not named. Though the Woolf novel is set in the Hebrides, the author spent her childhood vacations at a guest house in Cornwall, where she could see the now famous lighthouse on Godrevy Island, and she is thought to have used these memories as inspiration for the book. (Besides, as readers of the novel know, “nothing was simply one thing.”) The beach’s previous owner, Dennis Arbon, said that he would give proceeds from the sale to the Hall for Cornwall, a local theater.

Confirming the longstanding reports that Neil Patrick Harris would host the Emmy Awards (and fulfilling the wishes of Tonys viewers who hoped he would), CBS announced on Monday Mr. Harris would be the M.C. for the 61st Primetime Emmy Awards show. In a statement Mr. Harris said, “I’m looking forward to the challenge of the show — adding my own voice to it, while honoring the nominees and the entire year in television.

Maura Tierney, a star of the coming NBC series “Parenthood,” said Monday that she had a breast tumor, The Hollywood Reporter said, following the network’s announcement on Friday that it was postponing the show’s debut. In a statement, Ms. Tierney said, “I have discovered a tumor in my breast which requires surgery. I will not know either my exact diagnosis or course of treatment until that surgery is performed.” She added that her doctors told her that her condition is “very treatable.” Last week, NBC said that it would delay the premiere of “Parenthood,” based on the 1989 Ron Howard comedy, to 2010 from the fall and that it would postpone production for eight weeks while Ms. Tierney received a medical evaluation.

Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera for the last three seasons, got a big raise last year. For the fiscal year that ended last July — encompassing Mr. Gelb’s second full season on the job — his total compensation was $1.5 million, a 36 percent increase from a year before, according to a report by Bloomberg News that cited the company’s latest tax return. Mr. Gelb, 55, a former record executive, took over from Joseph Volpe in the fall of 2006 with aggressive marketing plans to draw new audiences, including high-definition live broadcasts of operas in hundreds of movie theaters around the world. But the Met has also been juggling a deficit and has been buffeted by the economy.

Ryan Seacrest has signed a $45 million deal to remain as host of “American Idol” for three more years, also giving the producers of “Idol” exclusive prime-time network rights to Mr. Seacrest’s services on “American Idol” or a successor show. The deal, between Mr. Seacrest and 19 Entertainment and announced by 19’s parent company, CKX Inc., provides Mr. Seacrest with a $10 million annual salary plus an upfront payment of $15 million for the exclusive rights to Mr. Seacrest’s image and merchandising rights related to “American Idol.”

You got jam-band front man in my classical orchestra. You got classical orchestra in my jam-band front man. Either way, the two will share the stage at Carnegie Hall on Sept. 12 when the New York Philharmonic performs a work by Trey Anastasio. In a news release on Monday, publicists for the New York Philharmonic said it would perform “Time Turns Elastic,” a work for vocals, electric guitar and orchestra composed by Mr. Anastasio, the lead singer and guitarist of Phish, and his longtime collaborator Don Hart. The performance, to be conducted by the Israeli conductor Asher Fisch (yes, Fisch), will also feature orchestrations of other works from the Anastasio catalog, and marks his New York Philharmonic debut. In a statement, Mr. Anastasio described “Time Turns Elastic” as “a piece of music that’s half Ravel and half Cream’s ‘Disraeli Gears.'”

The chief conductor and music director of the Bolshoi Theater resigned suddenly on Monday, Reuters reported, throwing the future of the theater’s $1 billion renovation project into chaos. Alexander Vedernikov, who had been at the Bolshoi for eight years, announced his decision on the opening day of the Bolshoi’s summer tour of Italy. “The theater is putting bureaucratic interests before artistic ones,” he said. “But the interests of art matter far more than the interests of bureaucracy.” Intended to take just three years, the ambitious renovation has so far taken four. The interior of the theater, which is near Red Square in Moscow, is now gutted. Nobody expects work to finish before 2011 at the earliest, and with Russia’s economic crisis expected to force cost cutting on the project, Mr. Vedernikov said he feared it would lead to fatal compromises on some of the most vital details, like the theater’s acoustics. The architect who led the project was fired months ago amid recriminations over changes to the designs, and the Russian news media have reported that the main contractor will be changed.

At a time when publishers are scrambling to keep customers willing to pay $26 for a hardcover book instead of $9.99 for an electronic version, the publisher of Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s forthcoming memoir is going in the opposite direction – issuing a limited edition it plans to sell for $1,000 a copy.

In an unusual move for a Broadway show, the producers of the musical “Hair” announced on Monday that they were canceling the Sunday matinee on Oct. 11 so that the cast could join the National Equality March that day in Washington in support of gay-marriage rights. Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, a producer of “Hair,” said that the decision reflected the spirit of the musical. “Its message of change and hope and inclusion is one we try to live, not just preach,” he said in a statement. The announcement was to be made at a rally in Los Angeles after the “Hair” cast taped a segment there for “The Tonight Show With Conan O’Brien” Monday. A spokesman for “Hair” said the producers were adding a performance for Monday, Oct. 5. People who have tickets to the Oct. 11 matinee can exchange them for another performance.

We spent the first minutes of the season premiere of “Entourage” Sunday night trying to remember where things stood for Vincent Chase, the movie star played by Adrian Grenier. Was he still reeling from the failure of his Pablo Escobar biopic? No, that was two seasons ago. Still feuding with Jason Patric on the set of their firefighter movie, “Smokejumpers”? Sorry, that was last season. Shooting “The Great Gatsby” for Scorsese? Oops – guess that happened in the off-season.

LONDON — I hadn’t planned my visit to the British Library’s exhibit on Henry VIII for the morning after I had seen the new revival of Tom Stoppard’s “Arcadia.” But it turns out that “Arcadia” is exactly what one should see immediately before plunging into contemplation of things past – I mean, way past.

The Rangers traded left winger Lauri Korpikoski to the Phoenix Coyotes for right winger Enver Lisin. The Rangers also came to terms with the restricted free agent forward Ryan Callahan on a multiyear deal. The deal avoided an an arbitration hearing on July 23. Callahan, 24, set career highs with 22 goals, 40 points and 81 games played last season.

The liquidity problems at CIT Group are certain to mean more bad news for small business. Late Sunday night, CIT acknowledged that it was "in active discussions with its principal regulators on a series of measures to improve the company's near-term liquidity position." CIT said it had retained a major New York law firm that specializes in bankruptcy filings but would not comment on the specifics of the assignment.

WASHINGTON - President Obama, seeking to assuage the concerns of Jewish leaders who worry he is being too tough on Israel and too soft on Iran, said during a private meeting at the White House on Monday that he is committed to Israel's security but does not believe it is essential for him to avoid all disagreement with the Jewish state.

Iran's opposition movement consecrated another martyr on Monday, with the funeral of a 19-year-old named Sohrab Aarabi, whose family just discovered on Saturday that he had died last month of a gunshot wound to the heart. Mr. Aarabi had been missing since the huge opposition rally in Tehran on June 15, which was followed by clashes between opposition protesters and Basij militia members during which several people were shot and killed.

Take-Two Interactive warned on Monday that financial results for the rest of its fiscal year will be significantly worse than it previously projected. The video game maker blamed a weaker-than-expected economy and a delay in the release of a big game.

New in stores are these blindingly bright sunglasses created by Germany's oddball design savant Bernhard Willhelm, together with the five-year-old Berlin-based optical collective Mykita. The three mirrored aviator styles were inspired by the 1976 Olympic skiers at Innsbruck and are handmade using cut sheet metal and screwless hinges, a process that gives them great flexibility and a snug fit. Although the flashy eye poppers are intended for the winter slopes, we'll be rocking them on the summer shores. $475 at Opening Ceremony and Seven in New York, and at American Rag in Los Angeles.

Universal's weekend ticket sales estimate for "Brüno" was pretty close to smack on the money. The risky comedy sold $30.6 million in tickets in North America, up a notch from the $30.4 that the studio projected for the weekend on Sunday morning.

Currently on view at On Stellar Rays gallery, the group exhibition "Lover" (through July 26) serves as an examination of different types of love: it's a hello kiss for new lovers and a swan song for love lost. There are works by Marilyn Minter, Robert Melee and Karen Heagle, who painted an arousing portrait of the actress Charlotte Rampling. But a lesser-known personality hangs nearby. It's a 1990 photograph of the drag queen Jimmy Paulette in New York shot by Nan Goldin. Today Madame Paulette is known as Jimmy Paul and is a A-list hairstylist working with big-name photographers like Steven Klein and Steven Meisel. Here, The Moment speak with Jimmy Paul about his days in front of the camera.

Thinning plants is a job for the callous. The row of carrot greens in my vegetable garden, for example, was looking as crowded as the Hummel cabinet at auntie's house. The carrots were not to blame for their predicament. Having failed extravagantly in my first round of sowing vegetables, I'd reseeded by the fistful. Now, a month later, the thriving greens were competing for space, sun, and probably some basic dignity. Dozens of carrots had a date with the reaper-or, to be less dramatic about it, a pinch of the thumb.

Formula One: In his seven years of racing in Formula One, an Australian, Mark Webber, hadn't qualified on pole or won a race. When he broke his leg in a bicycle accident over the off-season, his chances for winning in 2009 looked bleak. But his Red Bull team has been strong all year, and before the German Grand Prix at the Nurburgring last weekend, he had already scored four podiums, including three second-place finishes. He earned his first career pole position in qualifying on Saturday, which foreshadowed his first grand prix win on Sunday.

When we last heard from Jenny Staff Johnson, she and her family of four (Mom, Dad and two sons) were about to leave for China to become a family of five. They headed for Beijing just before the 4th of July to adopt a 6-year-old girl named Xi Juen, whose official name is now Rosemary Juen Johnson, and who prefers to be called JuenJuen. She was born with scoliosis (a curved spine) and will require a good deal of medical intervention when she arrives at her new home in Houston. But for the past week, she has been playing happily with her brothers, Joel and Clyde, and getting to know her parents, Jenny and Mark.

Three decades ago, the New York coffee cup was unmistakable -- the blue Greek-themed "Happy to Serve" you cups. Then, in the mid-1990s, the environmentally friendly Starbucks-style cups rushed to the fore -- holding lattes, mochas, cappuccinos, iced and hot, with fancy accessories like sippy lids and cardboard sleeves. But these days the corner coffee vendors have brought another distinctive style of cup to the New York morning ritual: random.One day your cup of joe carries the logos from Capital One. Sometimes they are purple and white, emblazoned with pharmaceutical names. Recently there has been a wave of green Nurse Jackie cups, advertising the Showtime series. Or recently, iced coffee cups read "Raymond James Stadium," (as in the football stadium from Tampa, Fla.), and "Bon Marche."

Google's new Chrome operating system is a challenge to Microsoft in several ways. It will offer a free rival to Windows, which can add $25 to $100 to the price of a computer. But it also represents a conceptual slap at the elaborate array of features that make up the soon-to-be-unveiled Windows 7. Chrome OS will be positively minimalist by contrast. It will be built on a simple version of Linux that is meant to run only one application: the Chrome browser. Google's idea is that anything for which you may have wanted a separate program can be done within the browser instead.

LEAR--Robert W.,of New Canaan, CT passed away on July 9, 2009. After retiring in 1977 from F&M Schaefer Corporation as Chairman and CEO, he founded the Executive-in-Residence program at Columbia Business School where, as full professor, he taught and counseled for 22 years. Both a classroom and endowed professorship are now named there in his honor. He held many corporate directorships and formed Advisory Boards for more than a dozen entrepreneurial companies. He also wrote three books, was a columnist for Chief Executive Magazine and his articles appeared in many magazines. Other activities included the Management Policy Council, the National Association of Corporate Directors, the Columbia Business School Board of Overseers, Waveny Care Center and St. Mark's Episcopal Church. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, sons William and Andrew and three grandchildren. Services will be held at 11:30 on Friday June 17 at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, CT.

WIGDOR--Ellen Susan, died peacefully Friday July 10, 2009 surrounded by her family and friends. Born in Brooklyn, New York she lived in Rockville Center before moving to Port Jefferson in 1969. She shared her passion for life with, and is survived by, her beloved husband Dr. Aaron Wigdor, her mother Shirley Milender, her loving children Caren and William Skutch and Douglas and Catherine Wigdor, as well as her four grandchildren Jacob, Julia, Carly and Simon. She will be missed by all who knew her. The family will receive friends on Sunday at the home in Port Jefferson from 5pm-9pm, on Monday in Port Jefferson from 2pm-4pm and 6pm-9pm and on Tuesday and Wednesday at 15 Olive Place in Forest Hills from 5pm-9pm.

STRAUSS--Dorothy Reilly, died on July 8, peacefully at her Manhattan home, after a long illness. Born in Philadelphia, July 10, 1917, daughter of Lenore Fitzgerald Reilly and William C. Reilly. Graduate of Goucher College (1939). Married (1947) fifty years to Edward M. Strauss, Jr. (1918-1997); resided since 1979 in New York City, with seventeen summers at Buck Hill Falls, PA. Survived by son Edward M. Strauss, III (Anne) of New York City and daughter Cynthia (Harry Sherr) of Wellesley, MA.; granddaughters Louisa and Eleanor Strauss and grandson Edward Sherr; brother Donald Reilly of Midlothian, VA, and many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by her brother Charles. Memorial service at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 East 60th St, New York, Monday July 27, 4:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please make a tax-deductible donation to the Fidelity Charitable Gift Fund, Dorothy R. Strauss Memorial Fund, P.O. Box 77001, Cincinnati, OH 45277-0053.

The top games rented by members of GameFly, the largest online video game rental site, are action and shooter titles. Ghostbusters, above, which is based on the '80s movies and available on six platforms, is the most recently released game among the top 10. Call of Duty: World at War was released last November. Standard Form 152 is not a famous federal form like the IRS 1040. But for more than four decades, it has been assigned the job of standing sentry over other federal forms. Agencies that want to create, kill or amend federal forms often have to fill out an SF152, also known as a Request for Clearance or Cancellation of a Standard or Optional Form, or file another form just like it.

Tagged disguised these e-mail messages to make it appear as though a friend was inviting them to view personal photos.

O'NEIL--Anne Kennedy, longtime resident of Manhattan's Upper East Side, Human Resources executive and civic leader died last Friday at her home after a long illness. She was 79. The widow of James M. O'Neil, she was born in Boston and graduated from the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in New York City. She had a long career as a Human Resources executive with R. H. Macy & Co., the Tobe-Coburn School and the First Boston Corporation where she was a Vice President until her retirement. She was also active in a number of civic and volunteer organizations, including the Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) and the Henry Street Settlement, and served as President of the New York Junior League. She is survived by a daughter, Anne (Mrs. Juan M.) Ocampo of New York City, a son, Martin L. O'Neil of London and five grandchildren: Mary Morrison Ocampo, Julia Rendon Ocampo, James O'Neil Nakajima, Mariko Nakajima O'Neil and Anne Nakajima O'Neil. A funeral Mass of Christian burial will be held on Thursday, July 16th at 11 o'clock at the Church of Saint Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street.

FRIEDMAN--Priscilla, passed away on July 9, 2009 after a courageous battle with cancer. She was a radiant beauty whose warmth, wit, intelligence and compassion endeared her to all who knew her. She will be sorely missed by her family and many friends. Priscilla is survived by Sol, her husband of 43 years, her children Jordan, Jill, Stephen (wife Rachel), Carrie Megan (husband Rob), her grandchildren Andrea, Lydia and Elyse Friedman, and Emma, Julia and Evan Megan, her mother Helen Michelson and her sister Lynn l'Hommedieu; as well as her beloved brother-in-law Joel Friedman. Service will be on Monday, July 13 at 2pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

GAGE--Alan Kenneth, age 91, passed away at home in Manhattan on July 8, 2009. Born September 3, 1917 he was a lifelong resident of New York City. Alan was a 1935 graduate of Riverdale Country School and the longest serving class agent, receiving several President's Cups for enlisting the highest percentage of donors of any class. A 1939 graduate of Yale University, he served as chair of the class agents and on the Board of Directors of the Yale Alumni Fund. In 1954 he began a career on Wall Street, later becoming president of Parrish & Company. He was most recently a Senior Vice President - Wealth Management/ Senior Portfolio Manger at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney. He also served as President of the Wall Street Financial Forum. He was a member of The Brick Presbyterian Church since 1962, serving as a Deacon and Trustee and spear headed its Evangelism Outreach Program, leading many to a relationship with Jesus Christ. He was also a member of the Yale Club, the Colony Club and the Dancers. Alan is survived by his daughters Heidi Jenkins and Victoria Rose, and their husbands Robert Jenkins and William Rose, four grandchildren Anabelle and Lucas Jenkins and Douglas Rose and Courtney Jeffus and their spouses Kaitlin Rose and Tyson Jeffus. Also surviving are his sister-in-law Suzanne Gage and niece and nephew Linda O'Connor and Thomas Gage, and three stepchildren; Bonnie Weyher McLamb, Harry Weyher and Laura Hall. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 2pm Monday, July 13, 2009. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to The Brick Presbyterian Church, 62 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128.

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME-TIME FEATURE: GOING UNDERCOVER From Turner Classic Movies, a night of films featuring good guys impersonating bad guys in order to solve crimes. At 8, in William Keighley's ''Bullets or Ballots'' (1936), a cop (Edward G. Robinson) joins a notorious racketeer to gain information about a police murder. (Robinson, above at right, with Humphrey Bogart, left, and Barton MacLane.) At 9:30 ''White Heat'' (1949) features James Cagney's signature performance as a ruthless gangster, Cody Jarrett (James Cagney), with a mother fixation. Edmond O'Brien plays the government agent who goes undercover to get close to Jarrett. At 11:30 Glenn Ford is a treasury agent posing as a criminal to try to dig up dirt on an evasive mobster called the Big Fellow in ''The Undercover Man'' (1949). 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Guests include Patrick Malone, author of ''The Life You Save,'' and Karrine Steffans, author of ''The Vixen Manual.'' Discussion topics include places to live and summer makeup.

He’s back: Russell Brand, the British wastrel turned cleaned-up comedian, will return as the host of the MTV Video Music Awards this fall, the cable channel said Tuesday in a news release. Mr. Brand, a star of the 2008 comedy “Forgetting Sarah Marshall,” was host of the awards last year, and in March his semi-scandalous autobiography “My Booky Wook,” in which he details his battles with drug and sex addictions, was published in the United States. The 2009 show will be held on Sept. 13 at Radio City Music Hall and broadcast on MTV. It is slated to include performances by Taylor Swift and Muse.

Prince Charles has resigned as the patron of a revered British heritage society in a dispute over his views on architecture and restoration, the British newspaper The Independent reported. Charles, the Prince of Wales, resigned from the British Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings after the group rejected a foreword that he wrote for a book about restoration. Though the society advocates for modern design and architecture in restorations, Prince Charles had written that old houses should be restored as they were originally built. The society declined the foreword after Prince Charles said he would not make any changes to it. Last month the Prince found himself in a public dispute with the architect Richard Rogers, after Charles wrote that the architect’s now canceled plans for a housing development in Chelsea would clash with other architecture in the area, including the Royal Hospital designed by Christopher Wren.

LONDON — Watching people get naked in the West End just isn’t what it used to be. Remember, o companions of my youth, when the sight of Nicole Kidman doffing her kit in “The Blue Room” inspired ecstasies among the old guard of theater critics (and had Charles Spencer of The Telegraph coming up with the legend-making description “pure theatrical Viagra”)? Do you recall the frissons generated when Kathleen Turner wore nothing but high heels in “The Graduate” and Jude Law (long before he donned Hamlet’s inky cloak) leapt rosy-cheeked from the bath in “Les Parents Terribles”? And when Daniel Radcliffe cast off his wizard’s robes and so much more in “Equus”?

The threat of a strike continued to loom over the Bayreuth Festival after workers’ unions and festival management failed to come to an agreement on Tuesday, Agence France-Presse reported. The annual festival dedicated to the music of Richard Wagner could be hobbled if 60 stagehands and lighting engineers and 100 freelance workers for the event represented by the Verdi union go on strike seeking higher wages. After almost 17 hours of negotiation between the union and festival officials, Verdi issued a statement saying that it would not continue discussions unless a “much better” pay offer was brought to the table. “Any further delay represents a serious threat to the Bayreuth Festival – and not just to the premiere,” the union said in its statement, according to Agence France-Presse. This year’s festival, the first to be directed by Katharina Wagner and Eva Wagner-Pasquier, is scheduled to open on July 25 with a production of “Tristan and Isolde.”

I was a political cartoonist and essayist for the duration of the Bush presidency, so I was professionally furious every week for eight years. The pejorative "Bush-hater" always rankled me - presuming that my rightful outrage at that administration's abuses was as arbitrary and irrational as misogyny or arachnophobia. And yet, looking back at my work from those years, even I am struck by its tone of shrill, unrelieved rancor. No wonder readers who met me in real life seemed surprised to learn that I was personable and polite; they must've been expecting someone more like Ted Kaczynski or the guy from "Notes from Underground." Reading over my own impassioned rants now, my main reaction is: Jeez Louise, what a sorehead.
Gentlemen. Gentlemen.A secretary is not a toy,No, my boy, not a toyTo fondle and dandle and playfully handleIn search of some puerile joy.No, a secretary is not,Definitely not, a toy.

ST. LOUIS -- Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner, watched coverage of Manny Ramirez's rehabilitation stint before he returned to the Los Angeles Dodgers this month. Ramirez was rehabbing as he served a 50-game suspension for violating Major League Baseball's policy on performance-enhancing drugs.
When President Obama declined this spring to throw out the ceremonial opening-day pitch at the new Nationals Stadium in Washington, it was sort of easy to understand why.
The new TNT drama tracks a brooding, renegade detective, played by Dylan McDermott, and the deep undercover operation he runs.
David Beckham, recently reunited with his L.A. Galaxy teammates, has repeatedly affirmed his commitment to Major League Soccer.

Rafael Nadal announced Tuesday on his Web site that he would resume practice on Monday and play in Montreal beginning Aug 8, his first tournament since his loss in the fourth round at the French Open. This is great for the Rogers Cup , considering Nadal graces many of its promotional posters.

Jay Goltz, who writes for the You're the Boss blog at The New York Times, noticed that the Whole Foods that just opened near his business in Chicago has priority parking for hybrids.

PARIS | The best things in life are free, or so the saying goes, and there is nothing like a warm summer evening in the French capital to prove that old truism. When the air is warm and the sun dips romantically toward the horizon, little beats a simple walk along the banks of the Seine.

Steve Ballmer's extra-large mocha, triple-shot frap must have kicked in at just the right time. Microsoft's chief executive put on one of his classic, chest-thumping performances on Tuesday for attendees gathered at the company's partner conference in New Orleans.

The artist Terence Koh has been appearing every night at the Whitworth Gallery in Manchester, England, as part of Marina Abramovic's performance showcase during this month's Manchester Festival (through July 19). For his four-hour piece, Koh lies on the floor in a shirt made from crushed pearls, his face and feet covered in powder. Curled up in the fetal position, he plays Nat King Cole's "Mona Lisa" over and over on his iPod. But tonight Koh is honoring the artist Dash Snow, who died today in an apparent drug overdose. Koh will change his tune to "Cheree" by the synth-punk band Suicide. As Koh explained in an e-mail message, "It is for one of my best friend's Dash and that is our favorite song together and we used to dance to it together." Strangely, the song was used in the closing scene of "Downtown 81," which was about Jean-Michel Basquiat, another artist who died way too soon.

The poll numbers aren't getting any more encouraging for New Jersey's embattled Democratic governor, Jon S. Corzine. A new survey by Quinnipiac University shows the Republican challenger, Christopher J. Christie, widening his lead slightly, while independent voters appear to be deserting Mr. Corzine -- even as he has begun attacking Mr. Christie in television commercials across the state.
Location: Fayetteville, Ark.
The Opinionator is live blogging the live bloggers following Sonia Sotomayor's confirmation hearing. Reload for updates.

The New York Times Company has sold WQXR-FM, the classical music station that it has owned since 1944, in a deal that shifts the station's call numbers (96.3) to Univision's Spanish-language station and moves WQXR to Univision's old position at 105.9, where it will be operated by WNYC as a listener-sponsored station. The good news, for classical music fans, is that the station will remain New York's only station dedicated solely to classical music -- although it will have a weaker signal and less prestigious position on the FM dial.

During a vacation in Paris, our Garden State foreign correspondent took careful notes in the flowerbeds of Paris with the eye of a new gardener, eager to bring lessons from the Old World back to her plots in South Orange.
The cocktail masters who have gained fame in the last decade have gleaned great wisdom in a bottle of whiskey. Now they plan to share what they've learned with New Yorkers at a cocktail conference.

One of my primary aims in going to Spain was to visit the Ribeira Sacra region in eastern Galicia. I've been wanting to do this for several years, and was thrilled to have the opportunity finally. You can read my report on the trip in the Dining section.

We are attending a wedding outside of Florence this summer and want to make the most of our visit to Tuscany. Our total time in Italy is seven days, three of which will be at the wedding. Presuming we can make day trips into Florence from the wedding location, what else should be included in our itinerary to best appreciate the region?

Looking for a nice literary artifact? Edith Wharton's letters - a packet sold at auction for more than $180,000 last month - may be out of reach, but collectors willing to settle for Lydia Millett's chili cat figurine or Kurt Andersen's Santa nutcracker will find plenty of bargains over at the new Web site Significant Objects.

The start of U.N.-backed trials of leading members of the Khmer Rouge in February has allowed victims to expose Cambodia's mostly silent past and educate those too young to remember the killing fields.
The labor-backed Working Families Party snubbed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg last week, but his union endorsements keep rolling in.

Anyone foolish enough -- as I was -- to try to read the accounting rules on financial instruments knows that they are mind-numbingly complex. I've sort of taken for granted that all this complexity was necessary, and maybe it is. But as we have seen in recent months,the widely varying rules have meant that one instrument would be accounted for quite differently from a seemingly similar one. Or it could be different from an identical one, based on the intent of the institution owning it.
Matt Stewart spent nearly five years writing his novel, "The French Revolution." He and his agent continue to try to hawk it to traditional publishers, so far without success.

Monday's finale of "Here Come the Newlyweds" along with the second-to-last installment of this season's "The Bachelorette" helped ABC earn its most viewers of the summer and the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49.
Judge Sonia Sotomayor endured tough grilling from Republicans on the Senate Judiciary Committee on issues ranging from gun control to the role of empathy.
Graydon Carter's latest restaurant spirits diners to a bygone era, when waiters wore crisp uniforms and ferried lobster thermidor to properly set tables.
Two weeks after Billy Mays's death, some producers are showing previously-unseen infomercial by the popular host, The New York Times reports.
Goldman Sachs blew past nearly every analyst's estimates Tuesday when it reported a record $13.8 billion in revenue for the second quarter. But how?

O.K., we heard you. In response to reader comments about our tasting of Tim Hortons and Dunkin' Donuts doughnuts, I made a "Timmies run" (note to Canadians: New Yorkers will not be saying that) for coffee this morning from one of the newly opened Tim Hortons in New York.

Bernard L. Madoff, sentenced last month to 150 years in prison for orchestrating a huge Ponzi scheme, was moved from his Manhattan jail cell to a penitentiary in North Carolina, a Federal Bureau of Prisons spokeswoman said Tuesday.

Miller Buckfire, the boutique investment bank specializing in restructurings, said on Tuesday that it had hired a senior official from the Securities and Exchange Commission to start a new practice to advise companies on government relations.

"Creation," a film about the life of Charles Darwin, starring Paul Bettany as the great naturalist and his real-life spouse, Jennifer Connelly, as Darwin's wife, Emma, will open the Toronto International Film Festival on Sept. 10, the festival announced Tuesday. The film is directed by Jon Amiel (whose other movies include "The Core" and "Entrapment").

Community colleges will receive an infusion of $12 billion from the Obama administration, my colleague, Jim Rutenberg, reports. The goal is both to stimulate the economy and to better prepare students for a job market that is struggling.
Judge Sonia Sotomayor responded to Jeff Sessions, ranking Republican about whether her heritage or sympathies affect her judgment.

As summer lingers, the no-frills grilled food that was so thrilling in May can use a little added excitement. This mustard, which gains its texture from toasted seeds, can turn plain grilled steak (or almost any other meat) into something a little more glamorous.

Markit, a supplier of financial data, said Tuesday that the Justice Department is investigating the market for credit default swaps, the largely unregulated financial contracts that rose from obscurity when they nearly toppled the insurance giant American International Group.

Updated, 2:20 p.m. | In a terse one-sentence letter to city officials today, City Councilman Miguel Martinez submitted his letter of resignation, effective immediately. The resignation comes as federal prosecutors in Manhattan are preparing to file charges against him stemming from an investigation into a nonprofit group he funded in northern Manhattan, according to people familiar with the investigation. The charges are expected to be filed as early as this week.

One of the characteristics of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers has been its commitment to create a level playing field between big companies and individuals who use the Internet. Its cumbersome decision-making process is open to input from all sides. And its core role - assigning the domain names used by Web sites - has been quite egalitarian: First come, first served. (Trademark issues aside.)

After Ted Williams's death seven years ago and during the ensuing controversy over the cryonic preservation of his remains, his daughter, Claudia, was rarely, if ever, heard. Her brother, John-Henry, was more the public figure, the one who occasionally spoke for his father and ran the Red Sox icon's businesses. He died of leukemia in 2004.

Yesterday yet another one arrived: a complaint from a diner who'd been shepherded to an early-evening reservation time, and to a bad seat in the house, only to notice that better real estate nearby went unused for hours on end.

Justin R. Saunders is the creative force behind Jjjjound, the photo-curating Web site with so many cool products that it sometimes crashes the browser. Every once in a while, we ask Saunders to share some of his all-time classic designs for men. Again, he delivered.

Over on City Room, A. G. Sulzberger reports on the opening of a new front in the sidewalk food-vendor wars: fruit stands. And Jennifer 8. Lee divulges the un-secret location of a one-night pop-up speakeasy coming to the Museum of the City of New York tomorrow.

"GlassWear," a new exhibition opening tomorrow, July 15, at the Museum of Arts and Design, upends the perdurable perception of glass in jewelry. The objects in the show are divided by the thinnest of conceptual panes: gem, stratum, symbol or simply as the transparent matter beyond which we see the world. According to Ursula Ilse-Neuman, the show's curator, glass in contemporary jewelry "is an expression of the artistic, social, political, scientific and technological forces fueling exploration in the arts today."

Bulent Unal, 45, has piled his table high with apples, bananas and mangoes on the same bustling stretch of 9th Avenue for years now, weighing and bagging fruit at a frenetic pace for the tourists heading to Times Square and the office workers crowding the sidewalks between 42nd and 43rd Streets.

Not only does New York does have an accidental governor, it has an accidental government, Clyde Haberman notes in his NYC column. Of six statewide elective offices, four are now filled by politicians who were not the people's choices.

As a decision looms over General Motors's plan to sell its Hummer unit to an obscure Chinese firm, the two Chinese regulators in charge of approving the deal seem to be taking opposite sides, Reuters reported.

Citroën has confirmed plans to build the Citroën GT, a two-seat sports car originally created for the virtual world of the Gran Turismo 5 racing simulator for the PlayStation 3. The car will be available worldwide, said Anouk van Vliet, a Citroën spokeswoman.
The CIT Group is one of the nation's biggest lenders to small businesses. But a debate is swirling in Washington over whether it is large enough - or important enough - to save.

Kimiko Hahn is the author of eight collections of poetry, Distinguished Professor of creative writing at Queens College, celebrated for work that is at once "sensual, lyrical, heartbreaking, intellectual and political." So why are we writing about her on TierneyLab?

With business publications suffering from scarce advertising, McGraw-Hill has hired Evercore Partners to sell its BusinessWeek, The New York Times's Richard Pérez-Peña reported, citing a person briefed on the plans.

Perella Weinberg Partners said Tuesday it has hired Christopher L. Bittman, the former chief investment officer for the University of Colorado Foundation, to oversee part of its growing asset management business.

Michael Huffington has filed a lawsuit against Carlyle Group, saying that the private-equity giant misrepresented the safety of Carlyle Capital, the publicly traded mortgage-securities fund that collapsed last spring, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The German company Software has made an offer to take over the information technology consultant IDS Scheer, the two firms said Tuesday as they announced the first big corporate acquisition in Germany this year.

Australian hedge funds returned an average of 1.3 percent in June, the fourth consecutive monthly gain, Bloomberg News has reported.

Potential bidders for Eddie Bauer, the outdoor clothing chain that filed for bankruptcy protection in June, are thinking of making offers to rival the $202 million stalking-horse bid tabled by private equity firm CCMP Capital, Bloomberg News reported.

A gigantic new Whole Foods Market opened recently within a mile of my business. It is a 75,000-square-foot wonderland of groceries and prepared foods. It is twice the size of its previous location and has a 420-space parking lot on its second floor. Whole Foods is arguably one of the most impressive and forward-thinking retailers to open in America in the last 30 years. It has been very successful catering to an upscale crowd that wants healthier, more organic and more interesting foods. But I want to get back to the parking lot.

SB LiMotive, an electric vehicle battery joint venture between Samsung SDI of South Korea and Robert Bosch of Germany, is acquiring the United States battery maker Cobasys, Samsung SDI said Tuesday, Reuters reported.

ROME | The work of the artist Giotto di Bondone is spread across a number of the most important monuments and churches in Italy, from Padua to Assisi. The impact of his career, which unfurled at the turn of the 14th century, is evidenced by the massive artists who announced their debt to Giotto: his artistic vision merited comments in Dante's "Divine Comedy" and Van Gogh's personal letters.
Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.
The oil giant Exxon Mobil, whose chief executive once mocked alternative energy by referring to ethanol as "moonshine," is about to venture into biofuels.

A federal judge agreed Monday to delay a hearing on an effort by federal prosecutors to force the Swiss bank UBS to disclose the names of 52,000 wealthy American clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

James M. Davis, the right-hand man of R. Allen Stanford, the Texas financier charged in a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, pleaded not guilty on Monday in his first appearance in federal court, The New York Times's Mauricio Guerrero reported.

The Chinese authorities have detained or questioned at least seven Chinese steel industry executives in a broadening corruption investigation connected to the detentions last week of four employees of the mining giant Rio Tinto, state-controlled news media reported Monday.

As banks and other financial institutions face pressure to raise more capital to shore up their balance sheets, a new source of money may be looming: blank-check companies, publicly traded vehicles set up specifically to make acquisitions.

Bernard L. Madoff, sentenced last month to 150 years in prison for orchestrating a massive Ponzi scheme, was moved from his Manhattan jail cell to a penitentiary in Atlanta, the Federal Bureau of Prisons said on its Web site in the early hours Tuesday.

The Rangers traded left wing Lauri Korpikoski to the Phoenix Coyotes for right wing Enver Lisin. The Rangers also came to terms with the restricted free-agent forward Ryan Callahan on a multiyear deal. The deal avoided an arbitration hearing July 23. Callahan, 24, set career highs with 22 goals, 40 points and 81 games last season.

The Red Bulls signed defender Leo Krupnik from Maccabi Haifa of the Israeli Premier League. Krupnik, 29, cannot be added to the team’s 24-man roster until after the international transfer window opens Wednesday. The club was also awaiting receipt of his international transfer certificate. Krupnik appeared in 30 matches last season for Maccabi Haifa, helping it win its 11th league title.

The police who are investigating the death of the former champion Arturo Gatti in Brazil are working on the assumption his wife strangled him with her purse strap while he drunkenly slept. The woman’s lawyer, however, insisted she was innocent and was too “fragile” to kill a boxer. Moises Teixeira, the lead investigator, said Monday that nothing was being ruled out but he was certain the woman acted by herself.
Asian stock markets followed Wall Street sharply higher Tuesday, invigorated by fresh hopes for improved bank earnings and signs the regional economy is recovering, The Associated Press reported.

Robert Louis-Dreyfus, a scion of great wealth who made his own fortune by applying a keen business sense to rescuing troubled companies, including Adidas, the sportswear maker, and Saatchi & Saatchi, the sprawling advertising agency, died on July 4 in Zurich. He was 63.

Shiseido and Estée Lauder may be possible acquisition targets if Procter & Gamble wants to add more beauty products and increase penetration in emerging markets, a Sanford C. Bernstein analyst predicted Monday.
Another day, another delay for the space shuttle Endeavour. As on Sunday, thunderstorms moved in around the launching pad.
A Southwest Airlines 737-300 made an emergency landing in Charleston, W.Va., after a one-by-one-foot hole appeared near an overhead storage bin half an hour after takeoff.
Arizonans with concealed weapons permits will be allowed to take a handgun into bars and restaurants that serve alcohol, under a bill signed by Gov. Jan Brewer.

Sacre bleu! Zut alors! You didn't think we Francophiles here at The Moment would forget Bastille Day, did you? To commemorate the 14th of July, we've enlisted Benoit Gouez, the chef de cave at Moët & Chandon, to clue us in on where a bona fide Frenchman goes to find a taste of home in New York. Not that you'll actually see him at any of these places today: Gouez will be spending the evening at RdV (409 West 13th Street), the hush-hush bar beneath Bagatelle restaurant, at a private gathering of wine collectors who will ceremoniously sip from a 1959 Moët magnum.
FRONT PAGE.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press obituary on Saturday about a pioneer in the modern riverboat casino industry referred incorrectly to him at one point. As the obituary correctly noted elsewhere, he was Bernard Goldstein, not “Mr. Bernstein.”.
An obituary on Thursday about the Moroccan Jewish singer Jo Amar misstated the date of his death. It was June 26, not June 29.

An art review on Friday about “The Sweeney Decade: Acquisitions of the 1959 Inaugural,” at the Guggenheim Museum, misstated the given name of a painter included in the exhibition. He was Jean-Paul Riopelle, not Jean-Pierre.

Because of an editing error, an article in the Escapes pages on Friday about river surfing on the St. Lawrence in Montreal misidentified the Web site founded by Chris Dutton, a surfer interviewed in the article. It is surfmtl.com, not Surfmontreal.com.

An article on Thursday about the planned appearance of Hayao Miyazaki, the renowned maker of animated films, at the Comic-Con International fan convention in San Diego this month referred incorrectly to the screening of his film “Ponyo” in Hollywood on July 27, which he is expected to attend. It will be a screening for people in the film industry — not the American premiere, which took place in June at the Los Angeles Film Festival.

An article on Wednesday about a royalty agreement between music labels and online radio services referred incorrectly to the audience for standard broadcast radio. The number of people who listen to broadcast radio in a given week has risen slightly in recent years; the audience is not shrinking.

A report in the Breakingviews.com column on Monday about similarities between the lender CIT and GE Capital, General Electric’s financial arm, misstated the amount of bonds that GE Capital has issued through the government’s Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program. The company had $74 billion in such debt outstanding at the end of the first quarter — not $109 billion.

The West Farms Journal article on Saturday, about the Bronx neighborhood where the 1950s television sitcom “The Goldbergs” was set, misstated the title of Jenna Weissman Joselit, a cultural historian, who said the tenement window conversations that prevailed in the “Goldbergs” era highlighted the lack of boundaries between public and private spaces. She has been named to the Charles E. Smith Chair in Judaic Studies at George Washington University; she is not chairwoman of Judaic studies there.

An article on Friday about the life of Sonia Sotomayor, President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, referred incorrectly at one point in some editions to the court on which she sits. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it is the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, not the United States District Court of Appeals.

An article on July 5 about the opening of the Statue of Liberty’s crown to the public for the first time in almost eight years referred incorrectly in some editions to the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents who were on Liberty Island during the reopening ceremony. They were there only to watch the ceremony; they were not armed and were not patrolling the island.

Carlos Tevéz agreed to join Manchester City on a five-year deal, further enhancing the wealthy Premier League club’s bid to join England’s and Europe’s elite. Tevéz, a 25-year-old Argentine striker, will complete his switch across Manchester from the more illustrious United, where he had previously played on loan, after a medical examination. City will have to pay $41 million to sign Tevéz from the group that owned his rights.

Joe Hachem, the 2005 World Series of Poker champion, said he had lost respect for a new brand of aggressive players who seemed to want to gamble all their chips on every hand in the main event. Hachem said after two hours of poker on Monday that the pace had not slowed at the no-limit Texas Hold ’em tournament in Las Vegas because many players were willing to risk their tournament with mediocre hands. Play started with 185 players, and 38 were eliminated in two hours, despite starting with many chips relative to minimum bets. Hachem said the overaggressive style was disrespectful to the tournament. Hachem was eliminated later in the day, leaving last year’s winner, Peter Eastgate, as the only former main event champion in the tournament.
