STONE--Edward Durell, Jr.,died peacefully in Vero Beach, FL on Friday, July 10, 2009. Ed was born in Norwalk, CT on August 30, 1932 to Orlean Vandiver and Architect Edward Durell Stone. He attended The Hill School in Pottstown, PA, received his Bachelor of Arts in Architecture from Yale University and his Master of Landscape Architecture from Harvard University. He also served as a Fighter Pilot, Captain, in the United States Air Force from 1954 to 1957. Ed Stone began his career in Fort Lauderdale with Frederick B. Stresau, one of the pioneers of landscape architecture in the State of Florida. In 1960 he founded Edward D. Stone, Jr. and Associates (EDSA), Fort Lauderdale, FL, one of the preeminent planning and landscape architecture firms in the world. Ed was elected a Fellow in the American Society of Landscape Archiects/ASLA in 1974 and awarded the Society's prestigious ASLA Medal in 1994, the "highest honor the American Society of Landscape Architects may bestow upon a landscape architect whose lifetime achievements and contributions to the profession have had a unique and lasting impact on the welfare of the public and the environment." Under his leadership, EDSA has received over 140 statewide, national and international awards. Ed was exceptionally proud of the EDSA Minority Scholarship which is awarded yearly by the ASLA. EDSA's most recent honor, the ASLA Landmark Award co-sponsored by the National Trust for Historic Preservation for PepsiCo's world headquarters in Purchase, NY was particularly gratifying. Designed over thirty years ago, PepsiCo's corporate campus was recognized for its excellence and inspiration to its people and their purpose. Among DSA's other projects are Atlantis in the Bahamas, PGA National Resort Community in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Madinat Jumeirah in Dubai, Fort Lauderdale's Beach Revitalization and Riverwalk, Daufuskie Island in South Carolina and Nova Southeast University in south Florida, and John's Island in Vero Beach, FL. Ed was appointed to the Presidential Commission of Fine Arts by Richard M. Nixon in 1971, reappointed by President Gerald R. Ford in 1976 and again in 1980 by President Jimmy Carter. He was a member of the Urban Land Institute and was honored to serve numerous other professional and civic organizations. Ed is survived by his wife, Helen 'Lollie' Ecclestone Stone; his son, Edward 'Ned' Durell Stone, III; his daughter Patricia (Chapin Koch) Stone; his son Mathew Whelpley; three grandchildren, Sarah, Lily and Peter Koch; his brothers, Robert V. (Betsy Bowman) Stone of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, Benjamin Hicks (Emily) Stone of Roxbury, CT, and sisters, Francesca Stone and Fiona Stone; as well as his nephew, Michael Amyette-Bowman Stone of New York, NY, two stepdaughters, Margaret (John) Shaffer, and Sheila (Nathaniel) Crosby and two step-granddaughters, Turner and Courtney Reynolds. Services will be held at Trinity Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, FL, (772)567-1146, on Thursday, July 16, 2009 at 11:00am. A reception will follow. The family suggests in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Ed's name to the following organizations: Trinity Church, 2365 Pine Avenue, Vero Beach, FL 32960, Visiting Nurse Association/Hospice, 1110 35 Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960 or ASLA EDSA Minority Scholarship Award, 636 Eye Street NW, Washington, DC 20001-3736. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach, (772)562-2325.

(49) THE RECKONING: THE BATTLE FOR THE INTERNATIONAL CRIMINAL COURT This documentary, part of the ''P.O.V.'' series on PBS, focuses on the independent International Criminal Court, the first permanent tribunal to seek justice for victims of genocide, war crimes and other atrocities. The filmmakers follow the chief prosecutor, Luis Moreno-Ocampo, as he and his team try to prosecute cases in Colombia, Uganda and Sudan (where the president, Omar al-Bashir, was charged with crimes against humanity), without the help of police or other enforcement agents. That's just one obstacle the prosecutors face. Though dozens of nations supported the court's creation, in 2002, many others, including Sudan, do not recognize its authority. Above, examining a skull in eastern Congo. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Guests include Martha Stewart; Janet Evanovich, the author of ''Finger Lickin' Fifteen''; and the actor David Arquette. Topics to be discussed include workplace bullying, germs in the kitchen and summer skirts.

O'NEIL--Anne Kennedy, longtime resident of Manhattan's Upper East Side, Human Resources executive and civic leader died last Friday at her home after a long illness. She was 79. The widow of James M. O'Neil, she was born in Boston and graduated from the Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in New York City. She had a long career as a Human Resources executive with R. H. Macy & Co., the Tobe-Coburn School and the First Boston Corporation where she was a Vice President until her retirement. She was also active in a number of civic and volunteer organizations, including the Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) and the Henry Street Settlement, and served as President of the New York Junior League. She is survived by a daughter, Anne (Mrs. Juan M.) Ocampo of New York City, a son, Martin L. O'Neil of London and five grandchildren: Mary Morrison Ocampo, Julia Rendon Ocampo, James O'Neil Nakajima, Mariko Nakajima O'Neil and Anne Nakajima O'Neil. A funeral Mass of Christian burial will be held on Thursday, July 16th at 11 o'clock at the Church of Saint Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street.

On the hot July day of the Moon shot, I was holed up in my apartment, trying to meet a deadline for New York magazine. CBS News kept calling, looking for someone to say on camera the criticism I felt: huge sums being justified by cold war arguments about militarizing space, and there was no way to vote for using that money to solve big problems on Earth. CBS finally sent a car and swore I would be back in an hour. I found myself sitting next to a student leader named Ira Magaziner who had his leg in a cast; the only other person they could find who would say what was ''unpatriotic,'' according to mountains of later hate mail.

In July 1969, I was in jail in the Polish town of Sztum, a serving three years for my role in the 1968 Polish student movement. I was 23. About the Apollo landing: I learned about it immediately from Trybuna Ludu, the Communist Party's official organ, the main source of information for political prisoners. The news was accompanied by acid, somehow envious, pieces of commentary. The Americans landing on the Moon had humiliated the Communist propaganda.

We watched Walter Cronkite broadcast the event. It felt amazing to be alive and to see these things happen in my lifetime. You couldn't help but think of John F. Kennedy and of Camelot fulfilling its promise, finally. Kennedy was dead and yet this had happened! Growing up in Florida, everyone around me was impressed by it. Until then I thought, ''I'm going to go into inner space and become an oceanographer.'' But after Apollo, everyone said that the future was going to be space. And it turned out that my future was in space.

KUHN--Leslie A.,MD. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of dear friend and colleague, Leslie A. Kuhn, MD, Professor of Clinical Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. For more than 50 years, Dr. Kuhn was devoted to excellence in clinical care, research, and education in the field of cardiology. His research focused on cardiogenic shock. Dr. Kuhn was the first director of the Ames Coronary Care Unit and later served as the Editor-in-Chief of the Mount Sinai Journal of Medicine. The Mount Sinai family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Kuhn's loved ones. Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Valentin Fuster, MD, PhD, Director of Mount Sinai Heart.

In an unusual move for a Broadway show, the producers of the musical ''Hair'' announced on Monday that they were canceling the Sunday matinee on Oct. 11 so that the cast could join the National Equality March that day in Washington in support of gay-marriage rights. Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, a producer of ''Hair,'' said that the decision reflected the spirit of the musical. ''Its message of change and hope and inclusion is one we try to live, not just preach,'' he said in a statement. Monday's announcement was made at a rally in Los Angeles after the ''Hair'' cast taped a segment there for ''The Tonight Show With Conan O'Brien.'' A spokesman for ''Hair'' said the producers were adding a performance for Monday, Oct. 5. People who have tickets to the Oct. 11 matinee can exchange them for another performance.

KUHN--Leslie A. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our long-standing colleague, teacher and friend. Clinical Professor of Medicine, specializing in Cardiology, Dr. Kuhn came to the hospital as in intern in 1948. He completed his residency, fellowship, and a research fellowship in Cardiology at Mount Sinai and dedicated more than 60 years of service to the institution and the care of his patients. In 1968, Dr. Kuhn became the first director of the Ames Coronary Care Unit, one of the largest facilities of its kind, designed exclusively for the medical care and treatment of heart attack victims. He was an active member of the AAS for decades and served as editor of The Mount Sinai Journal of Medicine. He was a beloved physician, a superb cardiologist, and a skilled educator. He had an extraordinary sense of humor and he made us all laugh. He will truly be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Steven B. Weinfeld, M.D., President Gila Leiter, M.D., Vice President Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator

Since I had been following the progress of Apollo closely, the successful landing of Apollo 11 came as no surprise. Everything happened just as I expected, except for one detail. I had not expected that the television camera would be the most important part of the mission, the first item to be deployed and the last to be abandoned. That was the big surprise, that NASA planned the Apollo operation as an international sporting event with the whole world watching. This strategy was brilliantly successful, but it had an unfortunate consequence. When the Russians walked out of the game, we walked out too.

Red Salvation Army kettles, accompanied by bell-ringing volunteers, are a familiar part of New York City's holiday landscape. They appear between Thanksgiving and Christmas, and the money they collect supports soup kitchens, food pantries and other social services. But this year, for the first time in more than three decades, the kettles are being deployed out of season, for a week in the height of summer.

I was on Cape Cod and had just gotten back from Vietnam, where I was not in combat, thank God, though I came home disaffected. In Vietnam, I'd seen an army occupying a country and that is pretty ugly. I hated the Army, and its vulgarity, which I had volunteered for through R.O.T.C. in 1965. At the moment of the Moon shot, I had really started to identify myself with the antiwar part of my generation. When I heard we had gone and landed on the Moon, I thought this was yet another depredation. This seemed like part of the technology of war, which it wasn't.

The day Apollo left Earth for the Moon, my husband and I and our three kids left England for America. We just had time to see lift-off on our rented TV and rush around the corner to return the TV before we caught a cab to the train to Tilbury to board our ship -- a small Russian liner, the Alexander Pushkin. The ocean crossing took about a week. News on board was limited to a daily printout, mostly about events in the U.S.S.R. But one afternoon the captain came on the ship's audio system and gravely, politely and a little ruefully congratulated the United States on the successful landing of the Apollo crew members on the Moon. We five Americans put up a little cheer, and our Russian fellow passengers cheered too, out there in midocean.

We were in Montreal and we finished our doubleheader there. We were going back to New York and we went through customs, heading toward our plane, and we walked by this bar and everyone was gathered around a television there. Gil Hodges [the Mets' manager] was very much a by-the-numbers guy. For him to stop was out of the norm. But everyone stopped this time. The thing I remember is Tug McGraw, God bless him, watching Neil Armstrong and saying, ''If we can get a man on the Moon, we can win the World Series.'' He was very emotional about it.

I was 17 or 18 and had moved to Philadelphia to be with my then-boyfriend, Peter Cunningham, the photographer. I needed to get away from the music industry and learn how to grow up. I had a huge hit at 15, ''Society's Child,'' and that was very polarizing. A lot of people hated me. Everything felt so apocalyptic. That summer, the '60s were winding down, and I was winding down right with them.

While NASA had a total of 11 flights in its Apollo program, only 6 actually landed on the Moon. Along with Neil A. Armstrong, who took the first step on the surface, 11 other men left the relative safety of their lunar landers to collect rock and dust samples and complete the goals of each mission. On each trip, one of the three astronauts remained in the command module and orbited the Moon until the others returned. After the Apollo program ended, the astronauts went on to varied endeavors. Profiles of all 18 are at nytimes.com/space; below, an update on the astronauts who traveled to the Moon on Apollo 11, in July 1969.
I was 12 and my family went to the town of Loveladies on the New Jersey shore to watch the Moon landing. I was very aware I was watching something singular and historic.

National League fans have probably grown weary of watching their favorite players lose year after year to the American League All-Stars -- they would have to go back to 1996 for an N.L. victory. The tie in 2002 was no consolation. But perhaps those fans could find some comfort in a touch of winning All-Star history out of Philadelphia. Yes, you read that correctly. Peter Gelb, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera for the last three seasons, got a big raise last year. For the fiscal year that ended in July 2008 -- encompassing Mr. Gelb's second full season on the job -- his total compensation was $1.5 million, a 36 percent increase over a year before, according to a report by Bloomberg News that cited the company's latest tax return. Mr. Gelb, 55, a former record executive, took over from Joseph Volpe in the fall of 2006 with aggressive marketing plans to draw new audiences. But the Met has been grappling with a deficit. Donations are down, and the company's endowment, once as high as $300 million, was down by a third at the beginning of 2009. Senior staff members -- including Mr. Gelb -- had a 10 percent pay cut starting in December, said Peter Clark, a Met spokesman, who confirmed Mr. Gelb's 36 percent pay increase for the 2007-8 season. The Met declined to comment on Mr. Gelb's contract. Nonunion employees are scheduled to take a 10 percent cut, beginning in August. The American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents the Met's singers, dancers and production workers, recently refused a request for contract concessions, saying it wanted to see the company's books.

An interest in space exploration wasn't anything new in my life. My mother was a space enthusiast and I grew up interested in the conquest of space. So I was tracking all that stuff for years. In 1966, I went on a campaign to get high-quality photographs of the Earth taken from space. Despite the space race, there had still been no strong photographs of the Earth from space. So when Apollo 8 went up on Dec. 29, 1968 -- the same year we first published the ''Whole Earth Catalog'' -- they finally took the first Earthrise photograph, the famous one that everyone now knows. And that helped spawn the environmental movement. That became the planetary icon. It replaced the mushroom cloud as the dominant image of the age, replacing an image of fear with an image of hope.
STRAUSS--Jenny. Dear Friend, cherished memories. We love you. Sally Berger and Family.

LEAR--Robert W.,of New Canaan, CT passed away on July 9, 2009. After retiring in 1977 from F&M Schaefer Corporation as Chairman and CEO, he founded the Executive-in-Residence program at Columbia Business School where, as full professor, he taught and counseled for 22 years. Both a classroom and endowed professorship are now named there in his honor. He held many corporate directorships and formed Advisory Boards for more than a dozen entrepreneurial companies. He also wrote three books, was a columnist for Chief Executive Magazine and his articles appeared in many magazines. Other activities included the Management Policy Council, the National Association of Corporate Directors, the Columbia Business School Board of Overseers, Waveny Care Center and St. Mark's Episcopal Church. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, sons William and Andrew and three grandchildren. Services will be held at 11:00am on Friday July 17 at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, CT.

KNUTSON--Donald I.,Ph.D., 68, Mathematician 1941-2009. On Friday, Donald Knutson, son of Charlotte and Henry Knutson, died at his home in Park Slope twenty-five months after being diagnosed with brain cancer. At M.I.T., Dr. Knutson earned his bachelor's degree, his doctorate and his wife, Andrea Allen Knutson. Don's 1968 doctoral thesis, "Algebraic Spaces", is still widely read today by those pursuing algebraic stacks. Don taught at Boston College, Columbia, where he guided doctoral students, and Fordham. In 1978, after receiving an M.B.A. from Columbia, Don started a 29-year career as a financial executive at CBS Television Network. Early in his career he was asked to determine what CBS should bid for the Olympics and NFL contracts. For the latter, Don's first step was to ask what the letters NFL meant. Later he developed many of the analytical systems that are in use at CBS today, and which he was still improving up until the day before he was diagnosed with a tumor in the center of his brain. After his surgery he attacked his neurological problems with a no-fuss cheerful curiosity. He relearned the alphabet using his grandson's puzzles, rejoined the Brooklyn Conservatory Chorale, attempted to dine in every Park Slope restaurant, and hiked the hills of Prospect Park, the Berkshires and the Swiss Alps. Even after last winter when a second tumor paralyzed his right side, he regarded dressing himself one-handed as an interesting project and continued to attend at least two plays or concerts weekly. The only challenge that he found heartbreaking was the decline in his ability to play the piano. Don is survived by his wife Andrea, his children Allen and Miranda, his grandchildren Fionn and Taran, his brother Robert, his five cats and his 5,000-book library. The wake will be held at the family home, 618 6th St., Brooklyn on Tuesday, 3-9pm. Contact: mknutsonw@gmail.com. A memorial concert at the Brooklyn-Queens Conservatory of Music is planned for the fall. Donations may be made in Don's memory to the Brooklyn-Queens Conservatory: bqcm.org/support.htm.

And now, after several dozen plays in London and its environs, I’m seeing dead people. It had to happen, I suppose. The implicit message of Ella Hickson’s “Eight”: Don’t trust anyone under 30 to be alive.

As you and your family set out to see the newly released “Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince,” you need not worry that the Catholic Church will disapprove. Agence France-Presse reported that the Vatican has given its approval to the latest “Harry Potter” movie, even though Pope Benedict XVI criticized earlier films in the franchise. On Wednesday, L’Osservatore Romano, the newspaper of the Holy See, wrote that “Half-Blood Prince,” the sixth entry in the film franchise adapted from the J. K. Rowling novels, was “the best of the series.” It added: “The mixture of supernatural suspense and romanticism sets the right balance, making the adventures of the protagonists more credible,” according to Agence France-Presse. In 2003, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, the future pope, wrote that the “Harry Potter” novels contained “subtle seductions” that could “deeply distort Christianity in the soul, before it can grow properly.”

Spurred, no doubt, by the New York Philharmonic’s embrace of the iPhone, Christie’s has become the latest cultural institution to offer its own dedicated application for the Apple mobile device, Reuters reported. On Wednesday, the auction house said that its free application, available at the iTunes App Store and the Christies.com Web site and through Facebook and Twitter, would offer access to its sales calendar and allow users to browse more than 450 auctions in over 80 categories including fine and decorative arts, jewelry, photographs, collectibles and wine. The application also offers detailed lot information and the ability to zoom in on images of offerings, as well as the all-important feature of e-mailing lots to friends. Christie’s told Reuters that it hoped to add a live-bidding component to the application.

Bello Nock, the star clown with the vertical red hair who left the Big Apple Circus in Manhattan in 2000 to become the big-top headliner at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus for eight years, will return to the one-ring Big Apple tent at Lincoln Center on Oct. 24 for a yearlong tour.

The Times’s film desk has received its fair share of offbeat swag, from “Tropic Thunder” bobbleheads to “Hamlet 2″ Sexy Jesus action figures. They also had the courtesy to include a straw. We’re still deciding whether or not we’d like to put it on our swag shelf next to our stuffed “Marley & Me” puppy.

Like some monster stitched together in a mad scientist’s laboratory, another Jane Austen novel is about to be grafted to a classic horror milieu in hopes of creating a best seller. Publishers Weekly reported that Quirk Books would follow its unexpected hit “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” with a new title, “Sense and Sensibility and Sea Monsters,” to be published on Sept. 15. “Zombies,” written by Seth Grahame-Smith, combined about 85 percent of Austen’s “Pride and Prejudice” text with a tale of undead flesh eaters. The new book, to be written by Ben H. Winters, will find the Dashwood sisters tossed from their home and sent to an island of man-eating sea creatures. Jason Rekulak, a Quirk Books editor, told Publishers Weekly that the book would take inspiration from everything from “Jules Verne novels to ‘Lost’ to ‘Jaws’ to ‘Spongebob SquarePants.’ ” Mr. Grahame-Smith, meanwhile, signed a two-book deal with Grand Central Press that includes a new book called “Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter.”

The neo-soul singer Maxwell kept his fans waiting eight years for a new album, but they didn’t forget him. “BLACKsummers’night” (Columbia), Maxwell’s first CD since 2001, opens at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with 316,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, his best sales week ever. (Michael Jackson’s collection “Number Ones” sold more, but it does not qualify for the chart.) Another new album, “Hannah Montana 3” (Disney), the third soundtrack to the hit television show, is No. 2 with 137,000 sales. Last week’s top seller, the 31st edition of the pop compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” fell to No. 3 with 101,000 sales. All Time Low, a pop-punk band from Maryland, bows at No. 4 with its third release, “Nothing Personal” (Hopeless), which sold just less than 63,000 copies, barely more than the Black Eyed Peas’ latest album, “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), which holds at No. 5 in its fifth week out.

If you think you have heard the names Barack Obama and Shepard Fairey in close proximity quite a bit over the last year, you will be hearing more of them soon. Mr. Fairey, the artist whose “Hope” poster of Mr. Obama became a ubiquitous part of the presidential campaign, is working on a coffee-table book, “Art for Obama,” that will be published in October and will include 150 images of the president or artworks inspired by his campaign, created by notable artists and designers such as Ron English, David Choe, Kwaku Alston, Maya Hayuk, Justin Hampton, Shel Starkman and Mr. Fairey. Profits from the book, which will feature collages, paintings, photo composites, prints, and computer-generated pieces and which Mr. Fairey will edit with Jennifer Gross, will be donated to Americans for the Arts.
In the two and a half weeks following Michael Jackson’s death on June 25 his fans have snapped up 2.3 million albums — 17 percent more than in 2007 and 2008 combined.

Most analysts believe that Bing, Microsoft's new search engine, is off to a solid start, with results that are close to matching Google's in relevance, a design that resonates with some consumers and a good brand. If nothing else, the release of Bing earned the beleaguered software giant, a perennial underdog in search, some respect.

Tesla Motors opened a dealership in Manhattan on Tuesday, just one day after Daimler announced it had sold a 4 percent stake in Tesla to Aabar Investments of Abu Dhabi. Daimler had bought a 10 percent stake in Tesla in May.

The private equity industry's main lobbying group said Wednesday it supported legislation that would require all firms of a certain size to register as investment advisers with the Securities and Exchange Commission, but urged lawmakers to avoid onerous regulations.

Updated, 2:09 p.m. | A Manhattan teenager has been arrested in the May 25 bombing of a Starbucks coffee shop on the Upper East Side, and the explosion appears to have been modeled on a scene from the 1999 film "Fight Club," the New York Police Department said on Wednesday.
An Iranian passenger jet en route to Armenia crashed west of Tehran Wednesday, killing all 168 on board.

During the recent sweat-soaked men's fashion shows in Milan and Paris, I found that by simply adding a pocket square to my sports jacket I was able to keep my shirt open at the neck (allowing for better air flow and necessary heatstroke prevention) while looking dressed-up. The basic shirt-and-jacket combo didn't seem like quite enough for the fashion flock, despite the 90-degree heat. Thankfully, I had brought a selection of cotton pocket squares, and every day I would select a different one for a bit of extra flair. A navy bandanna pattern looks great with a muted plaid shirt, while a white square with a colored border livens up a simple white shirt.

The headlines over the last week have reinforced the perception that the country's financial institutions, or at least some of them, are beginning to rebuild and profit. But resentment and the risk of public backlash against these banks remain, as shown by the recent opinions and editorials complaining about how ungrateful these banks are and suggesting they are once again trying to take advantage of the government and game the system.

While Karl Lagerfeld flaunted his latest peacockery in Paris last week, Desmond Payne, the master distiller at Beefeater, showcased his newest creation, the tea-steeped gin Beefeater 24 at Tales of the Cocktail. The five-day cocktail convention that invades New Orleans's French Quarter every July is a way for the country's mixologists to connect, learn, unwind and, of course, drink. By Day 4, even the most hard-core bartender wants the party to end, which is saying a lot.

Guillermo Linares, the commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Immigrant Affairs, is resigning to pursue the City Council seat vacated by Miguel Martinez, the Bloomberg administration announced on Wednesday. Mr. Linares represented the 10th District, which includes Washington Heights and Inwood in Upper Manhattan, from 1991 to 2001, when he was forced to leave because of term limits.
